title: Learning Corruption-Invariant Components and Cross-Modal Correspondence for Unsupervised Visible-Infrared Person Re-Identification
authors: Long Chen, Rui Sun, Xuebin Wang, Guoxi Huang, Jingjing Wu, Wei Jia
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: Unsupervised Visible-Infrared Person Re-Identification (US-VI-ReID) has great potential prospects because it does not require label information. However, corrupted pedestrian images collected due to corruption factors in real-world scenarios (e.g., noise, blur, and weather changes) largely limit the scalability of US-VI-ReID. In this paper, we explore the robustness of US-VI-ReID for the first time and propose a Multi-Granularity Spatial-Frequency Prototype Learning (MSPL) framework. The framework mainly consists of Multi-Channel Soft Augmentation (MSA), Robust Frequency Domain Feature Learning (RFL) module and Cross-modal Spatial-Frequency Prototype Matching (CSPM). Specifically, the MSA alleviates the sensitivity of model to color and abnormal samples through rich channel combinations and soft erasing. Subsequently, the RFL performs deep global filtering and amplitude attention compensated InstanceNorm to complete frequency and style modulation, concentrating on degradation-robust frequency content. Finally, the CSPM is designed to achieve multi-granularity prototype contrastive learning on cluster level and view level, then conduct cross-modal matching of multi-granularity spatial-frequency prototypes, thus establishing robust label association. With the above modules, our proposed framework can learn corruption-invariant feature components and generate robust cross-modal correspondence from unlabeled cross-modal images. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our MSPL outperforms other state-of-the-art methods by a large margin on the challenging SYSU-MM01-C and RegDB-C, while maintaining competitive on the SYSU-MM01 and RegDB.

title: A Generative Strategy for Target-Oriented Molecular Design: Integrating Docking Scores with Drug-Likeness Constraints
authors: Zhicheng Yang, Xiaolong Zhang, Xiaoli Lin
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: With the growing application of deep learning in drug design, efficiently generating molecules with desirable drug-like properties and target specificity remains a key challenge. Existing methods often rely on complex fusion of molecular and protein features, leading to high data demands and training costs. To address this, a novel molecule generation model based on multi-constraint optimization is proposed, incorporating docking scores, Lipinski’s Rule of Five, and other pharmacological constraints to guide generation. The model is built on a Bidirectional Gated Recurrent Unit (BiGRU) and improves training efficiency through cross-entropy loss optimization. Experimental results show that the proposed approach achieves superior performance in molecular validity, novelty, and uniqueness, and generates compounds with lower binding energies to target proteins, significantly enhancing the practicality and scalability of molecular design.

title: Collaborative Design of Antenna Array Topology and AP Deployment for Distributed MIMO Systems
authors: Lihua Pang, Haobing Jin, Yang Zhang, Zenghong Ke, Ao Du, Yijian Chen, Anyi Wang
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Wireless Communications and Signal Processing (WCSP)
abstract: Distributed multiple-input multiple-output (D-MIMO) systems have great potential in improving spectrum efficiency, service quality, and network capacity. A key factor affecting their performance is the design of access points (APs) placement and subarray configuration. This paper aims to maximize the ergodic sum rate by collaboratively optimizing the arrangement of subarray layout and the positioning of APs. Specifically, by employing uniform planar antenna arrays (UPAs) in the AP's subarray setup and strategically placing APs within a predefined zone, we can characterize the ergodic sum rate effectively. Given the complexity of the ergodic sum rate's expression, the optimization process begins by deriving an approximate expression through Jensen's inequality. This approximation then guides a reformulated optimization problem. Under fixed AP positions, the subarray antenna topology is initially optimized, followed by refining the locations of the APs. An iterative algorithm is employed to finalize the optimal antenna array designs and the precise deployment sites for multiple APs. Numerical simulation results show that the proposed approach achieves a near-optimal performance. For scenarios where several APs are circularly arranged to serve evenly distributed users, our findings suggest that the optimal deployment radius should be 0.63 times the cell radius when using UPAs with a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.91 \lambda$</tex> spacing.

title: Phase- jitter -tolerant characterization of programmable photonic circuits
authors: Jiajia Wang, Haoran Zhang, Shuying Li, Shuran Zhang, Yunping Bai, Xingyuan Xu
abstract: We demonstrated a universal and phase-jitter-tolerant characterization technique to measure the dynamic performance of programmable photonic integrated circuits (PICs). This approach provides a promising solution for PIC characterization, enabling accelerated physical parameter training.

title: A $\beta$-VAE-WGAN-Based Traffic Augmentation Model for Enhanced IoT Intrusion Detection
authors: Tong Liu, Yu Wu, Li Zhou, Mengting He, Gao Chen, Xuanrui Xiong
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Wireless Communications and Signal Processing (WCSP)
abstract: With the rapid growth of Internet of Things (IoT) devices, network security challenges-especially in malicious traffic detection-have become more prominent. Traditional Network Intrusion Detection Systems (NIDS) face significant challenges due to the high heterogeneity and dimensional complexity of IoT data. To improve NIDS performance in IoT environments, this paper proposes VWGM (Variational AutoencoderWasserstein Generative Adversarial Network-Based Generative Model with Multi-scale Feature Fusion and Coordinate Attention Mechanism). The model integrates a multi-scale feature fusion mechanism, a Beta Coordinate Attention Module (BCA), and introduces a Multi-Scale Soft Pooling Module (MSSPM) to improve data generation quality and feature extraction. VWGM maintains high structural consistency and semantic fidelity when generating IoT network traffic, effectively addressing the data scarcity problem. Experimental results on the MedBIoT dataset demonstrate that VWGM outperforms existing generative models in both Ablation Study Analysis and the generation of key feature data. In intrusion detection tasks, the model achieves significantly higher accuracy than CTGAN and SyNIG. This further validates that the proposed model has significant advantages in detection accuracy and overall performance in IoT security scenarios.

title:
Spatiotemporal Trend Fusion Feature Graph Convolution Network for Spatial Interpolation in Traffic Scenes
                    <sup>⋆</sup>
authors: Zhiang Hou, Shiyong Lan, Xinyuan Zhou, Wujiang Zhu, Yao Ren
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Sensors are always sparsely distributed in traffic networks due to high deployment costs, sensor damage, etc. Insufficient data may affect our perception of traffic scenarios, resulting in the inability of intelligent transportation systems (ITS) to efficiently perform traffic monitoring and scenario decisions. Spatial interpolation methods are used to infer the status of locations where no sensors are deployed. However, existing methods still have the following limitations: (1) Mainly interpolated unobserved nodes by extracting spatiotemporal dependencies between nodes, but ignored complex interaction patterns in feature dimensions. (2) Recent methods generally used standard TCN to extract temporal correlations, which is affected by abnormal data. (3) When extracting spatial correlations, the use of deep GCN layer can lead to over-smoothing problem. To mitigate these limitations, we propose a novel spatial interpolation model, namely, Spatiotemporal Trend Fusion Feature Graph Convolution Network (STFGCN). Specifically, a novel feature graph convolution network is used to capture complex interaction patterns. Secondly, the trend capture branch is used to alleviate the impact of abnormal data on TCN. Finally, a dual-stage spatial module is used to solve the degradation of detailed feature representations in deep GCN layer. Experimental results on six real traffic datasets demonstrate that our method outperforms state-of-the-art baseline models.

title: Feature-Aligned Diffusion: A Framework for High-Fidelity fMRI-to-Image Reconstruction
authors: LIU FUWEI
publish: 2025 22nd International Computer Conference on Wavelet Active Media Technology and Information Processing (ICCWAMTIP)
abstract: Recent fMRI-to-image reconstruction methods have primarily focused on associating fMRI signals with specific conditioning inputs of pre-trained diffusion models. However, such conditioning introduces information loss with respect to the original visual content, as the generative process of diffusion models tends to obscure this deficiency, resulting in generation based on reconstruction, rather than true reconstruction of the perceived stimuli. To address this issue, this paper proposes a feature-aligned reconstruction framework, which guides the diffusion trajectory through visual feature alignment extracted from fMRI signals, thereby overcoming the limitations of fixed conditional control in existing diffusion-based approaches. Experimental results on the Natural Scenes Dataset demonstrate that the proposed method achieves higher fidelity and semantic consistency in reconstructed images, providing a more faithful mapping between brain activity and visual perception.

title: Asymmetric U-Net with Gaussian Splatting for Single-View 3D Reconstruction
authors: Yifan Wang, Zhirui Xu, Xianting Zeng, Wenjun Zhou, Bo Peng
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: With the rapid advancement of computer vision and graphics, high-quality single-view 3D reconstruction has become increasingly significant in applications such as autonomous driving, robotics, and virtual reality. Traditional methods often struggle with the inherent ill-posed nature of single-view reconstruction, leading to limited accuracy and reduced detail retention. To address these challenges, we introduce an innovative framework that integrates an asymmetric U-Net architecture with 3D Gaussian splatting for single-view 3D reconstruction. Furthermore, our approach incorporates a novel 3D smoothing filter that constrains the maximum frequency of the 3D representation, effectively mitigating high-frequency artifacts in out-of-distribution rendering. By synergistically combining implicit and explicit representations, our method leverages the strengths of both to enhance reconstruction efficiency and quality. Experiments conducted on the SRN-Cars dataset demonstrate that our framework outperforms existing methods in quantitative metrics and qualitative assessments, achieving higher reconstruction accuracy and smoother surfaces.

title: Comprehensive Research on Trust-Based Clustering and Routing for Secure Network Communication
authors: Talari Ashok, Sabout Nagaraju
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Mobile Networks and Wireless Communications (ICMNWC)
abstract: In recent years, trust-based clustering and routing has emerged as an effective approach for enhancing security and energy efficiency in the context of Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs), Mobile Ad Hoc Networks (MANETs) and Internet of Things (IoT). By combining trust evaluation with clustering and routing mechanisms, these methods ensure secure data delivery by isolating malicious nodes. The optimization algorithms such as Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO), Genetic Algorithm (GA), Bacteria Foraging Optimization (BFO) and Crow Search (CS) effectively enabled intelligent cluster head selection and energy-aware routing, whereas Machine Learning (ML) and Deep Learning (DL) techniques introduced predictive trust modelling and adaptive decision making. With rising adoption of Low Power Wide Area Network (LPWAN) technologies like LoRaWAN, combination of trust-based optimization becomes required for ensuring secure, long-range and energy-constrained communications in IoT deployments. Despite these advancements, existing models face challenges like high computational overhead, difficulty in handling dynamic topologies, limited scalability and vulnerability to sophisticated attacks. This survey presents survey of recent optimization-driven and learning-assisted trust-based clustering and routing approaches by highlighting their methodologies, performance benefits and limitations for large-scale real-time deployments.

title: Design of Dual-Axis Servo Laser Ranging Pan - Tilt Scanning System
authors: Yulei Cui, Xingxing Shi, Yu Huang, Hao Zhang, Yiran Hu, Guang Wang
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotics, Control and Automation Engineering (RCAE)
abstract: Aiming at the problem that the surface shape accuracy of heliostats, a key component of tower-type solar thermal power plants, affects the solar energy concentration efficiency, this paper designs a heliostat surface shape accuracy scanning system based on a dual-axis servo laser ranging pan-tilt. The system is composed of a controller, a dual-axis servo pan-tilt, and a high-precision laser range-finder. Firstly, a position loop controller for the dualaxis servo pan-tilt is constructed based on the Linear Active Disturbance Rejection Control (LADRC) algorithm to improve the position positioning accuracy and scanning cycle. Then, the pan-tilt carries a high-precision laser range-finder to perform a holographic 3D scan on the back of the heliostat to obtain 3D point cloud data. Finally, the root mean square error of the point cloud is used as the standard for evaluating the surface shape quality. Through practical applications in industrial sites, the results show that the system is stable and reliable, and easy to deploy, meeting the requirements of automation and intelligence for surface shape accuracy detection during heliostat production.

title: Construction of Multi-Scale Biostatistical Analysis Framework and its Application in Biomedical Signal Feature Recognition and Classification
authors: Pengwei Zhu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Mobile Networks and Wireless Communications (ICMNWC)
abstract: Electrocardiogram and electroencephalogram (EEG) signals, as important carriers reflecting physiological activities, present significant challenges in terms of complexity, non-stationary characteristics, and susceptibility to interference. Any conventional processing strategy often struggles to maintain stable performance under unfavorable signal conditions. Therefore, this study constructs a multi-scale analysis approach that integrates fractal analysis, higher-order statistical features, and harmonic average box dimensions. It is used to enhance the expressive ability of the signal structure at different levels and improve the reliable feature quality of the classification model. The research process uses a decision tree model for signal category identification after feature generation. The experiment section deals with various wireless modulated signals as well as real electrocardiogram information. The samples of the electrocardiogram are held as a part of the assessment to test the strength of the approach on various kinds of data. The general findings indicate that this framework continues to have a clear quality discrimination capability within a low signal to noise ratio environment. The modulated signal has given high recognition rate under some conditions and obtained full accuracy classification performance under some conditions. The modified fractal dimension features of fractal intercept correlation fail to provide good effects in recognition in the electrocardiogram signal analysis, whereas the standard fractal dimension features do. The paper noted that its discriminatory nature in regard to abnormal waveforms is stronger. The overall research demonstrates potential of an obvious application, namely, in such the case as real-time biological signal processing and health monitoring. The next line of study will be to increase the use of the model over large scale datasets and research its how to couple with deep learning models, to facilitate further use of this analytical framework in clinical practice.

title: Augmented Reality-Enhanced Robot Teleoperation for Collecting User Demonstrations
authors: Shiqi Gong, Sebastián Zudaire, Chi Zhang, Zhen Li
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotics, Control and Automation Engineering (RCAE)
abstract: Traditional industrial robot programming is often complex and time-consuming, typically requiring weeks or even months of effort from expert programmers. Although Programming by Demonstration (PbD) offers a more accessible alternative, intuitive interfaces for robot control and demonstration collection remain challenging. To address this, we propose an Augmented Reality (AR)-enhanced robot teleoperation system that integrates AR-based control with spatial point cloud rendering, enabling intuitive, contact-free demonstrations. This approach allows operators to control robots remotely without entering the workspace or using conventional tools like the teach pendant. The proposed system is generally applicable and has been demonstrated on ABB robot platforms, specifically validated with the IRB 1200 industrial robot and the GoFa 5 collaborative robot. A user study evaluates the impact of real-time environmental perception, specifically with and without point cloud rendering, on task completion accuracy, efficiency, and user confidence. Results indicate that enhanced perception significantly improves task performance by 28% and enhances user experience, as reflected by a 12% increase in the System Usability Scale (SUS) score. This work contributes to the advancement of intuitive robot teleoperation, AR interface design, environmental perception, and teleoperation safety mechanisms in industrial settings for demonstration collection. The collected demonstrations may serve as valuable training data for machine learning applications.

title: Auction Consensus Algorithm with Loss Mechanism for Decentralized Task Allocation
authors: Jose Rodriguez, Wenjie Dong, Constantine Tarawneh, Qi Lu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Multi-Robot and Multi-Agent Systems (MRS)
abstract: This paper presents an Auction-Consensus Algorithm with a Loss Mechanism (ACALM), a decentralized task allocation method for multi-robot systems that enhances the existing Consensus-Based Auction Algorithm (CBAA) by incorporating a novel loss propagation mechanism. In contrast to purely greedy bidding strategies, it enables agents to dynamically update task priorities based on the accumulated loss from previously unsuccessful bids. This extended work reduces globally inefficient allocations caused by early suboptimal decisions. The proposed approach is evaluated through large-scale simulations in thousands of randomized scenarios and swarm sizes ranging from 5 to 120 robots. Compared to existing CBAA and GCAA algorithms, ACALM yields task assignments with higher global efficiency on average. The results also show that ACALM maintains effectiveness with larger swarms, suggesting strong robustness in large decentralized contexts. However, this improvement comes with an increase in communication overhead due to additional consensus rounds. Potential extensions include methods to reduce communication costs, support for multiple assignments per robot, and verification of functionality under asynchronous communication.

title: Velocity-Constrained Collaborative Control for Multi-UAVs: An Autonomous Inspection in Power Distribution Networks Case
authors: Limei Zhou, Linjian Cheng, Liang Sun, Pengfei Jiang, Xin Lu, Guanying Wang
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotics, Control and Automation Engineering (RCAE)
abstract: This article presents a velocity-constrained collaborative control strategy for multiple unmanned aerial vehicles (multi-UAVs) in autonomous inspection tasks within power distribution networks. By constructing a log-type barrier Lyapunov function (BLF) into the optimized backstepping strategy, the approach enforces strict velocity constraints to ensure safe and efficient operation. An identifier-actor-critic reinforcement learning (IAC-RL) framework is incorporated to adaptively estimate unknown dynamics and optimize leader-follower formation control (LFC) in real-time. Stability analysis demonstrates that tracking errors are semi-globally uniformly ultimately bounded (SUGGB), with velocity constraints preserved. Simulation results confirm the scheme's efficacy in achieving stable formations along overhead power lines.

title: VulSCS: A Source Code Vulnerability Detection System Using Secondary Code Slicing
authors: Yong Zhong, Bin Liu, Wenyin Yang, Junxian Ye, Jihui Liand Fen Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: In the context of the information age, the frequent occurrence of software vulnerabilities has emerged as a critical issue demanding immediate resolution. Traditional vulnerability detection methods have struggled to keep pace with the escalating security demands, while the advent of deep learning technology has introduced novel solutions to software vulnerability detection. Deep learning not only facilitates the automatic extraction of features, thereby reducing the cost of manual intervention, but also demonstrates remarkable advantages across various domains. In recent years, research on vulnerability detection based on deep learning has achieved notable progress, yet it still faces several limitations. This study focuses on C/C++ program vulnerability detection and proposes an enhanced approach, VulSCS, based on secondary slicing. By performing secondary slicing on source code exhibiting vulnerable behaviors, this method extracts code segments with higher representational value, thereby capturing richer vulnerability-related features. Experimental results indicate that, compared to state-of-the-art vulnerability detection tools, VulSCS improves detection accuracy by 3.2% and enhances detection efficiency by approximately threefold. This research offers new perspectives and methodologies for deep learningbased software vulnerability detection.

title: Heuristics Evaluation of Moodle E-Learning Using Specialized Educational Usability Indicators
authors: Ranty Deviana Siahaan, Sri Suning Kusumawardani, Indriana Hidayah
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Information Technology, Information Systems and Electrical Engineering (ICITISEE)
abstract: The rapid transition to online learning during and after the COVID-19 pandemic has urged educational institutions to re-examine the usability and pedagogical effectiveness of their Learning Management Systems (LMS). However, most existing evaluations rely on generic usability frameworks that overlook learning-specific aspects such as instructional design and learner motivation. This study proposes and applies 23 specialized heuristics indicators tailored for e-Learning usability assessment to evaluate the Moodle-based LMS of SMA Unggul Del (SUD), Indonesia. The indicators were synthesized from prior research and refined to capture four core dimensions: general usability, instructional design, course workspace usability, and motivational learning. An expert-based heuristics evaluation involving nine evaluators, comprising lecturers, graduate students, and UX professionals was conducted using structured task scenarios for both student and teacher interfaces. The findings revealed 126 usability issues (76 student-related, 50 teacher-related) distributed across 23 indicators, alongside quantitative ratings of indicators importance. Results show that 22 of the 23 indicators were deemed essential, validating their relevance for holistic e-Learning evaluation. Furthermore, the study provides a detailed list of usability issues and improvement recommendations to guide LMS developers in enhancing user experience and pedagogical quality. This research advances existing heuristics methods by embedding educational heuristics into usability evaluation, bridging the gap between human-computer interactions and learning design, and offering a practical framework for continuous LMS enhancement.

title: Rapid-Tuning ECL Wavelength Control System for LEO-Ground Coherent Optical Communication
authors: Xu Yang, Zongbi Yu, Yuanzhe Qu, Weiwei Mo, Hao Li, Yingxiong Song
abstract: We propose a rapid-tuning ECL wavelength control system for LEO-ground coherent optical communication. Experimental results demonstrate that the ECL achieves a Doppler frequency shift range of [-9.68, 12.41] GHz and a maximum sweep rate of 1.32 GHz/s.

title: Human Activity Recognition in Wireless Environments using a Lightweight Temporal Attention Fusion Network
authors: P. Sreekanth Reddy, Ladly Patel, A. Prithiviraj, Anandan. R, Mukesh Soni
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Mobile Networks and Wireless Communications (ICMNWC)
abstract: In this era, Human Activity Recognition (HAR) plays a vital role in allowing intelligent monitoring and interaction in smart Internet of Things (IoT) based environments. Even though, there are existing Wireless Fidelity (WiFi) Channel State Information (CSI)-based approaches, still these approaches struggle with limitations in real-time performance, environmental robustness and adaptability under signal interference. Therefore, to resolve these challenges, this manuscript proposes a Lightweight Temporal Attention Fusion Network (TAF-Net) for robust and efficient real-time HAR in wireless IoT settings. The proposed TAF-Net framework initializes with an adaptive median-Principal Component Analysis (PCA) which is a hybrid denoising stage that assist to mitigate noise and smoothens interference in CSI signals. Subsequently, spatial features are extracted using a One Dimensional-Convolutional Neural Networks (1D-CNN) block, while temporal dependencies are learned through a Bidirectional Gated Recurrent Unit (Bi-GRU) module. Finally, a temporal attention mechanism which signifies the most informative time steps and a fusion gate that adaptively integrates spatial-temporal representations before recognition through a fully connected SoftMax layer. Moreover, the proposed TAF-Net obtained an accuracy (99.87%), precision $\mathbf{(9 9. 8 2 \%), ~ r e c a l l ~ (~} 99.82 \%$), and F1-Score (99.74%), respectively.

title: Stochastic Battery Degradation Modeling Considering Cell-to-Cell Current Interactions
authors: Marcelo Santana, Jônatas Silva, Vinícius Almeida, Paulo Maciel
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: This paper introduces a stochastic model to characterize battery degradation using Stochastic Petri Nets (SPN). The model analyzes battery degradation under varying discharge currents, architectural configurations, state of health (SoH) thresholds, K-out-of-N (KooN) architectures, and cell imbalances. It assesses reliability based on individual cell data, distinguishing it from traditional methods by accounting for cell failure influence. A NASA dataset was used to study battery degradation trends under various imbalance levels. Probability distributions for the SoH decay process were incorporated into the models, and simulations were conducted to observe battery behavior across cell imbalance ranges from 5% to 80% of the SoH amplitude. Results confirm that the model effectively reflects degradation behavior related to battery reliability. Findings indicate the parallel-series (PS) configuration achieves up to 18.5% higher mean cycles to failure (MCTF) than series-parallel (SP) under significant imbalance, with modest advantages (around 3%) under balanced conditions. This shows the model accurately assesses reliability and can be adapted for battery packs.

title: Defending Deepfake via Texture Feature Perturbation
authors: Xiao Zhang, Changfang Chen, Tianyi Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: The rapid development of Deepfake technology poses severe challenges to social trust and information security. While most existing detection methods primarily rely on passive analyses, due to unresolvable high-quality Deepfake contents, proactive defense has recently emerged by inserting invisible signals in advance of image editing. In this paper, we introduce a proactive Deepfake detection approach based on facial texture features. Since human eyes are more sensitive to perturbations in smooth regions, we invisibly insert perturbations within texture regions that have low perceptual saliency, applying localized perturbations to key texture regions while minimizing unwanted noise in non-textured areas. Our texture-guided perturbation framework first extracts preliminary texture features via Local Binary Patterns (LBP), and then introduces a dual-model attention strategy to generate and optimize texture perturbations. Experiments on CelebA-HQ and LFW datasets demonstrate the promising performance of our method in distorting Deepfake generation and producing obvious visual defects under multiple attack models, providing an efficient and scalable solution for proactive Deepfake detection.

title: Visual Prompt Tuning Mamba for MRI Brain Tumor Classification
authors: Wei Wang, Fen Li, Lixin Guo, Jianxin Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Automatic MRI brain tumor classification plays an important role in the clinical diagnosis of brain tumors. Meanwhile, deep learning methods recently attract wide attention in this medical application. Different from existing methods that are mainly based on CNN and Transformer architectures, this paper attempts to explore Mamba-related models for MRI brain tumor classification, motivated by the recent success of state space models in capturing global features of medical images. More specifically, this paper introduces a novel vision prompt Mamba model, i.e., VPT-Mamba, for MRI brain tumor classification, which implants a visual prompt into the improved Vision Mamba to capture global and local important information of brain images. The VPT-Mamba utilizes the Mamba® as the backbone to mitigate feature artifacts of brain tumors by introducing register tokens into Vision Mamba, and it further incorporates the visual prompt tuning in input features to enhance feature representation. We evaluate the VPT-Mamba on two public and private brain tumor classification datasets. Our VPT-Mamba achieves the best ACC and AUC results of 99.510% and 99.966% on the public dataset, and the corresponding values are 96.582% and 99.125% on the private brain tumor dataset, respectively. Moreover, comparative experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of VPT-Mamba for this medical image classification application.

title: Adaptive RIS Phase Shift Optimization for Multi-User MIMO Systems
authors: Qilie Liu, Lu Wang, Yanan Xin, Xuan Wang
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Wireless Communications and Signal Processing (WCSP)
abstract: Reconfigurable Intelligent Surface (RIS) is considered a key enabling technology for next-generation wireless communication systems, due to its ability to reconfigure the propagation environment. However, current RIS configuration schemes, relying on perfect channel state information (CSI), are challenging to implement in practical settings. This paper proposes a RIS-assisted multi-user multiple-input multiple-output (MU-MIMO) system and a dynamic phase shift optimization algorithm based on deep reinforcement learning (DRL) to address issues such as channel uncertainty, user mobility, and adaptability. Initially, the interaction between the RIS and the wireless communication system is modeled as a Markov Decision Process (MDP). Subsequently, a DRL-based RIS control scheme is proposed, which integrates prioritized experience replay (PER) and a long short-term memory (LSTM) module into the conventional deep deterministic policy gradient (DDPG) algorithm, resulting in an enhanced approach named PL-DDPG. Unlike existing approaches, the proposed framework is further designed to enable real-time control of RIS phase shifts in randomly time-varying channel environments. Finally, simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves substantial improvements over existing benchmarks.

title: Online Learning for Edge Node Program Placement in Mobile Edge Computing Networks
authors: Mingjie Feng, Marwan Krunz
abstract: Mobile edge computing (MEC) is a key technology to support computationally intensive mobile applications with stringent latency requirements. With MEC servers deployed at network edge (e.g., base stations), the computational tasks generated by various applications can be offloaded to nearby edge nodes (ENs) and timely processed there. Meanwhile, future mobile applications will be more diverse and complex, which will need to be supported by a large number of complicated programs. As the storage space of ENs is limited, it is infeasible for each EN to store the program codes of all applications. Thus, it is necessary to optimize program placement at ENs to fully harvest the potential of MEC. In this paper, we investigate the problem of program placement and user association in storage-limited MEC networks. Such a problem is formulated as a sequential decision-making problem. We first consider the single EN scenario and propose an online learning-based solution. We then propose a solution framework for the multi-EN scenario, where we decompose the original problem into three subproblems and iteratively solve them with low-complexity approaches. Simulation results show that the average latency achieved by our proposed schemes is 30% to 70% lower than two benchmark schemes and is on average less than 10% higher than a lower bound.

title: TacShade 2.0: A New Greyscale Pattern-based Optical Tactile Sensor for Robotic Perception and Adaptive Admittance Control
authors: Jialong Yang, Zhenyu Lu, Chao Zeng, Fan Zhang, Chenguang Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Marker-based optical tactile sensors generally represent contact features through the displacement of discrete markers, but their performance is constrained by marker density and potential overlap of skin wrinkles. To address this issue, we develop TacShade 2.0, a greyscale pattern-based optical tactile sensor, inspired by the sketching and halftone principles introduced in our previous work [1]. TacShade 2.0 reflects external interactions through changes in the area and density of markers. This design enables higher spatial resolution, with a density of 64 markers/cm² and utilizes continuous greyscale features to reconstruct detailed point clouds of contacted objects. A fast tactile estimation model is developed by combining local and global greyscale features to extract contact depth and normal force through pattern optimization and sensor calibration. The experiments through seven indenters reflect that the estimation errors for contact depth and normal force are as low as 0.269 mm and 0.089 N, respectively, with an average processing time of about 0.035 s per image. Furthermore, we introduce, for the first time, a tactile feedback-based variable admittance control framework. Building upon an impedance model that captures the passive compliance of the sensor, a variable stiffness coefficient is derived to minimize the force tracking error relative to the desired force. As a result, this enables adaptive robotic exploration of different surfaces. Three experiments are conducted to demonstrate TacShade 2.0’s abilities in accurate normal force estimation, fast shape reconstruction, and robust curved surface exploration, even in the presence of unknown obstacles.

title: Estimation of Lower Limb Joint Torque Using Handrail Force and Floor Reaction Force During Sit-to-Stand Motion in the Elderly
authors: Yuta Wakamatsu, Ken Kikuchi, Hiroyuki Hamada, Kazuhiro Nakayama, Kanta Miyoshi, Atsushi Yamashita, Qi An
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Many elderly individuals experience a decline in motor function. To provide appropriate rehabilitation programs, a sufficient and convenient evaluation method is necessary. In this study, we focused on the sit-to-stand (STS) motion, a crucial activity in daily life, and used handrail to obtain force data safely and easily. Previous studies have proposed methods for estimating scores such as the Timed Up and Go test from forces applied to the hand, hip, and foot, classifying elderly individuals into several motor function categories. However, these indicators are insufficient for evaluating the function of specific muscles or joints in the lower extremities individually. The primary objective of this study was joint torque, which more directly represents the function of specific muscles and joints. We measured the time-series data of forces acting on the body during STS motions and developed a model using Long Short-Term Memory to estimate lower limb joint torques. As a result, knee and hip joint torques were accurately estimated from force applied to hand, hip and foot. Furthermore, this method demonstrated the potential for early detection of joint disorders. This approach allows for a detailed assessment of the state of the knee and hip joints simply by standing up while holding a handrail.

title: Mechanism-Aware Trajectory Prediction with Target-Area Fusion and Risk-Aware Interaction Modeling
authors: Hongyan Guo, Hongwei Hao, Qingyu Meng
publish: 2025 9th CAA International Conference on Vehicular Control and Intelligence (CVCI)
abstract: Accurate vehicle trajectory prediction is crucial for the safe and efficient operation of autonomous driving and intelligent transportation systems. However, the dynamic and complex nature of real-world traffic presents significant challenges, particularly in modeling interaction risks, fusing heterogeneous information, and incorporating domain-specific mechanistic knowledge. To address these issues, this study introduces a mechanism-aware trajectory prediction approach that systematically integrates physical principles with data-driven learning. By explicitly quantifying inter-vehicle collision risks through Time to Closest Point of Approach (TCPA) and Distance at Closest Point of Approach (DCPA), the method enhances both the safety and interpretability of interaction modeling. In addition, dynamic incorporation of lane semantics from predicted target regions ensures that generated trajectories remain physically feasible and contextually aware. A learnable query-based decoder further enables recursive fusion of dynamic agent states and static lane topology via attention mechanisms, supporting interpretable and confidence-aware multimodal trajectory generation. To capture the complexity of real-world scenes, heterogeneous graph neural networks are employed to encode high-definition map semantics and agent interactions. Extensive experiments conducted on the Argoverse 2 benchmark demonstrate that the proposed approach achieves state-of-the-art performance across multiple metrics, highlighting the effectiveness of integrating mechanistic knowledge with deep learning for reliable and interpretable vehicle trajectory forecasting in safety-critical scenarios.

title: SAM2v-BTR: Accelerating SAM 2 Training for 3D Medical Image Segmentation Through Bootstrap and Memory Annealing
authors: Enzhi Zhang, Junichiro Iwasawa, Keita Oda, Yuta Tokuoka
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Vision Transformers (ViTs) have revolutionized image classification, but their application in dense prediction tasks such as segmentation, particularly for 3D medical imaging, faces scalability challenges. To address these issues, there has been growing interest in utilizing foundation models like the Segment Anything Model (SAM) for medical image analysis. The recent introduction of SAM 2 has generated optimism regarding enhancements for tasks such as 3D MRI segmentation. However, SAM 2’s memory bank mechanism, designed for object tracking and segmentation, introduces computational complexity and memory overhead, limiting training efficiency. In this paper, we address these limitations by proposing a bootstrap and memory annealing approach. The bootstrap mechanism replaces the memory bank with ground truth data, significantly enhancing training speed without compromising performance, achieving a 6x improvement on 3D medical image benchmarks such as KiTS and ACDC. To counteract potential overfitting caused by the bootstrap approach, we introduce memory annealing, which adaptively adjusts the selection of ground truth frames based on validation loss, resulting in a 5.46% improvement on the KiTS dataset. Our approach accelerates model training while maintaining or improving segmentation performance, offering a robust solution for efficient 3D medical image segmentation.

title: A Multi-Condition Fault Diagnosis Logic Generation Method Based on Extended FMEA
authors: Junyou Shi, Zhilin Yang, Chengwei Zhaoxsx, Huidong Zhou
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on System Reliability and Safety Engineering (SRSE)
abstract: The increasing complexity of modern systems, driven by advancements in electronic and intelligent technologies, has led to diverse and dynamic operating states. Traditional fault diagnosis methods, relying on fixed thresholds and models, often fail to adapt to these variations, resulting in misdiagnosis and missed detections. To address this, a multi-condition fault diagnosis logic generation method based on extended FMEA is proposed. This method extends traditional FMEA by incorporating fault mode features and testability design considerations to identify relevant monitoring parameters and diagnostic criteria for each fault mode under different operating conditions. The method constructs a unified diagnostic logic framework that generates a set of logic for fault detection and isolation, ensuring diagnosis accuracy in complex systems with multiple conditions. A typical vehicle powertrain system is used as an example to demonstrate the method.

title: Low-Profile Metasurface-Integrated Ultra-Wideband Antenna with Enhanced Gain
authors: Deepa Negi, Aarti Bansal, Naveen Kumar
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Mobile Networks and Wireless Communications (ICMNWC)
abstract: In this paper a metamaterial-integrated compact antenna is proposed, and the design, simulation, and implementation are presented which works in Ultra-Wideband frequency (UWB) range. The FR4 substrate has been used to design a compact, flexible, wearable antenna. Metamaterial structure comprises of periodic arrangement of unit cells termed as metasurface, to achieve higher gain. The proposed integrated antenna exhibits maximum gain of 8.1 dBi with overall dimensions of 50 mm $\times$ 40 mm. Also, the gain enhancement of 3.2 dBi along with 0.2 GHz increment in bandwidth is observed after adding the metamaterial array. Thus, the proposed antenna is suitable for wearable applications.

title: Identifying Key Factors Influencing Student Satisfaction Using Explainable AI and Shapley Additive Explanations for Predictive Modeling
authors: Andi Dwi Riyanto, Arif Mu'amar Wahid, Aniec Anafisah Pratiwi
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Information Technology, Information Systems and Electrical Engineering (ICITISEE)
abstract: Student satisfaction plays an essential role in higher education, influencing student retention, academic success, and institutional quality. While machine learning (ML) models are increasingly used to predict satisfaction levels, their lack of transparency limits their usefulness for evidence-based decision-making. This study applies Shapley Additive Explanations (SHAP) to improve the interpretability of ML models trained to predict student satisfaction using a dataset of 2,527 institutional survey responses. Several models were evaluated, including Decision Tree Regressor, Random Forest Regressor, Support Vector Regressor (SVR), Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP), and XGBoost, with rigorous preprocessing applied through <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{k}$</tex>-fold cross-validation to avoid data leakage. SHAP was used to examine global feature patterns, individual-level explanations, and interaction effects, revealing how the models internally utilized survey dimensions such as student engagement, teaching quality, and infrastructure. Due to strong correlations among predictors, SHAP values were interpreted as reflections of model behavior rather than independent determinants of satisfaction. The results demonstrate that SHAP can effectively enhance the transparency of high-performing ML models, enabling institutions to better understand how satisfaction-related variables are represented within predictive systems. This work contributes to the growing field of Explainable AI in education by providing a robust, transparent framework for combining ML and SHAP with survey-based institutional data. The approach supports more responsible and interpretable analytics, offering stakeholders clearer insights into the structure and behavior of satisfaction prediction models while highlighting important methodological considerations for future research.

title: FCD-YOLO: An Accurate and Efficient Method for Underwater Object Detection
authors: Zheqi Yang, Jichen Zhang, Mian Li, Zhike Su, Aimin Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Underwater target detection presents substantial technical challenges due to the complex and dynamic characteristics of marine environments. Detection performance is frequently impaired by factors such as the presence of small targets with limited visual features, frequent occlusions from marine organisms and suspended particles, as well as significant morphological variations caused by varying viewing angles, lighting conditions, and target deformations in aquatic environments. To tackle these challenges, this paper presents an improved YOLOv8-based model, referred to as FCD-YOLO. The proposed model incoporates a FCA mechanism to emphasize key features while suppressing background noise. Additionally, it integrates a CCFF Module to effectively capture and merge multi-scale information for more comprehensive feature representation. To further improve adaptability, the original YOLOv8 detection head is replaced with a DyHead, enabling multi-scale feature detection and enhancing the model’s ability to handle targets of varying sizes. Experimental results on the URPC2020 dataset demonstrate that the FCD-YOLO model achieves a mean Average Precision (mAP) of 86.9%, representing a 5.0% improvement over the baseline YOLOv8 model. Comparative studies with other state-of-the-art detectors further validate FCD-YOLO’s superior accuracy. Ablation studies confirm the individual contributions of each component, with the FCA mechanism and DyHead module showing particularly significant impacts on small target detection performance. These results substantiate FCD-YOLO’s superiority and practical utility in complex underwater environments.

title: AFTR-HAR-Net: Adaptive Fusion and Temporal Reasoning Network for Robust Human Activity Recognition
authors: D. Chandra Prakash, Ann Theres Joy, Sowmini Bandaru, Balasubramani. R, Sakthivel Subramaniam
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Mobile Networks and Wireless Communications (ICMNWC)
abstract: In this era, Human Activity Recognition (HAR) has become a crucial component in healthcare monitoring, fitness tracking and smart IoT applications. Specifically, attaining accurate classification still struggles with various challenges where the deep learning approaches have limitations with multimodal fusion and efficient temporal modelling that leads to suboptimal performance on sensor data. Therefore, to resolve these limitations, this research proposes an Adaptive Fusion and Temporal Reasoning Human Activity Recognition Network (AFTR-HAR-Net) which is a lightweight robust framework that combines adaptive sensor fusion, a dilated Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) encoder and an Attention-guided GRU temporal reasoning module. In particular, the adaptive fusion mechanism learns modalityspecific significance weights which assists to improve resilience to sensor imbalance, then the dilated CNN captures multi-scale temporal features with minimal computational cost. Further, the GRU and attention layers helps to refine temporal dependencies which improves the discrimination of overlapping activities. The proposed AFTR-HAR-Net acquired higher results with 98.12% accuracy and 97.89% F1-Score when compared with the existing hybrid model namely CNN with Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory.

title: Fault Detection and Location Method for T-Type Inverters Based on Interval Sliding Mode Observer
authors: Ziyan Shang, Zehao Tian, Xiaoyan Zhang, Song Gao, Jiayi Hou, Chaobo Chen
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotics, Control and Automation Engineering (RCAE)
abstract: To address the challenge of locating multi-switch faults in T-type three-level inverters, this paper proposes an interval sliding mode observer-based fault detection and location method. The designed observer integrates interval observation with sliding mode variable structure theory. Subsequently, an adaptive threshold mechanism for fault detection is developed, centered on the characteristic residuals of currents. Furthermore, a hierarchical location strategy is established based on inverter open-circuit fault features, enabling accurate isolation of multiple faulty switches. Ultimately, simulation results verify the method's effectiveness.

title: LFNet: A Frequency–Texture Fusion Network With Distance Correlation Loss for Remote Sensing Scene Classification
authors: Guowei Wang, Xianbin Wen, Haixia Xu, Xinyu Wang
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Remote sensing scene classification (RSSC) aims to assign semantic labels to remote sensing images (RSIs). However, existing convolutional neural network (CNN)-based methods often suffer from limited feature representation due to their bias toward global semantics while neglecting local textures, their sensitivity to illumination variations, and their reliance on cross-entropy loss, which fails to explicitly model sample- wise relationships in the feature space. To address these challenges, we propose LFNet, a frequency–texture fusion network equipped with a distance correlation loss for geometry-consistent feature optimization. Specifically, a Local Binary Pattern Frequency Convolution Module (LFCM) is introduced, which consists of two parallel branches: (1) an OctBranch that captures complementary high- and low-frequency semantic information via octave convolution and dual attention refinement, and (2) an LBPBranch that extracts illumination-robust texture cues in the feature domain. In addition, a Distance Correlation Loss (DC-Loss) is designed to explicitly regularize pairwise Euclidean distances among samples, thereby enhancing intra-class compactness and inter-class separability in the embedding space. Extensive experiments on four public RSSC datasets, including UCM, AID, NWPU, and NATG, demonstrate that LFNet achieves competitive or superior classification performance, with up to 1.2% improvement in overall accuracy and 12.4% reduction in FLOPs compared with the baseline ResNet50, while maintaining strong robustness under varying illumination conditions.

title: Hash-based iris template protection using maximum entropy binary codes and CNNs
authors: Osman Demir, Thomas Schuth, Marta Gomez-Barrero
publish: 2025 International Conference of the Biometrics Special Interest Group (BIOSIG)
abstract: As biometric authentication becomes more common, protecting biometric data is becoming increasingly important. One widely used protection method is encryption. However, not all encryption methods are suitable for biometric data. On the one hand, the encryption solution can lead to worse performance or on the other hand, not fulfill all required security measures. This paper proposes a solution for iris template protection that results in hash-encrypted data using Maximum Entropy Binary (MEB) codes and Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN). The method is compared to a baseline approach to demonstrate competitive recognition performance. In addition, the privacy and security properties of the template protection are evaluated.
