title: Self-Supervised rU-net With Spectrum Branch: A Novel Framework for Subject-independent Emotion Recognition based on Peripheral Physiological Signals
authors: Jiaming Chen, Lifeng You, Ting Dang, Xiao Liu, Hongtao Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Frequency-domain features of peripheral physiological signals are vital for emotion recognition. However, existing end-to-end network architectures rarely extract them efficiently. To address this limitation, we propose a multimodal rU-Net model incorporating time-frequency information fusion. Specifically, the spectrum is integrated as a parallel branch alongside the time-domain branch for feature extraction. A fusion module enables direct frequency domain feature extraction and subsequent time-frequency fusion. By utilizing the rU-Net encoder with multimodal signal channels, our approach processes skin temperature (SKT), electrodermal activity (EDA), and photoplethysmography (PPG) data simultaneously, thus preventing model inflation from encoder stacking. The CASE and DEAP datasets have been validated using the leave-one-subject-out (LOSO) approach. In the 3-class classification, the best accuracy for valence (V) and arousal (A) were 69.36% and 71.34%, respectively, while in the 2-class classification V and A were 70.56% and 70.29%, respectively. This work offers valuable insights and a novel approach for future research in emotion recognition based on peripheral physiological signals collected by non-EEG wearable devices.

title: 102.47 Tb/s WDM Transmission in the Extended C+L Band over 1260.65 km of G.654.E Fiber with Hybrid Raman/EDFAs
authors: Zhongxing Tian, Zeyu Feng, Ziang Chen, Qingyu He, Wanzhen Guo, Dongdong Zou, Huan Huang, Lin Sun, Yancai Luan, Liang Mei, Ming Luo, Jian Zhao, Gordon Ning Liu, Gangxiang Shen, Yi Cai
abstract: We demonstrate a record 102.47-Tb/s WDM transmission over 1260.65-km in the extended C+L-band using 240 × 48-GBaud PCS-64QAM channels, enabled by broadband, flat-gain hybrid Raman–EDFA amplification, ultra-low-loss G.654.E fiber, and an optimized DSP architecture.

title: Towards Time-Frequency Gradient Consistency Guided Adversarial Attacks in Radio Frequency Fingerprinting Identification
authors: Hengda Su, Zhisheng Yao, Di Wei, Xixi Zhang, Qi Xuan, Guan Gui
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Wireless Communications and Signal Processing (WCSP)
abstract: With the rapid development of wireless communication technology, the legal authentication of wireless devices has become a key issue in the field of communication. The deep learning (DL)-based radio frequency fingerprint identification (RFFI) technology exhibits unique advantages such as strong generalization capability and high identification accuracy. However, it remains vulnerable to adversarial attacks designed by malicious attackers. Recent studies have shown that the attacker could generate adversarial samples by adding a small and imperceptible perturbation to the original signal samples, leading to incorrect results from the DL-based RFFI network. In light of the aforementioned issues, we propose a timefrequency gradient consistency (TFGC)-based attack framework, which integrates time-frequency gradient match (TFGM) and adjacent gradients interpolation (AGI) to solve the problems of perturbation neutralization and stealthiness issues in traditional attack methods. Several adversarial attacks are applied within this framework to verify its effectiveness. The performance evaluation is conducted on the RFFI model, based on complexvalued convolutional neural networks (CVCNN) and the WiFi dataset. Experimental results demonstrate that our proposed framework significantly improves both the effectiveness and stealthiness of the attack. Our experiment code can be found in https://github.com/HD-S-1/adversarial_attack_paper1

title: A 22Gb/s-54Gb/s Reconfigurable PAM-2/4/8 DSP-based Transmitter with 14-tap Feedforward Equalization
authors: Seung-Mo Jin, Dong-Ho Kim, Kwang-Ho Lee, Haram Ju, Gyu-Seob Jeong, Woorham Bae, Jaeduk Han, Min-Seong Choo
abstract: In recent high-speed serial interfaces, multi-level modulation has been widely adopted to improve bandwidth efficiency [1], [2], [3], [4]. As a result, flexibility in modulation schemes and robustness against various channel conditions have become critical requirements in transmitter (TX) design. The differences between analog based TX and digital signal processing (DSP) based TX are shown in Fig. 1. While analog-based TXs offer the advantage of low power consumption, the high-speed operation of the feedforward equalizer (FFE) imposes stringent timing constraints. Furthermore, they inherently lack flexibility in modulation schemes, and the hardware complexity increases with the number of FFE taps, as the data path size must scale accordingly [5]. As a result, analog implementations face limitations in effectively compensating for inter-symbol interference (ISI). In contrast, DSP-based TXs perform equalization through low-speed parallel processing, which significantly alleviates the timing constraints. The digital architecture also enables programmable allocation of pre- and post-cursor taps under a fixed tap budget. This provides improved configurability and adaptability over analog designs with fixed tap locations. This paper presents a DSP-based TX supporting NRZ, PAM-4, and PAM-8 modulation. A 14-tap FFE implemented within the DSP effectively compensates for ISI over channels with 17.3 dB insertion loss at the Nyquist frequency.

title: Demystifying OpenZeppelin’s Own Vulnerabilities and Analyzing Their Propagation in Smart Contracts
authors: Han Liu, Daoyuan Wu, Yuqiang Sun, Shuai Wang, Yang Liu, Yixiang Chen
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: OpenZeppelin is a building block for many smart contracts on Ethereum-compatible blockchains. It provides mod-ular and reusable libraries for various Ethereum standards (e.g., ERC20 and ERC721) and common functionalities such as upgradeable contracts. Little research has been done on Open-Zeppelin security except for a recent study, which focused only on the misuse of OpenZeppelin code, assuming OpenZeppelin itself is secure but contract developers may not follow OpenZeppelin’s function checks appropriately. We argue that, despite appearing robust, OpenZeppelin itself could have many vulnerabilities, and these library-level vulnerabilities could inadvertently affect third-party smart contracts, even without misuse from developers.We present ZepCompare, the first end-to-end system for demystifying OpenZeppelin’s own vulnerabilities and analyzing their propagation in third-party smart contracts. ZepCompare incorporates a manual analysis stage where we review OpenZeppelin’s 64 historical releases, identifying 109 vulnerable-fixed code pairs, exposing flaws in cryptographic utilities, access control, etc. Leveraging these pairs, ZepCompare introduces facts of changes, a novel structure capturing vulnerable and fixed code contexts for flexible matching. Evaluated across 88,605 contracts from three Ethereum-compatible chains, ZepCompare detects 4,708 instances of OpenZeppelin-derived vulnerabilities. Manual sampling and a ground-truth experiment confirm that ZepCompare achieves 86.7% precision and 77.1% recall. Our findings reveal significant security risks in both historical and the latest versions of OpenZeppelin libraries, underscoring the urgent need for systematic auditing of foundational contracts components.

title: Impact of Stress Distribution on Birefringence and Polarization-Mode Dispersion in Multi-Core Fibers
authors: Gustavo Ocampo, Kunimasa Saitoh
abstract: We explore the fundamental role of stress distribution on defining birefringence characteristics in multicore fibers. Our numerical analysis shows how different design parameters dictate stress patterns, directly influencing the fiber's overall polarization-mode dispersion performance.

title: VERT: Polyglot Verified Equivalent Rust Transpilation with Large Language Models
authors: Aidan Z.H. Yang, Yoshiki Takashima, Brandon Paulsen, Josiah Dodds, Daniel Kroening
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: Rust is a programming language that combines memory safety and low-level control, providing C-like performance while guaranteeing the absence of undefined behaviors by default. Rust’s growing popularity has prompted research on correct and idiomatic transpiling of existing code-bases to Rust. Existing work falls into two categories: rule-based and large language model (LLM)-based. While rule-based approaches are theoretically sound, they often yield unidiomatic and unsafe Rust code, and are limited to few source languages, which hinders maintainability and industrial application. By contrast, LLM-based approaches, while providing no guarantees, are polyglot and typically produce more idiomatic and safe Rust code. In this work, we present VERT, a formally correct, polyglot Rust translator with more idiomatic outputs. VERT supports any language that compiles to Web Assembly. Using the Web Assembly compiler, VERT obtains an oracle Rust program. Leveraging the LLM, VERT generates an idiomatic candidate Rust program. This candidate is verified against the oracle with model-checking to ensure equivalence.

title: Hybrid BPSO-GA Based sEMG Feature Selection for Hand Gesture Classification
authors: Arpana Sinha, Tirath Prasad Sahu, Suvendu Rup
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Intelligent Signal Processing and Effective Communication Technologies (INSPECT)
abstract: Electromyography (EMG) employs an sEMG signal for the assessment of muscle contractions or relaxation during muscle activity. It is crucial for diagnosing problems related to the muscles, facilitating clinical evaluations. This paper presents an efficient sEMG feature selection method aimed at categorizing 40 distinct hand movements recorded from 22 subjects. In machine learning, the process of identifying a relevant set of features from a larger pool is referred to as feature selection. The hybrid metaheuristic approach proposed in this study integrates binary particle swarm optimization (BPSO) and genetic algorithm (GA). This algorithm is specifically designed to handle highdimensional (HD) datasets, enhancing accuracy while minimizing computational time. Binary PSO is particularly effective during the exploitation phase, while the Genetic Algorithm (GA) demonstrates superior capabilities in the exploration phase when seeking optimal solutions. To assess the efficacy of the proposed algorithm, the K-Nearest Neighbor (KNN) classifier is utilized for experimental validation. The experimental results indicate that the proposed feature selection method attained an average classification accuracy of $\mathbf{8 8. 8 2 f o r}$ intact subjects. These results validate that the proposed approach performs on par with, or exceeds, current state-of-the-art techniques in EMG feature selection and classification.

title: Cross-Domain Knowledge Transfer in Multimodal AI Systems for Enhanced Predictive Accuracy
authors: Vivek Ghatala, Sai Bhuvana Kurada, Sangeeta Singh, Shashank Majety, Preeti Sharma Nair
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Computing Technologies (ICACT)
abstract: Recently, cross-domain knowledge transfer in multimodal AI systems has proven problematic. The issue applies especially to apps that must correctly and scalably merge text, graphics, and audio. This paper proposes a three-step approach that allows learning in diverse modes while remaining semantically aligned and domain-invariant. First, deep networks encode each modality. For semantic unification, each modality is projected onto a shared latent space. Domain discriminators generalize features, whereas reconstruction routes and attention approaches protect contextual information and reduce over-fitting. The second phase improves representations with intra- and inter-modal attention modules. It improves learning using contrastive goals, entropy regularization, and domain-based consistency. Finally, a meta-optimization layer, adaptive scoring algorithms, and uncertainty-guided ensemble outputs improve forecasts for confident decision-making. We checked how well the technique works by comparing it to five other models using classification measures (accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, and AUC-ROC) and system efficiency indicators. The Contrastive Multimodal Knowledge Distillation Approach has the highest adaptability, lowest errors, and 94.6% accuracy while spending less time and money. Contrastive learning and knowledge distillation jointly improve cross-domain transfer in multimodal situations, according to this study. The findings help us create smart, efficient, and scalable AI systems that can handle many real-world data sets.

title: Design of a multi-spectral superconducting nanowire single photon detector with high efficiency and high speed
authors: Dezhi Li, Ziqi Gao, Yan Zhang, Kai Yang, Shen He, Xinyi Liu
abstract: This Superconducting nanowire single-photon detectors (SNSPDs) are efficient devices that absorb and convert incident photons to discriminable signals. However, the multi-spectral response of it is limited due to the resonance of the traditional optical cavity. In this work, we present a multi-spectral SNSPD that can detect single photon at multiple wavelengths with high efficiency simultaneously. The stack structure consists of nanowires embedded in the high refractive index dielectric strips, spacer layers and the reflection layer. The designed detector shows absorption efficiencies of over 85% at the three target wavelengths of 1550 nm, 1310 nm and 1064 nm while the filling factor of nanowire is only 20%. Meanwhile, the reset time is dramatically reduced by applying the low-filling-factor nanowire. Such ultrafast, high-performance single-photon detectors are promising for the rapidly advancing fields of multi-spectral imaging, satellite laser ranging and quantum communications.

title: Bidirectional LSTM for ADHD Detection in Adults using EEG
authors: Nupur Chugh, M.P.S Bhatia
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Intelligent Signal Processing and Effective Communication Technologies (INSPECT)
abstract: Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder is a common brain condition that is rarely identified, since clinical measures are subjectively assessed. Non-invasive electroencephalography (EEG) is an objective technique for recording implicit patterns of cerebral electrical activity in ADHD. In this paper, bidirectional long- and short-term memory (Bi-LSTM) networks and an attention mechanism are incorporated to improve the detection of ADHD using EEG. By identifying critical time points that define categorization operations, the attention mechanism enables the Bi-LSTM model to better explain temporal correlations in the EEG data sequences. The proposed approach was evaluated using the Adult ADHD dataset, which is publicly accessible. With an average five-fold cross-validation classification accuracy of 98.35%, the proposed approach clearly outperforms the other methods. The results of the experiment demonstrate that the chosen strategy outperforms conventional machine learning techniques, obtaining high F1-score, precision, and recall values. As a result, Bi-LSTM may be a useful paradigm to create diagnostic tools and increase the accuracy of ADHD identification at the same time.

title: Studies of Infrared Thermography Camera Installation in 500 kV Switchyard
authors: Jayandi Panggabean, I Nyoman Surjana, Arwindra Rizqiawan, Nana Sutisna, Infall Syalfani, Trio Adiono
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on High Voltage Engineering and Power Systems (ICHVEPS)
abstract: The extra high voltage (EHV) power network serves as a crucial node within the broader power system, acting as the backbone of electricity supply. In Indonesia, the EHV system operates at 500 kV and encompasses not only the power lines but also essential components such as insulator banks (IBT), current transformers (CT), capacitive voltage transformers (CVT), lightning arresters (LA), as well as numerous jumpers and terminations. With the advancement of Smart Grid policies, there is an increasing necessity for continuous monitoring of all assets to ensure optimal performance and safety. A key component of this monitoring strategy involves the deployment of infrared thermography (IRT) cameras, which effectively identify anomalies related to overheating hotspots that could pose risks to the system’s integrity. Since the implementation of the IRT camera system in 2018, it has successfully conducted operational monitoring for over five years, demonstrating its effectiveness in enhancing predictive maintenance strategies. However, the installation and operation processes were not without challenges, necessitating the development of specialized solutions to address these issues. This paper outlines the specific challenges encountered during the installation and presents tailored solutions that were implemented to overcome them. By sharing these insights, the research serves as a valuable reference for future installations, aiming to improve the efficiency and reliability of EHV networks across Indonesia and potentially in other regions.

title: Deep Learning for Transaction Anomaly Detection: Evaluating the Efficacy in Mitigating Banking Frauds
authors: Penugonda Anusha, P. Deekshith Chary, Y. Ram Kumar, Kummari Jyothsna, N. Srivani, Koppolu Yamuna Devi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Computing Technologies (ICACT)
abstract: This paper explores the transformative potential of Deep Learning in transaction anomaly detection, specifically focusing on its efficacy in mitigating banking fraud. Leveraging neural networks, such as autoencoders, recurrent neural networks (RNNs), and long short-term memory networks (LSTMs), Deep Learning excels in discerning intricate patterns within vast datasets. In the high-stakes domain of banking, where fraud prevention is paramount, Deep Learning offers a promising approach to adapt to evolving fraud strategies continuously. This article explores the methodology for developing mathematical models in Deep Learning, focusing on neural network architecture, training, and evaluation metrics. Challenges such as model interpretability and the need for substantial computational resources are also discussed. A comprehensive literature review highlights recent advancements and diverse applications, offering insights into the evolving landscape of fraud detection. The inclusion of cross-validation techniques ensures the robustness and generalizability of Deep Learning models, providing financial institutions with adaptive defenses against fraudulent activities.

title: SMACmix-FCN: A Network for Generating Fluid Velocity Field in Turbulent Scenes
authors: Shuqiang Guo, Zhicheng Xie, Bin Xiao
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: The study of fluid flow phenomenon has always been a hot topic in fluid mechanics. Particle Image Velocimetry (PIV), as a non-contact method, is widely used in fluid mechanics experiments to obtain the velocity field data of fluids. The key of PIV is to extract the displacement vector information from pairs of particle images, so as to construct a two-dimensional velocity field. Aiming at the problem that the current deep learning methods used to generate two-dimensional velocity fields have low accuracy, resulting in large errors in the generated velocity fields, this study, based on the fully convolutional neural network as the basic framework, proposes a fluid velocity field generation network named SMACmix-FCN in turbulent flow scenarios. The fully convolutional neural network is designed with a four-layer encoder, a bottleneck layer, and four decoders, with the aim of upsampling the size of the feature maps to match the output size of the encoder blocks. Then, a feature extraction and aggregation module named SMACmix, which combines self-modulating attention and convolution, is proposed and designed. This module first passes through the Enhanced Approximate Self-Attention (EASA) branch to capture non-local information, and then utilizes the Local Detail Estimation (LDE) branch to capture local details. The addition of this module enables the network to learn the dense texture features between different receptive fields. Experiments show that the network proposed in this study can generate velocity fields with higher accuracy and exhibits good performance on different fluid datasets.

title: Research on Intelligent Detection Algorithm of MTU Turbocharger Solenoid Valve Based on Machine Learning
authors: Haiyan He, Kunming Jiang, Miao Ye, Wenbin Ren, Xiaoqin Gao, Yu Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th International Conference on Power, Intelligent Computing and Systems (ICPICS)
abstract: A kind of intelligent detection method based on SVM optimization algorithm is proposed. To improve detection precision, SVM model is optimized using PSO algorithm, and SVM kernel function parameters are adjusted automatically so that the model can recognize electromagnetic valve fault modes. At the same time, in view of the category imbalance problem of solenoid valve fault data, this paper proposes a data imbalance processing technology to further enhance the robustness of the model. By collecting the working data of the MTU turbocharger solenoid valve, including parameters such as current, voltage, pressure and temperature, an experimental platform is designed and an experimental data set containing normal and multiple fault modes is constructed. The proposed SVM optimization algorithm shows a high accuracy and recall rate in solenoid valve fault detection. Compared with traditional methods, the detection accuracy is improved by more than 15%. In addition, this method also has strong real-time performance and can quickly respond to the working status of the solenoid valve, providing effective support for engine fault prediction and maintenance.

title: MDW-Net: A Lightweight Convolutional Neural Network Model for Chinese Font Recognition
authors: Changlong Liu, Xuewen Zhou, Rong Jiang, Bin Zhou, Dan Ma
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th International Conference on Data Science in Cyberspace (DSC)
abstract: In this paper we introduce a lightweight convolutional neural network (CNN) model for font recognition tasks. The proposed model not only surpasses existing state-of-the-art (SOTA) model in recognition accuracy across multiple datasets but also reduces its parameter size to 20.9 k, only 0.12 percent of that of SOTA model. Inspired by insights gained from visualization analysis of depthwise-separable convolution, we improve upon MobileNet's inverted bottleneck structure by modifying several key aspects, including removing the non-linearity following expansion convolutions, employing stacked depthwise convolution, conditionally removing the projection layer, and other refinements. These improvements lead to a novel structure, which we name the MDW-Block (Multiple DepthWise convolution Block). Building upon the MDW-Block, we further design a lightweight font recognition model MDW-Net, incorporating the Additive Angular Margin Loss (ArcFace Loss). Comparative experiments validate MDW-Net's superiority, while ablation studies demonstrate the effectiveness of the MDW-Block modifications. This work offers a novel perspective for designing lightweight CNN.

title: Lpv Model-Based Model Predictive Steering Control Considering Steering Delay for Intelligent Vehicles
authors: Hongsheng Liu, Longxin Guan, Pingshu Ge, Jianping Yin, Qichong Huang, Lie Guo
publish: 2025 9th CAA International Conference on Vehicular Control and Intelligence (CVCI)
abstract: This paper investigates the challenges of dynamic parameter uncertainties and steering time delay in intelligent vehicle path tracking control. An LPV-based model predictive control strategy is developed, in which the steering delay is explicitly taken into account. The delay is modeled as a first-order inertial element and integrated into a control-oriented tracking model to reflect the steering system's time-lag characteristics. A LPV tracking model is then established to capture multiple dynamic uncertainties in vehicle behavior. Based on this, a LPVMPC controller is developed, embedding the steering delay directly into the optimization process to compute the optimal front wheel angle. Simulation results verify that the proposed method significantly enhances robustness and stability, reducing tracking errors and improving accuracy under varying road curvatures and delay conditions.

title: Data-Driven Deep-Koopman MPC for Trajectory Tracking of 4WS Autonomous Vehicles
authors: Rui Dong, Zongxuan Li, Yang Li, Nian Wang, Hongqing Chu, Bingzhao Gao
publish: 2025 9th CAA International Conference on Vehicular Control and Intelligence (CVCI)
abstract: This paper addresses the inherent trade-off between real-time performance and tracking accuracy for trajectory tracking control of autonomous four-wheel steering (4WS) vehicles in emergency obstacle avoidance scenarios. A Deep Koopman Model Predictive Control (DK-MPC) framework incorporating prior vehicle dynamics knowledge for supervised training is proposed. Through a dual-branch neural network architecture, the state encoder is designed to achieve an interpretable mapping of nonlinear systems into a lifted linear space, while the control network adaptively generates time-varying gain parameters to characterize nonlinear effects of control inputs. The framework is embedded within a linear MPC structure for rapid optimization. Simulation results demonstrate maintained realtime computational efficiency alongside significantly improved tracking accuracy, delivering an effective solution for real-time high-precision trajectory tracking control of 4WS vehicles.

title: High-Reliability Model Predictive Control of Three-Phase DAB-LLC DC Converter Under Light Load
authors: Linjiang Deng, Guangyu Tan, Yifan Zhang, Chengchen Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th International Conference on Power, Intelligent Computing and Systems (ICPICS)
abstract: Compared with the defect of traditional two-phase mode in light load operation, a modulation strategy of two-phase mode considering loss balance is proposed in this paper. This ensures consistent losses for each switch tube and improves reliability. At the same time, the dynamic response is improved by model predictive control. Finally, the performance of the proposed proposed strategy is verified by both simulative studies and experiments of the hardware in the loop (HIL) technology.

title: Polyglot: An Extensible Framework to Benchmark Code Translation with LLMs
authors: Marco Vieira, Priyam Ashish Shah, Bhavain Shah, Rrezarta Krasniqi
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) show great potential for automating code-related tasks. However, sound assessments are necessary to understand their true capabilities, particularly in code translation, where reliability is crucial. We introduce Polyglot, an automated, multi-language framework for evaluating the translation quality of LLMs between different programming languages. Leveraging the IBM CodeNet Project, an extensive collection of coding problems in multiple languages, we assess translation quality using syntactic correctness, execution reliability, semantic preservation, and static code metrics. Our evaluation focuses on translating C to Java, Python, and Rust, languages that follow distinct paradigms and represent alternatives to modernize C-based systems. We evaluate open-source LLMs using three prompting strategies to understand the impact on translation performance. Our findings highlight that while LLMs show promising results for simple code translation, their limitations regarding complex logic and distinct language paradigms require further analysis.

title: Systematic Review on AI Safety and Future Research Agenda
authors: Shun Zhang, Haiwen Lu
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on System Reliability and Safety Engineering (SRSE)
abstract: The Artificial Intelligence (AI) safety is critical for ensuring dependable deployment and mitigating risks in modern products and systems. This study conducts a systematic literature review using bibliometric analysis to map the evolution, key themes, and research gaps in AI safety. The bibliometrix R package was employed to analyze 123 peerreviewed articles (2014-2025) from Web of Science. The analysis included keywords co-occurrence, thematic evolution mapping, and collaboration network assessment. The USA and China lead in the publication number, but the influence of the USA is unique globally. Meanwhile, cross-disciplinary collaboration remained limited, especially computer science field almost dominate the contribution while safety engineering discipline rarely involved. Finally, a five-point multilevel research agenda was proposed to guide future emerging challenges and adaptive regulation.

title: MIMIC: Integrating Diverse Personality Traits for Better Game Testing Using Large Language Model
authors: Yifei Chen, Sarra Habchi, Lili Wei
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: Modern video games pose significant challenges for traditional automated testing algorithms, yet intensive testing is crucial to ensure game quality. To address these challenges, researchers designed gaming agents using Reinforcement Learning, Imitation Learning, or Large Language Models. However, these agents often neglect the diverse strategies employed by human players due to their different personalities, resulting in repetitive solutions in similar situations. Without mimicking varied gaming strategies, these agents struggle to trigger diverse in-game interactions or uncover edge cases.In this paper, we present MIMIC, a novel framework that integrates diverse personality traits into gaming agents, enabling them to adopt different gaming strategies for similar situations. By mimicking different playstyles, MIMIC can achieve higher test coverage and richer in-game interactions across different games. It also outperforms state-of-the-art agents in Minecraft by achieving a higher task completion rate and providing more diverse solutions. These results highlight MIMIC’s significant potential for effective game testing.

title: Evaluating Program Coverage for Code-Model Training
authors: Nandakishore Menon, Diptikalyan Saha
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: In recent years, CodeLLMs have revolutionized the way developers interact with code. One notable application has been program translation, such as converting COBOL to Java or C to Rust. A critical challenge in this domain is ensuring that CodeLLMs are trained on programs that cover all syntactic features of the target language. This issue is especially pronounced for legacy languages like COBOL and ABAP, which are syntactically rich and have limited availability of open-source programs. In this paper, we present a tool for evaluating the syntactic coverage of COBOL programs. At the core of our approach is a representation called the Coverage Tree, which compactly and intuitively captures the syntactic constructs covered by a set of programs. Additionally, the tool can generate code statements to address uncovered syntactic gaps. Experimental results with COBOL benchmarks demonstrate the effectiveness of the tool. Screencast URL: https://youtu.be/lM0KHzcvllY.

title: Reinforcement Learning with Skills and Expert Priors for Autonomous Driving Decision-Making
authors: Rende Chen, Xiangyun Ren, Jie Li, Guofa Li
publish: 2025 9th CAA International Conference on Vehicular Control and Intelligence (CVCI)
abstract: Autonomous driving systems are increasingly deployed in real-world scenarios, where they face complex operational challenges. These include high-density traffic, diverse road structures, and numerous traffic regulations. While rule-based decision-making frameworks work well in simple scenarios, they struggle in dense traffic environments due to frequent interactions and high scene complexity. This occurs because the state dimension of the driving systems increases exponentially, resulting in poor generalization and high computational complexity. Reinforcement learning (RL) addresses this by interacting with the environment to gradually explore policies for adaptive optimization, eliminating the need for extensive manual design. However, in dense traffic environments, issues such as low sample efficiency and high training costs remain challenging to avoid. To address these issues, we employ an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{R L}$</tex> method with parameterized skills and expert prior (PSEP), which introduces a parameterized skill model to shift the RL exploration space from low-level control variables to the parameterized skill space, thereby improving exploration efficiency. A reverse skill parameter recovery method is further utilized to enable expert demonstration trajectories to transfer from the control space to the skill space, thereby incorporating prior expert knowledge. Finally, the presented method is validated on the MetaDrive simulation platform. Experimental results demonstrate that the employed method exhibits advantages in both policy performance and training efficiency. By incorporating skill abstraction and expert knowledge transfer mechanisms, this work provides an effective solution to address decision-making challenges in dense traffic scenarios.

title: Testing Autonomous Driving Systems Through Blind-Spot Guided Fuzzing
authors: Sali Moussa
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: Autonomous Driving Systems (ADS) must reliably perceive and react to complex environments, even when sensor blind spots obscure critical objects. While existing testing methods often focus on dynamic interactions, they significantly underestimate safety risks arising from both dynamic occlusions (e.g., vehicles) and persistent static occlusions (e.g., buildings). This research proposal introduces a novel, unified framework for occlusion-aware ADS testing. We present Blind-Spot Guided Fuzzing, a technique that systematically generates critical test scenarios by leveraging Large Language Models (LLMs) to synthesize realistic seeds from accident reports and employs multi-objective optimization to evolve them. This approach is implemented in our Occlusion-Sensitive Fuzzing (OS-Fuzz) framework, which encompasses two specialized modules: BlindSpotFuzz (BSF) for dynamic occlusions and StaticOcclu-Fuzz (SOF) for static environmental occlusions that persistently hide Vulnerable Road Users. At its core, OS-Fuzz integrates a generalized occlusion model and innovative metrics to guide test generation and quantify the exploration of obscured inputs. Preliminary results against Apollo show BSF identifies over 50% more blind-spot-related collisions. Our comprehensive evaluation plan will benchmark OS-Fuzz against state-of-the-art techniques, rigorously analyzing the relative impact of static versus dynamic occlusions. This research aims to significantly enhance ADS safety by incorporating the critical dimension of sensor and environmental limitations into automated testing.

title: Design Modification of Transformer Bushing and Its Effects on Interbus Transformer’s Performance During Operation
authors: Natya Kartika Kirana, Fabianus Marintis Dwijayatno, Waski Bastaman, Adam Murfid
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on High Voltage Engineering and Power Systems (ICHVEPS)
abstract: Transformer bushings are an essential component of electrical transformers. It provides electrical insulation and mechanical support for the high-voltage connections within a transformer while protecting them from environmental factors like dust and moisture. According to CIGRE TB 642 in 2015, 14% of power transformer failures are caused by defective bushings. A symptom of the transformer bushing failure was detected at IBT $150 / 70 \mathrm{kV}$, owned by PLN UIT JBT. Comprehensive diagnostic testing, including tan delta and Dissolved Gas Analysis (DGA), revealed a deterioration in the bushing’s insulation properties, accompanied by evidence of thermal and electrical faults. The tangent delta (dissipation factor) test results for the IBT $150 / 70 \mathrm{kV}$, phase S, indicated a value of 1.63%, which exceeds the acceptable standard. Consequently, replacement of the bushing is required immediately. The availability and condition of spare materials within PLN may not consistently meet operational needs. A dimensional mismatch was observed between the existing bushing, ABB type GOB 650 LF123-192, and the replacement bushing, ABB type GOB 650 LF123-073. If the new bushing is installed without modification, the insulation distance between the high-voltage zone and ground will be too close, causing an increased risk of electrical discharge. To resolve this issue, modifications were made to the ABB type GOB 650 LF123-073 bushing by installing an adapter in the bushing chamber. Subsequent to the modified installation of the transformer bushing, a comprehensive monitoring program was implemented, incorporating thermal image, tan delta, and capacitance testing. The results of these tests confirmed that the bushing was functioning satisfactorily.

title: The Method for Assessing the Condition of Reactive Power Switching Contacts Based on Dynamic Resistance and Radiated Electromagnetic Waves
authors: Gao Jinyu, Hou Xinming, Gao Zichen, Liu Mingkui, Liang Shengyu, Zhang Rui, Jia Chunbo
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th International Conference on Power, Intelligent Computing and Systems (ICPICS)
abstract: In reactive power compensation systems, reactive circuit breakers are frequently subjected to capacitive and inductive load switching, making arc extinguishing chambers more susceptible to electrocorrosion under arcing. The extent of electrocorrosion directly impacts equipment reliability and lifespan. This study combines the advantages of the radiated electromagnetic wave method and the dynamic resistance method: the former uses non-contact, real-time signal acquisition to capture arc extinguishing electromagnetic radiation signatures; the latter uses resistance changes to reflect the state of the contacts and arc extinguishing medium, achieving complementary information. Through experiments under different operating conditions (e.g., varying voltages and switching frequencies), both types of signals are collected and their characteristics are analyzed in relation to the extent of electrocorrosion and remaining life, leading to the construction of a state classification model and lifespan assessment spectrum. Experiments have shown that this method can identify the status of arc extinguishing chambers throughout their entire lifecycle, with a classification accuracy exceeding 90%. It is non-invasive, real-time, and reliable, providing a basis for equipment maintenance and lifespan management, and possessing engineering value for the safe and stable operation of power systems.

title: Air-Fuel Ratio Control of Gasoline Engines Based on TD-ADRC
authors: Jinlong Liu, Jian Zhang, Yangqian Meng, Jinwu Gao
publish: 2025 9th CAA International Conference on Vehicular Control and Intelligence (CVCI)
abstract: Addressing the challenges of inaccurate intake estimation and oxygen sensor time delay in gasoline engine air-fuel ratio (AFR) control, this paper proposes an active disturbance rejection control (ADRC)-based strategy. First, an AFR dynamic model is established utilizing in-cylinder pressure information, wherein modeling bias caused by intake estimation inaccuracies and other uncertainties will be incorporated in the controller design. Subsequently, an ADRC-based disturbance rejection controller is designed. To compensate for the impact of oxygen sensor time delay, a delay block is incorporated into the extended state observer (ESO). Finally, co-simulation experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed control strategy for AFR regulation.

title: Distributed Multi-link Operation (MLO) for Frame Replication in Wireless Time-Sensitive Networking
authors: Jetmir Haxhibeqiri, Pablo Avila Campos, Thijs Havinga, Ingrid Moerman, Jeroen Hoebeke
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Advanced Communication Technologies and Networking (CommNet)
abstract: Wireless Time-Sensitive Networking (WTSN) faces challenges to ensure communication reliability without compromising communication latency. As communication in wireless link happens in the same channel, frame replication and elimination for reliability (FRER) in different bands or channels is not possible in the wireless part. However, with the new features like multi-link operation (MLO), FRER can be enabled in wireless links as well, improving the overall reliability of the communication. In this paper, we show how we achieve distributed MLO utilizing openwifi platform and wired TSN for synchronized transmission in multiple links. We show initial results of end-to-end reliability and latency when MLO is utilized under different traffic load levels on each operational link. We also show the effect of cross-node physical layer queue management for avoiding head-of-the-line queue blocking.

title: Some new Quantum Codes and LCD Codes over a finite non-chain ring
authors: Mohammed Sabiri
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Advanced Communication Technologies and Networking (CommNet)
abstract: Let $\mathcal{T} = {\mathbb{F}_{{p^s}}} + {u_1}{\mathbb{F}_{{p^s}}} + {u_2}{\mathbb{F}_{{p^s}}} + {u_3}{\mathbb{F}_{{p^s}}} + u_1^2{\mathbb{F}_{{p^s}}}$ be a finite non-chain ring. In this paper, we propose a method of constructing quantum codes and LCD codes from constacyclic codes over $\mathcal{T}$. The first codes are obtained via the Gray map and the Calderbank-Shor-Steane construction from Euclidean dualcontaining constacyclic codes over $\mathcal{T}$. The second codes are obtained as the gray image of consta cyclic codes of LCD codes over $\mathcal{T}$.

title: Multimodal Fully Actuated Optimal Control for Corner Module Architecture Electric Vehicle with Minimum Response to Spatial Perturbation
authors: Jincan Liu, Zhengchao Xie, Wenfeng Li, Pak Kin Wong, Jing Zhao
publish: 2025 9th CAA International Conference on Vehicular Control and Intelligence (CVCI)
abstract: The integration of the in-wheel motor, the steering motor, the braking system, and the active suspension system is viewed as the corner module architecture (CMA). The intelligent chassis equipped with four CMAs can be considered the CMA electric vehicle. The fully actuated feature of the CMA vehicles enables the perturbation suppression with a full rank control matrix. This work focuses on the development of an optimal fully actuated controller for the CMA vehicle system. First, the multibody modeling approach is proposed to adapt to the arbitrary configuration of the CMA vehicles. Second, the architecture of the fully actuated controller is established based on the CMA eigenstructures with the constraint of torque allocation. Furthermore, the control law is designed by employing the orthogonal decomposition of the spatial perturbation. Moreover, the solution of the fully actuated control law is obtained by deriving the optimal eigenvector of the eigenstructures to guarantee minimum response of the spatial perturbation. Finally, hardware-in-the-loop tests are implemented to examine the effectiveness of the proposed fully actuated controller.

title: Moving Target Imaging via TR-SOKT for SAR with Maneuvering Trajectory
authors: Yifan Wang, Shiyang Tang, Chenghao Jiang, Linrang Zhang, Jiahao Han, Zixuan He, Daobao Xu, Hongmeng Chen, Zhanye Chen
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: Maneuvers provide flexibility for SAR ground moving target imaging (SAR-GMTIm), but also means more complex echo characteristics, especially in high-resolution situations. This letter systematically analyzes and establishes an imaging model for SAR-GMTIm with maneuvering trajectory, revealing the high-order range cell migration, Doppler centroid ambiguity and other issues. Based on above issues, an imaging method based on time reversal-second order keystone transform (TR-SOKT) is proposed, which firstly corrects range walk migration (RWM) through TR, then range curve migration (RCM) is corrected by SOKT, and azimuth residual phase is estimated and compensated by high-order ambiguity function (HAF). The proposed method is not affected by Doppler centroid ambiguity, making it suitable for target with various velocities. Additionally, parameter search is not performed during migration correction, resulting in low computational burden. The performance of the proposed method is verified by simulation and real data experiments.

title: Geometric Model-Based Global Navigation Satellite System Sensor Emulator for Solving the Simulation-to-Real Problem in an Autonomous Driving Simulator
authors: Jae-Un Lee, Jong-Hoon Won
abstract: This article presents a global navigation satellite system (GNSS) sensor emulator designed for driving simulators, which generates position measurements that closely resemble those produced by actual GNSS receivers under urban driving conditions. The proposed approach utilizes the almanac to access up-to-date GNSS satellite information and incorporates geometry-based error modeling. This includes accounting for satellite geometry and multipath effects, with an emphasis on accurately replicating the surrounding environment to produce realistic position measurements. This method enables the emulation of complex interactions between GNSS signals and the environment, which is crucial for achieving realistic position measurements. To validate the feasibility of the proposed method, we implemented the GNSS sensor emulator in a real-time driving simulator and compared the emulated results with those from an actual GNSS receiver at the same location and time, using the digital twin approach.

title: Zak-Transform-Induced Optimal Sequences and Their Applications in OTFS
authors: Xiuping Peng, Congying Wu, Zilong Liu, Chunlei Li, Jianye Zhang, Xiangjun Li, Pingzhi Fan
abstract: This paper introduces a novel finite Zak transform (FZT)-aided framework for constructing multiple zero-correlation zone (ZCZ) sequence sets with optimal correlation properties. Specifically, each sequence is perfect with zero auto-correlation sidelobes, each ZCZ sequence set meets the Tang-Fan-Matsufuji bound with equality, and the maximum inter-set cross-correlation of multiple sequence sets meets the Sarwate bound with equality. Our study shows that these sequences can be sparsely expressed in the Zak domain through properly selected index and phase matrices. Particularly, it is found that the maximum inter-set cross-correlation beats the Sarwate bound if every index matrix is a circular Florentine array. Several construction methods of multiple ZCZ sequence sets are proposed, demonstrating both the optimality and high flexibility. Additionally, it is shown that excellent synchronization performance can be achieved by the proposed sequences in orthogonal-time-frequency-space (OTFS) systems.

title: A Method for LEO Satellite Topology Reconfiguration Based on Elastic Optical Network
authors: Yunhui Wang, Hongxiang Guo, JianWu
abstract: The flat topology of LEO satellite networks can impact communication performance. This paper demonstrates through experiments that elastic optical link switching enables path optimization. Additionally, we proposed a topology reconfiguration algorithm. Through comparison with the + Grid, our proposed method demonstrates better performance.

title: Improving Outage Performance of Multi-Relay-Assisted Integrated Sensing and Communications
authors: Die Hu, Yulong Zou, Meiqin Pan, Shuying Lin, Libao Yang
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Wireless Communications and Signal Processing (WCSP)
abstract: In this paper, we consider a multi-relay-assisted integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) system, where a base station (BS) simultaneously transmits information to a destination with the aid of multiple relays and detects a target with radar signal. To jointly improve the outage performance regarding dual functions of the system, we propose two transmission schemes, namely single-relay selection (SRS)-assisted ISAC (SRS-ISAC) scheme and multi-relay selection (MRS)-assisted ISAC (MRS-ISAC) scheme. For each scheme, we derive closed-form analytical expressions for the communication outage probability (COP) and the sensing outage probability (SOP). Utilizing our derived expressions, we formulate the COP minimization problem with a SOP constraint by optimizing the power allocation factor and apply the particle swarm optimization (PSO) algorithm. Moreover, compared with the round-robin scheduling (RRS)assisted ISAC (RRS-ISAC) benchmark scheme, both SRS-ISAC and MRS-ISAC schemes can achieve superior COP performance under the same SOP requirement, while the MRS-ISAC scheme achieves the most favourable performance tradeoff between sensing and communications.

title: Optimization of Charging Pile Resource Layout Combining Spatio-Temporal Constraints and Improved Particle Swarm
authors: Jun Dong, Bin Guo, Liyu Huang, Zhengyang Peng
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Energy Engineering and Power Systems (EEPS)
abstract: This study aims at the problem of optimizing the resource layout of electric vehicle charging piles and proposes a solution that integrates spatio-temporal constraints and the improved particle swarm optimization algorithm. By constructing a multi-objective optimization model covering construction and operation and maintenance costs, energy consumption costs and time costs, the probabilistic mutation strategy based on the single-dimensional search amplitude is introduced to improve the particle swarm optimization algorithm. This strategy effectively avoids the local optimum problem by dynamically dividing the search interval and counting the search frequency of each dimension. The experimental results show that within the test area of 98.8 square kilometers, this method stably maintains the coverage rate of charging piles at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$80 \%-90 \%$</tex>, which is more than 30% higher than that of traditional methods. The average waiting time for users was controlled within 10.9-14.6 minutes, which was 50% shorter than that of the comparison method.

title: GraphCrossFormer A Graph-Enhanced Cross-Attention Transformer for Crop Yield Prediction
authors: Qiang Cai, Xiang Lei, YaTing Huang, Yanzhao Ren, HaiSheng Li
publish: 2025 9th International Workshop on Control Engineering and Advanced Algorithms (IWCEAA)
abstract: Accurate prediction of crop yield in the context of climate and environmental change is essential for evaluating agricultural sustainability. We introduce GraphCrossFormer, a graph-enhanced cross-attention Transformer designed to quantify the joint effects of climatic and soil drivers on crop yields across various emission pathways and adaptation strategies. The model incorporates three essential modules within a unified workflow: initially, the GraphFormer layer employs an adaptive sliding window to build a feature graph, enabling message passing that models the dependencies among features, thereby improving local interactions and minimising noise. The resulting graph-structured embeddings are integrated with contextual representations, including emission pathways and adaptation types, via a multi-head cross-attention mechanism, enabling dynamic alignment between environmental features and scenario information. The integrated features are processed by a consolidated Transformer encoder that captures multi-scale structural and semantic connections among all variables. The modules constitute an integrated architecture that concurrently captures local feature interrelations, global semantic structures, and contextual adjustments. The analysis utilizing the attention mechanism enhances the model's interpretability. GraphCrossFormer exhibits enhanced performance relative to CNN, LSTM, and Transformer baselines in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{R}^{2}$</tex>, MAE, and RMSE when assessed on global datasets for wheat, rice, corn, and soybean, highlighting critical variables including rainfall, temperature, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO}_{2}$</tex> fluctuations. This framework allows for a comprehensive evaluation of interactions among climate, soil, and management, this further promotes the adaptation of agriculture to climate changes.

title: A Novel Medical Image Reconstruction Framework for 3D Chest CT Based on a Single 2D Anteroposterior X-ray Image
authors: Tao Tang, Wenjie Cai, Bin Yang, Jun Huang, Ying Zhou, Zhiqin Liu, Qingfeng Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: X-rays are widely used in clinical practice due to their low radiation exposure and cost. However, 2D imaging can result in overlapping anatomical structures. In contrast, CT scans generate 3D images, effectively addressing this limitation. Nevertheless, CT scans also have drawbacks, such as high radiation, high cost, and inability to be implemented within ICU settings. In this paper, we propose the AP2CT-GAN framework, which aims to reconstruct chest CT images from a single antero-posterior chest X-ray. The framework incorporates the Feature Enhancement Connection (FEC) and the Feature Dimension Converter (FDC) to enhance critical features and capture global contextual information, along with the Dual-Consistency Loss function propose to ensure that the reconstructed CT images maintain a high level of structural and textural consistency with the ground truth. Experimental results demonstrate that AP2CT-GAN outperforms existing methods, offering a low-radiation, low-cost CT imaging solution with valuable potential applications in resource-limited regions and ICU settings.

title: A Highly Robust Wearable Respiration Monitoring System for Clinical Application
authors: Yulin Qiu, Xi Chen, Tianyu Chen, Yunfei Chai, Weimin Lyu, Changyuan Yu
abstract: This study develops a wearable fiber optic respiration monitoring system using ellipse fitting and Arctan algorithms for accurate, robust, long-term tracking of breathing states, supporting clinical applications and patient monitoring in hospitals.

title: Design of Multi-Phase PWM-Driven Thermo-Optic Tuning Loop for High-Q Microring Wavelength-Locking
authors: Ziying Xie, Siyuan Zhang, Yifan Liu, Zhicheng Wang, Ziyue Dang, Hongguang Zhang, Daigao Chen, Xi Xiao, Min Tan
abstract: This paper presents a multi-phase pulse width modulation (PWM) driven thermo-optic tuning scheme for thermal ripple reduction. By introducing phase as an additional tuning factor, thermal ripples excited from different phase PWM signals can partially cancel each other, enabling higher tuning accuracy at the same PWM frequencies while maintaining the conversion efficiency. A two-phase PWM-driven tuning loop with post-layout simulation results validates the approach. Implemented in the 65 nm CMOS process, the proposed tuning loop achieves wavelength locking of a microring with Q-factor of around 11,590 and high power efficiency. Compared with other solutions in the literature, it achieves significantly higher resolution and smaller thermal ripple at just 10 MHz clock rate, making it suitable for high-Q microring wavelength locking applications.

title: GECAT: A Graph-Enhanced Causality-Aware Transformer for Industrial Control System Intrusion Detection
authors: Yuzhe Zhang, Shanshan Zhang, Wan Wei, Yingxu Lai
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Modern Industrial Control Systems (ICS) have become prime targets for cyberattacks due to the increasing connectivity and complexity of operational infrastructures. These attacks can have severe consequences, making intrusion detection crucial. Recent deep learning approaches have steadily improved intrusion detection accuracy. However, they often fail to model the relationships between multiple sensors and actuators, lack the integration of physical priors, and demonstrate limited adaptability to varying conditions. In this paper, we propose GECAT (Graph-Enhanced Causality-Aware Transformer), a novel intrusion detection framework tailored for ICS data streams. Our approach combines graph-based sensor relationship modeling, causal inference principles, and a specially designed temporal transformer backbone to robustly detect and classify complex attacks.We integrate physical domain knowledge with data-driven graph learning modules to create an adaptive representation that adapts to diverse scenarios and enforces realistic process constraints. Experimental results on SWaT and WADI demonstrate that GECAT significantly outperforms a comprehensive set of state-of-the-art baselines across multiple metrics, indicating its effectiveness in defending ICS against sophisticated adversaries. Additionally, extensive ablation studies confirm the distinct contributions of each core component in our design.

title: WaveConvX: Multi-Level Wavelet Enhancement for Histopathology Image Classification
authors: Yuzhe Zhang, Yi Fang, Feiran Liu, Zixuan Liu, Xibin Jia
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Artificial histopathological image classification is emerging as a promising approach for assisting early cancer diagnosis and informing treatment planning. Although convolutional neural network (CNN) based methods have achieved significant success, they still struggle to capture the rich multi-scale and high-frequency details inherent in pathological tissues. To address the above issue, we propose WaveConvX, a novel histopathological image classification model that integrates multi-level wavelet decomposition with the ConvNeXt backbone. Our approach applies a two-stage discrete wavelet transform (DWT) to intermediate feature maps, enabling the decomposition of features into multiple frequency sub-bands. High-frequency components are enhanced using Adaptive Power Gabor Convolution (APGConv), while mid-frequency ranges are refined through tailored attention mechanisms. These processed sub-bands are then fused via inverse wavelet transforms, producing feature maps enriched with both global context and local morphological cues essential for accurate diagnosis. Comprehensive experiments are conducted on three public datasets (BreakHis for breast cancer, KBSMC for gastric cancer, and LC25000 for lung and colon cancer). The results demonstrate that WaveConvX consistently outperforms ten state-of-the-art benchmarks, achieving superior accuracy, F1 scores, and robustness across multiple types and magnifications of cancer. Our work demonstrates the significant potential of wavelet-enhanced CNNs in histopathological image analysis.

title: FE-HGAT: Frequency-Enhanced Hybrid Graph Attention Network For Traffic Prediction
authors: Yao Ren, Wujiang Zhu, Shiyong Lan, Xinyuan Zhou, Hongyu Yang, Zhiang Hou
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Traffic flow prediction is crucial for urban traffic management and planning. However, although existing research has achieved promising results, most methods primarily focus on time-domain processing, with insufficient exploration of frequency-domain signal characteristics. Moreover, existing approaches often fail to effectively distinguish and simultaneously model the spatial dependencies between nearby and distant nodes. To address these issues, this paper proposes a Frequency-Enhanced Hybrid Graph Attention Network (FE-HGAT) for traffic flow prediction. Our approach employs a dynamic filter in the temporal dimension, which utilizes Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) to enhance key frequency-domain features, thereby better characterizing the temporal dependencies in traffic data. Besides, to capture spatial dependencies between nodes at varying distances, we design a dynamic threshold module to distinguish between nearby and distant nodes, employing external attention (EA) and a mixture-of-experts-enhanced graph attention network (MOE-GAT) to model local dependencies and long-distance semantic similarities, respectively. Experiments demonstrate that FE-HGAT outperforms existing baseline models on several public transportation datasets, validating its effectiveness in traffic forecasting. The code is available at https://github.com/ry123scuer/FE-HGAT.

title: A Probe Selection Method Based on Enhanced Electrostatic Discharge Algorithm for 5G MIMO OTA Test
authors: Yuping Wang, Nan Ma, Ke Peng, Zhaoting Li, Xuanrong Li
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Wireless Communications and Signal Processing (WCSP)
abstract: The multi-probe anechoic chamber (MPAC) has been recognized as the most promising approach for 5 G massive multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) over-the-air (OTA) testing. However, the high system cost due to excessive hardware requirements (e.g., a large number of probes) remains an urgent issue to address. To cope with the challenges posed by the increase in the number of probes in a three-dimensional multi-probe anechoic chamber, this paper proposes a new probe selection method based on the electrostatic discharge algorithm (ESDA). Furthermore, an enhanced ESDA is proposed by integrating three diversity-preserving mechanisms into the baseline ESDA. The enhanced ESDA effectively reduces the number of probes while accurately simulating the spatial characteristics of target channel. By combining the probe selection method based on the enhanced ESDA and the probe weight optimization method based on the power spectrum, we achieve joint optimization of probe weights and positions. Simulation results indicate that, compared with existing methods, the proposed method has better convergence speed and channel reconstruction accuracy, and is suitable for many large-scale MIMO test scenarios.

title: Frequency-Domain Data Augmentation Based Contrastive Learning Framework for Bearing Fault Diagnosis with Few-Shot Learning
authors: Zhewen Yu, Ziqing Ye, Yiqi Liu
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotics, Control and Automation Engineering (RCAE)
abstract: Data-driven bearing fault diagnosis has gained significant attention in recent years with the wave of artificial intelligence (AI). However, labeling the data samples requires intensive expert knowledge, posing challenges in real-world applications. Contrastive Learning (CL) can learn discriminative representations without labels and has emerged as a promising approach to addressing the challenges of few-shot learning. Together with the fact that generic methodologies for data augmentation in contrastive learning usually do not take into account the frequency-domain knowledge, we proposed a Frequency-domain Data Augmented Contrastive Learning framework (FACL). FACL is proposed and used to shift data augmentation from the time domain to the frequency domain and integrates with CNN-based backbone models, thereby enhancing the ability of CNN architectures to decode complex failure modes and improve their robustness. Comprehensive experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework exhibits strong adaptability in pre-training performance when working together with three CNN-based backbone models.

title: Optimal Placement of Dynamic Thermal Rating Considering Transient Temperature of Overhead Lines with Two-Stage Robust Guarantee against N-1 Contingency
authors: Yingjie Zhao, Yao Zhang, Yongfei Li, Wei Huo, Hanting Zhao, Jianxue Wang
abstract: Dynamic thermal rating (DTR) is an economically efficient technique to improve the transmission capacity of existing overhead lines and alleviate transmission congestion caused by high penetration of renewable energy. However, it is still challenging to optimize the DTR placement with security assurance under N-1 contingency, which suffers from the curse of dimensionality in traditional optimization approaches. In this paper, a two-stage robust optimization approach for optimal placement of DTR devices is proposed to improve the transmission capacity of overhead lines. First, a transient temperature calculation model of overhead lines and its simplified approximation are proposed to possess the desirable property of convexity in the following model. Then, a two-stage robust optimization model for optimal placement of DTR devices is developed to avoid the cascading failure or blackout under N-1 contingency. An alternating current optimal power flow model based on second-order cone programming is utilized to calculate the line current more accurately. Case studies on several test systems verify the effectiveness of the proposed method in improving transmission capacity and reducing total cost.

title: Calculation of Positive-Sequence and Zero-Sequence Impedances of Three-Phase Submarine Cables
authors: K. F. Goddard, J. Rzempołuch, S. Chaudhary, G. Callender, P. Lewin
abstract: This paper describes semi-analytical calculation methods for the positive-sequence and zero-sequence impedances of 3-phase armored cables with solid sheaths and a single armor layer. Separate equivalent circuits are defined for these two impedances. Subsequently, circuit component values are calculated based on 2D field equations, with some 3D effects modeled. The existing approach for calculating zero-sequence impedance is corrected and expanded by inclusion of additional inductances due to sole no idal fields and magnetic armor effects. 3D finite-element models of cables with magnetic and non magnetic armor are used to assess the accuracy of our circuit models; discrepancies are less than 3% at frequencies between 50 Hz and 5 kHz. Python code with the implementation of the method is provided for accessibility.
