title: Cross-Lingual SynthDocs: A Large-Scale Synthetic Corpus for Any to Arabic OCR and Document Understanding
authors: Haneen Al-Homoud, Asma Ibrahim, Murtadha Al-Jubran, Fahad Al-Otaibi, Yazeed Al-Harbi, Daulet Toibazar, Kesen Wang, Pedro J. Moreno
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Data and Software Engineering (ICoDSE)
abstract: Cross-Lingual SynthDocs is a large-scale synthetic corpus designed to address the scarcity of Arabic resources for Optical Character Recognition (OCR) and Document Understanding (DU). The dataset comprises over 2.5 million of samples, including 1.5 million textual data, 270K fully annotated tables, and hundred thousands of real data based charts. Our pipeline leverages authentic scanned backgrounds, bilingual layouts, and diacritic aware fonts to capture the typographic and structural complexity of Arabic documents. In addition to text, the corpus includes variety of rendered styles for charts and tables. Finetuning Qwen-2.5- VL on SynthDocs yields consistent improvements in Word Error Rate (WER) and Character Error Rate (CER) in terms of OCR across multiple public Arabic benchmarks, Tree-Edit Distance Similarity (TEDS) and Chart Extraction Score (CharTeX) improved as well in other modalities. SynthDocs provides a scalable, visually realistic resource for advancing research in multilingual document analysis.

title: Pothole Detection using Enhanced Compact Convolutional Transformer and YOLOv11 model
authors: Lahar Srivastava, Dileep Kumar Yadav, Ambrish Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Intelligent Signal Processing and Effective Communication Technologies (INSPECT)
abstract: With the advanced growth of technology, the transportation infrastructure, which is accelerated in extreme weather, challenging vehicles in different areas, and also increasing traffic loads, potholes, etc., are the major issues for roadway maintenance. This paperwork discusses the method to overcome the issues of pothole detection using a YOLOv11 deep learning based model and enhances the performance using the advanced Compact Convolutional Transformer to improve the accuracy. The model compares the existing models of deep learning and improves the performance of detection and the efficiency of the model. The result outcomes improve in the VGG16 model, gives 97.04% accuracy and recall in the ResNet16 model, which gives 1.00%.

title: Iris Liveness Detection for Video Replay Attack Using Quality Metrics and EfficientNetB7
authors: Vaishali C. Kulloli, Maheshwari S. Biradar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Data and Software Engineering (ICoDSE)
abstract: The replay attack is a potentially serious threat to the dependability of Iris recognition systems, in which authentic biometric characteristics are reproduced from pre-recorded video recordings. To this end, we present a robust Iris Liveness detection framework based on best-frame selection, deep learning classification, and quality metric evaluation. To evaluate the performance, a real dataset of 115 eye samples of the users were used along with fake data. Video frames were presented to Laplacian sharpness variance algorithm for best frame selection. The best frames were categorized by passing them through a fine-tuned EfficientNetB7 model. Furthermore, biometric quality metrics (pupil-Iris ratio, grayscale utilization etc.) were combined to improve the Liveness. As testing dataset is divided into two subset 40 videos and 60 videos. The experiments demonstrated the accuracy of 92.50 % and 91.67% for 40 videos and 60 videos respectively. In addition, EfficientNetB7 exhibited excellent accuracy and robustness in distinguishing between real and spoofed samples. These findings validate our design's generalization across genuine and attack domains, and demonstrate that it can be used as a scalable solution for real-time Iris spoof detection

title: Cooperative UAVs for Remote Data Collection under Limited Communications: An Asynchronous Multiagent Learning Framework
authors: Cuong Le, Symeon Chatzinotas, Thang X. Vu
abstract: This paper addresses the joint optimization of trajectories and bandwidth allocation for multiple Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) to enhance energy efficiency in the cooperative data collection problem. We focus on an important yet underestimated aspect of the system, where action synchronization across all UAVs is impossible. Since most existing learning-based solutions are not designed to learn in this asynchronous environment, we formulate the trajectory planning problem as a Decentralized Partially Observable Semi-Markov Decision Process and introduce an asynchronous multi-agent learning algorithm to learn UAVs’ cooperative policies. Once the UAVs’ trajectory policies are learned, the bandwidth allocation can be optimally solved based on local observations at each collection point. Comprehensive empirical results demonstrate the superiority of the proposed method over other learning-based and heuristic baselines in terms of both energy efficiency and mission completion time. Additionally, the learned policies exhibit robustness under varying environmental conditions.

title: Capsule-ConvKAN: A Hybrid Neural Approach for Medical Image Classification
authors: Laura Pituková, Peter Sinčák, László József Kovács, Peng Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: This study conducts a comprehensive comparison of four neural network architectures: Convolutional Neural Network, Capsule Network, Convolutional Kolmogorov–Arnold Network, and the newly proposed Capsule-Convolutional Kolmogorov–Arnold Network. The proposed Capsule-ConvKAN architecture combines the dynamic routing and spatial hierarchy capabilities of Capsule Network with the flexible and interpretable function approximation of Convolutional Kolmogorov–Arnold Networks. This novel hybrid model was developed to improve feature representation and classification accuracy, particularly in challenging real-world biomedical image data. The architectures were evaluated on a histopathological image dataset, where Capsule-ConvKAN achieved the highest classification performance with an accuracy of 91.21%. The results demonstrate the potential of the newly introduced Capsule-ConvKAN in capturing spatial patterns, managing complex features, and addressing the limitations of traditional convolutional models in medical image classification.

title: Exploring Backbones for DeepLabv3+ in Semantic Segmentation for Driving Scene Understanding
authors: Mohammad Omar Faruk, Nazmus Sakib, Mohammad Anwar Hosen, Michael Johnstone
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Semantic segmentation is a crucial task in autonomous driving, enabling pixel-level understanding of complex road environments. DeepLabv3+ has emerged as a robust architecture for semantic segmentation, owing to its powerful Atrous Spatial Pyramid Pooling (ASPP) and decoder modules. However, the performance of DeepLabv3+ heavily depends on the choice of backbone network, which influences feature extraction, segmentation accuracy, computational efficiency, and inference speed. This paper investigates the impact of various backbones, including ResNet, Xception, Inception, and MobileNet, on the performance of DeepLabv3+ for semantic segmentation of driving scenes using the CamVid dataset. The study systematically compares these backbones, addressing their trade-offs between computational cost and segmentation precision. Results reveal that InceptionResNetV2 achieves the highest performance with an accuracy of (90.83%) and mIoU of (83.58%) but at the cost of higher computational demands, while MobileNetV2 offers a lightweight alternative with competitive performance (mIoU 81.33%). The analysis highlights the strengths and limitations of each backbone, offering valuable insights into optimizing segmentation models for autonomous driving scenarios. Future research should explore hybrid backbones to balance accuracy, efficiency, and explainability for diverse driving environments.

title: Federated Learning Algorithm Based on Model Compression and Parameter Smartification
authors: He Donglin, Jiayang, Liu Guanhong, Cheng Hua, Luo Hao, Zhang Yang, Zhang Fengli
publish: 2025 22nd International Computer Conference on Wavelet Active Media Technology and Information Processing (ICCWAMTIP)
abstract: Compared with traditional centralized learning, federated learning enables edge clients' local training/data processing to boost privacy/security. To address its challenges (large models, high communication costs, limited computing resources), this paper proposes CSFedAvg, a federated algorithm based on model compression and parameter sparsification. Its advantages: clients use a masking matrix to sparsify/compress parameters (cut communication overhead); server aggregates/evaluates them (maintain accuracy, reduce burden); it fits mainstream federated optimization and resource-constrained scenarios. Simulations show CSFedAvg enhances privacy/communication efficiency while preserving training accuracy.

title: ArchERL: Evolutionary Reinforcement Learning Framework for Efficient Hardware Architecture Design without Domain Knowledge
authors: Yuwei Huang, Yuhui Shi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: With the stagnation of Moore’s Law scaling, efficient hardware architectures employing compute-in-memory paradigms have become increasingly crucial to sustain AI innovations. This motivates the development of high-throughput architectures with balanced energy-latency profiles through machine learning algorithms. However, for human-in-the-loop optimization methods, human labor is involved in most of the iterations, whereas for automated methods, either expert domain knowledge is required in the design or the search space is relatively small. To address these challenges, we propose ArchERL, an evolutionary reinforcement learning (ERL) framework that represents the first application of ERL to general hardware architecture design. Specifically, ArchERL tightly couples population-based evolutionary algorithm for global exploration with an actor-critic reinforcement learning module for prior-light policy refinement, and ArchERL employs periodic weight synchronization and gradient feedback between the two modules to achieve efficient collaborative search and rapid convergence. To evaluate the proposed method, extensive experiments are conducted in multiple simulated hardware environments, including the DRAM controller and DNN mapping. The results demonstrate that ArchERL achieves leading performance and outperforms widely used baselines in both efficiency and effectiveness.

title:
Establishing Role Networks by Providing a Crowdsourcing Platform
                    <sup>*</sup>
authors: Haibin Zhu, Chengyu Peng, Kevin Zhe Yu, Jiajun Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Social relations are complex. Traditional social network analysis encounters too complex social networks to identify and solve social problems. Thanks to the Environments – Classes, Agents, Roles, Groups, and Objects (E-CARGO) model and the methodology of Role-Based Collaboration (RBC), it is possible to clarify and build role networks to abstract and simplify the social relationships among people or agents.This article clarifies the role relationships from the viewpoint of E-CARGO/RBC, and presents the engineering challenges, which make the establishment of the world role networks impossible for one development team. Therefore, a crowdsourcing platform is required. To meet this requirement, this paper describes our practice in building a crowdsourcing platform that supports the final establishment of role networks for society. This work is the first effort to establish role networks in the world.The practice described in this paper provides good practice for researchers and practitioners to conduct social network analysis and understand the complexity of social organizations.

title: PAT-Agent: Autoformalization for Model Checking
authors: Xinyue Zuo, Yifan Zhang, Hongshu Wang, Yufan Cai, Zhe Hou, Jing Sun, Jin Song Dong
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: Recent advances in large language models (LLMs) offer promising potential for automating formal methods. However, applying them to formal verification remains challenging due to the complexity of specification languages, the risk of hallucinated output, and the semantic gap between natural language and formal logic. We introduce PAT-Agent, an end-to-end framework for natural language autoformalization and formal model repair that combines the generative capabilities of LLMs with the rigor of formal verification to automate the construction of verifiable formal models. In PAT-Agent, a Planning LLM first extracts key modeling elements and generates a detailed plan using semantic prompts, which then guides a Code Generation LLM to synthesize syntactically correct and semantically faithful formal models. The resulting code is verified using the Process Anal y sis Toolkit (PAT) model checker against user-specified properties, and when discrepancies occur, a Repair Loop is triggered to iteratively correct the model using counterexamples. To improve flexibility, we built a web-based interface that enables users, particularly non-FM-experts, to describe, customize, and verify system behaviors through user-LLM interactions. Experimental results on 40 systems show that PAT-Agent consistently outperforms baselines, achieving high verification success with superior efficiency. The ablation studies confirm the importance of both planning and repair components, and the user study demonstrates that our interface is accessible and supports effective formal modeling, even for users with limited formal methods experience.

title: Predictive Modeling For Earthquake Detection and Magnitude Estimation
authors: Ridhi Singh Gaur, Rajni Bhati, Nidhi, Ritu Rani, Garima Jaiswal, Arun Sharma
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Intelligent Signal Processing and Effective Communication Technologies (INSPECT)
abstract: Earthquakes are the devastating disasters which are posing a major risk to the human life globally. Earthquake prediction before its occurrence is the very important as it can alert people about the earthquake before it’s occurrence so that people can prepare well for its post effects and can save their lives as well. This paper reviews various methodologies for the prediction of earthquake and its magnitude, the major challenges that we face in the precise prediction of earthquake and various strategies and improvements that can contribute in handling the post-event scenario efficiently. Using various machine learning algorithms, we have developed a model which can predict earthquake and its magnitude. For developing this, we have used Sci-kit Learn Library. We have obtained data set through USGS (United States Geological Survey) website for implementing machine learning classification and regression algorithms. Classification algorithms used on our data set to predict earthquakes include Random Forest, KNN(K-Nearest-Neighbors), Decision Tree, Logistic Regression, SVM(Support Vector Machine) and Naive Bayes. For predicting magnitude of earthquake, Multi-Linear Regression Algorithm is used.

title: Impact of Data Acquisition Accuracy on the Performance of Digital Twin Optical Networks
authors: Junfeng Cao, Nan Hua, Kangqi Zhu, Qianchi Qin, Siqi Wu, Xiaoping Zheng
abstract: We present an integrated modeling–emulation–validation framework to systematically analyze how data acquisition accuracy impacts the performance of digital twin optical networks. The framework is experimentally validated using spectrum classification tests as a representative scenario, revealing key degradation mechanisms and providing practical guidelines for resource allocation in the sensing layer.

title: Phase-Guided Cross-Frequency Integration Network for ISAR and Optical Image Fusion
authors: Ze Wang, Lei Liu, Zhenxi Zhang, Rongzhen Du, Wanting Zhou, Man Zhou, Jingjing Cai, Feng Zhou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Inverse synthetic aperture radar (ISAR) and optical image fusion aims to generate a composite image that simultaneously emphasizes the prominent contours of spacecraft from optical images and preserves the rich texture information inherent in ISAR images. However, the limited receptive fields of spatial-domain methods restrict their ability to capture global contextual dependencies among strong scattering points in ISAR images and to effectively integrate complementary optical features. To tackle this challenge, we propose a phase-guided cross-frequency integration module (PGCFIM), which exploits the intrinsic global modeling capability of the frequency domain and the semantic expressiveness of the phase spectrum. Specifically, a deep Fourier transform is employed to establish an image-wide receptive field for intra-domain global modeling. Subsequently, phase components are explicitly aggregated, and a gating mechanism is introduced to guide the integration of inter-domain long-range dependencies, enabling effective learning of complementary cross-modal representations. To eliminate reliance on hand-crafted fusion strategies, we design an end-to-end network, named PGCFINet. By jointly enhancing cross-domain interaction, frequency-domain global awareness, and explicit complementary feature integration, PGCFINet significantly strengthens cross-domain and cross-modal information interaction representation. Furthermore, to mitigate the current lack of ISAR and optical image datasets, we construct a new dataset comprising various spacecraft models, offering an alternative benchmark for evaluation. Extensive experiments demonstrate show that PGCFINet achieves superior performance than state-of-the-art methods in both qualitative and quantitative assessments. Moreover, PGCFINet is extended to infrared and visible image fusion, and the favorable results further validate its robust generalization ability. The codes of our fusion method and the dataset are forthcoming at https://github.com/WangZe0622/PGCFINet.

title: EmoBTA: A Sentiment Analysis Model Fusing Semantic Modeling and Sentiment Focusing
authors: Saijia Su
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th International Conference on Power, Intelligent Computing and Systems (ICPICS)
abstract: The explosive growth of social media data makes it an important source of public sentiment analysis, which is of key value for opinion management and social sentiment monitoring. However, traditional approaches struggle to capture the semantic intricacies inherent in informal social media texts, and existing deep learning models face limitations such as weak temporal dependency modeling and ineffective sentiment weight distribution. To this end, this study proposes an EmoBTA sentiment analysis model that incorporates a semantic representation module, a sequence modeling module, and a key feature focusing module, considering both semantic modeling and sentiment-focusing capabilities. By using the Hugging Face TweetEval dataset, a multi-stage fusion model of semantic representation, sequence modeling, and key feature screening is constructed, and comparative experiments and ablation experiments are designed to verify the effectiveness of the model. The experimental results show that the proposed model achieves an accuracy of 72.20 % on the test set, with a 0.25 % improvement over the BERT+Transformer baseline and a 0.65 % improvement in the macro-averaged F1 value. Compared with existing methods, the model shows obvious advantages in accuracy and robustness, confirming the effectiveness of the attention mechanism for dynamic focusing of key sentiment information.

title: Optimal fractional order Kalman consensus filter based on historical information
authors: Rui Chen, Chengjia Zhang, Chenxi Jia, Chengkun Li, Yiheng Wei
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: An optimal fractional order Kalman consensus filter (OFOKCF) is developed in this paper to address distributed state estimation challenges within fractional order systems. By leveraging historical state information, the algorithm captures long-term dynamics and model the system more precisely. A consensus mechanism ensures node consistency, while covariance intersection simplifies cross-correlation computations, using trace-based adaptive weights for multi-dimensional states. The simulation validates the effectiveness and accuracy of OFOKCF. The approach offers a scalable solution for distributed estimation in sensor networks and cooperative control, particularly for fractional order systems.

title: 22-nm Ultra-High-Speed Area-Efficient ECC using 5T Dynamic XOR/XNOR Gates for High-Performance SRAM Applications
authors: Daiki Kitagata, Kenichiro Takiguchi, Shunya Nagata, Kouji Satou, Daisuke Nakamura, Miki Tanaka, Haruyuki Okuda
abstract: A new ultra-high-speed (UHS) area-efficient dynamic XOR/XNOR (DXOR/DXNOR) gates using 5 transistors are proposed to reduce error correction code (ECC) overhead for high-performance SRAM applications. The proposed DXOR exhibits about 30% gate delay and 50% gate area reduction compared to the conventional XOR by virtue of dynamic operation and pass-transistor logic configuration. The improvement is further enhanced using the novel array architecture using large-aspect-ratio 2-type tall and narrow layout in hybrid. The operation and performance of the proposed DXOR are evaluated in the fabricated 22 nm TEG and $\times 1.25$ frequency improvement is computationally verified for the high-speed (HS) SRAM with dynamic ECC circuit using the proposed architectures.

title: Diagnosing Abnormalities in the Insulation Characteristics of XLPE Cable Termination
authors: Shin-Ichi Kobayashi, Shigeharu Suzuki, Daichi Sonoyama
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on High Voltage Engineering and Power Systems (ICHVEPS)
abstract: This paper describes the detection sensitivity evaluation of two types of partial discharge measurement methods as a method for diagnosing abnormalities in XLPE cable terminations, which are numerous and structurally complex among 77 kV XLPE lines in Japan, as well as an overview of the evaluation of a diagnosing method of abnormalities based on the concentration of acetylene gas inside 77 kV XLPE cable terminations.

title: FFR Service of Li-ion BESS to Improve Grid’s Inertial Response with Hydro-Turbine Governors and Frequency-Dependent Loads
authors: Ivo Saputra, Johanes Hendra Febrianto Rajagukguk, Kukuh Arung Pinanditho, Adyatmoko Wirananto, Elvanto Yanuar Ikhsan, Munawwar Furqan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on High Voltage Engineering and Power Systems (ICHVEPS)
abstract: Nowadays, the utilization of battery energy storage systems (BESS) for fast-frequency reserve (FFR) services has become an important approach to enhance the inertial response of modern power systems that are experiencing a significant reduction in stored kinetic energy from synchronous machines. The main objective of this paper is to investigate and compare different FFR service strategies in the context of a small-sized power system dominated by hydro power plants equipped with governor control and frequency-dependent (damping) loads. A detailed dynamic model of a 1-MW Lithium-ion (Li-ion) BESS is developed and integrated into the test-case system to provide various FFR schemes. By systematically applying these FFR services under a defined disturbance scenario, the study aims to evaluate their influence on the grid frequency trajectory, with particular focus on the maximum instantaneous frequency deviation (IFD). The simulation results clearly demonstrate that the provision of FFR from the BESS consistently improves the system inertial response across all service types, with an enhancement of approximately 11.27% in the maximum IFD compared to the no-FFR case. Notably, while all FFR schemes show beneficial effects in reducing the frequency nadir, certain deactivation strategies may induce a secondary frequency shock, potentially affecting overall system stability. These findings highlight the importance of carefully designing both the activation and deactivation mechanisms of FFR services.

title: Enhancing Model Transparency with Causality-Aware Surrogate Frameworks in Explainable AI
authors: Trisna Ari Roshinta, Gábor Szűcs
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI) plays a crucial role in high-stakes decision-making by ensuring that machine learning models provide clear and trustworthy explanations. However, many existing interpretability methods, such as SHAP and Partial Dependence Plot (PDP), struggle to differentiate between correlation and causality. To overcome this challenge, we introduce a causality-aware surrogate modeling framework that improves the global interpretability of complex models. Our approach combines Probability of Sufficiency (PS), Probability of Necessity (PN), and Probability of Causality (PoC) with decision tree-based rule extraction to identify rules and features that have a direct causal impact on the target outcome. Experiments on the German Credit dataset reveal that certain rules exhibit strong sufficiency while showing weak necessity, highlighting key causal factors in loan approval decisions. Among these, savings and duration stand out as critical features for counterfactual reasoning. By ensuring that extracted rules capture true causal relationships rather than misleading correlations, our method enhances model transparency, trustworthiness, and counterfactual fundamentals.

title: Investigation on the Electromechanical Response and Parameter Optimization of a Piezoelectric-Structure Coupled Dynamic Impact Energy Harvester
authors: Zhi Wang, Qing Mao, Ruiyang Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Sensing, Diagnostics, Prognostics, and Control
abstract: In light of the pressing demand for energy recovery systems and high-performance sensors in the current automotive industry, this paper investigates the electromechanical response of a bilayer circular plate structure—comprising a conventional material layer and a piezoelectric material layer—under a constant central cylindrical pressure. By establishing a piezoelectric-coupled finite element model, a systematic analysis is conducted to examine the influence of key geometric parameters, such as cylinder radius, plate radius, and layer thicknesses, on both the absolute average voltage and the maximum deformation of the structure. The findings reveal that variations in these geometric parameters significantly affect the strain distribution and charge accumulation efficiency, thereby determining the electromechanical output performance and deformation behavior. Through parameter optimization, the structure can be tailored for either energy harvesting or sensing applications. This study provides a theoretical foundation and optimization guidance for the structural design of high-performance piezoelectric energy harvesters and sensors aimed at automotive applications.

title: Research on Classification Method of Airborne Lidar Point Cloud based on Deep Learning
authors: Guowei Zheng, Peng Jia, Xiaofei Li, Xiangting Li, Li Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th International Conference on Power, Intelligent Computing and Systems (ICPICS)
abstract: This paper proposes a method for classifying airborne lidar point cloud objects based on the Transformer architecture, aiming to improve the model's ability to understand irregular spatial structures and the recognition accuracy of multi-category objects. By constructing an end-toend model that includes relative position embedding, multihead attention mechanism and residual structure, highprecision extraction and classification output of point-level semantic information are achieved. Experiments were carried out on the ISPRS Vaihingen dataset, and the results showed that the proposed method outperformed the comparison model in terms of overall accuracy, average IoU and small target recognition ability. The influence of each core module on the model performance was further analyzed through ablation experiments, verifying the effectiveness and robustness of its structural design. This study provides a new solution path for high-precision point cloud classification and has good application and promotion prospects.

title: Secrecy-Driven Robust Beamforming Under Age of Information Constraints for Satellite-Terrestrial Integrated Networks
authors: Mingyi Ji, Haitao Zhao, Huaicong Kong, Bo Xu, Haibo Dai, Xianbin Wang
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Wireless Communications and Signal Processing (WCSP)
abstract: This paper presents a robust secure beamforming (BF) strategy that incorporates information freshness into the physical layer security (PLS) design of satellite-terrestrial integrated network (STIN). In the considered framework, satellite networks serve earth stations in the presence of multiple eavesdroppers, while terrestrial networks, operating over the same spectrum, provide multicast services to ground users. To capture the dynamics of status update timeliness, we model the evolution of the Age of Information (AoI) using a discrete-time Markov chain, taking into account both the activation thresholds and access probabilities of users. Based on this model, we derive a closed-form expression for the secrecy margin of the wiretap channel, thereby jointly quantifying data freshness and communication security. Assuming imperfect channel state information, we formulate an optimization problem to maximize the average secrecy margin, subject to constraints on average AoI, quality of service (QoS), eavesdropping probability, and total transmit power. To tackle the inherent non-convexity caused by probabilistic constraints, we adopt Bernstein-type inequalities to transform them into tractable deterministic equivalents. An efficient solution algorithm is then developed by integrating successive convex approximation with difference-of-convex programming, enabling effective computation of the optimal BF vectors. Extensive simulation results confirm that the proposed approach achieves notable improvements over existing methods in both secrecy performance and information freshness, offering a unified and practical solution for secure and timely communication in future 6 G integrated networks.

title: Data-Driven SOC Estimation with Uncertainty Quantification for EV Batteries
authors: Rifat Islam Rony, Mursalin Biswas Emon, Mehedi Hassan
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Information and Communication Technology (EICT)
abstract: Abstract:A precise estimation of the state-of-charge (SOC) in lithium-ion batteries (LiBs) is vital to an improvement in performance, safety and durability of electric vehicles (EVs). This paper presents a data-driven method of SOC estimation, where data is trained using the Transformer-based model (FT-Transformer) with Monte Carlo (MC) dropout appended to calculate prediction uncertainty. To reflect the dynamic behavior of batteries, the model includes time-series lagged features and uses the synthetic minority oversampling technique (SMOTE) to overcome data imbalance, thus enhancing total accuracy. Observational data shows that the model obtained is accurate in terms of having low mean absolute error (MAE) of 0.447 and root mean squared error (RMSE) of 0.714, besides yielding predictable uncertainty measure on an individual observation basis with a converge of 0.956 within 95% confidence interval. The given strategy provides an efficient real-time SOC estimation, thereby enhancing the reliability of energy management and ensuring safe operation of EVs.

title: Frequency-Reconfigurable Yagi-Uda Antenna Based on Vanadium Dioxide
authors: MengYu Dong, JunQiang Zhang, XiYing Huang, ZhengHao Xing, JiaWei Tao, QingTao Cheng, HuiJuan Niu
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Infocomm Technology (ICAIT)
abstract: A frequency-reconfigurable Yagi antenna based on vanadium dioxide (VO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>) phase-change material is investigated in this paper. Utilizing the characteristics of insulating and metallic phase transition of VO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> material, the designed antenna achieves dynamic switching features at the operating frequency between the X-band ($8-12 \mathrm{GHz}$) and the Ku-band ($12-18 \mathrm{GHz}$). Simulation results demonstrate that the antenna exhibits good impedance matching, radiation directivity, and gain performance in both states of the $\mathbf{V O}_{\mathbf{2}}$ material. Compared to traditional PIN diode solutions, VO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> material offers lower RF loss, not only a simpler configuration and superior thermal stability, but easier integration and miniaturization, making it suitable for future communication and radar systems.

title: Noninvasive Glucose Monitoring Device for Diabetes Mellitus Detection
authors: Md. Altab Hossain, Sheikh Md. Rabiul Islam
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Information and Communication Technology (EICT)
abstract: A specially designed noninvasive device for measuring blood glucose levels to support diabetes patient monitoring. Diabetes patients’ blood glucose monitoring has become a challenge in daily tracking. Generally, an invasive method is not suitable for frequent monitoring of blood glucose levels; the invasive technique used to measure blood glucose level monitoring is painful and expensive. Moreover, pricking fingers has become a possibility of infection risk and damage to the tissue after a long period. This paper presents the noninvasive method used to design a blood glucose sensor for monitoring blood glucose levels. A Near-Infrared LED (940 nm) and a photodiode are used to design a glucose sensor for measuring blood glucose noninvasively. The performance is shown by the normalized root mean squared error (NRMSE) value of 17.8996, correlation coefficient $\left(\boldsymbol{R}^{\mathbf{2}}\right)$ value of $\mathbf{0. 9 2 2 0}$, and mean absolute percentage error (MAPE) value of 0.0792. Performances analysis of the noninvasive blood glucose measurements is also conducted methods are Clarkes error grid (CEG) analysis, Parkes error grid (PEG) analysis, and Surveillance error grid (SEG) analysis used to determine errors between invasive and noninvasive methods of blood glucose testing.

title: BenGQL: An Extensible Benchmarking Framework for Automated GraphQL Testing
authors: Abenezer Angamo, Marcello Maugeri
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: GraphQL APIs provide a unified endpoint for retrieving and uploading data in a web application. Due to its efficient data-fetching strategy, which allows for the retrieval of only the required data, GraphQL is gaining popularity. Its software nature necessitates robust testing, both functional and non-functional. As automated testing tools, including load testers and fuzzers, are developed to assess GraphQL APIs, they lack a common set of case studies for rigorous evaluation and comparison.To address this gap, we present BenGQL, a benchmarking framework containing 23 representative open-source GraphQL server applications, spanning different underlying engines and schema complexities. BenGQL provides an extensible infrastructure for running testing tools against these case studies, enabling developers and researchers to: (i) execute testing tools against the same case studies, (ii) analyse and compare results using custom analysis modules, and (iii) extend the benchmark with new case studies, tools, or metrics.The ultimate goal of BenGQL is to foster more rigorous, reproducible research in automated GraphQL testing by providing both the case studies and the infrastructure for running experiments. As a consequence, we release the source code at https://github.com/marcellomaugeri/BenGQL, inviting other researchers to contribute. A video demonstration is also available at https://youtu.be/wZ06Xxa_Koo.

title: DNAFuzz: Descriptor-Aware Fuzzing for USB Drivers
authors: Zhengshu Wang, Peng He, Fuchen Ma, Yuanliang Chen, Shuoshuo Duan, Yiyuan Bai, Yu Jiang
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: USB is a widely used interface standard in modern operating systems for connecting computers to various external devices. External devices can launch attacks by injecting random data into the host via USB, causing memory errors or even system-level crashes. Fuzzing has been proven to be an effective method to detect USB driver vulnerabilities. However, existing fuzzing methods generate testing inputs without considering the format and semantics of USB descriptors, which define device functionality. As a result, many test cases fail to pass the host’s input validation mechanism, leading to ineffective testing.In this paper, we propose DNAFuzz, a USB driver fuzzer that generates descriptor-aware payloads. First, it utilizes USB specifications to parse the field definitions and item types of USB descriptors for modeling. Then, based on the field description list and semantic information, DNAFuzz designs mutation strategies to guide the generation of payloads. This approach improves the quality of test cases and the fuzzing effectiveness. Currently, we evaluated DNAFuzz on multiple versions of Linux kernel USB drivers and compared it with state-of-the-art fuzzers, including USBFuzz and Syzkaller. Results show that DNAFuzz significantly improves input quality, successfully increasing the proportion of tests with execution times exceeding 2 seconds by 358% and 65%. In addition, DNAFuzz detected 15 bugs, 11 of which have been fixed or confirmed by the corresponding maintainers.

title: A 415 μ W BLE Receiver with Third-Harmonic Time-Interleaved Passive Mixer and Reconfigurable AFIR Filter Achieving 26.5dBm Out-of-Band IIP3
authors: Zongle Ma, Yicheng Chen, Kaixue Ma, Keping Wang
abstract: Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) receivers are gradually evolving from traditional active RF front-ends [1, 2] to passive RF front-ends [3, 4] that aim to meet the power efficiency and blocker resilience requirements. Traditional zero-IF receivers (Fig.1, upper) are based on $\mathrm{g}_{\mathrm{m}}$-LNA and quadrature mixer, leading to high DC power and nonlinearity. The mixer-first passive receivers (Fig.1, middle) achieve lower power consumption and improved linearity by eliminating the active $\mathrm{g}_{\mathrm{m}}$-LNA and employing passive front-end with capacitors and switches driven by LO. However, even in the mixer-first architecture, the LO generation remains a bottleneck for power reduction as it relies on the oscillator frequency and multi-stage buffers.

title: A 28 nm AI microcontroller with tightly coupled zero standby power weight memory featuring standard logic compatible 4 Mb 4-bits/cell embedded flash technology
authors: Daewung Kim, Seong Hwan Jeon, Young Hee Jeon, Kyung-Bae Kwon, Jigon Kim, Yeonghun Choi, Hyunseung Cha, Kitae Kwon, Daesik Park, Jongseuk Lee, Sihwan Kim, Seung Hwan Song
abstract: Microcontrollers targeted for battery powered smart edge devices are often required to run inferencing tasks at a place where sensor data are generated for real-time response using a locally stored AI model once it is trained from the cloud. Power gating technique is often deployed to save an idle mode power consumption of the microcontrollers for low power applications, and the AI model can be stored and updated in an embedded Non-Volatile Memory (eNVM) during a lifetime of the device without consuming standby power during the idle mode. Typically, such a multiple-time programmable eNVM technology requires additional fabrication steps beyond a standard logic process and is configured to store only single bit information per a unit memory cell limiting efficiency of AI computation [1]. In this work, we report an AI microcontroller with zero-standby power weight memory featuring standard logic compatible 4-bits/cell Embedded FLASH (EFLASH) technology, tightly coupled to a Near-Memory Computing Unit (NMCU) for cost effective and low power edge AI computing applications.

title: Automated Pfirmann Grading of Lumbar Disc Degeneration Using Deep Learning: An End-to-End Framework for MRI Analysis
authors: Ruchi Jain, Vikas Sakalle
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Intelligent Signal Processing and Effective Communication Technologies (INSPECT)
abstract: Lumbar disc degeneration assessment through Pfirrmann grading is crucial for clinical diagnosis but suffers from inter-observer variability and time-intensive manual evaluation. This paper presents a precise deep learning framework for automated Pfirrmann grading of lumbar disc degeneration from MRI scans. Our method introduces a novel preprocessing pipeline that integrates focus-slice aggregation, N4 bias field correction, and adaptive cropping techniques to address common MRI artifacts and enhance image quality. To overcome limited dataset challenges, we implement extensive data augmentation strategies which includes geometric transformations (flipping, rotation, shearing) and noise injection. The framework implements UNet architecture for precise disc segmentation, followed by classification using 5 state-of-the-art convolutional neural network architectures: ResNet50, DenseNet121, InceptionV3, VGG16, and EfficientNetB7. The experimental results demonstrate superior performance with EfficientNetB7, achieving 94.2 % classification accuracy on our dataset. Comprehensive evaluation through precision-recall analysis validates the clinical reliability of our approach, while Grad-CAM visualizations provide interpretable feature maps that align with radiological assessment criteria. The proposed preprocessing pipeline enhances model robustness against limited training data and variability in MRI acquisition parameters. Our automated grading system shows promise for clinical deployment, thereby reducing diagnostic time while maintaining high accuracy standards consistent with expert radiological assessment.

title: Research on the method of improving the positioning accuracy of redundant robot based on null-space stiffness optimization
authors: Ying Liu, Chengyou Xie, Tianfu Ai, Xianen Zhou, Ting Liu, Hang Zhou, Suihong Liu, Dequan Zeng, Antonio Petitti
publish: 2025 2nd International Symposium on AI and Cybersecurity (ISAICS)
abstract: The low stiffness has significantly hindered the applications of robots in high-precision processes. For the redundant characteristics of the seven-degree-of-freedom robot, null-space stiffness optimization is presented to address the issue of infinite solutions in the inverse kinematics. According to the static stiffness model, we can identify the joint stiffness coefficient of the robot. Furthermore, we establish the evaluation index for the stiffness characteristics of the robot, and optimize the configurations of the robot. A simulation study utilizing a LBR iiwa7 R800 robot has been conducted to verify that the position accuracy has been significantly improved by considering the identified joint deflections. The proposed method can extend and validate on the other industrial and collaborative serial robots.

title: Research on Control Optimization for Safe and Stable Operation of an Airport Chilled Water Three-Stage Pump System Based on Simulation
authors: Kaijia Zhao, Kun Zhang, Gang Wei, Weipeng Pan, Haipeng Hou, Limin Niu, Zhewen Xu, Yingying Hao, Cheng Qian
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Energy Engineering and Power Systems (EEPS)
abstract: The stable and efficient operation of chilled water systems is critical for ensuring functional performance and costeffectiveness in large public buildings. Airport terminals, characterized by their long-distance chilled water distribution requirements from energy plants, typically employ three-stage pump systems for optimal hydraulic adaptation. However, the complex pipeline network and hydraulic characteristics of such systems present significant challenges. Conventional empiricallydriven designs often neglect coupling effects between pump stages, frequently resulting in hydraulic imbalances, inadequate cooling supply to terminal units, and equipment overloading. This study investigates a three-stage chilled water pump system at a major international airport. Utilizing hydraulic system simulation technology, we developed a comprehensive pipeline network model and conducted multi-condition analysis to formulate solutions ensuring safe and stable system operation. Our methodology involved: 1) quantitative identification of hydraulic coupling mechanisms and risk assessment, 2) precise localization of zero-pressure-difference nodes through comparative condition analysis, and 3) targeted optimization of operational parameters to resolve system deficiencies. The optimization results demonstrate significant improvements: the secondary pump system achieved precisely <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$622.2 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{h}$</tex> flow rate (0% deviation from design specifications), while tertiary pump flow variations were maintained within <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 10 {\%}$</tex> tolerance. All operational pump working points were verified to lie precisely on manufacturer performance curves, completely resolving prior hydraulic coupling imbalances and equipment overload issues. The optimized system now delivers reliable operation while accurately matching terminal cooling load requirements.

title: Natural Language Rationales with Sub-QAE Prompting: World Knowledge Discovery through Self-Questioning Architecture
authors: Hongfei Wang, Xiao Wei, Jinshuai Hu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Visual Question Answering with Natural Language Explanations (VQA-NLE) requires models to provide logically grounded explanations while generating accurate answer. Existing methods struggle with complex questions that demand comprehensive logical reasoning and world knowledge integration. We propose that decomposing the target image and question into question-answer-explanation triples containing visual cues, world knowledge, and object relationships can enhance image understanding, question comprehension, and knowledge retrieval for final answer reasoning. We call the proposed method Sub-QAE Prompting that includes three key steps. We train a visual question generation (VQG) model using instruction-aligned question contexts which subsequently utilized to generate the sub-questions from image. Then generate image-based and text-based sub-questions via the VQG model and frozen large language model respectively. Last we construct question-answer-explanation triples by deriving corresponding answers and explanation for generated subquestions, and encode question-answer-explanation triples into visual-aware prompting module for MLLM to generate the final answer and explanation. Experimental results on the two challenge benchmark VQA-X and A-OKVQA demonstrate that our method achieves state-of-the-art performance compared to existing VQA-NLE approaches.

title: First-Order Quantified Separator in Alloy Analyzer
authors: One An
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: First-Order Logic (FOL) is a powerful language for specifying system invariants and properties, yet its formal complexity often hinders its adoption. To address this, we present Folloy, a tool that synthesizes FOL specifications from examples. Our core contribution translates specification learning into a constraint satisfaction problem by declaratively modeling FOL syntax and semantics in the Alloy Analyzer. This method is expressive, allowing synthesis of non-prenex formulas and user-defined syntactic constraints. By leveraging a Max-SAT solver, Folloy also guarantees that the learned formula is minimal in size. We evaluate our tool on benchmark problems and show that while this general approach is slower than a specialized algorithm, it solves a broader class of problems, establishing a trade-off between performance and expressive power.

title: An SC-Fano Based Enumerator of Low-Weight Codewords for Polar/PAC Codes
authors: Xingyu Zhou, Shaohua Wu, Junhua You, Yajing Deng, Qinyu Zhang
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Wireless Communications and Signal Processing (WCSP)
abstract: The maximum likelihood (ML) decoding performance of linear codes is strongly influenced by the weight distribution, especially the number of low-weight codewords. In this work, we propose a successive cancellation (SC) code weight analyzer for polar codes and polarization-adjusted convolutional (PAC) codes. By feeding raw BPSK codewords into the SC analyzer under a noiseless channel, the SC metrics are shown to effectively characterize the weight of codewords. This insight motivates a bit-flipping strategy for efficient enumeration of lowweight codewords. Furthermore, we present an SC-Fano based enumerator that accurately accounts the low-weight codewords of polar codes and PAC codes without restrictions on rateprofiling. The results demonstrate that the proposed enumerator significantly reduces computation time for short to moderate block lengths compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: V2G Identity Privacy Protection Mechanism Based on Revocable and Linkable Ring Signatures
authors: Zhen Yan, Junchu Lu, Jinhui Cao, Xiaoqiang Di, Shiying Zhou, Changsheng Gao
publish: 2025 9th CAA International Conference on Vehicular Control and Intelligence (CVCI)
abstract: With the large-scale integration of electric vehicles into the power grid, Vehicle-to-Grid (V2G) networks, while enabling smart energy management and bidirectional energy exchange, also face numerous challenges, particularly in terms of security and operational efficiency, which have become increasingly prominent. To address the risk of identity privacy leakage caused by frequent EV connections in V2G systems, this paper proposes a conditional privacy-preserving scheme based on revocable and linkable ring signatures. The scheme utilizes linkable ring signatures to achieve anonymity for vehicle owners while incorporating the SM2 public-key encryption algorithm to construct a revocable tag mechanism. It ensures anonymity while granting regulatory authorities the ability to reveal identities under specific conditions, thereby achieving controllable anonymity. Furthermore, to reduce the computational overhead of signatures in large-scale applications, the scheme introduces a Non-Interactive Summation Argument (NISA) algorithm, enabling signature length to grow logarithmically with the ring size. Theoretical analysis and experimental results demonstrate that the scheme achieves a favorable balance between identity privacy protection, security, and efficiency, making it suitable for privacy-sensitive scenarios such as V2G payments.

title: Generalized Inverse Design of a Compact Thermo-Optic Switch on SOI Platform
authors: Jiangbo Lyu, Guangbiao Wang, Yanhua Shen, Yazhi Pi, Zhenmin Chen, Ke Xu, Lei Wang
abstract: We propose and demonstrate a compact thermo-optic switch designed using a generalized inverse design method that decouples the thermal and electromagnetic simulations by first computing the temperature distribution and then incorporating it into the optical optimization process. The inverse-designed device is implemented on a silicon-on-insulator (SOI) platform, where heating induces refractive index changes to achieve optical switching between two output ports. The final structure, with a footprint of only 15 μm×8 μm, achieves an insertion loss of -1.42 dB (unheated) and -1.25 dB (heated, P<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">heating</inf> = 17.56 mW, t<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">response time</inf>=105μs), crosstalk levels of −28.11 dB and −31.61 dB, and 3 dB bandwidths of approximately 10 nm for the two thermal states. These results demonstrate the effectiveness of inverse design in realizing high-performance, thermally reconfigurable photonic switches, and highlight its potential for future dense and programmable photonic circuits.

title: Impact of Antenna Siting Openness on VHF Channel Characteristics
authors: Kai Yi, Xiaoying Zhang, Zhihao Mu, Xiaoran Liu, Haitao Zhao, Jun Xiong
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Wireless Communications and Signal Processing (WCSP)
abstract: VHF frequency band play a critical role in the emergency communications. In vehicular emergency communication scenarios, propagation environment, especially the antenna siting openness directly affect the channel characteristics. Channel measurements are conducted at 45 MHz and 240 MHz bands in urban scenarios to investigates the impact of site openness on the channel properties. Key results demonstrate that high-openness environments significantly increase wireless channel multipath complexity, leading to richer multipath components, larger root-mean-square delay spread and path loss, as well as reduced Ricean K-factor under LOS conditions. In most high-openness scenarios, smaller Temporal PDP Correlation Coefficient (TPCC) and more pronounced frequency-selective characteristics are observed. Furthermore, within the VHF band, both path loss and Ricean K-factor increase with rising center frequency, while the root-mean-square delay spread decreases with increasing frequency. These findings provide valuable guidance for the design of VANET communication systems in emergency scenarios.

title: Ultra-High Capacity Optical Transmission over Anti-Resonate Hollow-Core-Fiber
authors: Xumeng Liu, Zhixue He, Chao Li
abstract: Anti-resonant hollow core fiber (AR-HCF) is a promising alternative for next-generation optical interconnects, as it outperforms standard single-mode fiber (SSMF) via its intrinsic superior optical properties in terms of its theoretically low attenuation, low chromatic dispersion, low nonlinearity and low Rayleigh backscattering. These inherent merits make AR-HCFs highly advantageous for data center optical interconnects, which are facing unprecedented demands for data traffic. This paper presents a comprehensive review of high-capacity optical interconnects for data centers enabled by AR-HCFs, aiming to address the evolving performance requirements of both IM/DD optical interconnects and coherent optical transmissions. It shows that AR-HCF has the enormous potential for enabling ultra-high-capacity optical transmission.

title: Mapping Frequency-Dependent Functional Alterations in Spinocerebellar Ataxia Type 3 and Their Neurochemical Correlates
authors: Liu Xinyuan, Guo Jing, Liu Chen, Chen Huafu
publish: 2025 22nd International Computer Conference on Wavelet Active Media Technology and Information Processing (ICCWAMTIP)
abstract: Multi-band frequency analysis offers a framework to decompose brain signals into distinct frequency bands, which help us understand how oscillatory dynamics are differentially modulated by specific physiological mechanisms. In this study, multi-band frequency analysis was leveraged to examine the abnormal frequency-dependent amplitude of low-frequency fluctuation (ALFF) in 89 patients with spinocerebellar ataxia type 3 (SCA3) compared to 151 healthy controls, and further investigated their spatial association with 18 neurotransmitter receptor maps. Results showed that patients with SCA3 exhibited a frequency-dependent spatial reorganization: ALFF reductions shifted from occipitoparietal and posterior cerebellar regions in low frequencies to ventral frontoparietal and anterior cerebellar areas in high frequencies. Crucially, alterations in specific bands were significantly predicted by receptor densities, with 5-HTIB, H3, and mGluRs making the largest contributions.

title: Static StabilityAnalysis of a Novel Stair-Climbing Wheelchair
authors: Mohammed Said U. Y., Sachin S., Hari Krishnan R
publish: 2025 International Conference on Robotics and Mechatronics (ICRM)
abstract: Mobility is the basic health factor that contributes towards social integration and well being of an individual. Persons with locomotor disabilities depend on wheelchairs for daily mobility. While manual or powered wheelchairs serves the basic mobility needs, negotiating stairs is still a big challenge. Stair-climbing wheelchairs are uncommon in India primarily due to their high cost and the fact they are typically imported. Indigenous development can make them more affordable. As part of this initiative, a stair climbing wheelchair is being developed. This paper emphasizes on analysis of static stability of this wheelchair. Analysis of static stability aids in ensuring that the wheelchair remains stable and does not tip over while negotiating the steps.

title: Assessing the Short-Term Impact of Air Pollution and Socioeconomic Factors on the Overall Mortality of Taranto: an eXplainable Machine Learning Approach
authors: Domenico Lofù, Gianluca Colonna, Paolo Sorino, Fabio Castellana, Angela Lombardi, Azzurra Ragone, Rodolfo Sardone
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Increasing emissions due to urbanization pose a significant threat to human health. Air pollutants such as NO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>, PM<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2.5</inf>, and PM<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">10</inf> have a well-documented impact on quality of life and mortality risk. Numerous studies are currently investigating the correlation between air pollution and adverse health effects, highlighting the risks associated with exposure to such emissions. In this context, models capable of predicting mortality by leveraging information on pollution and socioeconomic factors are essential for prevention. This work contributes to this field by using Machine Learning (ML) to predict mortality in the Municipality of Taranto (Italy). We propose an eXtreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost) regression model that uses air pollution levels and socioeconomic data to assess mortality risk over a grid-based map of the examined city. Our study aligns with state-of-the-art findings, further expanding the understanding of the correlation between emissions, economic conditions, and mortality. The proposed model achieves a Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) of 1.61 on the test set, demonstrating the effectiveness of this approach. Additionally, eXplainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI) analysis is conducted using Shapley values to gain insights into the model’s decision-making process and better understand the importance of each feature in predicting mortality risk.

title: Modeling and Evaluation of Bike-Sharing Systems for Planning Sustainable Urban Mobility
authors: Renata Dantas, Akin Dagba, Ioná Rameh, Jamilson Dantas, Paulo Maciel
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: As urban centers increasingly grapple with the challenges of population growth, traffic congestion, and environmental degradation, the need for sustainable mobility solutions has become imperative. This study presents a performance evaluation of a public bicycle-sharing system through the application of Stochastic Petri Nets (SPNs), which are employed to model and simulate user behavior under dynamic conditions. Drawing on recent advances in urban mobility and shared transportation research, the proposed stochastic framework effectively captures key operational metrics, such as bicycles in transit, station availability, waiting probability, system utilization, and the occupancy of docking stations. A case study analyzes three high-demand stations across varying demand scenarios (baseline, 25%, and +25%). Findings reveal that, while the system performs adequately under current demand levels, it becomes vulnerable to saturation with increased usage and demonstrates operational inefficiencies when demand decreases. The model offers valuable insights to inform operational strategies, guide infrastructure development, and support public policy aimed at fostering integrated and sustainable urban mobility.

title: Condition-based Maintenance Policy Optimization Incorporating Accelerated Degradation Modeling With External Shocks
authors: Jin Li, Renqing Li, Yan Song, Zhangyong Xie
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on System Reliability and Safety Engineering (SRSE)
abstract: Condition-based maintenance (CBM) effectively ensures product availability while minimizing costs. Degradation modeling plays a crucial role in optimizing CBM policies. For certain mechanical systems, degradation accelerates due to external shocks. This paper investigates the optimization of CBM policies for such accelerated degrading products subject to external shocks. A nonhomogeneous Poisson process models the occurrence of external shocks. Furthermore, an accelerated degradation model is developed based on the Inverse Gaussian process. The optimal CBM policy is then derived by minimizing the expected cost rate. Finally, a numerical example demonstrates the rationality and practical applicability of the proposed methods.

title: Which AI and How Trusted by Human Energy Stakeholders? Comparing Generative AI ChatGPT With Domain Specific AI-ENERGIA-SYS
authors: George A. Tsihrintzis, Elissaios Sarmas, Vangelis Marinakis, Dimitrios Panagoulias, Evangelia-Aikaterini Tsichrintzi, Maria Virvou
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) has been growing significantly recently, based on machine learning, deep learning and the latest Generative AI and Large Language Models (LLMs), like ChatGPT. All AI tools are promising to improve decision-making in many domains, including complex ones, such as energy. As such, there have been energy-specific AI systems that incorporate domain expertise, in addition to general-purpose LLMs that integrate knowledge on a plethora of domains, including energy, based on their training from the internet. However, AI systems can produce errors due to their probabilistic nature, and many users, like energy stakeholders, lack the training to use them effectively. Which AI do we mean and how well is it trusted. It is worth exploring differences in AI systems.By employing the VIRTSI model, this paper compares trust states of energy stakeholders on domain specific AI systems versus general-purpose generative AI. For the purposes of the comparison, we use a domain specific AI-based Energy system entitled AI-ENERGIA-SYS that has been previously developed versus ChatGPT 4.0 by OpenAI. VIRTSI is a rigorous computational model for the dynamics of human trust states, spanning from overtrust to distrust, through user modelling and quantifies the efficiency of the interaction in VIRTSI-adapted confusion matrices. The findings reveal that ChatGPT is persuasive and user-friendly to stakeholders, but its lack of domain awareness and explainability leads to overtrust, risking decision quality. In contrast, AI-ENERGIA-SYS, though more complex, supports better trust calibration, meaning that, when trusted, it is usually correct, but it is not trusted so frequently as ChatGPT. The results suggest that future combinations of energy-specific AI systems with general-purpose generative AI could provide improved trust dynamics and more effective decision support.

title: Performance Evaluation of OLSR vs. SARNet in Search-and-Rescue FANETs
authors: Houssem E. Turki, Hideaki Takanobu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Multi-Robot and Multi-Agent Systems (MRS)
abstract: Search-and-Rescue Network (SARNet) is a lightweight hybrid routing protocol for unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) swarms deployed in search-and-rescue missions. SARNet enhances the Optimized Link State Routing protocol (OLSR) with event-driven topology updates and signal-to-interference-plus-noise-ratio (SINR)-based link-quality triggers. This paper evaluates a partial implementation of SARNet, which currently includes these two mechanisms, while flow-aware QoS modules remain future work. Using the KogakuinMobility model to generate realistic, mission-oriented UAV trajectories, we compare SARNet and OLSR in five urban maps and an open-field setting with OMNeT++/INET simulations. In dense city environments, both protocols exhibit low packet delivery ratios (PDR <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$<7 {\%}$</tex>), with OLSR maintaining slightly higher PDR and consistently lower overhead due to its timer-driven control. In open terrain, both sustain high PDR (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\approx \mathbf{8 5}-\mathbf{9 5 \%}$</tex>) under light and moderate loads but degrade sharply at 3.93 Mb/s due to MAC/PHY saturation rather than routing. SARNet's reactive SINR triggers increase control traffic as network density grows, reflecting sensitivity to parameter tuning. These findings indicate that while SARNet's event-driven design improves adaptivity, further refinements, such as adaptive hysteresis or threshold adjustment, are required for stable and scalable communication in diverse search and rescue flying ad hoc network (SAR-FANET) deployments.

title: A Bio-Inspired PSO-Based Energy Balancing and Routing Design for Wireless Sensor Networks
authors: K R Lathakumari, K L Hemalatha, Sowmini Bandaru, D. Kesavan, V. Preetha
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Mobile Networks and Wireless Communications (ICMNWC)
abstract: In the modern era, bio inspired optimization mechanisms have evolved rapidly with the increasing deployment of large-scale Internet of Things (IoT) architectures. Efficient energy management is a crucial task, particularly in multi sink Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs) where challenges such as energy imbalance, hotspot formation, reduced network lifetime and inefficient routing patterns continue to persist. However, the existing Quantum inspired Genetic algorithm based Multiple Sinks deployment approach (Q-GEMS) struggled with slower convergence, limited energy balancing capability and failed to prevent hotspot formation, which limited uniform energy depletion across the network and balance network operation. Therefore, this research proposed a Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) based Energy Balancing and Routing mechanism to achieve uniform energy consumption across the network. This research begins with the multi sink WSN model with defined node deployment, and radio energy configuration. Next, a particle encoded search mechanism guided by Energy Balance Index (EBI) is employed to optimize sink placement and cluster organization by reducing residual energy variance. After this, an adaptive Cluster Head (CH) rotation is applied to continuously monitor real time EBI variations and dynamically reassigns leadership to maintain uniform load distribution. Finally, the routing phase integrates the optimized topology and balanced CH structure to ensure energy aware path selection and avoidance of overloaded nodes. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed PSO based energy balancing and routing mechanism achieved greater network lifetime till 1070 rounds with 0.97 energy balance factor at 10 sinks.

title: NAEF: A Novel Framework in Evaluating Enterprise Artificial Intelligence from Insights and Decisions
authors: Heru Purnomo Ipung
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Information Technology, Information Systems and Electrical Engineering (ICITISEE)
abstract: This paper proposes a novel framework for evaluating enterprise AI, continuing from the previous NAEF Architecting Enterprise AI Framework that emphasizing the integration of three frameworks (TOGAF, BADIR, and INSIGHT) to create a robust and comprehensive methodology, in which at the end of the previous paper was acknowledging the important of Trusted AI. Building upon this architectural foundation, this work further addresses a critical impediment to realizing the strategic value of enterprise AI: the chasm between technical validation and executive trust. While technical teams concentrate on component-level correctness-measuring factual accuracy and task completion-business leaders require holistic assurance across a sociotechnical spectrum that includes governance, ethics, and transparency. This disconnect creates a “trust blind spot,” leading to technically sound but organizationally inert AI investments. To bridge this gap, a unified, multi-layered Enterprise AI Evaluation Framework is proposed to move beyond component-level metrics. This framework introduces a holistic assessment of AI systems by integrating technical validation with the principles of organizational trust-building. It evaluates AI on three progressive levels: Technical Correctness (Is the system functionally correct?), Systemic Credibility (Can the process be trusted?), and Institutional Integrity (Does the decision align with organizational values and risk tolerance?). The framework provides a strategic roadmap for engineering credible and trustworthy AI, transforming trust from a soft goal into a measurable, manageable strategic asset. Sample previous works were cited to highlight the issues, challenges and opportunities from the framework point of view.

title: Few-Shot Substation Anomaly Object Detection via Variational Aggregation and Multi-Head RPN
authors: Zhongqin Bi, Yikun Guo, Weina Zhang, Dan Dai
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Due to the rare occurrence of abnormal targets in substations, detecting these anomalies can be framed as a few-shot learning problem, for which recent few-shot object detection (FSOD) methods offer promising solutions. However, the complexity of substation scenarios makes current FSOD approaches struggle to control class centers, resulting in trained models typically exhibiting bias towards base classes and tending to confuse novel classes with base classes. To address these issues, we propose a feature aggregation method based on Variational Autoencoder (VAE) that transforms instance-level features into class distributions, thereby enhancing the robustness of feature aggregation. Additionally, to improve the quality of region proposal generation in sample-limited and complex environments, we integrate a multi-head attention mechanism into the Region Proposal Network (RPN), enabling it to produce more relevant region proposals. Extensive experiments on the Substation Abnormal Target Dataset (SATD2024) demonstrate that our approach consistently outperforms existing methods across various settings. Furthermore, we validate the effectiveness and generalization of our method on the public Pascal VOC dataset.

title: Autoregressive Neural Network Benchmark Analysis of the Gray-Scott Equation
authors: Wenfeng Lai, Fangying Song
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Computational Intelligence and Applications (ICCIA)
abstract: This paper utilizes numerical solutions generated by the Gray-Scott equations. The numerical algorithm is based on the Explicit Finite Difference Method for solving partial differential equations, with time advancement performed using the simple Forward Euler Method. The concentrations of chemical substances are updated using a fixed time step. Similar to traditional autoregressive models applied to time series data, we apply neural network models to time slices formatted as n × n data.The models we employ include FNO, U-Net, ResNet, FFN, and DeepONet. While FNO is currently widely used by many researchers, there are also studies applying U-Net, ResNet, FFN, and DeepONet to this type of data. However, most of these applications are based on single time-window approaches. This paper introduces improvements by extending the use of U-Net, ResNet, FFN, and FNO to multi-time-window scenarios and demonstrates their performance. Experiments show that increasing the number of time windows helps neural network models to better extrapolate over longer time horizons.We present both single time-window prediction results and continuous multi-step predictions. In most cases, multi-step predictions suffer from accumulated errors, leading to increasing inaccuracies over time. Notably, we find that FNO generally exhibits better predictive potential compared to the other models.

title: A 1024-Channel VCO-Based CTDSM Neural Readout IC with Slot-Level Channel Replacement
authors: Hyeok-Ki Hong, Joonseong Kang, Byungsu Jung, Nahmil Koo, Seong-Joong Kim, Hankyu Lee, Dong-Jin Chang, Mikyung Kim, Junyeub Suh, Jonghan Kim, Takhyung Lee, Anes Ju, Jaechun Lee, Chang-Woo Shin, Kitae Park, Chisung Bae
abstract: With the growing demand for advanced biomedical research tools, significant progress have been made in developing integrated circuits (ICs) for both implantation and support of biological growth on electrode surfaces. [1–5] These applications demand low noise levels for accurate bio-signal measurement, scalability to support thousands of channels, and reliability to prevent chip replacement during biomedical experiments, avoiding biological damage. Consequently, biomedical applications in close proximity to living tissues are constrained by stringent requirements, including compact size, minimal heat dissipation, and high yield for each analog frontend (AFE) channel, along with long-term reliability. A promising candidate for such biomedical applications is the VCO-based continuous-time delta-sigma modulator (CTDSM), which eliminates bulky, power-hungry components like anti-aliasing filters and instrumentation amplifiers [6–10]. However, achieving multi-channel scalability to thousands of channels and ensuring long-term reliability in VCO-based architectures remain significant challenges due to the sensitivity of VCOs to process variations. As the number of channels increases, higher single-channel yields are required to ensure full chip functionality. For a 1024-channel chip, even a single-channel yield of 99.9% results in only 35.9% of fully functional chips. Allowing a limited number of faulty channels can improve the yield. To achieve a 90% yield for 1024-channel chips, the required singlechannel yields are $99.99 \%, 99.95 \%, 99.31 \%$ for 0, 1, and 10 allowable faulty channels, respectively. However, these yield requirements increase significantly as the number of channels and desired chip productivity grow. In this paper, we present a 1024channel VCO-based CTDSM architecture with slot-level channel replacement, designed to improve productivity for multi-channel chips and compensate for malfunctioning channels during long-term usage.

title: Revolutionizing Shopping with RFID-Enabled Automated Billing and Bulk Scanning
authors: Falguni Rinke, Shlok Vij, Sunidhi Haware, Giridhar Urkude
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Computing Technologies (ICACT)
abstract: Enhancing the retail shopping experience through technology opens the door to faster, smarter, and more inclusive customer journeys. This study introduces an RFID-enabled smart shopping cart designed to improve convenience, accessibility, and efficiency. Equipped with passive RFID readers and a built-in display, the cart automatically identifies items and presents key details such as product name, price, expiry date, and discounts without requiring line-of-sight scanning. The system is tailored for ease of use, particularly benefiting elderly and visually impaired users while also significantly reducing physical effort. Unlike traditional barcode systems, RFID allows for high-speed, contactless scanning of multiple items simultaneously. Checkout is streamlined through automated cart-level billing, minimizing wait times and store operating costs. With its scalable, intelligent design, this solution showcases the transformative potential of RFID technology in shaping the future of retail automation.

title: HE4-Mediated Identification of Epithelial Ovarian Cancer Subtypes: Vertical TFET Biosensor Modelling
authors: Yash Uchhasare, Varun Mishra
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Intelligent Signal Processing and Effective Communication Technologies (INSPECT)
abstract: This paper presents a simulation-based study of an In0. $53 \mathrm{Ga} 0.47 \mathrm{As} / \mathrm{Si}$ vertical field-effect transistor (VFET) biosensor for label-free identification of epithelial ovarian cancer subtypes, including Mucinous, Endometrioid, Undifferentiated, and Serous. The structure integrates an indium gallium arsenide source with a silicon drain and channel, optimized for high sensitivity to the Human Epididymis Protein 4 (HE4) biomarker. The HE4 interaction with the sensor surface produces distinct electrical responses, enabling discrimination among subtypes based on surface potential, energy band diagrams, electric field distribution, transfer characteristics, subthreshold swing, and ION/IOFF ratio. The results demonstrate a clear correlation between sensor response and malignancy level, providing a theoretical foundation for VFET biosensors as a fast, accurate, and non-invasive diagnostic platform for ovarian cancer subtype identification.

title: Unsupervised Chinese Word Segmentation via Bidirectional Language Modeling and Segment-Level Feature Enhancement
authors: Xinyi Sun, Lijie Yin, Junkai Wang, Zijia Li
publish: 2025 2nd International Symposium on AI and Cybersecurity (ISAICS)
abstract: For addressing low-frequency word recognition and vague boundary words in Chinese word segmentation unsupervised, the paper proposes a solution that employs bidirectional probabilistic consistency and segment-level semantics. The solution employs a bidirectional long shortterm memory (Bi-LSTM) network for learning the forward and backward contextually dependent relations to have a highly balanced perception of semantic information. Attention-pooling-based segment-level encoder is capable of encoding the global meaning of candidate word segments, and an adaptive gating process combines character-level and segment-level information. It is a good approach to construct a probabilistic model to trade off among local character relationships and global segment semantics. In addition, we introduce an efficient path search algorithm using Viterbi decoding with feature-fusion scoring and a maximum wordlength constraint together with parallelization, which collectively enhance inference speed.
