title: Variable frequency and pulse width 1560 nm pulsed incoherent source for core pumping of Gain-Switched Thulium-doped fiber laser
authors: Ray Man, L F K Lui, K S Tsang, Dicky Chung, Victor Ho, Sonia Wong
abstract: We presented a 1560 nm incoherent pulsed ASE source for core pumping a gain-switched Thulium-doped fiber laser operating in the nanosecond regime. The achieved pulse energy exceeded 80 µJ, with a peak power greater than 1300 W and a pulse width of 60 ns. This source was employed to drive the Thulium-doped fiber, resulting in a gain-switched laser that produced 20 µJ pulses with a duration of 30 ns at a repetition rate of 10 kHz. The spectral suppression ratio between 1720 nm and 1560 nm exceeded 30 dB.

title: Towards Real-Time Safe UAV Trajectory Planning Using Clustering of Nearby UAVs in Dense Urban Environments
authors: Stylianos Exadaktylos, Christian Vitale, Panayiotis Kolios, Georgios Ellinas
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Rapid urbanization trends have resulted in a significant increase in global urban population over the past few decades. This growth is projected to continue, further exacerbating traffic congestion in road networks. Urban air mobility presents a promising solution to alleviate this congestion, offering substantial environmental, economic, and societal benefits. However, to fully realize these benefits, autonomous flight and automation are crucial for safely managing the high density of aircraft expected in urban airspaces.To address this challenge, this work proposes an innovative model predictive control (MPC) framework for generating ondemand, safe 3D trajectories for fleets of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) operating in dense urban environments. Specifically, it introduces a near real-time MPC method designed to enhance the airspace’s capacity to accommodate an increasing number of flights within a confined area, while consistently adhering to stringent safety standards. An extensive simulation study is conducted to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed framework in planning safe, on-demand trajectories in complex urban settings.

title: Study on the Cathode Emission Mechanism of CuCr25 Prepared by Electromagnetic Suppression
authors: Jinglei Zhu, Junxiang Liu, Lu Zhu, Yong Wang, Haibo Su, Jie Zhang, Jun Xiao
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Energy Engineering and Power Systems (EEPS)
abstract: Electromagnetic suppression is an advanced forming technology that utilizes the instantaneous Lorentz force generated by intense pulsed magnetic fields to achieve rapid densification of powder materials. With advantages such as high loading rate, uniform densification, and low processing damage, it has been widely applied in the field of material preparation. Electromagnetic suppression technology is a technique that uses electromagnetic fields to regulate the preparation, processing, or treatment of materials. The CuCr25 bulk with a relative density of more than 97% was prepared by electromagnetic suppression after the Cu powder and Cr powder were mixed uniformly, without involving the precipitation process of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{C r}$</tex> phase like other processes. The cathode spot characteristics of CuCr alloys prepared by other processes have been well studied. However, the cathode spot characteristics of CuCr alloys prepared by electromagnetic suppression have not been investigated. In this paper, the cathode spot characteristics of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CuCr25}$</tex> prepared by electromagnetic suppression under different voltages were studied. The morphology after ablation was analyzed. The experimental results showed that cathode spots tended to split into a greater number of smaller spots as the current increased. The initial breakdown phase was still mainly concentrated on the Cr phase and the edge of Cr phase.

title: A Multi-UAV-Enabled CCICI Joint Optimization Framework for Digital Twin Channel Modeling
authors: Taiming Zhang, Haitao Zhao, Guijin Tang, Miao Liu, Jie Yang, Guangliang Pan, Hongbo Zhu
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Wireless Communications and Signal Processing (WCSP)
abstract: To meet the requirements of real-time link sensing and efficient response in channel modeling for sixth-generation (6 G) digital twin (DT) networks, network architectures are evolving toward the convergence of heterogeneous capabilities. In response to this trend, this paper proposes a multi-unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV)-enabled Communication-Computing-IntelligenceControlling Integrated (CCICI) joint optimization framework to efficiently support the collection and uploading of linkstate information. The proposed framework adopts a hierarchical multi-UAV system, consisting of mobile edge servers with trajectory control and task scheduling capabilities, as well as statically deployed working UAVs, collaboratively performing urban environment data collection, processing, and uploading of link-state information. Under constraints such as UAV maximum flight speed and limited communication resources, the framework jointly optimizes UAV flight trajectories and service scheduling strategies, including movement direction selection and service assignment. A heterogeneous Graph Neural Network (GNN) is utilized to model the complex task dependencies and dynamic communication topology among UAVs. Moreover, a QMIXbased multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) method under the centralized training and decentralized execution (CTDE) paradigm is employed to overcome the limitations of traditional methods in handling dynamic scenarios and partial observability. To guarantee data timeliness and prompt system responsiveness required by DT channel modeling, Age of Information (AoI) and service delay are adopted as the core optimization metrics. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed framework effectively reduces these two metrics, confirming its effectiveness and stability in dynamic urban environments.

title: A 40-nm Sub-mJ/transfer HDC-SNN Hybrid Processor Enabling On-Chip Few-Shot Transfer Learning for IoT Applications
authors: Anqin Xiao, Jinqiao Yang, Wanlin Yang, Xin Zhang, Yuhan He, Ziyi Yang, Li-Rong Zheng, Zhuo Zou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Artificial Intelligence
abstract: This work presents a brain-inspired processor that combines Hyperdimensional Computing (HDC) and Spiking Neural Network (SNN), or HDC-SNN hybrid, to enable on-chip few-shot transfer learning (FSTL) for IoT applications. Such an HDC-SNN hybrid architecture utilizes SNN for efficient feature extraction to suppress the size of the vector dimension, thus mitigating intensive operations and the memory footprint for HDC. It also leverages the few-shot and single-pass learning capability of HDC, eliminating the need for abundant labeled samples and training epochs. This processor utilizes a task-agnostic spiking HDC encoder to generate spatio-temporal feature vectors, followed by an on-chip learning HDC classifier. Furthermore, the implementation of on-chip learning uses the schemes of weight access from destination-neuron with memory bank (WAD-MB) and batch-by-batch gradient computation (BGC), achieving a significant improvement on training latency and cache size. This design is fabricated in a 40-nm CMOS technology with a peak efficiency of sub-mJ/transfer (mJ/class and mJ/patient by on chip FSTL) at 0.72V and 65MHz, occupying a core area of 1.56 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. For typical neuromorphic datasets, this processor achieves a 1.6-35× improvement in training energy per class and a 3.5- 52× reduction in training latency per sample, compared to state-of-the-art processors. For patient-specific and class-incremental scenarios, it achieves an accuracy of over 96% in both ECG arrhythmia detection and bearing anomaly detection. Specifically, it requires only 2-minute training samples for a new patient with 0.1 mJ energy, achieving a 4.5× improvement in energy efficiency; it employs 3-shot learning for a new class with only 0.3 mJ energy, reducing training epochs by over 100×.

title: Multiscale Grid Intelligence to Fight Artificial Intelligence Data Center Grid Defection: Unlocking a Faster, Cheaper, and Cleaner On-Grid AI Rollout
authors: Thomas Morstyn, Yihong Zhou, Ian Whitfield
abstract: Rapid advances in artificial intelligence (AI) computing capabilities have led to a race to build larger-scale data centers with escalating power demands. AI companies are now planning data center sites with up to 5 GW capacity, and the International Energy Agency (IEA) projects that data center demand could grow to 1,700 TWh by 2035 (6% of current total global electricity demand). Power grid connections are becoming a major bottleneck, and it can now take more than five years to receive a grid connection for a new data center in the United States and Europe. The challenge of getting grid connections has driven a new trend toward grid defection, where data centers are being fully or partially supplied by local microgrids with dedicated generation assets. In some regions this is a voluntary choice, but in most cases, it is the only option available for building a new data center. For most data centers, it is likely that a substantial grid connection would be beneficial from both an economic and a sustainability perspective due to how main power grids unlock generation economies of scale and enable lower-cost renewable integration. However, inefficient AI data center grid defection is being driven by a reliance on preexisting technical approaches and institutional barriers to change. In this article, we propose “multiscale grid intelligence” as a new framework to fight AI data center grid defection and support closer coordination between data centers and power grids. The proposed framework embeds power-grid-focused analytics into how data centers are planned and operated, accounting for cooptimization opportunities across spatial scales (from data center rack-level distribution to national transmission) and time scales (from second-to-second frequency balancing to years-ahead network planning). Across these scales, we identify a range of opportunities for intelligent planning and operation that could offer significant value if implemented together. The article discusses the value multiscale grid intelligence can offer power system and AI stakeholders and proposes key areas for future research.

title: Low-Complexity Nonlinear Equalizer with a Hybrid Decision Scheme Based on Threshold Pruning for IM/DD Systems
authors: WenXiang Cui, Quanzhen Luo, Lipeng Feng, Yi Cai, Gangxiang Shen, Gordon Ning Liu
abstract: We propose a novel hybrid decision scheme based on threshold pruning, which removes redundant branches in multi-symbol decision. The proposed scheme significantly reduces complexity with negligible performance degradation in high-speed IM/DD PAM-4 systems.

title: AGS-MADDPG: Multi-Agent Path Finding with Partially Observations Based on Attention Mechanism and Reinforcement Learning
authors: Jianguo Gong, Yisheng An, Peng Li, Tao Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: We proposes Attention Gumbel-Softmax Multi-Agent Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (AGS-MADDPG), a multi-agent reinforcement learning algorithm for collaborative pathfinding under partial observability. Traditional methods face challenges including non-differentiable policy gradients and inefficient exploration in discrete action spaces. We address these by integrating the MADDPG framework with Gumbel-Softmax for differentiable policy optimization and adaptive exploration via temperature annealing. A multi-head attention mechanism in the critic network explicitly models inter-agent dependencies by dynamically weighting teammates’ action features, enhancing Q-value estimation precision and training stability. Evaluations in Pogema environments with random obstacles and complex layouts demonstrate improved convergence speed, pathfinding success rates, and average path length compared to baseline methods. The results validate the effectiveness of combining differentiable discrete policies with explicit attention-based coordination for multi-agent collaboration in partially observable settings.

title: A 64⨯64 SPAD-based Full-resolution Multimodal Imager with High Background Light Immunity and Reconfigurable Extrapolation Photon Counting
authors: Jin Hu, Qianjin Xu, Rui Ma, Xiayu Wang, Dong Li, Yang Li u, Zhangming Zhu
abstract: High-precision and low-power 2D/3D imaging systems have been widely deployed in robotics, autonomous vehicles [1, 2], augmented reality, and biometric identification. Single-photon avalanche diodes (SPADs)-based imager have emerged as a key technology for 2D/3D imaging due to their single-photon-level sensitivity and CMOS compatibility. However, strong ambient illumination pose a challenge to accurate long-range detection due to the pile-up effect. To address this issue, correlation-based photon event detection circuits without resolution loss [3] and multi-event time-to-digital converters (TDCs) [4] are proposed in prior works, albeit at the cost of increased resource overhead. In addition, it is challenging to achieve high dynamic range (HDR), low power consumption and high precision simultaneously. In 2D imaging, counters could be used for photon counting due to the inherent digital nature of SPADs [5]. However, the counting depth is always limited due to restricted pixel area. The counting DR could be enhanced by performing HDR extrapolation counting [6] or by chaining counters [7] in adjacent pixels at the expense of spatial resolution loss. To address these issues, this work presents: (1) a power-efficient and high precision dual-clock quantization architecture for 3D operation with high BG immunity. (2) a 2D HDR imaging solution that reuses and reconfigures 3D imaging hardware resources without spatial resolution loss.

title: Power System Fault Diagnosis Model Based on Big Data
authors: Weimiao Jia, Kuo Wang, Zhiqi Ge, Guangyu Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th International Conference on Power, Intelligent Computing and Systems (ICPICS)
abstract: This study attempts to use big data technology as a tool to build an elite force for power system fault diagnosis and actively improve the stability and reliability standards of the power system. By cleverly adopting the distributed computing expertise of Apache Spark, this framework cleverly absorbs the essence of the support vector machine (SVM) algorithm and successfully pushes the boundaries of fault classification and diagnosis to the forefront. The data are collected from various sensors and monitoring systems of the power system and pre-processed after standardization and feature extraction. Subsequently, the SVM model was implemented for real-world training and testing analysis, and its hyperparameters were carefully tuned through crossvalidation. Experimental data reveal this phenomenon. The proposed model shows high accuracy and real-time performance in dealing with various power system faults. Especially when facing complex fault diagnosis challenges, the support vector machine (SVM) model shows significant advantages compared with the old technical framework. The power system fault diagnosis guardian wizard empowered by big data technology has efficient and accurate fault detection capabilities, which greatly expands the actual application space of the application.

title: The Characteristics of Leakage Current with Megohmmeter Test on Polymer Insulators Conditioned with Salt-Fog Test
authors: Arief Budi Ksatria, I Made Yulistya Negara, Dimas Anton Asfani, I Gusti Ngurah Satriyadi Hernanda, Daniar Fahmi, Bagus Septianto
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on High Voltage Engineering and Power Systems (ICHVEPS)
abstract: This study conducted a megohmmeter test to assess insulators. The megohmmeter test was selected because it is a commonly used tool. Generally, the insulation resistance value is compared to the standard to evaluate the condition of the equipment. The use of a more cost-effective and portable megohmmeter offers significant convenience to users. The results of this study will serve as supplementary alternative references and enhance the existing literature on the measurement of leakage current in polymer insulators due to salt contaminants. The leakage current data were processed using the normal distribution method. Therefore, the threshold value can be used to distinguish the condition of the insulator. Furthermore, the data distribution of the characteristics of the leakage current-insulation resistance was processed using the CoG method and radar chart area. Subsequently, the three methods (normal distribution, CoG method, and radar chart area method) were compared to determine which method could significantly differentiate the type of insulator. Based on the normal distribution calculation, the mean value and standard deviation of the leakage current-15s (New Insulator) are 17.79 $\mu \mathbf{A}$ and 4.32, respectively. Meanwhile, the mean value and standard deviation of the leakage current - 15s (Insulator with Salt-Fog Test) are $60.22 \mu \mathbf{A}$ and 15.12, respectively. The comparison of the standard deviation in the distribution of leakage current data (15s) between the conditioned and new insulators was 350%. Based on the comparison of values between the two isolators, the largest ratio was obtained from the Normal Distribution $(301-350 \%)$, Radar Chart Area $\boldsymbol{(} \mathbf{1 6 2 \%} \boldsymbol{)}$, and Center of Gravity ($\mathbf{1 5 3 \%} \boldsymbol{)}$ methods.

title: Blockchain Empowering the Secure Circulation and Governance System Construction of Industrial Data Elements: Challenges, Technical Paths and Policy Support
authors: Chao Yang, Yongfang Mao, Linji Ye, Xu Liu, Mingshan Qin, Lulu Pan, Jiao Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Sensing, Diagnostics, Prognostics, and Control
abstract: Industrial digitalization advances rapidly, positioning industrial data as a core driver of intelligent development and digital economy growth. However, applications face challenges in ownership demarcation, cross-entity circulation, security and privacy protection, and value realization, hindering data elementization and market allocation. Blockchain technology, featuring distributed consensus, immutable data, and smart contracts, enables trustworthy, transparent, and efficient data circulation and governance. This paper addresses governance challenges by highlighting blockchain's role in ownership confirmation, collaborative sharing, security compliance, and trust-building. It proposes a blockchain-based federated privacy computing governance architecture and constructs solutions across technical pathways, policy support, and industrial ecosystem development.

title: LMT-SDNN: A Lightweight Malicious Traffic Detection Method for the Internet of Things Based on Multi Teacher Distillation
authors: Dawei Xu, Yunfang Liang, Chunhai Li, Xiaolong Zhou, Chuan Zhang, Liehuang Zhu, Jian Zhao
abstract: The rapid proliferation of Internet of Things (IoT) devices, coupled with their inherent security vulnerabilities, has significantly expanded the attack surface, intensifying threats such as man-in-the-middle attacks, traffic hijacking, and distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks, thereby posing serious risks to the security and reliability of the entire ecosystem. The network traffic associated with IoT devices is diverse and dynamic, often exhibiting complex structural features such as periodic fluctuations, varying packet sizes, and time-varying patterns that make detection challenging. Although deep learning has demonstrated strong capabilities in efficiently identifying complex and dynamic malicious traffic through powerful feature extraction and adaptive learning abilities, its high model complexity, substantial computational demands, and large parameter sizes hinder direct deployment on resource-constrained IoT devices. In order to tackle this issue, this paper proposes a malicious traffic detection framework for the Internet of Things (IoT) based on multi-teacher knowledge distillation. The proposed model, termed the Lightweight Multi-Teacher Spatiotemporal Distillation Neural Network (LMT-SDNN), employs two high-performance teacher models: Residual Inception and a One-Dimension Convolution Netural Network (1D-CNN) integrated with idirectional Long Short-Term Memory (BiLSTM), to effectively capture the complex structural features of network traffic. Furthermore, a novel Time-Related Window Loss (TRW) function is design to enhance the student’s ability to capture temporal features, thereby improving its overall performance. The effectiveness of LMT-SDNN is validated through comparisons with five baseline models on two publicly available datasets, ToN_IoT and BoT_IoT. Experimental results show that LMT-SDNN achieves a compression rate of over 99% in both model complexity and parameter count, while maintaining an accuracy exceeding 99%, indicating its strong potential for multiclass malicious traffic detection in IoT environments.

title: Forecast Accuracy Improvement and Purchase Order Automation Using a Multi-Model Approach in Semiconductor Supply Chain: A Case Study
authors: J Gohitha Maheshwari, N Tanushri, Ramana Gowda, Vatsal Singh Bhutiyal, K V S Rajeswara Rao
abstract: In semiconductor manufacturing, efficient procurement and inventory management are critical to minimize disruptions and ensure seamless production. This study presents a data-driven solution to address inefficiencies in purchase order generation and material forecasting through a custom-built 12-model ensemble forecasting algorithm. Unlike conventional methods, this framework blends statistical and machine learning techniques—ranging from time-series models to neural networks—to deliver highly accurate demand predictions. This paper focuses on per-item forecasting model selection development for semiconductor material planning. Unlike traditional approaches that apply a single model across all materials, semiconductor materials display highly heterogeneous consumption patterns due to differences in part types, usage rates, and production cycles. This heterogeneity makes a uniform forecasting approach suboptimal and motivates the need for per-item model selection. Rarely applied in the semiconductor domain, this ensemble approach enhances industry-specific forecasting and procurement practices. The model was trained and validated on real operational data from one of India’s largest semiconductor manufacturers, ensuring practical relevance and adaptability. Implementation results show marked improvements in forecast accuracy, reduced reliance on manual planning, and faster responses to demand-supply fluctuations, demonstrating a scalable path toward automation and resilience in high-tech procurement. The specific objective is to predict, for every relevant Part ID, the monthly material requirements needed to maintain uninterrupted production. This study was undertaken at a leading semiconductor manufacturing company in India, covering approximately 300–310 active material items sourced from 45–50 suppliers. The solution was integrated with the facility’s ERP system using Python-based automation and structured Excel imports for seamless execution.

title: Sharing Computing Power: Enhancing Energy Efficiency and Reducing Carbon Emissions
authors: Jingjun Sun, Zhi Fu, Jiahao Ma, Xiaochen Liu, Yi Wang
abstract: As the key driver of digital economy development, computing power can become costly due to increasing energy consumption and carbon emissions associated with IT equipment. One potential solution is to promote sustainable computility–electricity–carbon coordination by sharing access to underutilized computing resources. This article introduces energy- and carbon-aware computing power sharing, highlighting its potential to enhance energy efficiency and reduce carbon emissions. Precisely, this article defines computing power sharing with four pillars: participants, resources, purposes, and methods. Participants in the sharing framework shape heterogeneous computing power supply and demand features as well as energy and carbon footprints of computing resources. Feasible sharing frameworks for multilayer resources and corresponding sharing purposes, especially energy and carbon targets, are further classified. Meanwhile, various supporting methods and techniques adopted for these sharing purposes or associated issues are discussed. This article concludes with an analysis of future challenges, followed by policy recommendations.

title: A Low-Cost, Human-Centered, Voice-Guided Automated Pill Dispenser for Assistive Medication Management
authors: Pranav A Kamath, S.T. Thunhaal, B Arjunan, Kagitala Lakshmi Ramani Reddy, Piyush Pratap Singh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Robotics and Mechatronics (ICRM)
abstract: Older and visually impaired persons tend to have difficulty with taking medication on time, and this poses health threats. Here, a mobile smart pill dispenser is proposed to enhance medication compliance through autonomous pill delivery at predetermined times. The device offers voice and vibration notifications, which are suitable for users with sensory disabilities. Based on a small robotic platform, it features a programmable dispensing module and an easy-to-use scheduling interface for remote access. Experimental outcome exhibits high accuracy of pill delivery and user satisfaction, indicating a viable solution for home healthcare assistance

title: Demystifying the Evolution of Neural Networks with BOM Analysis: Insights from a Large-Scale Study of 55,997 GitHub Repositories
authors: Xiaoning Ren, Yuhang Ye, Xiongfei Wu, Yueming Wu, Yinxing Xue
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: Neural networks have become integral to many fields due to their exceptional performance. The open-source community has witnessed a rapid influx of neural network (NN) repositories with fast-paced iterations, making it crucial for practitioners to analyze their evolution to guide development and stay ahead of trends. While extensive research has explored traditional software evolution using Software Bill of Materials (SBOMs), these are ill-suited for NN software, which relies on pre-defined modules and pre-trained models (PTMs) with distinct component structures and reuse patterns. Conceptual AI Bills of Materials (AIBOMs) also lack practical implementations for large-scale evolutionary analysis. To fill this gap, we introduce the Neural Network Bill of Material (NNBOM), a comprehensive dataset construct tailored for NN software. We create a large-scale NNBOM database from 55,997 curated PyTorch GitHub repositories, cataloging their TPLs, PTMs, and modules. Leveraging this database, we conduct a comprehensive empirical study of neural network software evolution across software scale, component reuse, and inter-domain dependency, providing maintainers and developers with a holistic view of its long-term trends. Building on these findings, we develop two prototype applications, Multi repository Evolution Analyzer and Single repository Component Assessor and Recommender, to demonstrate the practical value of our analysis.

title: Time-Delay Model Predictive Control Strategy for Series Hybrid Electric Vehicles Considering Parameter Uncertainty
authors: Mingjun Zha, Weida Wang, Chao Yang, Liuquan Yang, Xuelong Du, Hao Zhong
publish: 2025 9th CAA International Conference on Vehicular Control and Intelligence (CVCI)
abstract: Series hybrid electric vehicles (SHEVs) must regulate the DC-bus voltage even though the engine-generator set exhibits a delayed power response and its dynamic parameters are uncertain; conventional rule-based or delay-neglecting MPC schemes therefore lose accuracy during rapid transients. To address this problem, we propose a Time-delay Model Predictive Control (TMPC) strategy that embeds a torque-response delay model of the engine and generator in the prediction horizon and equips it with an online parameter estimator that continuously refines the model. By explicitly propagating the extra delay states, TMPC can anticipate the finite time required for torque build-up and preload the battery or adjust engine commands before the voltage starts to deviate. Meanwhile, the recursive estimator monitors operating data in real time, updates the delay magnitude and dominant dynamics, and feeds the revised parameters back into the optimiser at every sampling step, ensuring that the internal model stays aligned with the plant even as temperature, load level, or component ageing shift its behaviour. Simulation results demonstrate that, compared with a conventional rule-based (RB) strategy, the proposed method keeps the system markedly more stable during rapid acceleration.

title: BARAKUDA: A Strategic Innovation for Asset Management and Policy Optimization in Prepaid Electrical Energy Monitoring
authors: Ahmad Taufik, Muhammad Ricky Ardiansyah, Irfan Zidni
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on High Voltage Engineering and Power Systems (ICHVEPS)
abstract: The asset data collection process for prepaid kWh meters at PT PLN (Persero) using the ACMT (Aplkasi Catat Meter Terpusat) still has several shortcomings, including the lack of customer coordinate tagging, unregulated data input limits, and limited menu categories for anomaly detection. This negatively impacts the monitoring of electricity theft and kWh meter malfunctions (such as Blank/Error/Inscek), causing Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) for Distribution Losses, Energy Sales, and P2TL (Penertiban Pemakaian Tenaga Listrik) Acquisition to fall short of the 100% achievement target. Therefore, the researcher has developed a prepaid kWh asset data application named BARAKUDA (Baca pRAbayar aKUrat dan terDAta) to address the deficiencies of the ACMT application at UP3 Pematang Siantar.

title: Simulation Analysis of the Roll-Yaw Coupled Safety Boundary for Multi-Axle Heavy-Duty Vehicles
authors: Jinyu Liu, Le Chen, Hang Li, Zunyan Hu, Jianqiu Li, Minggao Ouyang
publish: 2025 9th CAA International Conference on Vehicular Control and Intelligence (CVCI)
abstract: This paper presents a Simulink-based dynamic model of an eight-axle distributed-drive heavy-duty vehicle to analyze coupled roll-yaw instability under complex scenarios. A criterion framework is proposed to identify rollover and sideslip risks. Through simulations involving crosswinds, split-friction roads, and sharp turns, a speed-steering angle safety boundary is extracted. Results show that the boundary decreases nonlinearly with increased steering input and load. The proposed model effectively captures critical instability and provides quantitative insight for path planning and active safety control.

title: Functional Safety Modeling and Design for LiDAR in Autonomous Driving
authors: Xin Zhao, Xianghua Li, Qingguo Yu, Chengguang Li, Kun Jiang, Kai Sun, Diange Yang
publish: 2025 9th CAA International Conference on Vehicular Control and Intelligence (CVCI)
abstract: With the rapid development of the intelligent connected vehicle industry, the safety performance of intelligent driving assistance systems has become a core factor in consumers' car purchase decisions. As the core safety component of the perception layer, the safe operation of LiDAR is directly related to the overall reliability of the system. This paper focuses on typical automotive LiDAR systems and their application scenarios, innovatively combines the physical architecture of LiDAR with functional safety goals and constructs a set of systematic failure mode and risk assessment models. The study identifies through analysis two safety goals for LiDAR in intelligent driving: point cloud data reliability and human eye safety. Furthermore, an indepth fault tree analysis (FTA) was carried out for the core component architectures of LiDAR, such as optics, circuits, and algorithms, to identify key failure modes and their impacts, and define safety requirements covering the complete driving scenario accordingly. Based on this, the study proposes a specific functional safety concept scheme for automotive LiDAR. This work provides a systematic safety analysis framework and architecture reference based on the perspective of LiDAR for the functional safety construction of the perception system of intelligent connected vehicles, laying an important technical foundation and practical basis for its safe application in intelligent assisted driving systems.

title: AlignCoder: Aligning Retrieval with Target Intent for Repository-Level Code Completion
authors: Tianyue Jiang, Yanli Wang, Yanlin Wang, Daya Guo, Ensheng Shi, Yuchi Ma, Jiachi Chen, Zibin Zheng
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: Repository-level code completion remains a challenging task for existing code large language models (code LLMs) due to their limited understanding of repository-specific context and domain knowledge. While retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) approaches have shown promise by retrieving relevant code snippets as cross-file context, they suffer from two fundamental problems: misalignment between the query and the target code in the retrieval process, and the inability of existing retrieval methods to effectively utilize the inference information. To address these challenges, we propose AlignCoder, a repository-level code completion framework that introduces a query enhancement mechanism and a reinforcement learning based retriever training method. Our approach generates multiple candidate completions to construct an enhanced query that bridges the semantic gap between the initial query and the target code. Additionally, we employ reinforcement learning to train an AlignRetriever that learns to leverage inference information in the enhanced query for more accurate retrieval. We evaluate AlignCoder on two widely-used benchmarks (CrossCodeEval and RepoEval) across five backbone code LLMs, demonstrating an 18.1% improvement in EM score compared to baselines on the CrossCodeEval benchmark. The results show that our framework achieves superior performance and exhibits high generalizability across various code LLMs and programming languages.

title: Efficient cross-domain multi-factor authentication
authors: Yongjiao Li, Zhenlei Wang, Zhu Cao
abstract: Secure cross-domain authentication is crucial for protecting information exchange across terminals in different security domains. However, existing cross-domain authentication models suffer from inflexibility, high storage and computational consumption. In response to these problems, a cross-domain multi-factor authentication protocol with improved efficiency (CDAuth) is proposed. CDAuth employs a universally applicable multi-factor authentication approach, integrating pseudo-identity, attribute concealment, and biometric hiding. The authentication information sets can be freely added or modified to accommodate various access scenarios. This boosts privacy, flex-ibility, and applicability compared to traditional methods. Furthermore, multi-edge servers as Certification Authorities (CAs) store only the union of terminal attributes and a verification token per user in their subdomains, instead of each user’s attribute and biometric sets as in traditional schemes, significantly reducing storage consumption. Additionally, replacing the bilinear pairing operations with the native group operations, while maintaining security, significantly reduces computational consumption. Our analysis shows that CDAuth can resist common security attacks and is more efficient than the previous schemes.

title: Spatial Language Likelihood Grounding Network for Bayesian Fusion of Human-Robot Observations
authors: Supawich Sitdhipol, Waritwong Sukprasongdee, Ekapol Chuangsuwanich, Rina Tse
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Fusing information from human observations can help robots overcome sensing limitations in collaborative tasks. However, an uncertainty-aware fusion framework requires a grounded likelihood representing the uncertainty of human inputs. This paper presents a Feature Pyramid Likelihood Grounding Network (FP-LGN) that grounds spatial language by learning relevant map image features and their relationships with spatial relation semantics. The model is trained as a probability estimator to capture aleatoric uncertainty in human language using three-stage curriculum learning. Results showed that FP-LGN matched expert-designed rules in mean Negative Log-Likelihood (NLL) and demonstrated greater robustness with lower standard deviation. Collaborative sensing results demonstrated that the grounded likelihood successfully enabled uncertainty-aware fusion of heterogeneous human language observations and robot sensor measurements, achieving significant improvements in human-robot collaborative task performance.

title:
Application of phonon-assisted energy relaxation for management of laser properties of bismuth active centers associated with silicon
                    <sup>*</sup>
authors: Alexander Elopov, Konstantin Riumkin, Denis Lipatov, Mikhail Yashkov, Sergei Firstov, Mikhail Melkumov
abstract: Application of multi-phonon-assisted energy relaxation for adjustment properties of laser media is demonstrated. A novel approach of laser active media luminescence properties improvement by co-doping of germanosilicate bismuth-doped optical fiber with boron is suggested. Influence of co-doping with boron on quantum yield, branching ratio and lifetime of luminescence of bismuth active center associated with silicon (BAC-Si) in Bi-doped borosilicate fibers were investigated. The multi-phonon decay rates of electron transitions in BAC-Si were obtained for germanosilicate fibers doped with different concentrations of boron.

title: Adaptive Low-Complexity Hybrid Precoding Algorithms for 6G Communication Systems Operating at Higher Frequencies
authors: Madhu Kumar Vanteru, Anvesh Thatikonda, Sravan Kumar Vanam, Madhavi Kesoju, Ranjith Kumar Siddoju, Karthik Kumar Vaigandla
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Computing Technologies (ICACT)
abstract: The rapid growth of the telecommunications sector has intensified interest in advanced wireless communication systems. Among emerging technologies, Terahertz (THz) communication is especially promising, aiming for data rates over 100 Gbps and ultra-low latency to support future applications. A key challenge in THz systems is the implementation of hybrid precoding algorithms. To address this, recent research has introduced low-complexity hybrid precoding methods that reduce computational load and the required number of RF chains without degrading performance. One effective strategy leverages channel sparsity, using techniques like compressive sensing and greedy algorithms to select the most significant channel paths, thus minimizing RF chain usage. Another approach involves clustering antennas, applying analog precoding within each cluster to lower complexity while maintaining efficiency.

title: Edge-Aware Graphormer for Downlink Covert Communication Optimization in Aerial Cell-Free Networks
authors: Yanjun Chen, Yanpeng Dai, Ling Lyu
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Wireless Communications and Signal Processing (WCSP)
abstract: Aerial cell-free networks enhance coverage and communication covertness via cooperative beamforming among aerial access points. However, the tradeoff between transmission covertness and rate assurance poses challenges for the downlink communication optimization of aerial cell-free networks. This paper proposes an Edge-Aware Graphormer (EA-Graphormer) for downlink covert communication optimization in aerial cellfree networks under covertness, maximum transmit power, and fronthaul capacity constraints. We first derive closed-form expressions for the eavesdropper's received power and downlink rates, and then use the Kullback-Leibler divergence between signal distributions to characterize covertness. After that, the EA-Graphormer algorithm is designed which incorporates edge similarity and node centrality into message passing mechanism to jointly optimize user association, power control and fronthaul bandwidth allocation. Simulation results show that the EAGraphormer algorithm strictly satisfies covertness constraints and improves the minimum downlink rate of users.

title: An Optimization Method for Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Smoke Screen Deployment Strategy Based on the Shadow Cone Model
authors: Tuyun Lan
publish: 2025 9th International Workshop on Control Engineering and Advanced Algorithms (IWCEAA)
abstract: In response to the threat posed by high-speed unmanned probes, deploying smoke screens using Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) to obscure high-value targets is a critical defensive measure. This paper proposes a comprehensive optimization framework for designing UAV flight and smoke bomb deployment strategies, aiming to maximize the effective obscuration duration. Firstly, a novel “shadow cone” geometric model is established for accurately determining whether a target is effectively obscured, which serves as the core criterion for evaluating smoke effectiveness. Based on this, a series of nonlinear optimization models with time-varying geometric constraints are constructed to address various mission scenarios, from single-UAV operations to multi-UAV cooperative engagements. The decision variables in these models include the UAV's flight speed, heading, and the deployment and detonation times for each smoke bomb. To solve these high-dimensional and complex optimization problems, we employed Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) and Differential Evolution (DE) algorithms. Simulation experiments demonstrate that the proposed methods can derive effective strategies, achieving optimal obscuration durations of 4.470s, 7.28s, 11.4 s, and 13.223s in progressively complex scenarios.

title: Pump Division Multiplexing for Compact High-Efficiency Multicore and Multi-Channel Erbium-Doped Fiber Amplifiers
authors: Haoshuo Chen, Nicolas K. Fontaine, Jakub Kostial, Roland Ryf, Kwangwoong Kim, Tam Huynh, Ells Burrows, Xiaonan Xu, Ting-Chen Hu, Lauren Dallachiesa, Mikael Mazur, Jesse E. Simsarian, Cang Jin, Hirotaka Sakuma, Takemi Hasegawa, Tetsuya Hayashi, David T. Neilson
abstract: We propose direct pumping of multicore (MC) erbium-doped fiber amplifiers (EDFAs) using a pump diode array chip with multiplane light conversion. Experiments demonstrate compact fan-in/fan-out-free 4/7-core MC EDFAs, and a single-mode (SM) EDFA array via pump-division multiplexing, achieving SM EDFA-level efficiency while supporting scalable integration.

title: High-Precision Micro-Displacement Measurement Based on F-P Interferometer with Improved Quadrature Demodulation Algorithm
authors: Hao Luo, Jinlong Yu, Ju Wang
abstract: In this work, a high-precision micro-displacement measurement based on F-P interferometer is proposed and experimentally demonstrated. Combined with the improved orthogonal algorithm, the system achieves a resolution of 23 pm and a precision of 9 nm.

title: AI-Based Resource Scheduling in 5G NOMA Cellular Networks
authors: Mincheng Zhao, Mingqing Han, Ligang Du, Jiyuan Pan, Yongfeng Yan, Fuqiang Li
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Wireless Communications and Signal Processing (WCSP)
abstract: The deployment of 5G networks has introduced advanced multiple access technology such as Sparse Code Multiple Access (SCMA) to meet the growing demand for high spectral efficiency and massive connectivity. SCMA, a nonorthogonal multiple access (NOMA) technique, allows multiple users to share the same time-frequency resources through sparse codebook-based multiplexing. However, efficient scheduling in SCMA networks presents significant challenge due to the complexities of dynamic resource allocation. In this paper, we propose two Artificial Intelligence (AI)-based methods, corresponding a Multi-Agent Deep Reinforcement Learning (MARL) approach and a Large Language Model (LLM)-empowered approach, for resource scheduling in 5G SCMA networks. we study the AI methods to solve optimal resource scheduling policies that adapt to varying network conditions. Through extensive simulations, we demonstrate that the AI-based schedulers can effectively learn the scheduling strategies and achieve better performance as genieaided methods compared with traditional scheduling algorithms in terms of throughput, and user fairness.

title: Self-Immunized Fiber-Optic Current Sensor via Dual-Light-Path Noise Cancellation
authors: Xinyi Zheng
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Energy Engineering and Power Systems (EEPS)
abstract: In fiber-optic current sensors (FOCS), the paramount determinant of measurement precision is the dual stability of the Verdet constant and the polarization state in the sensing coils. These performance-defining parameters are subject to degradation from the adverse effects of fluctuating environmental conditions, including temperature variations and mechanical stresses, which can lead to substantial measurement deviations. In response to these issues, this work introduces a selfcompensating FOCS configuration that utilizes two distinct sensing links. The developed system integrates a main sensing module along with a compensation module, both operating within a closed-loop control framework. Through this architecture, the design actively mitigates fluctuations in the Verdet constant induced by temperature changes, as well as suppresses detrimental birefringence phenomena occurring within the sensing fibers. Such a strategy delivers a highly reliable method for precision current detection, making it particularly suitable for power system monitoring and industrial electronic applications, where operational dependability and resilience against environmental interferences are of paramount importance.

title: Turbulence phase reconstruction by OAM-based modal decomposition for ultra-low crosstalk free-space vortex beam multiplexing
authors: Yaoyao Liu, Gengliang Zhao, Lang Zhou, Xiaohang Jia, Andong Wang, Long Zhu
abstract: We propose a turbulence compensation scheme for free-space vortex beam multiplexing communications by orbital angular momentum (OAM)-based turbulence phase reconstruction (OAM-TPR). A convolutional neural network (CNN) is employed to establish the relationship between distorted beam distributions and turbulent OAM coefficients. After compensation, the received power of the target mode (l=3) is enhanced 1, 3 and 5 dB under weak to strong turbulence (D/r<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</inf>=2, 4 and 6), respectively. Furthermore, significant crosstalk suppression is observed, with over 18 dB reduction for the adjacent mode (Δl=1) and over 13 dB suppression for the lager mode spacing (Δl=2) averagely. The OAM-TPR compensation method offers a novel solution for mitigating mode crosstalk in atmospheric OAM multiplexing communications.

title: Machine Vision-Based Recognition of Cotton Rows at the Topping Stage
authors: Xin Li, Gulbahar Tohti
publish: 2025 9th International Workshop on Control Engineering and Advanced Algorithms (IWCEAA)
abstract: To address the limitations of current crop row detection methods—such as inadequate adaptability in complex environments during the cotton topping stage and the detection of key agronomic traits within rows—this study introduces an integrated approach combining object detection and image processing. First, the YOLOv8n model was selected for cotton apical bud detection, with the detected bud coordinates used as feature points for crop rows. Initial row fitting was performed using the DBSCAN algorithm and the Least Squares Method (LSM). Subsequently, the GA-ExG vegetation index combined with Otsu's method was applied for image threshold segmentation to generate initial crop row masks. Local traversal outside the masks was then conducted to optimize the crop row boundaries, and the midline of the refined boundaries was defined as the navigation line. Experimental results showed that the proposed method achieved an average navigation line heading angle deviation of 2.59° and a mean Intersection over Union (IoU) of 86.53% for crop row detection. Consequently, the proposed approach can offer reliable technical support for the field operation of topping robots.

title: Variation Reduction for Signal-to-Noise Ratios and Low Frequency Noise of Far infrared Imaging Pixels Using an Array of Schottky Diode Detectors in CMOS and Post-Fabrication Selection
authors: Muhammad Musab Farooq, Frank Zhang, Behnam Pouya, K. O Kenneth
abstract: To mitigate the low frequency noise variability in Schottky barrier diodes (SBD’s) fabricated in a 110-nm foundry CMOS process and its effect on the performance of electromagnetic-thermal far-infrared (FIR) detectors, post-CMOS-fabrication selection of a subset of an array of parallel connected SBD detectors that form a pixel to reduce the noise and to increase the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) is demonstrated. This technique at 20 THz reduces the SNR variation by ~4 dB compared to using all detectors in 5×5 arrays of FIR detectors with a 3.5 μm × 2.5 μm patch antenna. Furthermore, this technique is used to increase the worst-case SNR by ~5 dB. The sub-array combination of the 5×5 detector array with the highest SNR is utilized to create a thermal image of two 10-Ω carbon resistors with peak temperatures of 420 K and 380 K, respectively. The structural similarity index (SSIM) is employed to demonstrate that switching off varying subset combinations of detectors within a pixel does not degrade the image quality. The highest specific detectivity, D* of the pixels at 20 THz reported in this paper is 2.1 × 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</sup>, which is the highest reported D* for detectors not employing a thermal isolation cavity and operating at ~10 THz and above.

title: Prescribed-Time Adaptive Backstepping Control of Multi-Quadrotor Cooperative Suspension System
authors: Wei Liu, Hongzhen Guo, Xuejun Liu
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotics, Control and Automation Engineering (RCAE)
abstract: This paper proposes a prescribed-time adaptive backstepping control strategy for addressing the tracking control problem in a multi-quadrotor cooperative suspension system with unknown external disturbance. The proposed control strategy consists of a payload controller and a quadrotor controller, which are responsible for tracking the trajectory of the payload and the quadrotor, respectively, to achieve the desired bounded convergence of the tracking error within a prescribed time. Additionally, an adaptive law is designed to compensate for the unknown disturbance, thereby enhancing the robustness of the control system. Rigorous stability analysis is conducted to prove the uniform ultimate boundedness of all signals in the closed-loop system. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed method is verified through numerical simulations.

title: Integrated PC-FMCW Automotive Headlamp for Communication, Sensing, and Illumination
authors: Shuanghe Liu, Tongzheng Sun, Lu Wang, Jiaming Lin, Jian Song, Yuhan Dong
abstract: To meet the increasing demand for high-precision sensing, high-speed communication, and adaptive illumination in intelligent driving scenarios, we propose an integrated system based on phase-coded frequency-modulated continuous wave (PC-FMCW) laser headlamps. Leveraging the coherence of laser sources, the system integrates FMCW chirps and phase modulation within a single optical beam, enabling simultaneous sensing and communication without compromising illumination performance. Distance estimation is achieved through beat frequency extraction, while communication data is encoded using differential phase shift keying (DPSK). An adaptive driving beam (ADB) mechanism dynamically adjusts the beam angle and intensity in real time based on the detected position and posture of surrounding targets. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed system enables robust and seamless integration of communication, sensing, and illumination, achieving communication rates up to Gbps level and ranging accuracy better than 0.5 meters, indicating strong robustness and promising application potential.

title: Efficient Micro-Segmentation Generation for Wireless Network Zero-Trust Security: A Graph Diffusion-Based Approach
authors: Yinqiu Liu, Guangyuan Liu, Tianwen Zhu, Jingjing Wang, Qiuming Zhu, Hongyang Du, Dusit Niyato
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Wireless Communications and Signal Processing (WCSP)
abstract: Zero-trust security has emerged as a critical form for addressing the unique vulnerabilities of wireless networks, but its implementation faces significant practical challenges. First, realizing zero-trust requires partitioning the network into multiple isolated, application-specific micro-segmentations with customized security policies. Second, to accommodate increasingly complex service demands, service provisioning within micro-segmentations should utilize Service Function Chains (SFCs) that distribute services across heterogeneous devices. Therefore, this paper proposes an efficient micro-segmentation generation approach called LLM-enhanced Graph Diffusion (LGD). Specifically, we model zero-trust wireless networks as a hierarchical graph structure that captures both physical characteristics and trustworthiness relationships, and formulate the micro-segmentation generation problem as a controllable generation problem. Additionally, we present LGD based on graph diffusion models that optimize micro-segmentation through a progressive denoising process. Furthermore, LGD leverages the cognitive capabilities of Large Language Models (LLMs) to reduce action space dimensions through intelligent filtering and heuristic guidance, thereby accelerating convergence and improving solution quality. Extensive experiments demonstrate that LGD-generated micro-segmentations achieve 40% higher service provisioning efficiency compared to existing baseline approaches. Moreover, comprehensive evaluations across various network scenarios showcase the scalability and robustness of the proposed approach.

title: Application of the Generalized Pareto Model in Earthquake Analysis of Guizhou Province, China
authors: Zhao Lin, Liu Liyin, Luo Yinqi
publish: 2025 22nd International Computer Conference on Wavelet Active Media Technology and Information Processing (ICCWAMTIP)
abstract: To analyze the distribution characteristics and return levels of earthquake magnitudes in Guizhou province, China, a two-parameter Pareto distribution model is used to estimate the probability of strong earthquakes. Based on the Peaks Over Thresholds (POT) model, the optimal threshold is determined using the mean excess plot. Maximum Likelihood Estimation(MLE) is employed to obtain the estimated values of the parameters of the two-parameter Pareto distribution model. Furthermore.a more accurate 95% confidence interval for the shape parameter is calculated through Profile Likelihood Estimation, demonstrating that the earthquake magnitudes in Guizhou province follow a heavy-tailed distribution. Finally.the possible range of magnitudes of strong earthquakes that may occur in Guizhou province is verified using the return level plot for a 1000-year return period.

title: A Unified Mapping Framework for Automated Valet Parking Based on 3D Gaussian Splatting
authors: Tang Yaolun, Lu Guangtong, Qiu Zhijie, Chen Hong, Luo Jin
publish: 2025 22nd International Computer Conference on Wavelet Active Media Technology and Information Processing (ICCWAMTIP)
abstract: With the advancement of autonomous driving technology, parking assistance systems have evolved to the stage of Home-zone Parking Assist. As the current mainstream parking assistance system, HPA still faces the limitation that manual driving is required during the first parking session to learn the route. This paper proposes a unified Infrastructure-side Automated Valet Parking mapping method based on 3D Gaussian Splatting. This method utilizes 3D Gaussian splatting to reconstruct parking lot scenes. Based on the parking path and camera calibration, it generates corresponding rendering paths for each vehicle camera. The rendered images are then pre-delivered to the vehicle-side visual SLAM system to generate the parking map. Experiments conducted in a simulation environment demonstrate the effectiveness and accuracy of the method across various vehicle models with different camera configurations.
