title: Parallel Structure for Nonlinearity Mitigation based on Enhanced Regular Perturbation Theory
authors: Yichao Wang, Peiyun Ge, Tianrun Sun, Jiarun Zhao, Lixia Xi, Xiaoguang Zhang
abstract: We proposed and numerically validated a novel parallel fiber nonlinearity mitigation structure. The approach delivers 0.4 dB Q-factor improvement with 84% complexity saving compared to digital back propagation for 130-GBaud systems.

title: MSRA-Net: An Efficient Deep Learning Architecture with Spatial Attention for Diabetic Retinopathy Classification from Retinal Images
authors: Meherose Hossain Tasnia, MrithikaDutta, Fahim Sahriar, Farhana Rahman, Adiba Masud, Kazi Rifat Ahmed
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Information and Communication Technology (EICT)
abstract: Diabetic Retinopathy (DR) is a serious complication of diabetes mellitus that involves progressive deterioration of the blood vessels in the retina and can result in permanent vision loss. The stealthy development of the disease requires vigorous early diagnosis mechanisms. This paper presents MSRA-Net, a new Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) architecture that is specifically designed to diagnose diabetic retinopathy from fundus images automatically. This methodology involves the utilization of Mish activation functions (M) for stability in training, Spatial Attention modules (S) to prioritize pathologically relevant areas, Residual Blocks (R) to retain important features, and AdaptiveAvgPool2d (A) to retain global spatial information. The APTOS 2019 Blindness Dataset is used and employs preprocessing methods such as Contrast Limited Adaptive Histogram Equalization (CLAHE) and Gaussian blur for image quality improvement. Empirical validation asserts that MSRANet accomplishes 96.1% accuracy, surpassing a number of state-of-the-art deep learning methods. Architectural excellence of the proposed network in feature extraction and classification has encouraging prospects for clinical applicability in early detection frameworks for DR, which can be used to alleviate the public health burden of diabetes-related vision loss.

title: Securing Packet and Optical Transport Connectivity Services in Multi-Stakeholder Untrusted Networks
authors: Pol Alemany, Mattin Antartiko Elorza Forcada, Sergiy Remezov, Miriam Castro, Diogo Nogueira, Ricard Vilalta, Lluis Gifre, Javier José Díaz, Antonio Pastor, Guillermo Gómez, Sonia Castro, José Cunha, Javier García, Alberto González Barneo, Raul Muñoz
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Communications Society
abstract: This paper presents a security and trust solution for 6G transport networks, focusing on the integration of Distributed Ledger Technology (DLT), Closed-Loop (CL) automation, and trust-based security management across multi-domain, multi-provider environments. The proposed solution is designed to enhance the security of End-to-End (E2E) services by enabling operators to define security and trust requirements while allowing providers to fulfilconnectivity services needs dynamically. Key elements of the solution include blockchain-based smart contracts to manage operator-transport provider agreements and Level-of-Trust (LoT) metrics for continuous trust evaluation. The paper highlights the role of security service level agreements (SSLAs) and trust-aware SLAs (TSLAs) in ensuring the integrity of service deployment and operations. Additionally, the integration of real-time monitoring and automated mitigation actions via CLs ensures that the system adapts to threats dynamically, maintaining continuous service security. The use of Artificial Intelligence -driven analytics for threat detection and mitigation further supports the robust security framework proposed for next-generation 6G systems. A multi-stakeholder scenario based on the use of different optical and packet-based transport domains is used in the experimental test case to validate the system’s effectiveness in dynamically reconfiguring security resources and adapting to evolving threats, showcasing its potential to meet the high-security demands of 6G networks. The solution ensures uninterrupted service and robust protection in multi-provider environments.

title: Enhanced Region-Aware Fusion Network: A Multimodal Deep Learning Framework for 3D Brain Tumor Segmentation in MRI Volumes
authors: Ssemwogerere Rajab, Qin Zhen, Alzahrani Atiah Abdullah E, Almathani Mohammed Adnan, Missaoui Mohammed El Amine, Ansu Badjie, Ologun S. Babatunde
publish: 2025 22nd International Computer Conference on Wavelet Active Media Technology and Information Processing (ICCWAMTIP)
abstract: Effectively segmenting brain tumors from multimodal 3D MRI scans presents a formidable challenge due to the heterogeneous nature of tumor structures and the inherent modality imbalance. This study presents the Enhanced Region-Aware Fusion Network, an end-to-end architecture that integrates spatial-probabilistic reasoning with adaptive modality fusion for volumetric medical image segmentation. The Probability Map Estimator is the fundamental module of this study. It generates region confidence maps, guiding an Enhanced Region-Aware Fusion Module to study dynamic attention weights across various MRI modalities. Then the fused representations are further polished by a shared decoder to enable precise tumor description. Enhanced Region-Aware Fusion Network simultaneously minimizes both Binary Cross-Entropy and Dice losses, thereby enhancing sensitivity at tumor boundaries and effectively addressing label imbalance. We evaluated our model on the BRA TS2020 dataset. Results show that Enhanced Region-aware Fusion Network surpasses the conventional multimodal fusion approaches while maintaining spatial consistency within tumor regions. Enhanced Region-Aware Fusion Network highlights its promise for clinical MRI tumor diagnosis.

title: AutoFid: Adaptive and Noise-Aware Fidelity Measurement for Quantum Programs via Circuit Graph Analysis
authors: Tingting Li, Ziming Zhao, Jianwei Yin
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: Quantum computers in the Noisy Intermediate-Scale Quantum (NISQ) era face significant challenges due to inherent noise and limited qubit coherence. Accurate fidelity evaluation of quantum states necessitates multiple repeated measurements to obtain statistical results. But determining the optimal number of measurements remains an open problem due to the dynamic, device-dependent nature of quantum noise. Existing methods either assume prior knowledge of the noise model or inherently employ a fixed measurement strategy, which limits their applicability in practical deployment scenarios. This paper presents AutoFid, an adaptive and noise-aware fidelity measurement framework that automatically determines the number of required tests based on circuit structure and hardware feedback. AutoFid models quantum circuits as Directed Acyclic Graphs and estimates structural complexity via random walks, enabling estimation of measurement effort. It further incorporates transpilation-aware features such as gate fidelity, depth inflation, and crosstalk to refine iteration budgets. During runtime, AutoFid dynamically samples fidelity results and employs an early stopping strategy based on confidence intervals to reduce redundant measurements while preserving accuracy guarantees. We evaluate AutoFid on 18 quantum benchmarks executed on real IBMQ hardware platforms. Experimental results show that AutoFid reduces measurement costs by more than 50% compared to both fixed-shot and learning-based baselines, while consistently maintaining fidelity bias below 0.01. Additional analysis using classical software testing metrics and ablation studies demonstrate its effectiveness, robustness, and adaptability across a wide range of quantum workloads.

title: Sparse Bayesian Learning for Designing Intelligent Planar Arrays with the Reduced Number of Antenna Elements
authors: Haiou Shen, Ning Ma
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Infocomm Technology (ICAIT)
abstract: This paper proposes an effective method for the optimal synthesis of intelligent planar arrays using a reduced number of antenna elements based on sparse Bayesian learning. Within the SBL framework, the synthesis problem for sparse planar arrays is cast as an approximation task subject to sparsity constraints, which is addressed through an iterative solution procedure. By simultaneously optimizing both element positions and excitation weights, the proposed approach enables dynamic reconfiguration of radiation patterns with accurate pattern matching and minimal element count. A set of representative simulation experiment is included to illustrate the efficacy and benefits of the proposed methodology.

title: Hybrid Meta-Heuristic Based Crosstalk-Aware Automatic Mapping for Optical Network-on-Chip
authors: Chen Zhao, Qiuyan Yao, Hui Yang, Daqing Meng, Yijie Liang, Junji Feng
abstract: We propose a multi-strategy hybrid meta-heuristic mapping method to address crosstalk issues in Optical Network-on-Chip task mapping. Compared with existing mapping algorithms, this method reduces average crosstalk by 19.4% and improves signal-to-noise ratio by 21.86%.

title: Parameter Identification for Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motors Based on LGWO-SA-EKF
authors: FengRui Guo, HengZhan Yang, JinYuan Hao
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotics, Control and Automation Engineering (RCAE)
abstract: To address the instability issues in vector control caused by time-varying parameters of Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motors (PMSM), this paper proposes an enhanced parameter identification method integrating an improved Grey Wolf Optimizer (LGWO-SA) with Extended Kalman Filter (EKF). The approach employs Logistic chaotic mapping to optimize population distribution and incorporates a simulated annealingbased probabilistic transition mechanism to strengthen global search capability. A dual-regularized fitness function combining exponential residual suppression and Frobenius norm constraints is designed to improve noise resistance. Simulation results demonstrate that under dynamic operating conditions, the proposed method reduces identification errors for stator resistance, inductance, and flux linkage by over 70 % compared to conventional EKF, with convergence time under 0.5 s and parameter fluctuations limited to below 1.5%. This significantly enhances the accuracy and robustness of online parameter identification, providing an effective solution for high-precision servo control systems.

title: Nabla Fractional Algorithm for Distributed Resource Allocation Based on PID Protocol in Cooperative-Competitive Network
authors: Xintong Ni, Yiheng Wei, Xiuxian Li, Jinde Cao
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: The cooperative-competitive network has broad application prospects due to its advantages in aligning with practical production and life. This work, for the first time, combines the predictive capability of the proportional-integral-derivative (PID) protocol for error and the flexibility of an additional order parameter in fractional calculus to solve the distributed resource allocation problem in cooperative-competitive networks, and provides a discrete time algorithm for the design. The analysis proves that the algorithms can Mittag-Leffler converge to the optimal solution of the distributed resource allocation problem. Finally, numerical simulations are provided, demonstrating the effectiveness of the algorithm, along with a set of comparative simulation that validate the superiority of the proposed algorithm.

title: Photovoltaic Ultra-Short-Term Power Prediction Using CNN-LSTM with Attention Mechanism
authors: Yihao Huang, Xu Ming, Lianxin Lv
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Energy Engineering and Power Systems (EEPS)
abstract: In the context of low-carbon energy transition, the intermittent nature of photovoltaic power generation poses significant challenges to grid security and economic operations. Ultra-short-term photovoltaic power forecasting enhances grid dispatch management, improving the operational efficiency and cost-effectiveness of power systems. This paper proposes an improved prediction method that integrates multi-layer attentional mechanisms with Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks. The approach first employs attentional mechanisms within CNN networks to extract spatial relationships between features, then combines LSTM models with attentional mechanisms for temporal data processing. Compared with the original CNN, LSTM, and CNN-LSTM models, the proposed framework demonstrates significantly improved prediction accuracy.

title: An Automatic Modulation Classification Algorithm Based on Adaptive Visibility Graph and GNN Incorporating GRU
authors: Lingzhao Zhang, Haitao Zhao, Qin Wang, You Wu, Haibo Dai, Hongbo Zhu
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Wireless Communications and Signal Processing (WCSP)
abstract: Automatic modulation recognition (AMR) is crucial for modern wireless systems. However, existing methods often struggle to effectively model the spatio-temporal correlations in signals and the interplay between In-phase (I) and Quadrature (Q) channels. We propose AVG-GRU, a novel end-to-end framework addressing these limitations. AVG-GRU first employs a 1D convolutional neural network with an attention mechanism to extract and fuse features from I/Q signals. To enhance temporal representation, an adaptive visibility graph maps both the original I/Q and fused signals into graph structures. A graph neural network (GNN) incorporating gated recurrent unit (GRU) then integrates features from these multiple graphs. Finally, modulation classification is performed. Evaluated on RadioML2016.10b datasets, AVG-GRU outperforms state-of-theart methods such as AvgNet and GIGNet to achieve improved modulation recognition accuracy.

title: ConsMatch: Semi-Supervised Medical Image Segmentation via Multi-View Contrast and Feature Consistency
authors: Yuhan Chen, You Li, Bin Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: In the task of semi-supervised medical image segmentation, the focus is on how to fully utilize unlabeled data. However, most of the current methods can hardly solve the problems of difficult segmentation of medical image contours and insufficient feature exploration of unlabeled data. To overcome the above problems, this paper proposes a semi-supervised medical image segmentation framework based on multi-view contrast and feature consistency named ConsMatch. We design two key modules: MCR (Multi-View Contrastive Representation) module, which utilizes the contrastive learning idea to maximize the feature similarity of the same image under different perturbations, and at the same time, minimizes the redundant structural similarity between different images; FCR ( Feature-level Consistency Regularization) module, which guides the model to learn features with stable structural expressions by minimizing the difference in the distribution of structural similarity matrices under different enhancement views. The method introduces structural constraints in the feature space, and strengthens the model’s ability to learn from unlabeled data in multiple dimensions through multi-view comparison representation learning and structural consistency regularization. We conduct extensive experiments on the ACDC dataset as well as the LA dataset, both of which yield high performance. Our code can be found in https://github.com/magic-fortune/ConsMatch.

title: Conjugated Capabilities: Interrelations of Elementary Human Capabilities and Their Implication on Human-Machine Task Allocation and Capability Testing Procedures
authors: Nils Mandischer, Larissa Füller, Torsten Alles, Frank Flemisch, Lars Mikelsons
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Human and automation capabilities are the foundation of every human-autonomy interaction and interaction pattern. Therefore, machines need to understand the capacity and performance of human doing, and adapt their own behavior, accordingly. In this work, we address the concept of conjugated capabilities, i.e. capabilities that are dependent or interrelated and between which effort can be distributed. These may be used to overcome human limitations, by shifting effort from a deficient to a conjugated capability with performative resources. For example: A limited arm’s reach may be compensated by tilting the torso forward. We analyze the interrelation between elementary capabilities within the IMBA standard to uncover potential conjugation, and show evidence in data of post-rehabilitation patients. From the conjugated capabilities, within the example application of stationary manufacturing, we create a network of interrelations. With this graph, a manifold of potential uses is enabled. We showcase the graph’s usage in optimizing IMBA test design to accelerate data recordings, and discuss implications of conjugated capabilities on task allocation between the human and an autonomy.

title: A Review of Live Shopping for Indonesian MSMEs: Trends and Implications
authors: Prayoga Pribadi, Dhanar Intan Surya Saputra, Sakhrul Rifan Hardian, Siti Nahla Amalina, Adam Prayogo Kuncoro, Rujianto Eko Saputro
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Information Technology, Information Systems and Electrical Engineering (ICITISEE)
abstract: The rapid development of digital technology has brought about significant transformation in the Indonesian economic sector, especially in micro, small, and medium enterprises (MSMEs). One of the latest innovations in e-commerce, now a global trend, is live shopping, which integrates direct interaction between sellers and consumers through real-time video streaming platforms. This innovation has proven effective in increasing consumer interaction and sales conversion. Live shopping offers MSMEs opportunities to expand their market reach by utilizing social media platforms, such as Instagram, Facebook, and TikTok, as well as marketplaces like Shopee and Tokopedia, which are widely used in Indonesia. This study aims to systematically review the application of live shopping in social commerce and explore its impact on the digital transformation and market expansion of MSMEs in Indonesia. Through a literature review spanning 2020 to 2024, this study identifies the benefits and challenges of adopting live shopping and its role in supporting the growth of MSMEs. The study's results show that live shopping not only increases the visibility of MSMEs but also facilitates global market expansion without the need for physical stores. However, this study also reveals the challenges faced by MSMEs, including limited digital skills, disparities in internet infrastructure, and intense market competition. This article concludes with practical recommendations for MSMEs to optimize their live shopping strategies and accelerate their digital transformation, enabling them to remain competitive in the global market.

title: Multiagent Safe Reinforcement Learning by Decentralized Event-Triggered Min-Max Optimization
authors: Shunsuke Otani, Naoki Hayashi, Masahiro Inuiguchi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: This paper addresses decentralized event-triggered reinforcement learning with safety constraints. Each agent has an individual reward function and safety constraints that depend on the joint actions of agents. The objective is to maximize the team’s long-term return while satisfying the safety constraints. We formulate the reinforcement learning problem as a nonconvex-concave min-max optimization problem and propose a decentralized policy gradient algorithm. Each agent has estimations for the optimal primal and dual solutions of the min-max optimization problem. Different from the existing decentralized reinforcement learning, the agents share these estimates only when the error exceeds a predefined threshold. We show that the estimates of agents converge to a neighborhood of a locally optimal solution while effectively reducing the communication overhead.

title: Research on PCA-ALS–Based Imputation of Missing INS and GPS Latitude-Longitude Data
authors: Xuejiao Zhao, Rui Liu, Baidong Zheng, Yang Liu
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on System Reliability and Safety Engineering (SRSE)
abstract: In response to missing latitude-longitude observations in inertial navigation system and GPS integrated positioning, the paper proposes a missing-data imputation method based on principal component analysis initialization and alternating least squares. Synchronized INS/GPS observations are assembled into a matrix, and incomplete data are simulated by randomly masking approximately $10 \%$ of entries. A weighted covariance matrix is then computed to extract dominant directions, and PCA is used to obtain initial factor loadings and scores. The factor model is subsequently refined via an ALS procedure augmented with ridge regularization to enhance robustness, ultimately reconstructing the missing trajectory samples. Using synchronized INS/GPS data as a case study, the proposed approach is compared with linear interpolation, spline interpolation, and mean imputation. Results indicate that PCAALS leverages cross-sensor correlation structure to recover missing values more effectively, achieving lower root-mean-square error and higher correlation coefficients than the baselines, and yielding a more faithful reconstruction of the complete trajectory.

title: Design of 16x1 Multiplexer using CMOS Technology for High Speed Communication Switch
authors: Sweta Chander, Sanjeet Kumar
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Mobile Networks and Wireless Communications (ICMNWC)
abstract: In this reported paper the design and implementation of a $16 \times 1$ multiplexer utilizing a hierarchical approach based on $2 \times 1$ multiplexers in CMOS technology. The proposed architecture leverages the flexibility and scalability of 2x1 multiplexers to construct a higher-order multiplexer with reduced complexity. The design is carried out using Cadence Virtuoso, a widely used platform for analog and digital circuit design. The utilization of CMOS technology using gdpk 45 nm ensures low power consumption and improved performance characteristics. The research explores the challenges and considerations in the design process, addressing issues such as signal propagation delay, power dissipation, and area overhead. Trade-offs between these factors are analyzed to optimize the overall performance of the 16x1 MUX implementation. Simulation result including average power and delay. Average power of $2 \times 1$ mux is $487.9 \mathrm{E}-3 \mathrm{~W}$ which is lower and $16 \times 1$ mux has more average power which is $492.6 \mathrm{E}-3 \mathrm{~W}$.

title: Privacy-Utility Trade-off in Federated LLM Fine-Tuning: A Dynamic Game Approach
authors: Yuntao Wang, Kun Qian, Yanghe Pan, Zhou Su, Wei Wang
abstract: Fine-tuning large language models (LLMs) is critical for adapting pretrained models to specialized downstream tasks. Federated LLM fine-tuning enables privacy-aware model updates by allowing data owners (DOs) to contribute a global LLM without exposing local data. However, full-parameter fine-tuning in federated settings incurs significant computational and communication overhead, while frequent gradient exchanges increase the risk of privacy leakage, such as memorized data inference. Parameter-efficient fine-tuning (PEFT) with differential privacy (DP) offers a low-overhead alternative with formal privacy guarantees, but fails to strike privacy-utility tradeoff under heterogeneous privacy preferences: individual DOs may inject excessive DP noise to maximize privacy, whereas the curator aims to minimize noise to preserve model quality. In this paper, we present an innovative game-theoretical framework that enables dynamic privacy trading within differentially private federated LLM fine-tuning. In the game, DOs strategically adjust their local DP noise levels in exchange for customized incentives from the curator, thereby balancing privacy and utility. We begin by establishing a theoretical convergence bound that quantifies the influence of locally injected noise on the global model utility. Under this bound, we analytically characterize the pure-strategy Nash equilibrium of the game, accounting for DO heterogeneity, curator budget constraints, and noise estimation errors. For mixed-strategy settings with incomplete information, we design a hierarchical reinforcement learning algorithm that jointly learns DOs’ optimal noise-saving strategies and the curator’s optimal pricing policy without presupposing their private information. Experiments on real-world datasets demonstrate that the proposed scheme improves DO utility, reduces curator cost, mitigates free-riding, and accelerates convergence compared to existing methods.

title: Improving Wald’s (approximate) sequential probability ratio test by avoiding overshoot
authors: Lasse Fischer, Aaditya Ramdas
abstract: Wald’s sequential probability ratio test (SPRT) is a cornerstone of sequential analysis. Based on desired type-I, II error levels α, β, it stops when the likelihood ratio crosses certain thresholds, guaranteeing optimality of the expected sample size. However, these thresholds are not closed form and the test is often applied with approximate thresholds (1 – β)/α and β/(1 – α) (approximate SPRT). When β > 0, this neither guarantees error control at α, β nor optimality. When β = 0 (power-one SPRT), this method is conservative and not optimal. The looseness in both cases is caused by overshoot: the test statistic overshoots the thresholds at the stopping time. Numerically calculating thresholds may be infeasible, and most software packages do not do this. We improve the approximate SPRT by modifying the test statistic to avoid overshoot. Our ‘sequential boosting’ technique uniformly improves power-one SPRTs (β = 0) for simple nulls and alternatives, or for one-sided nulls and alternatives in exponential families. When (β > 0), our techniques provide guaranteed error control at α, β, while needing less samples than the approximate SPRT in our simulations. We also provide several nontrivial extensions: confidence sequences, sampling without replacement and conformal martingales.

title: Electrocardiogram Signal Classification using a Lightweight CNN–TCN with Transfer Learning
authors: P. Nagarathna, M. Krishna Chaitanya, Raja Shekhara Chary Marrelli, V. Ruba Devi, G Ravi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Mobile Networks and Wireless Communications (ICMNWC)
abstract: Nowadays, Electrocardiogram (ECG) signal classification is used to automatically identify normal and abnormal heart rhythms by analyzing the electrical activity patterns of the heart. However, the existing 2D-Convolutional Neural Network-Long Short-Term Memory (2D-CNN-LSTM) struggled with high computation complexity, poor generalization to unseen patients and limited adaptability. To address these limitations this research proposed a Lightweight Multi-Scale Dilated Residual Temporal Convolutional Network (MS-DR-TCN) model with Transfer Learning (TL). This process begins with collection of ECG signal data from Massachusetts Institute of Technology Beth Israel Hospital (MIT-BIH) arrhythmia database. Then the data is preprocessed by high pass filtering to remove baseline drift and notch filtering to suppress powerline interference, min-max normalization to scale ECG amplitude in a fixed range and segmentation to extract individual cardiac cycles. After that, the proposed MS-DR-TCN is employed where 1D-CNN capture local ECG morphology, TCN learn long-range temporal dependencies and SE Channel Attention enhances informative feature channels. Next, in classification and TL stage a dense Softmax classifier generates arrhythmia labels and probability scores whereas TL improves generalization across patients, similarly quantization and pruning ensure real-world inference on edge enabled Internet of Things (IoT) devices by providing an accurate, adaptive, and computationally efficient ECG classification framework. From the results, the proposed MS-DR-TCN provided better results in terms of Accuracy (98.43%), Precision (98.11%), Recall (97.87%) and F1-Score (97.98%) when compared to existing 2D-CNN-LSTM model.

title: Advancing AI-Enhanced Financial Security: A Review of Facial, Voice, and Medical Biometrics for Identity Verification
authors: Zhicong Chen, Alice Xiaodan Dong, Gareth William Peters, Jennifer Chan, Weidong Huang, Chun-Cheng Lin
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Identity verification is a critical component of financial data and systems security and privacy preservation, and is required by regulatory guidelines to ensure compliance with regulatory requirements and to aid in fraud prevention. With advances in artificial intelligence (AI), deep learning, and statistical methods, financial institutions are increasingly adopting multifactor authentication (MFA) that incorporates biometric-based approaches to perform authentication of identities for access to accounts, records or data and for verification of decision making and confirmation of actions.This paper presents a systematic review of current methodologies that utilize facial recognition, voice biometrics, and other data for identity verification in financial institutions. We explore the effectiveness and challenges associated with these approaches, highlighting recent developments in AI-driven models, deep learning architectures, and statistical techniques. In addition, we discuss the integration of multimodal biometric data and the decision and access systems that are developed for MFA approaches to improve security and accuracy. This review offers insights into the future of biometric identity verification in the financial sector.Our findings suggest that the integration of multi-modal data in financial applications could serve as a valuable avenue for future research and practical applications. In addition, investigating the role of biometric authentication in back-end systems is an important area worth further exploration.

title: XAI4DDoS: Explainable ML Pipelines for Binary and Multiclass Network Attack Detection
authors: Mauparna Nandan, Ritwika Das
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Intelligent Signal Processing and Effective Communication Technologies (INSPECT)
abstract: Distributed Denial-of-Service (DDoS) attacks jeopardize network resilience by inundating systems with harmful traffic, thereby obstructing legitimate access. As networks become increasingly intricate due to the development of IoT, conventional signature-based techniques are inadequate for identifying emerging risks. This research introduces XAI4DDoS, an explainable machine learning framework for binary and multiclass DDoS detection utilizing ensemble models such as XGBoost, LightGBM, and AdaBoost. The system attains a high accuracy of up to 99.50 % on the CICIoT2023 and DDoS Network Logs datasets. It incorporates SHAP, LIME, Permutation Feature Importance, Partial Dependence Plots, and DiCE counterfactuals to improve model interpretability. The integration of global and local XAI methodologies addresses the transparency deficit, facilitating ethical, data-informed intrusion analysis. Insights obtained from these explanations reveal essential markers of DDoS activity, hence enhancing network protection in critical infrastructures.

title: Optimizing Robotic Manipulation and Grasping Techniques for Complex Tasks Using Reinforcement Learning and Computer Vision
authors: Sandeep Kumar, Deepika Mallampati, Rasveen, M Sudhakar, B. Sabitha, Shilpa Choudhary
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Computing Technologies (ICACT)
abstract: The changing and unclear nature of real-world settings has made it hard for robots to manipulate and grasp things in complicated ways for a long time. Traditional methods don't always work well when things change and are not flexible enough for quick exchanges. We present a new approach that uses the interaction between computer vision and reinforcement learning (RL) to improve robotic handling and grabbing methods. Our proposed work makes it easier for robots to learn and change independently, so they can make good plans by interacting with their surroundings. At the same time, computer vision helps it understand because it provides a safe and effective learning method. By modeling different situations and task variations, the robot can learn grabbing and manipulating skills that work well in real life. Our work uses repeated training and improvement to help robots learn complex movement skills, such as precisely moving objects, holding them deftly, and confidently dealing with object uncertainty. To see how well our system works, we do a lot of tests on various complex handling tasks, such as sorting objects, putting them together, and moving flexible objects around. We compared our proposed work with standard methods; our results show significant changes in how well tasks are done and how reliable they are. We also use actual tests on an artificial platform to show that learned rules can be used in real-world situations.

title: Switching Control Method for Grid-Forming LC Inverters
authors: YiFan Li, Xin Guo
publish: 2025 9th International Workshop on Control Engineering and Advanced Algorithms (IWCEAA)
abstract: To address the issue that existing grid-forming control strategies rely on traditional linearized models for the inner-loop controller, making it difficult to balance the nonlinear characteristics of the converter with high-performance control objectives, this paper proposes a switching control strategy for grid-forming inverters based on switched system theory. A switched model capable of accurately describing the nonlinear operating characteristics of the inverter is established to replace the traditional averaged linear model. A switching state feedback controller, compatible with the switched model, is designed to enhance the dynamic response performance and control accuracy of the inner loop. The outer loop adopts the droop control principle, enabling autonomous power distribution and grid support functions for the inverter. Simulation and experimental results demonstrate that, compared to traditional linear control methods, the proposed switching control strategy exhibits stronger robustness, faster dynamic response, and superior power quality under various operating conditions, providing a novel solution for high-performance control of grid-forming inverters.

title: Hierarchical Transfer Learning Method for Cross-industry Accounting of Electricity-Energy-Carbon Models
authors: Bing Fang, Jiayi Zhang, Shanli Wang, Shaoxia Xing, Huanxiu Xiao, Jiale Wu
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Energy Engineering and Power Systems (EEPS)
abstract: With the advancement of the global carbon neutrality agenda, accurately accounting for energy consumption and carbon emissions within industrial enterprises has become a critical challenge in realizing low-carbon transformation. To address the issue of multi-scale heterogeneity encountered by electricity-energy-carbon accounting models during cross-industry applications, this paper proposes a hierarchical, fine-grained transfer learning framework. The framework is structured into three levels: macro, meso, and micro. At the macro level, it extracts common industry-wide features; at the meso level, it adapts process flows through a dynamic process mapping mechanism; and at the micro level, it enables fine-grained parameter-level adjustments, thereby facilitating the rapid adaptation of the model to the cement industry. The research demonstrates that this framework effectively mitigates the challenges posed by inter-industry process differences by establishing a shared industrial feature space and an adaptive mapping mechanism, offering methodological support for the development of a unified multi-industry carbon accounting system.

title: AI Driven Virtual Interview Platform
authors: Aditi Nagpure, Rohit Kharat, Trushna Deotale
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Computing Technologies (ICACT)
abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) and cloud-based technology are transforming the recruitment industry with new tools, new solutions for smarter hiring. The paper addresses the design and development of an AI-driven virtual interview platform that aims to maximize candidate evaluation and recruiter decision-making. The system works by automating question generation, speech-to-text transcription in real-time, and AI-enabled evaluation based on Natural Language Processing (NLP) algorithms. It gives the recruiters in-depth performance analytics along with providing candidates with an interactive and unbiased interview experience. Designed with scalable technologies like OpenAI APIs, React.js, Node.js and MongoDB, the platform is designed to be flexible, transparent, and adaptable to various recruitment requirements. This study not only overcomes conventional recruitment challenges such as human bias, inefficiency, and high operating costs but also enables data-driven, unbiased, and efficient recruitment. The paper then discusses the technology architecture, methodologies for implementation, and how AI-based virtual interviews could influence the HR industry and candidate preparation ecosystems.

title: Differentiated Adversarial Training Method Based on Samples
authors: Lu Zhang, Wenhao Wang, Chunlong Fan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: In recent years, deep learning neural networks have made remarkable progress, especially in the application of computer vision. Although these networks have extraordinary capabilities, they are obviously vulnerable when they are subjected to malicious interference. Although researchers have proposed many methods to improve the robustness of the model to interference, the existing antagonistic training methods still have obvious limitations: excessive consumption of computing resources and disastrous catastrophic overfitting. In order to meet these challenges, we put forward Dynamic Label Smoothing (DLS) and Differential Disturbance Strategy (DPS), and developed a new countermeasure training framework, FGSM-DSEM, which integrates dynamic exponential moving average and momentum-guided gradient direction. A large number of experiments on different network architectures and data sets show that the FGSM-DSEM method significantly enhances the robustness of the model, while significantly reducing the risk of the catastrophic overfitting problem, and achieves these improvements with minimum training overhead.

title: A Spatiotemporal Machine Learning Framework for Ecologically-informed Bird Sighting Prediction
authors: Meriam Harissa, Jana Amin, Srijita Das, Zheng Song
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Fine-grained bird sighting prediction is crucial for advancing ecological research, informing conservation planning, and enhancing the birdwatching experience while fostering public awareness of biodiversity. The rapid expansion of citizen-based bird observation networks has led to an exponential accumulation of bird sighting records, which can be leveraged to train machine learning models for more precise predictions. However, general-purpose machine learning models often fail to incorporate ecological factors that influence bird activity, resulting in less accurate predictions. In this paper, we present an ecologically informed machine learning framework based on LightGBM that integrates spatiotemporal correlations, ecological context, and dynamic environmental variables to improve bird sighting predictions. The framework captures temporal trends using rolling windows, applies spatial smoothing to account for observation proximity, and models ecological dependencies—such as temperature-food interactions—through interaction terms. Key environmental factors, including habitat classifications, weather conditions, and seasonally adjusted food availability proxies, are dynamically incorporated to enhance ecological relevance. Evaluation results demonstrate significant improvements in predictive accuracy, with increased F1-scores compared to baseline methods. By embedding ecological principles into machine learning models, this framework enables data-driven insights that reflect real-world environmental complexities, providing a powerful tool for biodiversity monitoring and conservation strategies.

title: Cross-coupled Voltage Doubler with Improved Subthreshold Performance
authors: Reyhan Ramadhan, Masato Saito, Takashi Tokuda
publish: 2025 IEEE International Meeting for Future of Electron Devices, Kansai (IMFEDK)
abstract: We propose an improvement to the cross-coupled voltage doubler which enables it to operate from subthreshold-to-superthrehsold input voltage conditions. Such capability is important for applications in energy harvesting systems. Incorporating a low-power subthreshold level shifter, the drive strength of the discharge-side PMOS switches are improved, allowing the input voltage to be reduced. We implemented the proposed design in 180 nm standard CMOS process and verifed the design in silicon.

title: An Improved Small-Target Detection Framework for Expressway Incidents Based on YOLOv8
authors: Zunyi Xu, Yongjing Wang, Chuanyun Zhang, Chen Li
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Infocomm Technology (ICAIT)
abstract: The expressway video surveillance system is an important part of expressway infrastructure. The manual inspection of expressway accident detection may miss small targets such as pedestrians, non-motorized vehicles, or vehicle-dropped objects. Currently, the detection sensitivity and accuracy of the computer vision-based is relatively low for small targets. In this paper, we have proposed an improved small-target detection framework for expressway incidents based on YOLOv8 (You Only Look Once). A small-target detection layer has been added to the YOLOv8 framework in order to make the network more focus on small-target detection and improve detection effectiveness. In response to the issue of missed detection in the process of detecting small targets for expressway incidents, a Bidirectional Fusion (BiFusion) structure has been designed, which adds the novel crossscale connections and uses new feature fusion methods to improve the accuracy of small-target detection. The Efficient Multi-scale Attention (EMA) mechanism has been introduced into the YOLOv8 framework to improve the accuracy of small-target detection by modeling long-range dependencies to retain accurate positional information. The improved YOLOv8 framework has been experimentally validated on the public dataset MS COCO (Microsoft Common Objects in Context). The results have shown that its mAP (mean Average Precision) value reaches 64.9%, which is higher than that of the original framework by 1.8%. To further validate the performance of the proposed framework for target detection in the expressway environments, experiments have been carried out on the dedicated dataset for Highway Simulation Scenarios (HSSD). The results show that it has the highest detection accuracy of 98.8%, which is higher than that of the original YOLOv8 framework by 1.2%, and the detection speed is 163 FPS (Frames Per Second). The improved framework has a better detection performance for small targets in expressway accidents.

title: High-power and dense semiconductor optical amplifier array
authors: Yang Ke, Yueyang Shi, Ying Liu, Yanfang Wang, Ruijun Wang, Siyuan Yu
abstract: We present a high-power and dense c-band semiconductor optical amplifier array. Each channel of the array exhibits a high output power greater than 22 dBm, with channel-to-channel uniformity better than 0.5 dB.

title: On the Performance of SMASH: a Non-Preemptive Window-Based Scheduler for Multiserver Jobs
authors: Diletta Olliaro, Sabina Rossi, Adityo Anggraito, Andrea Marin, Marco Ajmone Marsan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Parallel and Distributed Systems
abstract: The efficient execution of data center jobs that require simultaneous use of different resource types is of critical importance. When processing capacity is the crucial resource for jobs execution, the locution multiserver jobs is used, where the term server indicates processors or CPU cores providing processing capacity. Each multiserver job carries a requirement expressed in number of servers it requires to run, and service duration. Achieving efficient execution of multiserver jobs relies heavily on effective scheduling of jobs on the existing servers. Several schedulers have been proposed, aimed at improving resource utilization, at the cost of increased complexity. Due to the limited availability of theoretical results on scheduler behavior in the case of multiserver jobs, data center schedulers are often designed based only on managers' experience. In this paper, aiming to expand the understanding of the multiserver job schedulers' performance, we study Small Shuffle (SMASH) schedulers, a class of nonpreemptive, service time oblivious, window-based multiserver job scheduling algorithms that strike a balance between simplicity and efficient resource utiliza tion, while allowing performance evaluation in simpler settings. SMASHimplies only a marginal increase in complexity compared to FIFO, yet it delivers substantial performance improvements for multiserver jobs. Depending on the system parameters, SMASH can nearly double the system's stability region with respect to FIFO, leading to significantly lower response times across a broad region of loads. Moreover, the magnitude of this improvement scales with the chosen window size, allowing performance to be tuned to the system's operating conditions. We first study the capacity of SMASH with analytical tools in simple settings, then we investigate the performance of SMASH and other schedulers with simulations under more realistic workloads, designed with parameters derived from measurements of real data centers. Results show that SMASH offers a very good compromise between performance and complexity.

title: Variable Structure IPT System with Constant Current and Constant Voltage Output Characteristics
authors: Yajing Yang, Zhaowei Gong, Ningchao Zhang
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotics, Control and Automation Engineering (RCAE)
abstract: Inductive power transfer (IPT) technology is widely used in vehicle battery charging and it addresses the safety problems of traditional contact charging. To simplify the control of the charging system and to meet the requirement of constant current followed by constant voltage this paper introduces a variable structure compensation network. The compensation network in an IPT system is a high order resonant circuit with multiple resonant frequencies that enable load independent voltage and current outputs. This paper presents an analytical method for constant current and constant voltage using arbitrary higher order compensation networks. It also analyzes an IPT system based on a dual mode control strategy that switches between LCC-LCC and LCC-S compensation networks to achieve constant current and constant voltage outputs.

title: Applicability Evaluation of Synthetic Images for Performance Testing via Quality and Similarity Assessment
authors: Hajime Nada, Yoshimitsu Ogawa, Hidetsugu Uchida, Tetsushi Ohki, Shigefumi Yamada, Kazuhiko Sumi
publish: 2025 International Conference of the Biometrics Special Interest Group (BIOSIG)
abstract: With the growing prevalence of biometric recognition technology, the demand for diverse large-scale test datasets is significant, and data collection costs are increasing. Consequently, synthetic images attract attention as a potential solution. However, some synthetic images deviate from target representativeness; even if visually close, subtle alterations can negatively impact biometric recognition accuracy. To address the challenge, this paper introduces a novel Applicability Evaluation framework for synthetic images and biometric engines based on the image quality and score similarity. Synthetic Image Quality Assessment (SIQA) evaluates how closely synthetic images approximate target representativeness. Score Similarity Assessment (SSA) compares biometric engine scores and verifies identity similarity that is crucial for performance testing. Experimental results demonstrate that this framework effectively identified combinations of synthetic images and biometric engines that maintain recognition accuracy while ensuring the reliability of biometric performance testing. It can improve the trustworthiness and efficiency of biometric performance testing.

title: Defect Detection Method for Casting CT Images Improved Based on Yolov5
authors: Jinqiang Wang, Ruohai Di, Liangliang Li, Bing Liu, Peiyuan Zhang, Chuchao He
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotics, Control and Automation Engineering (RCAE)
abstract: In the field of industrial manufacturing, the integrity of metal castings is a key factor in ensuring the reliability of products. With the increasing complexity of industrial components and the rising production demands, it has become crucial to detect internal defects (such as pores, cracks and inclusions) in CT images of castings. Ignoring these defects may lead to serious equipment failures. This study proposes an improved casting defect detection algorithm based on yolov5. The improvement of yolov5 in this study mainly lies in adding a small target detection layer, including the addition of the Triplet Attention mechanism and the CA attention mechanism, so as to better represent the feature information of small targets. In addition, the detection effect of small targets is enhanced through data augmentation and the interference of complex backgrounds is reduced. The improved yolov5n model was compared with the original yolov5n model on the self-built dataset. The mAP increased by 2.8% and 3.4% respectively, showing certain advantages in defect detection of CT images of castings.

title: SystemVue-Based Method of Generating Interference Signals Directed Against Unmanned Aerial Vehicles with Dual Beidou and GPS Navigation
authors: Siyu Hu, Haiyang Sun, Ding Chen, Min Ji
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotics, Control and Automation Engineering (RCAE)
abstract: In this paper, we propose a method of generating interference signals directed against unmanned aerial vehicles with dual Beidou and GPS navigation based on SystemVue. First of all, according to the principles of the C/A code in the GPS system and the B1I code in the Beidou system, pseudo-random ranging codes of dual navigation system were designed. Next, we converted the simple navigation message into binary code and used a frequency modulator to simulate binary phase shift key modulation, so as to obtain the original launch signal. Subsequently, the generated spoofing interference signal is generated after adjusting the synchronization parameters of the pseudo-ranging code and carrier via a semi-physical simulation platform. As delineated above, a SystemVue software-based system for generating interference signals was developed. During the experiment, the pseudo-code Doppler frequencies increased by 0.1 Hz, carrier Doppler frequencies increased by 5 Hz, and the pseudo-code and carrier phases increased by 5 degrees. The generated interference signals were obtained correctly. Subsequent to demodulation, the data code exhibited a discrepancy from that of the original data code. The interference signals generated by the GPS system and the BDS system are similar in waveform, but the interference signal of the B1I code is more susceptible to interference. In summary, the designed interference signal can effectively disrupt the navigation performance of UAV under specific conditions.

title: Unsupervised Methods for UAV Engine Damage Scoring
authors: NingChao Zhang, ZeYu Zhang, TianLi Ma, Peng Wang, Lin Li, Chuan He
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotics, Control and Automation Engineering (RCAE)
abstract: To address the problem of in-service damage assessment for UAV engines, this paper proposes an unsupervised scoring-based modeling approach. Multidimensional features comprising three-axis vibration, temperature, and rotational speed are used as inputs to construct three models: Mahalanobis Distance, Autoencoder, and Kernel Density Estimation. These models quantify the deviation of each sample from the healthy state from the perspectives of statistical distribution, feature reconstruction, and probability density, respectively. Each method outputs a normalized damage score, where higher values indicate greater potential damage severity. The scores can be used independently or combined through weighted averaging to form a comprehensive evaluation result. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed approach can effectively characterize varying degrees of engine damage without requiring labeled data and exhibits strong generalization capability.

title: An Improved Particle Swarm Optimization Algorithm for Task Allocation
authors: Zhinan Liu, Xiaoning Ma, Haoran Gong, Yumeng Liang, Fanjun Meng, Yikai Zhang
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotics, Control and Automation Engineering (RCAE)
abstract: As a representative scenario in multi-UAV cooperative operations, the target encirclement mission imposes stringent requirements on the real-time performance and global optimality of task allocation. To address this challenge, an improved Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) algorithm is proposed for task allocation in multi-UAV target encirclement missions. Building upon the standard PSO framework, the proposed algorithm integrates a differential evolution-based crossover strategy to enhance population diversity, and incorporates a mutation mechanism to avoid premature convergence. In addition, a dynamic inertia weight adjustment scheme is employed to achieve an adaptive balance between global exploration and local exploitation, while an elite retention strategy is designed to preserve the best-found solution throughout the iteration process. An optimization model for the target encirclement mission is established accordingly. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed algorithm significantly outperforms conventional PSO and other classical allocation methods in terms of task completion rate, capture efficiency, and system coordination. These findings verify its effectiveness and adaptability in dynamic target encirclement mission scenarios.

title: Task Offloading in Hierarchical UAV Enabled MEC Network: A Trust Region Policy Optimization-Based Approach
authors: Tianqin Xiao, Conghui Lu, Xin Xu, Yang Zhang
abstract: With the explosion of multimedia applications and heterogeneous Internet of Things (IoT) devices in service under 5G, the flying ad hoc network (FANET), which acts as an edge server, is overwhelmed by traffic overload. Existing FANET architectures are incomplete for large-scale scenarios, and it is a challenge to optimize unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV) offloading decisions and coordinate within the network. In this article, we propose a novel three-layer computational framework for UAVs, which specifies the functions and roles of UAVs in the system. To analyze model performance quantitatively, the interactions of units and tasks are formulated as Markov decision processes (MDP). Then, we consider delay, energy and resource allocation to minimize the total system cost. To solve the problem, a multi-agent TRPO-based hierarchical computation and offloading (MATRPO-HCO) scheme is proposed to determine the optimal offloading decision for large-scale networks. Simulation results show that the proposed framework is superior to alternative schemes with respect to Quality of Service (QoS) and fairness.

title: Experimental Evaluation of AI-Augmented Cybersecurity Requirements Generation Leveraging LLMs’ Capabilities
authors: Juan C. Yelmo, Yod-Samuel Martín, Santiago Perez-Acuna
abstract: When it comes to cybersecurity requirements, catalogs of standard controls are a double-edged sword: they offer reusable resources applicable anywhere, yet they entail tedious, error-prone manual instantiation work. As the definitions of these cybersecurity controls are written in natural language, we analyze whether large language models (LLMs) may help automate that process. We ran an empirical evaluation where frontier versions of LLaMa, Qwen, Mixtral, and GPT were asked, leveraging best prompting practice, to generate cybersecurity requirements for a realistic system, departing from its functional specification plus definitions of abstract cybersecurity controls extracted from ISO/IEC 27002. We compared the results to a ground truth created by human experts, and a gold standard pooled from the aggregation of all human- and LLM-produced results, considering phenomena such as hallucinations, new requirements discovered by LLMs, or partial overlaps. Results show that open-weights LLMs can parallel human experts in coverage and help uncover additional requirements when used under human-in-the-loop curation. Relative F2 score against the gold standard (prioritizing recall over precision) reached 1.14× in the best LLM configuration (in comparison to human experts): a LLaMa 3.1 405B model, prompted with an explicit chain-of-thought pipeline made of three sequential steps and four parallel and coalesced runs, and moderate values for hyperparameters that balance diversity and determinism. Our work contributes a benchmark of applied capabilities of LLMs for security by design in non-code artifacts. Although recall values leave room for improvement as LLMs advance, results provide initial evidence that this approach is feasible in our case study.

title: An Energy-Aware Offline-Online Co-Design Framework for Robust Sensor Management in Wireless Sensor Networks
authors: Heng Li
abstract: This paper proposes an energy-aware offline-online co-design framework for robust sensor management in Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs). The goal is to optimize the trade-off among energy consumption, the number of active sensors, and estimation accuracy, while ensuring rapid recovery from dynamic disturbances like node failures and deceptive attacks. The framework integrates an offline Hybrid Initialization Greedy Sensor Selection (HIGSS) algorithm to select a robust and efficient initial sensor set, and an Online Sensor Replacement (OSR) mechanism for lightweight runtime maintenance. Comprehensive experimental results verify that the proposed co-design framework achieves superior performance in network lifetime, energy efficiency, and recovery capability compared to conventional approaches.

title: A dual-stage reconstruction and optimization deep learning framework for generating high-precision seamless precipitable water vapor across the mainland United States
authors: Chaoqian Xu, Xiuguang Yao, Yibin Yao, Qi Zhang, Xiongwei Ma, Yuqing Liu, Yunzheng Huang, Yiyang Zhao, Zheyan Liu, Liang Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Precipitable water vapor (PWV) is critical to global climate dynamics, the terrestrial water cycle, and extreme weather events. However, current Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) near-infrared (NIR) PWV products suffer from low accuracy, vulnerability to clouds, and incomplete spatiotemporal coverage. Therefore, we propose a dual-stage reconstruction and optimization deep learning framework that fuses MODIS NIR remote sensing data with Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) observations to generate high-precision, large-scale, and spatially continuous PWV. Firstly, a cascaded spatiotemporal generative adversarial network (CSTGAN) was developed to reconstruct PWV in cloud-contaminated regions using the clear MODIS PWV, generating seamless reconstructed PWV. Secondly, an optimization model based on a random forest method was applied to correct the reconstructed PWV by GNSS-derived PWV, yielding final enhanced accuracy PWV . The CSTGAN integrates spatial and temporal reconstruction modules within a generative adversarial network architecture, enabling a cascade learning mechanism to capture complex spatiotemporal patterns. The study focuses on the mainland United States from 2018 to 2023. During reconstruction, the CSTGAN achieves a Pearson correlation coefficient (R) exceeding 0.98 and a root mean square error (RMSE) below 1.39 mm on the test sets under 70% artificial masking rates when comparing the masked regions of reconstructed dataset with their clear-sky MODIS counterparts. After optimization, the final seamless PWV exhibit an R of 0.97 and RMSE of 2.97 mm against independent GNSS validation data, representing a 44.5% RMSE reduction compared to the reconstructed PWV product. This approach overcomes the critical limitation of MODIS NIR PWV unavailability under cloud conditions, significantly enhancing the utility of satellite-derived PWV. The resulting 1km resolution, seamless PWV advance hydrological cycle analysis, climate monitoring, meteorological retrievals, and atmospheric delay correction, offering transformative potential for Earth system science research and applications.

title: Research on Multispectral Radiation Thermometry Based on the IWOA-DEPSO Hybrid Optimization Algorithm
authors: GuoXiang Zhou, NingChao Zhang, ZeYu Zhang, ZeKai Liu, YaJing Yang, WeiJie Zheng
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotics, Control and Automation Engineering (RCAE)
abstract: To address the limitations of traditional solving methods in temperature inversion models, this paper proposes an efficient and accurate novel hybrid optimization algorithm-the IWOA-DEPSO algorithm - for multispectral temperature inversion. By combining the strengths and weaknesses of the two algorithms, the temperature values obtained by the IWOA algorithm are used as the initial points for the DEPSO algorithm. This approach integrates the strong convergence of the IWOA algorithm with the high stability, speed, and solution robustness of the DEPSO algorithm, thereby overcoming the poor solving stability of the IWOA algorithm and resolving the difficulty in determining initial values for the DEPSO algorithm. As a result, high-precision, high-speed, and highly stable temperature inversion for high-impact radiation fields is achieved. To verify the universality of the proposed algorithm, five spectral channels were selected for temperature inversion, and the results were compared with those obtained by other algorithms. The simulation results demonstrate that the proposed algorithm offers advantages such as high inversion accuracy and fast inversion speed, providing a new solution for data processing in multispectral hightemperature measurements.

title: Mutually-orthogonal-plane-based Optical-flow-regulated Diffusion Model for Stationary Head CT Reconstruction
authors: Qi Wang, Weiwen Wu, Fenglin Liu, Yufang Cai, Yueh Z. Lee, Youzuo Lin, Zirong Li, Yinan Feng, Jianping Lu, Christina R. Inscoe, Ge Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Radiation and Plasma Medical Sciences
abstract: Stationary head CT (sHCT) plays a critical role in detecting intracranial lesions. However, its fixed gantry restricts projection angles and undermines reconstruction accuracy. Recent studies have shown that score-based generative models (SGMs) can restore high-quality images from limited projections in two-dimensional (2D) limited-angle CT. Extending SGMs to three-dimensional (3D) sHCT is still challenging, as achieving high-resolution images without incurring excessive computational cost remains an open problem. To address this challenge, this study proposes a mutually orthogonal plane-based optical-flow-regulated (MOPO) diffusion model that effectively balances sampling efficiency and reconstruction accuracy. Specifically, we establish a 3D artifact-aware framework that incorporates a cross-plane attention mechanism to explicitly model and mitigate inter-slice artifact propagation. Furthermore, we design a mutually orthogonal plane-based (MOP) accelerated sampler capable of reducing the sampling process to as few as 10–20 steps. This approach achieves up to a 160× speedup while maintaining high reconstruction accuracy. To ensure global consistency, an anisotropic optical flow regularization is introduced, constructing non-rigid displacement fields between adjacent slices for structural coherence. Experimental results demonstrate that the MOPO-based framework outperforms existing methods in artifact suppression, detail preservation, and computational efficiency, providing a novel solution for high-fidelity and accelerated sHCT reconstruction.

title: The Impact of Smart Manufacturing Capabilities on Business Model Innovation in Manufacturing Enterprises
authors: Tongtong Geng, Yueping Du, Jinghong Lan, Jiangyue Qu, Yong Jiang
abstract: With the rapid growth of the global economy and ongoing technological advancements, smart manufacturing has become a vital force driving industrial transformation. This study investigates how smart manufacturing capability influences business model innovation (BMI) in manufacturing enterprises. It further examines the mediating role of new productive forces and the moderating effect of patient capital in this relationship. Despite the significance of smart manufacturing, existing research offers limited insight into its impact on BMI. To address this gap, this study collected data from manufacturing firms across various industries through a questionnaire survey. The data were analyzed using Structural Equation Modeling (SEM) and hierarchical regression analysis. The results show that smart manufacturing capability significantly promotes BMI. This indicates that advancements in smart manufacturing can drive innovation by optimizing production processes, improving resource efficiency, and enhancing market responsiveness. Moreover, new productive forces serve as a key mediator in this relationship, suggesting that enhanced smart manufacturing capabilities improve firms' production efficiency and innovation capacity, thereby facilitating business model transformation. Patient capital also plays a significant moderating role, demonstrating that long-term resource investment and strategic persistence amplify the positive effects of smart manufacturing on innovation. To ensure the rigor of the study, four robustness checks were conducted: substitute variable tests, subsample analyses, lag effect tests, and multicollinearity diagnostics. All results confirmed the stability of the core conclusions. This study provides a new theoretical perspective on the relationship between smart manufacturing and BMI. It also offers empirical support for research on technology enablement in engineering management and provides practical guidance for the digital transformation of manufacturing enterprises.

title: Secrecy Capacity of Power Beacon Assisted Short Packet Wireless Networks in the Presence of Multiple Eavesdroppers
authors: Abdullah Al Noman, Md. Zahurul Islam Sarkar, Abid Hasan
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Information and Communication Technology (EICT)
abstract: Power Beacon (PB)-assisted short packet wireless networks refer to systems where energy limited transmitters first harvest wireless power from a dedicated PB before transmitting short confidential data packets under strict latency constraints. In this paper, we explore the secrecy performance of such networks in the presence of multiple eavesdroppers. Specifically, we develop a novel closed form mathematical expression for the ergodic secrecy capacity (ESC) over Nakagami-m fading channels, which captures the joint effect of wireless energy transfer and fading dynamics. The accuracy of the analytical findings is further validated through Monte-Carlo simulations, showing excellent agreement with the theoretical results. Our results demonstrate that optimizing the fading parameters and channel configurations significantly enhances secrecy capacity, particularly at high transmit signal-to-noise ratio (SNR), while also revealing the existence of an optimal energy harvesting length for secure transmission. This study not only establishes a solid theoretical foundation for secrecy in PB-assisted short packet systems but also provides valuable guidelines for designing secure, ultra reliable, and energy efficient Internet of Things (IoT) and wireless networks.

title: Microchannel Cooling for Performance Enhancement of GaN-on-Si HEMT With a Low Rj-a of 13.5 K/W
authors: Jiajun Zhou, Xin Feng, Weihang Zhang, Kui Dang, Yachao Zhang, Zeyang Ren, Yanjing He, Xianhe Liu, Hong Zhou, Zhihong Liu, Yue Hao, Jincheng Zhang
publish: IEEE Journal of the Electron Devices Society
abstract: Gallium nitride (GaN) is a high-performance wide bandgap semiconductor material with unique physical and chemical properties such as higher breakdown electric field, higher electron density, superior electron mobility and saturation velocity. These properties endow GaN with unparalleled advantages in high-frequency and high-power applications. However, a primary challenge faced by the industrialized GaN HEMT is thermal management, particularly in handling higher power densities, which leads to a serious degradation in electrical performance and long-term reliability. In this study, electrothermal analysis for GaN HEMT is conducted based on two thermal resistance models for natural air cooling and microchannel cooling, proving a minimum 40% reduction in Rj-a using microchannel cooling and an optimal coolant flow rate to guide the actual experiment. Furthermore, the experimental result shows that microchannel cooling technology significantly enhances the thermal convection capacity, resulting in a 35.2% increase in the saturation current. Moreover, the Rj-a can be reduced to 13.5 K/W with 65% improvement at a cooling flow rate of 460 mL/min, and the surface heat flux density reaches 2200 W/cm2, which is 106% higher than that of natural air cooling.

title: IPv6 Target Generation Driven by Fine-tuned Large Language Model
authors: Xingqi Cheng, Shan Jing, Liang Jiao, Chuan Zhao, Hongjuan Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: The rapid advancement of the Internet has brought the exploration and management of the IPv6 address space to the forefront of network research. With its 128-bit addressing scheme, IPv6 provides approximately 340 undecillion addresses, effectively mitigating the address exhaustion issue inherent in IPv4. The immense address space of IPv6 renders traditional brute-force scanning, once effective for IPv4, no longer feasible. This challenge calls for the development of efficient and precise IPv6 address generation methods to ensure the stability and security of the Internet. To tackle this challenge, this study introduces an innovative IPv6 address generation method leveraging a fine-tuned Large Language Model (LLM), enhanced by the vLLM inference framework to improve generation efficiency. This approach leverages the strong learning and generalization capabilities of LLMs to effectively handle the complexities of IPv6 address generation. We begin with an initial classification of IPv6 addresses to reduce the model’s learning complexity. Next, we curate a fine-tuning dataset and apply the LoRA technique to fine-tune the Qwen-7B-chat model. The results show that the fine-tuned LLM outperforms existing methods in generating IPv6 addresses, especially in terms of generation speed and accuracy.

title: A novel metrology-informed framework for critical nodes identification in sensing and measurement networks
authors: Xueyin Huang, Xiaohui Jing
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on System Reliability and Safety Engineering (SRSE)
abstract: The identification of critical nodes in sensing and measurement networks is vital for system resilience. Traditional methods, based solely on network topology, often overlook the uncertainty inherent in these assessments. This study introduces a Metrology-informed Criticality Index (MCI) that evaluates nodes not only by their sensitivity (functional impact upon failure) but also by their robustness (stability of their importance ranking under network perturbations). We validate the MCI through attack simulations on synthetic scale-free networks. Results demonstrate that attacks targeting nodes identified by our MCI lead to a more rapid and severe degradation of network performance compared to those using degree or betweenness centrality. This work provides a more reliable and practical tool for prioritizing the protection of critical assets in infrastructure monitoring systems.

title:
ICasA: 3D Object Detection Model with Feature Enhancement and Uncertainty Modeling
                    <sup>*</sup>
authors: Huaiqing He, Yujia Zhai, Haohan Liu, Kanghua Hui
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: ICasA addresses the issue of insufficient spatial feature extraction, which hinders detection accuracy, by making the following improvements to CasA. Focal sparse convolution is introduced to enhance its 3D backbone network, optimizing the information flow extraction between non-empty voxel feature locations. Additionally, a multi-scale feature attention fusion module is created and embedded into the 2D backbone network. This mechanism first uses convolutions with varying strides to deepen the network structure and enhance global feature extraction capabilities, and then improves the feature attention fusion means, dynamically activating features at different scales and positions while retaining the original feature maps. Next, a dual-threshold control focal sparse convolution is introduced in the fourth stage of the 3D backbone network of CasA in order to suppress small object noise and control the expansion of voxels, thereby effectively enhancing the feature representation of small objects. Meanwhile, to overcome the stronger annotation instability for small objects, the IoU-DE module is proposed. On the KITTI dataset, the ICasA model achieves a 1.68% improvement in mAP compared to CasA, with the 3D average precision (AP@R40) for pedestrians and cyclists improving by 3.14% and 2.17%, respectively. Furthermore, compared to existing advanced methods, ICasA demonstrates more stable detection performance across all object categories.

title: Green Procurement Oriented Carbon Emission Accounting for Power Grid Enterprises
authors: Changtao Xie, Lin Deng, Zhitao Tang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Mobile Networks and Wireless Communications (ICMNWC)
abstract: Under the background of global climate governance and national carbon neutrality strategies, green procurement has become a core initiative for power grid enterprises to drive the low-carbon transition of their supply chains. However, the effective implementation of green procurement faces severe challenges due to the lack of standardized carbon emission accounting methodologies for grid materials. To addresses this issue, we propose an innovative Multi-level Hybrid Carbon Accounting Model (MH-CAM) based on an in-depth analysis of typical grid materials. The model establishes a scientific “cradle-to-gate” accounting boundary, identifies key emission drivers, and integrates a tiered calculation framework with a hybrid engine combining the IPCC method, mass-balance principles, and a novel tiered electricity carbon accounting approach. The outcomes of this research not only address the gap in supply chain carbon accounting standards within the power industry, but also accelerate the green transformation of the entire power industry value chain.

title: Bounded Sub-Optimal Algorithms for Teamwise Cooperative Multi-Agent Path Finding
authors: Zhenlong Fang, Yilin Cai, Zhongqiang Ren
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Multi-Robot and Multi-Agent Systems (MRS)
abstract: Multi-Agent Teamwise Cooperative Path Finding (TC-MAPF) seeks collision-free paths for the agents from their start to goal locations. In addition, agents are grouped into multiple teams, and each team has its own objective function to optimize. TC-MAPF arises in scenarios such as the coordination of multiple autonomous vehicles at a signal-free traffic intersection, where, for example, the vehicles from each direction naturally forms a team. TC-MAPF was recently studied and optimal planners such as TC-CBS has been developed. While being able to find all Pareto-optimal solutions for TC-MAPF, these optimal planners usually suffer from limited scalability as the number of agents grows. This paper develops a bounded sub-optimal planner TC-CBS-TF for TC-MAPF, trading off solution quality for scalability, by leveraging and extending several bounded sub-optimal search techniques for MAPF to handle multiple teams as in TC-MAPF. We test TC-CBS-TF and baselines on various maps with up to 50 agents, and TC-CBS-TF achieves up to 68 % higher success rates.

title: A Comparative Study on the Efficiency of Doped/Undoped Graphene Nanoribbon-GNR and Copper Interconnects at 16nm Technology
authors: Sandip Bhattacharya, Subhajit Das, Abir J Mondal
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Intelligent Signal Processing and Effective Communication Technologies (INSPECT)
abstract: This study conducts a comparative evaluation of graphene nanoribbon (GNR) interconnects-both pristine and doped-against traditional copper (Cu) interconnects, with a focus on propagation delay and power consumption. Using 16 nm technology, the analysis involves four interconnect materials: Cu, pristine GNR, lithium (Li)-doped GNR, and ferric chloride (FeCl<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>)-doped GNR. A ten-stage CMOS inverter chain is employed to assess performance. Results indicate that pristine GNR achieves significantly lower delay, approximately 2.2-3.5 times less than Cu, 1.8-2 times less than FeCl<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>-doped GNR, and 1.54-1.7 times less than Li-doped GNR. Additionally, pristine GNR consumes the least power at $1.8 \mu \mathrm{~W}$, compared to $\mathrm{Cu}(6.34 \mu \mathrm{~W})$, Li-doped GNR $(3.66 \mu \mathrm{~W})$, and FeCl<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>-doped GNR ($4.2 \mu \mathrm{~W}$) for a $10 \mu \mathrm{~m}$ interconnect length. These findings underscore the potential of pristine GNR as a highly promising material for next-generation AI and IoT-focused chip designs in nanoscale technologies.
