title: Transformer-Based Rapid Impedance Matching Optimization for Large-Scale 5G Antenna Arrays
authors: Zhiqi Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th International Conference on Power, Intelligent Computing and Systems (ICPICS)
abstract: In 5G systems, large-scale antenna arrays still face challenges in impedance matching efficiency, including the inefficiency of traditional tuning methods, reliance on manual adjustments, and difficulties in processing complex, high-dimensional inputs. This paper proposes a fast impedance matching optimization method that integrates Transformer models with electromagnetic theory. The model takes the S11 reflection coefficient of the antenna array as input and predicts optimal matching circuit parameters through deep learning, enabling efficient and automated matching processes. To verify the effectiveness of the proposed method, we conducted simulations on patch antenna arrays using HFSS, generating training and test datasets. The proposed Transformer architecture incorporates multi-scale shared encoders and local linear layers, enhancing its ability to capture global and local impedance trends. Experimental results show that only 2000 samples can significantly improve model performance. During the training phase, the model's loss gradually converged as the number of iterations increased. Using S11 samples from the test set for predictions, the mean squared error (MSE) of six-dimensional component values decreased from 0.447 to 0.172, while the mean absolute error (MAE) reduced from 0.461 to 0.298. These achievements demonstrate the feasibility and effectiveness of this method in large-scale impedance matching tasks.

title: Cooperative Edge Content Caching With Popularity Prediction in UAV-Assisted Vehicular Networks
authors: Qichao Xu, Mengzhen Cheng, Jie Jin, Zhou Su, Dongfeng Fang, Yuntao Wang, Yuan Wu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering
abstract: Edge content caching is a key enabler of low-latency multimedia delivery (e.g., short videos and images) in unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV)-assisted vehicular networks (UVNs). Nevertheless, UVNs still face substantial challenges in achieving efficient delivery under stringent latency constraints, mainly due to UAVs' limited onboard storage and the highly dynamic nature of content popularity. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a cooperative edge content caching scheme for UVNs. Specifically, we first present a hierarchical caching framework driven by popularity prediction. Highly popular content is replicated across all UAVs, whereas low-to-medium-popularity content is cooperatively distributed among them. To forecast popularity, we design a two-module predictor that couples a long short-term memory (LSTM) network, which captures temporal request patterns, with an attention mechanism that adaptively reweights salient contextual features. We further model cooperative interactions among UAVs as a coalition-formation game that incentivizes collaborative caching of low-to-medium-popularity content. Within this game, we develop a stable coalition-partition formation algorithm to enable mutually beneficial cooperation, and a dynamic-programming-based greedy algorithm to derive near-optimal caching decisions for UAVs within each coalition. Finally, extensive experiments demonstrate that the proposed approach substantially improves popularity-prediction accuracy and effectively incentivizes cooperative caching, thereby enhancing overall content-delivery efficiency in UVNs.

title: Using Multiple Model Fusion and Attention Mechanism to Recognize Autism based on Facial Images
authors: Ru Chen, Weiyang Chen, Yi Pan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is a neurodevelopmental condition typically emerging in early childhood, characterized by challenges in social interaction, communication deficits, restricted interests, and repetitive behavioral patterns. While no complete cure exists, early intervention remains critical for symptom management and skill development in affected children. Traditional diagnostic approaches depend on clinical assessments by mental health experts following established criteria, yet these methods are constrained by subjectivity, prolonged evaluation periods, and high costs. Aiming at the problem that most of the existing studies use a single deep learning model to classify autistic facial images with insufficient accuracy, this study presents an innovative deep learning framework MFAN that combines pre-trained VGG16 and MobileNetV2 architectures with a Convolutional Block Attention Module (CBAM). By exploiting the discriminative facial features distinguishing autistic and neurotypical individuals, the proposed model aims to classify ASD status using facial images. Evaluation metrics include accuracy, precision, and recall. After rigorous training and validation protocols, the MFAN model achieved 92.67% test accuracy and an AUC-ROC of 0.9635. These results outperform standalone VGG16 and MobileNetV2 models and their simple combinations, demonstrating enhanced classification efficacy. The findings highlight the potential of deep transfer learning for scalable ASD screening, offering a promising tool for early detection in population-level contexts.

title: Bin2Vec: Interpretable and Auditable Multi-View Binary Analysis for Code Plagiarism Detection
authors: Moussa Moussaoui, Tarik Houichime, Abdelalim Sadiq
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Advanced Communication Technologies and Networking (CommNet)
abstract: We introduce Bin2Vec, a new framework that helps compare software programs in a clear and explainable way. Instead of focusing only on one type of information, Bin2Vec combines what a program looks like (its built-in functions, imports, and exports) with how it behaves when it runs (its instructions and memory usage). This gives a more complete picture when deciding whether two programs are similar or not. Bin2Vec represents these different types of information as views that can be inspected separately using easy-to-read charts, and then brings them together into an overall similarity score. Bin2Vec acts as a bridge between binary representations and machine learning techniques by generating feature representations that can be efficiently processed by machine-learning models. We tested Bin2Vec on multiple versions of two well-known Windows programs, PuTTY and 7-Zip. The primary results strongly confirmed that our method compute an optimal and visualization-friendly representation of the analyzed software. For example, PuTTY versions showed more complex behavior and memory activity, while 7-Zip versions focused more on performance-related patterns. Overall, Bin2Vec provides decisions that are both reliable and explainable to humans. Because it is modular and easy to extend, it can be applied to tasks like auditing, verifying software origins, or quickly screening large numbers of programs in cybersecurity and reverse-engineering work.

title: Path-Based Explanation for Temporal Knowledge Graph Completion
authors: Ziyi Chen, Chenxi Zhu, Ye Wang, Aiping Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th International Conference on Data Science in Cyberspace (DSC)
abstract: In the digital age, temporal knowledge graphs (TKGs) have emerged as powerful tools for representing dynamic knowledge by incorporating a temporal dimension to capture changes in entities and relationships over time. However, existing temporal knowledge graph completion (TKGC) models often operate as black boxes, lacking the ability to explain their reasoning processes. This paper proposes Temporal Power-Link (TePo-Link), a prototype system based on an improved Power-Link algorithm that integrates temporal information to generate clear and intuitive explanatory reasoning paths for TKG completion. The system consists of a Quadruple Edge Scorer (QES), a path enforcing learning module, and a path generation module. Experimental results demonstrate that TePo-Link can generate high-quality explanatory paths, enhancing the transparency and credibility of the models. Analysis of the temporal distribution on the reasoning paths and ablation experiments further reveal the dynamic characteristics of the models, providing a basis for model optimization.

title: Thermal-Dynamic-Constrained Steering Angle Tracking Strategy for Steer-By-Wire System in Heavy-Duty Commercial Vehicles
authors: Shuxin Tao, Yuewei Hu, Han Dong, Jiaqi Li, Yahui Liu, Xuewu Ji
publish: 2025 9th CAA International Conference on Vehicular Control and Intelligence (CVCI)
abstract: To address the coupled constraint of steering dynamic response and thermal safety in heavy-duty commercial vehicle Steer-by-Wire (SBW) systems, this study proposes a steering angle tracking strategy that jointly ensures dynamic performance and motor thermal protection. A trajectory smoother is first designed to generate feasible reference profiles within the temperature-constrained dynamic limits of the actuator. A multi-objective Linear Quadratic Regulator (LQR) controller integrated with an extended state observer (ESO) is then employed to enhance tracking accuracy and suppress disturbances caused by load variations. Finally, a thermal protection module based on a simplified dual-node thermal network predicts winding temperature in real time and adaptively adjusts the motor current limit via a PD controller to prevent overheating. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed strategy effectively reduces control saturation and improves tracking performance while maintaining thermal safety, thereby enhancing the robustness and reliability of SBW systems under high-load conditions.

title: Latra: A Template-Based Language-Agnostic Transformation Framework for Effective Program Reduction
authors: Zhenyang Xu, Yiran Wang, Yongqiang Tian, Mengxiao Zhang, Chengnian Sun
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: Essential for debugging compilers and interpreters, existing reduction tools face a fundamental trade-off. Language-Specific reducers, such as C-Reduce and ddSMT, offer highly effective reductions but require substantial engineering effort for each target language. Conversely, language-agnostic reducers, like Vulcan, sacrifice effectiveness for broad applicability.To bridge this gap, we present Latra, a novel template-based framework that balances both aspects, enabling general, effective, targeted program reduction. Latra combines language-agnostic reduction with user-defined, language-specific transformations. It facilitates user-defined transformations through a user-friendly domain-specific language based on simple matching and rewriting templates. This minimizes the need for deep formal grammar knowledge. Latra empowers users to tailor reductions to specific languages with reduced implementation overhead.Our evaluation shows that Latra significantly outperforms Vulcan. On average, it reduces 33.77% more tokens in C and 9.17% more tokens in SMT-LIB, with 32.27% faster execution in SMT-LIB. Notably, Latra closely matches the effectiveness of language-specific reducers, i.e., C-Reduce and ddSMT (89 vs. 85, 103 vs. 109 tokens on average), while significantly reducing engineering effort (167 vs. 5,685, 62 vs. 118 lines of code). We strongly believe that Latra provides a practical and cost-efficient approach to program reduction, effectively balancing language-specific effectiveness with language-agnostic generality.

title: Federated Learning for Privacy-Preserving Biometric Authentication in Distributed Transportation Systems
authors: Dilip Kr. Barman, Dushmanta M. Kalita, Abhijit Boruah
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Intelligent Signal Processing and Effective Communication Technologies (INSPECT)
abstract: Biometric authentication systems in smart transportation networks face significant privacy challenges due to centralized data processing requirements. Conventional approaches compel authorities to privately share their raw biometric data, which in turn invites serious privacy dangers and presages looming legal compliance issues under GDRP & CCPA etc. This paper propose FedBioAuth, a prototype collaborative privacypreserving biometric authentication framework based on federated learning that facilitates the model training of FL among various transportation networks while preserving individual identification. Our approach combines federated deep learning with differential privacy mechanisms to train robust facial recognition models while keeping biometric data localized. Our prototype achieves 97.3% authentication accuracy across heterogeneous networks while providing formal privacy guarantees through $(\varepsilon, \delta)$-differential privacy with $\varepsilon=1.2$ and $\delta=10^{-5}$. Simulationbased evaluation over five transportation authorities shows that 95.3% anomaly detection accuracy with 80% communication overhead reduced compared to centralized approach. In addition to retaining an extremely high level of privacy preservation with a successful rate for reconstruction attacks lower than 0.3%, the system also provides two organizations to work together ensuring circumferential security from different perspectives.

title: Feedforward Neural Network Training by an enhanced Particle Swarm Optimization
authors: Divya Bairathi, Mithlesh Arya, Manju Lata Joshi, Shirish Nagar, Abha Jain, Megha Gupta
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Intelligent Signal Processing and Effective Communication Technologies (INSPECT)
abstract: Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) is a widely-known metaheuristic based swarm behavior observed intelligence. Although PSO is known for its excellent performance, it suffers from stagnation and low exploration. To alleviate these limitations, Random Opposition Based Learning (ROBL) has been incorporated-rated with PSO. The variant of PSO is named Random Opposition based Particle Swarm Optimization (ROPSO). ROPSO applied in neural network training for different datasets. The results present that ROPSO can approximate optimal solutions very effectively.

title: Motion Sickness Level Recognition in Real Road Driving via Multimodal Feature Fusion
authors: Jiahao Cheng, Ke Chen, Yangbin Jin, Gang Guo, Wenbo Li
publish: 2025 9th CAA International Conference on Vehicular Control and Intelligence (CVCI)
abstract: As the electric vehicle industry grows, passengers' expectations for ride comfort are increasing. However, while electric vehicles provide passengers with intelligent, convenient and economical travel, they also lead to an increase in the probability of motion sickness. The problem of motion sickness has become a shackle limiting the development of electric vehicles, and the solution to the problem of motion sickness first requires accurate identification of the degree of motion sickness. To address this need, this paper proposes a multimodal identification model of occupant motion sickness level based on individual motion sickness attributes, physiological parameters and vehicle driving parameters. In order to verify the effectiveness of the model, this paper designs and implements a real-vehicle motion sickness inducing experiment, which collects a large amount of subjective data, physiological data, and vehicle driving data of the occupants. The experimental results show that the accuracy of the multimodal recognition model can reach 84.67 %. In addition, the validity of the fusion model was further verified by ablation experiments, and the results showed that the model has high reliability and validity in practical applications, which provides a strong technical support for the solution of the motion sickness problem in electric vehicles.

title: Shrunk, Yet Complete: Code Shrinking-Resilient Android Third-Party Library Detection
authors: Jingkun Zhang, Jingzheng Wu, Xiang Ling, Tianyue Luo, Bolin Zhou, Mutian Yang
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: Managing third-party libraries is a costly and critical task for enterprises, essential for both vulnerability assessment and license compliance. Existing android software composition analysis tools focus on mitigating code obfuscation but neglect the impact of code optimization, which is deeply integrated into build pipelines and disrupts library structure.To tackle these challenges, we developed LibSleuth, a detection tool designed to be resilient to code shrinking and obfuscation. It is based on the observation that even after shrinking, the remaining code still retains functional completeness. LibSleuth adopts two novel strategies: (1) Method level functional module matching: We break down feature matching to method level and define a functional module as related methods that represent used functionality. This allows us to detect libraries based on functional module completeness to address code shrinking. (2) Context-enhanced multi-level filtering: To improve robustness against obfuscation and reduce the cost of pairing, LibSleuth leverages contextual relationships to enhance feature stability and adopts a coarse-to-fine progressive matching process.We evaluated LibSleuth on datasets containing obfuscated and optimized Android apps. LibSleuth outperforms state-of-the-art academic and commercial tools in both scenarios. Under combined code shrinking and obfuscation, LibSleuth achieves an average 27.74% higher version level F1-score. Moreover, our analysis of 10,000 real world Android apps shows that 20.35% still depend on vulnerable library, demonstrating the practical utility of LibSleuth for downstream tasks.

title: Reinforcement Learning with Attention-based Multi-Scale Convolution Networks for Imperfect Information Games
authors: Weilin Yuan, Zhenzhen Hu, Jiaxing Chen, Shaofei Chen, Weiwei Zhao, Lina Lu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Game theory plays a pivotal role in addressing Imperfect Information Games (IIGs), having given rise to the development of a suite of superhuman agents. However, constructing information sets and game trees in game theory approaches restricts the transferability of strategies. Recently, Reinforcement Learning (RL) has been introduced from the perfect information game to IIG, owing to its generalization capabilities. Yet, the challenges of efficient feature abstraction and stable learning within the RL paradigm persist. To address these challenges, we explore a stable actor-critic training framework with knowledge distillation based on supervised learning to enhance proximal policy optimization in strategy learning (MCA-PPO). For feature extraction, we engineer a multi-scale convolutional neural network that amalgamates local feature information across various receptive field sizes, unearthing the latent information embedded within potential feature sequences. We refine the network architecture further by integrating it with an attention mechanism, enabling it to discern relationships between feature channels and to autonomously identify the essence of multi-scale features. Regarding strategy learning, we employ the knowledge distillation technique to mitigate the instability inherent in proximal policy optimization, thereby hastening the progression of strategic learning. Finally, we conducted a systematic and comprehensive analysis of the MCA-PPO algorithm through a series of experiments on Teax Hold’em poker, showing the efficacy and transferability of the MCA-PPO framework.

title: Understanding Resource Injection Vulnerabilities in Kubernetes Ecosystems
authors: Defang Bo, Jie Lu, Feng Li, Jingting Chen, Jinchen Wang, Chendong Yu, Yeting Li, Wei Huo
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: Cloud-native technologies have revolutionized application development, with Kubernetes emerging as the de facto standard platform for containerization and orchestration. Kubernetes manages applications through API objects called resources, where users declare desired states via resource definitions that are processed by controllers to reconcile system discrepancies. However, this resource-based architecture introduces resource injection vulnerabilities, where controllers perform privileged operations using user-controllable fields without adequate validation. Attackers can exploit these weaknesses by injecting malicious content into resource fields to achieve unauthorized access and privilege escalation.In this paper, we conduct the first comprehensive study on 125 resource injection vulnerabilities from 8,306 Kubernetes-related vulnerabilities across common databases. For all studied vulnerabilities, we investigate their vulnerable fields, root causes, privileged operations, exploitation conditions, and fixing strategies. Our study reveals many interesting findings that can guide the detection and mitigation of resource injection vulnerabilities, as well as the development of more secure cloud-native applications.

title: YOLOv8-CTCD: An Improved YOLOv8 for Cherry Tomato Cluster Detection in Robotic Harvesting
authors: Gang Wang, Shanglei Chai, Zhiyuan Zhang, Zhi Zeng, Yibin Tian
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Cherry tomato harvesting is generally performed manually. Robotic harvesting is gaining increasing interest from both academia and industry. This paper proposes a cherry tomato cluster detection algorithm based on YOLOv8, named YOLOv8-CTCD. First, the YOLOv8 input channels are adjusted to enable 4-channel RGB-D images as input. Subsequently, a CARAFE-M module is designed to replace the upsampling method in YOLOv8n. It maintains a lightweight architecture while achieving a larger receptive field, allowing effective aggregation of contextual information. In addition, it assigns greater weight to more important features. Moreover, a C2f-MLCA module is introduced into YOLOv8, which integrates information from feature maps at different levels and enhances the network’s capability of feature extraction. It also integrates the SPPELAN module to strengthen its feature fusion capability. YOLOv8-CTCD has been evaluated using a private cherry tomato dataset obtained from a greenhouse farm. The experimental results show that it achieves an mAP@50 of 93.8% and an mAP@50:90 of 68%, which represents improvements of 2.1% and 3% over YOLOv8n, respectively.

title: A Multi-Objective Optimization Method using DNN-NSGA-II for Recommending Milling Process Parameters
authors: Jiajie Cui, Xuao Hou, Ming Chen, Shijin Zhang, Jialun Peng
publish: 2025 2nd International Symposium on AI and Cybersecurity (ISAICS)
abstract: To address the issue of complex surface milling, where process parameter selection relies heavily on manual experience and cannot guarantee optimality, a multiobjective optimization framework using DNN-NSGA-II is proposed. The methodology integrates data-driven modeling and optimization to achieve high-precision prediction and constraint-aware parameter optimization. Firstly, a highfidelity dataset of $\mathbf{4, 6 8 8}$ samples is generated via UG NX and VERICUT, which includes inputs for various process parameters as well as outputs for machining times and quality metrics. Secondly, a Deep Neural Network (DNN) surrogate model is trained based on the dataset. Employing a five-layer MLP architecture with GELU activation functions, the model achieves high-precision prediction of machining time, residual volume, and overcut volume on the test set. Finally, an improved NSGA-II multi-objective optimization algorithm integrates dynamic weighting and process constraints to balance efficiency and quality. Experiments on aerospace blade machining show that optimized parameters reduce machining time prediction error to $3 \%$. Residual deviation and overcut deviation are controlled at $35 \%$ and $77 \%$, respectively. And the weighting mechanism can effectively balance various machining efficiency and performance requirements. This optimization method provides an effective solution for optimizing process parameters in complex surface milling operations, significantly enhancing milling performance.

title: Learning Optimal Transport for GPU Allocation: A Deep Learning Approach to Efficient Resource Scheduling
authors: Chengze Du, Zhiwei Yu, Heng Xu, Haojie Wang, Bo Liu, Jialong Li
abstract: The widespread application of large language models (LLMs) has intensified the demand for GPU resources. Effective GPU resource scheduling and allocation lead to better task completion satisfaction in terms of response speed and completion rate. Current mainstream methods primarily rely on heuristic algorithms or optimization approaches for resource allocation. However, each has significant limitations: greedy algorithms lack global perspective, resulting in performance degradation; optimization methods involve high computational costs, making them unsuitable for real-time inference systems. To address these issues, we develop a hybrid method called Deep Optimal Transport (DOT), which combines the structure of optimal transport with deep learning. During the training phase, our approach learns mappings from states to optimal solutions, while in the inference phase, it efficiently obtains near-optimal allocation schemes through a single forward pass. Experiments show that compared to existing methods, our approach achieves higher task completion rates for user GPU inference tasks while maintaining lower methods making costs.

title: Towards a shift and sustain-based decoding architecture for Covert Visuospatial Attention BMI in a natural environment
authors: Paolo Forin, Stefano Tortora, Emanuele Menegatti, Luca Tonin
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Covert visuospatial attention (CVSA) enables users to direct focus without eye movements, offering a promising non-invasive control modality for brain-machine interface (BMI) systems. Traditional CVSA-based BMIs rely on decoding α-band electroencephalography (EEG) activity from whole-trial data, often overlooking the temporal dynamics of attentional processing. In this study, we propose a novel control framework that explicitly separates the CVSA task into two subcomponents: shift attention and sustained attention. EEG signals were recorded from nine participants performing a CVSA task in a real-world environment. Through spectral feature analysis and temporal segmentation, we identify distinct patterns associated with each subcomponent and train dedicated classifiers accordingly. Our pseudo-online analysis suggests that combining the outputs of two task-specific classifiers significantly improves both trial-level classification accuracy (by an average of +23.74%) and area under the curve (AUC) (by +4.49%) compared to the conventional approach. These findings suggest that modelling the temporal structure of CVSA can enhance decoding performance and offer a more robust foundation for attention-based BMI.

title: Modal Bandwidth and VCSEL Transmission Capability of Multimode Fibers at Long Wavelengths Including 980 nm and 1060 nm
authors: Xin Chen, Hao Dong, Hao Chen, Simit Patel, Meagan David, Ming-Jun Li
abstract: Through Monte Carlo simulation, we obtained the modal bandwidth of common types of multimode fibers at long wavelengths from 950-1090 nm. The VCSEL transmission reaches for 25/50/100G are calculated to provide guidance for relevant applications.

title: A Simple Narrow-Linewidth Brillouin Random Fiber Laser with a Rayleigh-Scattering-Assisted Linear Cavity
authors: Jinyang Hu, Pei Zhou, Kun Liu, Wenxin Chen, Nianqiang Li
abstract: A simple narrow-linewidth Brillouin random fiber laser (BRFL) with a Rayleigh-scattering-assisted linear cavity is proposed and experimentally demonstrated. The proposed scheme utilizes only a single spool of standard single-mode fiber (SMF) and a reflective mirror, achieving both Brillouin gain amplification (BGA) and random distributed feedback (RDF) within the same fiber segment. Experimental results indicate that the BRFL generates a single-longitudinal-mode laser output with a remarkably narrow linewidth of 514.98 Hz. This proposed scheme provides a compact and cost-effective solution for narrow-linewidth laser generation, with promising potential for applications in coherent light sources, optical communication, and optical sensing.

title: FedDLFA: A Robust Defense Mechanism Against Label-Flipping Attacks in Federated Learning
authors: Shiwen Hu, Changji Wang, Yuan Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Federated learning effectively safeguards data privacy by enabling local model training across multiple clients. However, it remains susceptible to label flipping attacks, which can significantly degrade the global model’s performance, even when the proportion of malicious clients is small. Existing defense methods often rely on assumptions regarding client data distribution or attacker proportions, which limits their effectiveness in real-world scenarios characterized by data heterogeneity and unknown attack scale. This paper introduces a novel and robust defense mechanism, FedDLFA. FedDLFA is grounded in a key insight: Due to the adversarial nature of the training objective, malicious clients exhibit significantly distinct neural activation patterns under standardized inputs compared to normal clients. FedDLFA extracts neural activation vectors from all client models, calculates their cosine similarity, constructs a similarity matrix, and applies clustering techniques to divide clients into two groups. Subsequently, it employs a density-size joint scoring mechanism to identify potential clusters of malicious clients. Experiments conducted on the MNIST, FMNIST, and CIFAR10 datasets, under both IID and Non-IID settings, demonstrate that FedDLFA achieves superior accuracy and effectively mitigates attack success rates compared to existing state-of-the-art methods.

title: Attention- and Uncertainty-based Enhancements to U-Net Model for Semantic Segmentation of Aerial Imagery for Land Cover Classification
authors: Kyawt Kyawt Htay, Jaya Sreevalsan-Nair
publish: 2025 International Conference on Robotics and Mechatronics (ICRM)
abstract: Deep learning solutions, particularly the U-Net model, are widely used for land cover classification (LCC) tasks in earth observation imagery. However, the applicability and extensibility of such models across different datasets are understudied. The goal of this study is to propose model enhancements for the U-Net and its variant U-Net++, namely, using squeeze-and-excitation for the attention mechanism, residual blocks for model convergence, and Bayesian learning for uncertainty estimation, for LCC. The systematic performance analysis of these models for two publicly available high-resolution aerial imagery datasets demonstrates the data- and model-dependent usability of the proposed enhancements. The baseline and proposed models are also compared with the state-of-the-art LCC segmentation models. This study concludes the merit of specific model enhancements and systematic studies to arrive at enhanced models.

title: Priority Region Guided Hybrid A* with Rich-Semantic Task Representation for Autonomous Mining Trucks in Open-Pit Mines
authors: Xiuyuan Li, Yafei Wang, Yichen Zhang, Ruoyao Li, Mingyu Wu, Jiyuan Zhang
publish: 2025 9th CAA International Conference on Vehicular Control and Intelligence (CVCI)
abstract: Efficient global path planning for autonomous mining trucks operating in open-pit mines is often hindered by irregular mountain shapes, stringent heading constraints, and long travel distances. Conventional planning algorithms either ignore the vehicle's non-holonomic constraints or demand prohibitive computational effort when the state space grows explosively. To overcome these difficulties, this paper introduces Priority Region Guided Hybrid A* (PR-HA*), a novel framework that tightly couples deep learning with classical heuristic search. First, a rich-semantic task representation that comprehensively encodes the planning task is fed into a semantic segmentation network to generate a dense probabilistic map of priority regions. Second, the binarized priority region is transformed into an informative heuristic that directly replaces the conventional obstacle-based term inside Hybrid A*. Field experiments conducted on a real shovel-loading platform demonstrate that PR-HA* significantly reduces expanded nodes and overall planning time compared with established baselines, while simultaneously delivering shorter, smoother, and kinematically feasible paths.

title: Semantic SZZ: Mitigating the Impact of Misclassified Corrective Changes in Just-in-Time Software Defect Prediction
authors: Ronaldo C. Veras, George G. Cabral, Adriano L. I. Oliveira
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: In the evolving landscape of software engineering, accurate identification of defect-inducing commits is critical to improving software quality and reducing development costs. This paper revisits the widely adopted SZZ algorithm, which is utilized for labeling commits as clean or defect-inducing, to address one of its main limitations, i.e., its reliance on outdated corrective commits identification strategies. We propose an innovative approach that integrates the semantic understanding capability of the GPT OpenAI model into the SZZ flow to better interpret commit messages. Our experiments reveal, for some projects, a large number of commits incorrectly interpreted as defect-fixing, consequently, leading to the misclassification of commits as defect-inducing. As an example, for the Postgresql dataset, the number of defect-inducing commits was reduced in 21% when compared to the original SZZ. Furthermore, results of our experiments strongly suggest that, as a result of the proposed SZZ labeling process, the JIT-SDP problem has been shown to be more challenging than originally reported by previous works.

title: Research on the System Architecture of Communication Network in Virtual Live Art Exhibition
authors: Xiangjun Liu, Alex S. Hwang
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th International Conference on Power, Intelligent Computing and Systems (ICPICS)
abstract: This paper proposes a system architecture of virtual live art exhibition based on communication network optimization, with special attention to how to use intelligent algorithms to optimize bandwidth allocation to ensure the smooth operation of the system and the real-time nature of user interaction. The core innovation lies in the proposal of a bandwidth adaptive algorithm (UBSBA) based on user behavior prediction. The algorithm predicts the user's bandwidth demand in real time by analyzing the user's behavior pattern in the virtual exhibition, and dynamically adjusts the bandwidth allocation strategy to ensure the optimal utilization of network resources and the smoothness of the exhibition. To verify the effectiveness of the algorithm, this paper designs experiments including multiple evaluation indicators such as bandwidth utilization, delay, and response time, and compares them with the traditional fixed bandwidth allocation method. The experimental results show that the UBSBA algorithm can increase bandwidth utilization by about 20% and reduce delay by 30% in a multi-user concurrent environment, while greatly improving user experience and transaction completion rate. In addition, the stability and response speed of the system under high load conditions have also been significantly improved.

title: A Large Scale Study of AI-based Binary Function Similarity Detection Techniques for Security Researchers and Practitioners
authors: Jingyi Shi, Yufeng Chen, Yang Xiao, Yuekang Li, Zhengzi Xu, Sihao Qiu, Chi Zhang, Keyu Qi, Yeting Li, Xingchu Chen, Yanyan Zou, Yang Liu, Wei Huo
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: Binary Function Similarity Detection (BFSD) is a foundational technique in software security, underpinning a wide range of applications including vulnerability detection, malware analysis. Recent advances in AI-based BFSD tools have led to significant performance improvements. However, existing evaluations of these tools suffer from three key limitations: a lack of in-depth analysis of performance-influencing factors, an absence of realistic application analysis, and reliance on small-scale or low-quality datasets.In this paper, we present the first large-scale empirical study of AI-based BFSD tools to address these gaps. We construct two high-quality and diverse datasets: BinAtlas, comprising 12,453 binaries and over 7 million functions for capability evaluation; and BinAres, containing 12,291 binaries and 54 real-world 1-day vulnerabilities for evaluating vulnerability detection performance in practical IoT firmware settings. Using these datasets, we evaluate nine representative BFSD tools, analyze the challenges and limitations of existing BFSD tools, and investigate the consistency among BFSD tools. We also propose an actionable strategy for combining BFSD tools to enhance overall performance (an improvement of 13.4%). Our study not only advances the practical adoption of BFSD tools but also provides valuable resources and insights to guide future research in scalable and automated binary similarity detection.

title: Research on The Mechanical Similarity of Small-Scale Models of Train Bogie Frames
authors: Shi Huifeng, Lu Sisi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Sensing, Diagnostics, Prognostics, and Control
abstract: The mechanical behavior of train bogies during service is complex and variable. Using model experiments to simulate and analyze the service mechanical properties of the original structure is an important approach to achieve efficient and low-cost safe operation and maintenance management of trains as well as new product development. In this study, the frame of a high-speed train bogie was selected as the research object. Based on similarity theory and dimensional analysis method, the mechanical similarity criteria between the small-scale model and the prototype were constructed. Moreover, the prediction effects of two small-scale modeling methods—Grid Direct Scaling (GDS) and Geometric Scaling and Re-discrete (GSR)—on the mechanical properties of the prototype were in-vestigated. The results show that the small-scale frame model constructed by GDS has a higher similarity in static mechanical properties to the prototype. However, due to the existence of the strain rate effect, both small-scale models established by the two methods exhibit large errors in predicting the dynamic properties of the prototype.The research results can provide scientific and theoretical support for the structural design and model testing of train bogies.

title: Bitcoin Price Prediction: A Systematic Literature Review and Bibliometric Analysis
authors: Akhlis Munazilin, Mochamad Agung Wibowo, Rizky Parlika
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Information Technology, Information Systems and Electrical Engineering (ICITISEE)
abstract: Bitcoin price prediction has emerged as a critical research domain due to the asset's extreme volatility and growing financial significance. Despite the rapid increase in academic interest in this topic, the existing literature remains fragmented, with inconsistent methodologies and diverse evaluation metrics hindering the systematic accumulation of knowledge. To address this gap, this study conducted a Systematic Literature Review (SLR) combined with bibliometric analysis of 130 peer-reviewed scientific articles published between 2021 and 2025, retrieved from Scopus, IEEE Xplore, and EBSCO databases. We applied the PRISMA 2020 framework for study selection and used VOSviewer for keyword co-occurrence analysis and thematic clustering. Our findings revealed four dominant research clusters: (1) deep learning architectures (especially LSTM and its hybrid variants), (2) sentiment analysis from social media, (3) technical indicators and on-chain metrics, and (4) hybrid forecasting frameworks. We show that LSTM-based hybrid models (e.g., CNN-LSTM, Bi-LSTM with attention mechanism) consistently outperform other models in terms of RMSE and MAE, while XGBoost excels in price direction prediction accuracy. The integration of non-traditional data specifically, Twitter sentiment analyzed using contextual language models like roBERTa and on-chain metrics like MVRV significantly improves predictive performance. However, we also identify widespread methodological weaknesses, including the use of a random train-test split inappropriate for time-series data, the lack of out-of-sample validation, and the near-absence of economic evaluations (e.g., profitability, Sharpe ratio). Based on these findings, we propose a future research agenda focused on developing standardized benchmarks, realistic economic validation, and explainable AI (XAI) based frameworks to bridge the gap between academic models and practical applications in the crypto market.

title: Envisioning Intelligent Requirements Engineering via Knowledge-Guided Multi-Agent Collaboration
authors: Jiangping Huang, Dongmin Jin, Weisong Sun, Yang Liu, Zhi Jin
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: Requirements Engineering (RE) is an initial and critical phase in software development, with the aim of producing well-defined software requirements specifications (SRSs) from rough ideas of clients. It involves multiple tasks (e.g., elicitation, analysis) and roles (e.g., interviewer, analyst). With the rise of Large Language Models (LLMs), many studies have leveraged LLMs to support specific RE tasks. However, existing LLM-based agents often lack domain knowledge integration and fall short in simulating the complex collaboration of human experts across the full RE process. To address this gap, we propose KGMAF, a knowledge-guided multi-agent framework designed to assist requirements engineers in developing high-quality SRSs. KGMAF comprises six LLM-based agents and a shared artifact pool. Each agent is equipped with predefined actions, dedicated functions, and injected knowledge tailored to specific RE tasks. The artifact pool stores both intermediate and final artifacts, serving as a communication channel for inter-agent collaboration. A human-in-the-loop (HITL) mechanism is embedded to guide and validate agent outputs. We present the design of KGMAF, along with preliminary experiments and a case study to demonstrate its practicality. This work lays the foundation for future research on knowledge-driven multi-agent collaboration in RE and highlights key challenges in building trustworthy intelligent assistants for real-world RE tasks.

title: Generation of Tunable Phase-Coded Microwave Pulses Based on Active Mode-Locking Optoelectronic Oscillator
authors: Boxiong Cui, Chenyang Ma, Cheng Gu, Xinyu Jin, Wen Xie, Zhengyang Xie, Xin Zhao, Pengwei Gong, Zheng Zheng
abstract: We proposes and verifies a method for generating phase-coded microwave pulse signals based on Active Mode-Locking Optoelectronic Oscillator (AML-OEO). With the help of the AML-OEO, this scheme utilizes a phase modulator driven by phase-coded signals, where the duration of each voltage polarity code is the same as the OEO loop delay, generating phase-coded coherent microwave pulse trains. Such signals have the advantage of a large time-bandwidth product, which can balance the detection range and range resolution of radar, while also possessing characteristics such as anti-interference and low interception. In experiments, we obtained the phase-coded microwave pulse sequences using square waves and 7-bit Barker codes respectively.

title: Holistic Specification of the Human Digital Twin: Stakeholders, Users, Functionalities, and Applications
authors: Nils Mandischer, Alexander Atanasyan, Ulrich Dahmen, Michael Schluse, Jürgen Rossmann, Lars Mikelsons
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: The digital twin of humans is a relatively new concept. While many diverse definitions, architectures, and applications exist, a clear picture is missing on what, in fact, makes a human digital twin. Within this context, researchers and industrial use-case owners alike are unaware about the market potential of the-at the moment-rather theoretical construct. In this work, we draw a holistic vision of the human digital twin, and derive the specification of this holistic human digital twin in form of requirements, stakeholders, and users. For each group of users, we define exemplary applications that fall into the six levels of functionality: store, analyze, personalize, predict, control, and optimize. The functionality levels facilitate an abstraction of abilities of the human digital twin. From the manifold applications, we discuss three in detail to showcase the feasibility of the abstraction levels and the analysis of stakeholders and users. Based on the deep discussion, we derive a comprehensive list of requirements on the holistic human digital twin. These considerations shall be used as a guideline for research and industries for the implementation of human digital twins, particularly in context of reusability in multiple target applications.

title: Impact of DC Drift on Pairwise Maximum Likelihood Receiver with Single-FFT in Layered Asymmetrically Clipped Optical OFDM Systems
authors: Yamin Huang, Wenhui Ma, Xuezhi Hong
abstract: The impact of DC drift on the performance of the pairwise maximum likelihood receiver with single-FFT in layered asymmetrically clipped optical orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (LACO-OFDM) systems is studied analytically. The DC drift mitigation method based on per-layer optical power matching for LACO-OFDM is then proposed. The effectiveness of the proposed method is verified both numerically and experimentally.

title: Polarization Insensitive Wide Incident Angle Stable Graphene Based Wideband Terahertz Absorber
authors: Vikram Maurya, Sarthak Singhal
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Intelligent Signal Processing and Effective Communication Technologies (INSPECT)
abstract: Terahertz electromagnetic wideband absorber is presented in this work. This structure comprises of a graphene based slotted annular octagonal ring resonator and gold platted ground plane. In the designed absorber, the upper resonator and bottom ground plane are separated by a dielectric layer, achieving absorption above 80% across the $2.95-13.54 \mathrm{THz}$ range with relative bandwidth of 128.44% having a compact volume of $12 \mathrm{um} \times 12 \mathrm{um} \times 3.835 \mathrm{um}$. The designed absorber exhibits polarization insensitivity and have angular stability upto 40°. The proposed geometry has several advantages over the previously available structures in terms of simple geometry, Compact and ultrathin dimensions, relative bandwidth and high angular stability.

title: Detection and Prevention of Blackhole Attacks in WSNs Using Supervised Machine Learning
authors: Mohammed Yasmeen, S. Samatha Goud, E. John Alex, B Venkata Krishnaveni, Ch Cury, P. Venkatapathi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Computing Technologies (ICACT)
abstract: The dynamic nature of node mobility in wireless networks significantly impacts key performance metrics such as end-to-end (E2E) delay, packet delivery ratio (PDR), throughput, and overall accuracy. Understanding these impacts is critical for designing adaptive protocols and efficient network systems. Objective: This study aims to analyze the effects of node mobility on network performance by simulating and evaluating key metrics over multiple rounds of node movement under varying conditions.Methods: The study employs a simulation-based approach using a dynamic network model. Nodes are simulated under a Random Waypoint Mobility Model, with data collected at 10-time steps to measure performance metrics. The main variables analyzed include E2E delay, PDR, throughput, and accuracy. Cross-validation techniques were applied to optimize the results, and the findings were statistically analyzed for reliability. Results: The results revealed that E2E delay, PDR, and throughput fluctuate significantly due to node mobility, while accuracy remained consistent at 70.50%. High node mobility resulted in increased E2E delay and reduced PDR, whereas scenarios with stable or minimal movement exhibited better throughput. The results demonstrate that node clustering and movement speed have profound effects on network efficiency. Conclusions: The study concludes that network performance in dynamic environments is highly dependent on node movement patterns. Future work should focus on developing adaptive routing protocols that predict and mitigate the effects of mobility on critical performance metrics.

title: High-performance Vibration Sensing Based on Subband Phase-Shift Transform in Integrated Sensing and Communication System
authors: Yan Zuo, Wu Liu, Yafeng Cheng, Xiang Li, Ming Luo
abstract: We experimentally propose a high-performance integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) system which suppresses interference fading in Φ-OTDR, achieving a $82.8{\text{p}}\varepsilon /\sqrt {{\text{Hz}}} $ strain sensitivity and a 10 m spatial resolution, while simultaneously supporting 100 Gbps DP-QPSK transmission.

title: Physics-Informed Neural Network-Based Method for Vehicle Status and Control Variables Predictions
authors: Yuchen Zhang, Boshi Zhang, Zehui Ma, Qingchen Cheng, Nan Lin, Shuming Shi
publish: 2025 9th CAA International Conference on Vehicular Control and Intelligence (CVCI)
abstract: To address critical vehicle instability under extreme operating conditions, this paper proposes a state prediction method that integrates physical prior knowledge with data-driven methods, based on a physics-informed neural network. It innovatively incorporates time-varying information of control variables into the prediction process. First, a nonlinear 7-degree-of-freedom(7DOF) vehicle dynamics model, along with physical models for front-wheel steering angle and driving torque, was constructed and incorporated as physical prior knowledge into the prediction framework. Subsequently, the physics-informed neural network framework embeds physical prior knowledge into the neural network to constrain the data-driven prediction process. The proposed method effectively enhances the prediction horizon and accuracy by incorporating future control variations during iterative prediction. Simulation and experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves superior prediction performance, effectively supporting the design of stability control strategies.

title: A Reusable Library for Secure Attendance Systems: Fraud Mitigation Based on QR Code and Geolocation
authors: Akmal Oktavian, Wawan Gunawan, Mezan el-Khaeri Kesuma
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Data and Software Engineering (ICoDSE)
abstract: While modern attendance systems based on QR Code and Geolocation offer efficiency, they suffer from significant security vulnerabilities, such as buddy-punching via screenshots and location manipulation using Fake GPS applications. Moreover, most existing solutions are monolithic and not reusable, hindering efficient adoption. This research addresses these issues by developing a reusable library for the Android platform that provides ready-to-use fraud mitigation functionalities. The library consists of two primary modules: GeoValidator for geofencing-based location validation and fake location detection, and SecureQR for generating time-based dynamic QR Codes (TOTP). Evaluation results demonstrate that the library successfully detected 100% of 10 tested Fake GPS applications and remained stable under abnormal conditions. Performance evaluation shows negligible memory overhead for GeoValidator and operational latencies under 430 ms, proving its efficiency. Usability testing with external developers showed ease of integration, with an average implementation time of 20 – 40 minutes, while an expert validation yielded a maximum feasibility score of 5. 0 0. This research delivers a secure, efficient, and reusable solution to facilitate the development of automated attendance systems for various organizations.

title: The Risk-Driven Reinforcement Learning-Based Left-Turn Motion Control for Intelligent Vehicles at Unsignalized Intersections
authors: Gaojian Cui, Xuze Yao, Chaolong Song, Xizhe Huang, Xiaohui Lu, Shaosong Li
publish: 2025 9th CAA International Conference on Vehicular Control and Intelligence (CVCI)
abstract: Unsignalized intersections are widely present in urban road networks and are characterized by the absence of traffic signal control, leading to uncertain and highly dynamic vehicle interactions. These conditions pose significant challenges for autonomous driving, particularly during left turns, which demand adaptable decision-making under ambiguous priorities and dynamic traffic. Reinforcement Learning (RL) is well suited for handling such complexity, enabling agents to learn adaptive control policies directly from data without relying on predefined rules. It supports continuous policy improvement through interaction, making it effective for real-time decision-making in uncertain environments. However, RL still faces a key limitation: during training, high-risk experiences such as those involving potential collisions are relatively scarce and easily overshadowed by abundant low-risk samples. This imbalance leads to underutilization of critical experiences, hindering the learning of robust collision avoidance strategies. To address this issue, we propose a Risk-Driven Soft Actor-Critic (RDSAC) method, which combines scene risk assessment with a dual-replay buffer to enhance the utilization of high-risk experience samples and thereby improve vehicle safety. Experiments demonstrate that RDSAC significantly improves learning efficiency, policy stability, and collision avoidance performance compared to SAC in left-turn scenarios at unsignalized intersections.

title: Detection of Training Movements in Physical Education using 3D-Aware Spatio-Temporal Graph Transformer
authors: Wentao Yuan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Mobile Networks and Wireless Communications (ICMNWC)
abstract: Recently, accurate monitoring of training movements is crucial in physical education and sports training to improve performance, prevent injuries and ensure correct exercise execution. However, the existing 3-Dimensional (3D) skeleton-based methods faces issues such as limited modeling of Spatio-Temporal (ST) correlations and limited generalization to varied motion patterns. Hence, this research proposes 3DAware ST Graph Transformer (3D-STGT) framework for accurate detection of complex training movements across varied viewpoints and subjects. Here, the proposed 3D-STGT framework address existing challenges by generating smooth and standardized 3D skeleton data for capturing the rich ST patterns. Initially, the input data is collected from videos of physical exercises and then, VideoPose3D is employed for 3D pose estimation to convert the 2 D video frames into 3D skeleton sequences by reconstructing the joint positions. Then, the data augmentation, min-max scaling, linear interpolation and uniform sampling are used to increase the dataset variability, clean, smooth and standardize the 3D skeleton sequences respectively. After that, the 3D-STGT is employed to extract the high-level ST feature embeddings that represent posture and motion dynamics. Finally, the Fully Connected Neural Network (FCNN) with softmax activation classifies the exercise sequences to detect training movements by mapping the extracted embeddings into exercise labels. From the results, the proposed 3D-STGT framework achieved better results in terms of accuracy (98.9%) than the existing Synergistic FibroblastOptimized Malleable Convolutional NN (SFO-MCNN) model.

title: Policies Over Poses: Reinforcement Learning Based Distributed Pose-Graph Optimization for Multi-Robot SLAM
authors: Sai Krishna Ghanta, Ramviyas Parasuraman
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Multi-Robot and Multi-Agent Systems (MRS)
abstract: We consider the distributed pose-graph optimization (PGO) problem, which is fundamental in accurate trajectory estimation in multi-robot simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM). Conventional iterative approaches linearize a highly non-convex optimization objective, requiring repeated solving of normal equations, which often converge to local minima and thus produce suboptimal estimates. We propose a scalable, outlier-robust distributed planar PGO framework using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning (MARL). We cast distributed PGO as a partially observable Markov game defined on local pose-graphs, where each action refines a single edge's pose estimate. A graph partitioner decomposes the global pose graph, and each robot runs a recurrent edge-conditioned Graph Neural Network (GNN) encoder with adaptive edge-gating to denoise noisy edges. Robots sequentially refine poses through a hybrid policy that utilizes prior action memory and graph embeddings. After local graph correction, a consensus scheme reconciles inter-robot disagreements to produce a globally consistent estimate. Our extensive evaluations on a comprehensive suite of synthetic and real-world datasets demonstrate that our learned MARL-based actors reduce the global objective by an average of 37.5% more than the state-of-the-art distributed PGO framework, while enhancing inference efficiency by at least 6X. We also demonstrate that actor replication allows a single learned policy to scale effortlessly to substantially larger robot teams without any retraining. Code is publicly available at https://github.com/herolab-uga/policies-over-poses

title: Transformers for Recommendation Systems on Grant Selection Recommendations
authors: Sahirul Alim Tri Bawono, Rudi Hartono, Abdul Aziz, Agus Purbayu, Nanang Maulana Yoeseph
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Information Technology, Information Systems and Electrical Engineering (ICITISEE)
abstract: In human life, decision-making is a constant process, involving choices such as selecting a car, house, or school. This research aims to simplify this process by providing a ranked list of recommendations, where the top-ranked option represents the most appropriate choice. The Transformer is a method used to understand the context of a text. In the specific problem of grant selection, the available data consists of the category descriptions for each grant and the proposal abstracts. By understanding the context of both, the system is expected to provide recommendations for grant categories to the applicants. The evaluation results, showing an MRR of 0.2, indicate that on average, the correct recommendation is found at rank 5 out of 12 choices, placing it within the top half of the ranked list. The low MRR in some cases is attributed to the high similarity between grant categories, where the only differentiators are minor details like collaboration partners or research group categories.

title: Routing Optimization in Communication Networks using Trust-Aware Deep Reinforcement Learning with Graph Neural Networks
authors: Qingxiao Su
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Mobile Networks and Wireless Communications (ICMNWC)
abstract: With rapid growth of modern communication infrastructures, routing optimization has become important for ensuring reliability, low latency and efficient resource utilization in dynamic network environments. Traditional models struggled in adapting rapid topology changes, inconsistent link behavior and security threats which resulted in performance degradation. To overcome these challenges, this research proposes Trust-Aware Deep Reinforcement Learning with Graph Neural Network (TA-DRL-GNN) framework for secure and energy-efficient routing. Initially, network data is extracted as node-level features like forwarding behavior, link quality, mobility and energy status. These features are then encoded into graph representations where nodes link to network devices and edges denotes the communication links. The GNNbased trust modeling mechanism evaluates relational trust scores by capturing multi-hop dependencies and detecting malicious or unreliable nodes. Then, Deep Q-Network routing agent uses trust scores along with real-time network states for selecting optimal next-hop nodes. Finally, multi-objective fitness evaluation integrates residual energy, throughput and connectivity reliability to ensure balanced routing. The proposed TA-DRL-GNN model achieves better results in terms of reduced delay ($\mathbf{0. 0 0 2 2 ~ m s}$), lower energy consumption ($\mathbf{0. 0 5 8}$ mJ) and increased throughput (0.92 bps) when compared with existing model.

title: Adaptive Cross-Modal Gated Framework for Intelligent Medical Diagnosis using Multimodal Data Fusion
authors: Huili Chang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Mobile Networks and Wireless Communications (ICMNWC)
abstract: Nowadays, intelligent medical diagnosis has heavily depended on multimodal data fusion to improve early cardiac disease detection. However, the existing models assume equal reliability across Electrocardiogram (ECG) signals and echocardiogram images which led to make them vulnerable to noise, artifacts and inconsistencies that commonly arise in real clinical environments. Hence, this research proposes Adaptive Cross-Modal Gated Framework (ACMGF) model to achieve more dependable cardiac diagnosis by employing reliabilityaware fusion which automatically down-weights the noisy modalities by generating the more stable fused representations. Initially, the input data is collected ECG data and echocardiogram images from PTB-XL and CAMUS datasets respectively. Then, the images are processed with bilinear interpolation and intensity normalization to ensure data consistency and ECG signals are fed into linear resampling, high-pass filter and z-score normalization for noise suppression as well as uniform scaling respectively. After that, the feature extraction is performed by using EfficientNet-B0 for imaging data and a Temporal Convolutional Network (TCN) for ECG signals to produce the discriminative latent representations. Further, these embeddings are integrated through a CMGF mechanism to adaptively balance the modality contributions by using learned reliability weights. Finally, the fused representation is classified by using an XGBoost model to generate highly interpretable and robust cardiac diagnostic predictions. The proposed ACMGF model outperformed the existing Variational Autoencoder (VAE)-based multimodal fusion in terms of accuracy (0.9984) and precision (0.9983) respectively.

title: Nonlinear Finite-Time Observer for Periodic Signal Estimation and Its Case Study for Electroencephalogram
authors: Madoka Murakami, Hisakazu Nakamura
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Real-time brain-computer interfaces (BCIs) require fast and accurate α-band power estimation. However, α-waves are low-frequency components, which makes their rapid extraction using conventional methods, such as bandpass filters (BPF), difficult. This study applies a nonlinear finite-time observer (FTO) to extract low-frequency features from electroencephalogram signals. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed FTO achieves a convergence time of 4 ms compared to 700 ms with BPF. Moreover, the FTO captures -8 dB attenuation as motor imagery-related α-band power, twice the magnitude obtained with conventional methods (-4 dB). Thus, compared to conventional approaches, the FTO enhances responsiveness and clarity in detecting motor imagery-related reductions in α-band.

title: Anchor-based Multimodal Verification: A Dynamic Query Framework for Fake News Forensics in Short Videos
authors: Pijian Li, Qingbao Huang, Feng Shuang, Yi Cai, Haonan Cheng, Qing Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: The proliferation of maliciously altered short videos on social media platforms poses a significant threat to information security ecosystems, eroding public trust in digital media. Despite recent advancements in detecting fake video news, significant challenges remain in the forensic analysis of short videos, leading to issues of bias. First, as technology rapidly advances, fake videos are becoming increasingly semantically convincing, undermining the effectiveness of current classification methods. Second, the heterogeneous nature of video modalities (visual, textual, audio) creates critical challenges for models to learn discriminative feature representations. To address these challenges, we propose a dynamic query framework for fake news forensics in short videos, termed the Semantic Guided Adaptive Network (SGAN). Our approach is motivated by the need to utilize superficial alignment to identify suspicious manipulations through anchor-based verification and to leverage the adaptive capability of learnable queries to learn the heterogeneous boundary in each modality. Specifically, SGAN comprises a verification module and a flexible query learning module. The verification module employs text as the anchor to verify detailed context, mining fine-grained information while emphasizing key features, thereby providing candidate manipulations for downstream modules. The query learning module leverages learnable queries to map heterogeneous forensic features and integrates them through multi-level fusion for decision-making. Extensive experiments conducted on two widely used datasets demonstrate the effectiveness and generalization of the proposed method.

title:
Emotional Speech Synthesis via Diffusion Transformer with Reference Audio Pool
                    <sup>*</sup>
authors: Qian Shen, Jian Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Emotional Speech Synthesis (ESS) is valuable in emotional human-computer interaction, virtual assistants, and media dubbing. However, current methodologies face persistent challenges in emotional diversity and acoustic granularity. To effectively enhance the diversity and subtlety of emotional expression, this paper proposes an emotional speech synthesis method based on the Diffusion Transformer (DiT) architecture with reference audio pool. The main contributions include: (1) Designing an emotional modeling strategy for speech synthesis based on a reference audio pool. By randomly sampling the reference audio corresponding to emotional categories, it overcomes the limitation of single-reference constraints on emotional diversity; (2) Replacing U-Net with a Diffusion Transformer backbone and using overlapping patches to enhance local details; (3) Introducing the style encoder and style adapter modules for cross-attention-based blending of emotional features and text embeddings. The experimental results of Chinese and English emotional speech synthesis based on the ESD dataset show that the proposed model achieves higher speech synthesis naturalness and emotional similarity, verifying the effectiveness of the method.

title: Electricity Demand Forecasting of Bangladesh Based on Darts Temporal Fusion Transformer (DTFT)
authors: Nripendro Biswas, Iftekhar Hossain, Mohammed Faysal Jaman, Md. Mehedi Hassan, Munaem Ahmed Mahdi
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Information and Communication Technology (EICT)
abstract: Bangladesh is a fast-growing economic country in South Asia, where the forecast of electricity demand plays a major role in the energy management system. Accurate forecasting ensures stability and an efficient power supply. Due to rapid urbanization and increased industrial activity, electricity usage in the country has been fluctuating. As a result, we lack a proper forecasting model for accurate forecasts and face many problems, such as blackouts and load shedding. In this study, we have proposed a time series analysis machine learning model using the Python Darts library, Temporal Fusion Transformer (TFT), which is designed for multi-horizon time series forecasting and includes powerful features such as attention mechanisms, recurrent neural networks, and additional features. We have collected the demand data set and added different features, such as temperature, pressure, and humidity, to make it more realistic. We have compared the performance of the TFT model with the FB Prophet model. During the forecast of December 2024 on the data set, TFT achieved the lowest MAPE of just 1.76 and surpassed FB Prophet in all performance metrics.
