title: Active Adaptation Control for Reconfigurable Vehicles Based on Collaborative Fault-Tolerant Mechanism
authors: Jianxiang Wang, Biao Liu, Tao Jiang, Yue Yang, Yaoyao Tan, Xiaojie Su, Peng Shi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: This paper presents a universal and adaptive control framework for reconfigurable vehicles subject to composite motion disturbances, incorporating a collaborative fault-tolerant mechanism. A model-based cascaded control architecture is developed based on the vehicle’s kinematic and dynamic models. To ensure safety, an improved adaptive geofencing strategy is proposed which integrates capability constraints with barrier functions in the kinematic loop. For dynamic feedback, an adaptive gain-filtered extended state observer enables accurate disturbance estimation from noisy outputs and improves robustness via feedforward compensation. Meanwhile, a collaborative fault-tolerant mechanism further allocates control inputs to mitigate actuator faults. Finally, experimental results validate the proposed method’s effectiveness under complex interference scenarios.

title: Semantic-Guided and Enhanced Memory Few-Shot Display Anomaly Detection
authors: Luo Sijie, Chen Huaixin, Wang Zhixi
publish: 2025 22nd International Computer Conference on Wavelet Active Media Technology and Information Processing (ICCWAMTIP)
abstract: In the context of display manufacturing, guaranteeing product quality is challenging due to complex fabrication processes and frequent product iterations. Consequently, Few-Shot Anomaly Detection (FSAD) has emerged as a critical solution. Existing FSAD methods built on general vision backbones fail to capture subtle and weak defects, while recent approaches based on Contrastive Language-Image Pre-training (CLIP) introduce high-level semantics but insufficiently exploit the category-specific information embedded in limited normal samples. To address these limitations, this paper proposes a Semantic-Guided and Enhanced Memory FSAD method tailored for display inspection. The method incorporates a Semantic Branch that leverages CLIP's cross-modal alignment to provide robust semantic discrimination, and an Enhanced Memory Branch that constructs a stable multi-view memory bank through weak affine augmentation of few normal samples to improve feature matching. Extensive experiments on the AnoLCD dataset demonstrate that the proposed method achieves state-of-the-art performance across six metrics in 1-, 2-, 4-, and 8-shot scenarios compared to five state-of-the-art methods.

title: DQN-Based Online Optimization of Amplifier Reconfiguration Order for Stability and Reliability in Intelligent Optical Networks
authors: Yu He, Yongjie Shi, Yuchen Song, Yihang Lou, Lixia Xi, Xiaoguang Zhang
abstract: We propose a DQN-based online method for optimizating EDFA reconfiguration order in optical networks, featuring an adaptive reward design. This approach avoids up to 1 dB of GSNR degradation and consistently outperforms 98.2% random orders.

title: Beyond Target-Level: ISAC-Enabled Event-Level Sensing for Behavioral Intention Prediction
authors: Haotian Liu, Zhiqing Wei, Yucong Du, Jiachen Wei, Xingwang Li, Zhiyong Feng
abstract: Integrated Sensing and Communication (ISAC) holds great promise for enabling event-level sensing, such as behavioral intention prediction (BIP) in autonomous driving, particularly under non-line-of-sight (NLoS) or adverse weather conditions where conventional sensors degrade. However, as a key instance of event-level sensing, ISAC-based BIP remains unexplored. To address this gap, we propose an ISAC-enabled BIP framework and validate its feasibility and effectiveness through extensive simulations. Our framework achieves robust performance in safety-critical scenarios, improving the F1-score by 11.4% over sensor-based baselines in adverse weather, thereby demonstrating ISAC’s potential for intelligent event-level sensing.

title: LO-Free Self-Driven Down-Conversion via Combination Resonance in CMOS-MEMS Resonators
authors: Nilabh Basu, Ting-Yi Chen, Jun-Chau Chien, Wei-Chang Li
abstract: This letter demonstrates local-oscillator-(LO)-free frequency down-conversion using combination resonance (CR) in a CMOS-MEMS resonator. A single RF tone injected into an engineered three-mode cluster triggers CR and produces low-frequency components—including an IF tone selectable by a baseband filter—without any locally generated reference. The modal triplet is deterministically placed by optimizing VIA locations using a particle swarm optimization (PSO) algorithm to satisfy the CR condition in a 0.35-μm CMOS-MEMS process. Measurements confirm LO-free translation and the emergence of a distinct IF component under single-tone excitation; representative spectra below and above the onset are presented. This work establishes the feasibility of LO-free down-conversion in standard CMOS-MEMS, offering a monolithic solution for secure wake-up receivers with intrinsic hardware-level interference rejection.

title: Enhancing Geo-Transferability in Building Function Classification through Similar Place Knowledge Retrieval
authors: Xucai Zhang, Yue Zheng, Xiaobing Wei, Hongkai Gu, Xiaoping Liu, Frank Witlox, Nico Van De Wedge, Haosheng Huang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Understanding the use of buildings (i.e., building functions) is crucial for effective urban management and policy making. Recently, many deep learning-based models have been developed to identify building functions. However, their high performance depends on a large labeled dataset, which is a significant challenge for cities with limited labeled data. To close this gap, we propose a similar-place knowledge-retrieval-based framework for building function identification that enables a trained model to be directly applied/transferred to other cities without additional training needed. Our approach combines remote sensing imagery, POI data, and building footprints to capture the macro and micro built environment. Specifically, this framework includes two different modules: 1) a geo-aware transformer-based model to capture fine-grained spatial interactions between buildings; 2) a hierarchical node clustering algorithm with a similar-place knowledge-retrieval layer for portraying the coarse-grained features. This combination clusters all neighbors of a target building into a ’place’ and then conducts a coarse-grained knowledge transfer based on the similarity match. The evaluation conducted across nine cities demonstrates that the proposed model outperforms all state-of-the-art baselines, achieving an average improvement of 21.98% in cross-city predictions, as measured by Cohen’s kappa coefficient. More importantly, the ablation study shows that integrating our knowledge-retrieval layer into other deep-learning baselines significantly improves their cross-city prediction performance. Additionally, the transferability performance analysis indicates that greater similarity between the sample distributions in the source and target cities contributes to the proposed model’s higher transferability. In summary, the proposed knowledge-retrieval layer is an effective and reliable component for enhancing cross-city prediction and has strong potentials for application in cities without labeled data to support city management and sustainable urban planning.

title: Robust URLLC Beamforming in SWIPT via Data-Augmented Model-Driven Deep Learning
authors: Kai Liang, Yifei Zhou, Xiaotian Jiang, Guorong Zhou, Gan Zheng, Kai-Kit Wong, Chan-Byoung Chae
abstract: This letter studies robust beamforming for ultra-reliable low-latency communications (URLLC) downlink transmission with imperfect channel state information (CSI) in a simultaneous wireless information and power transfer (SWIPT) system. By modeling CSI estimation errors via statistical distributions, we maximize the minimum rate quantile among all users through the joint optimization of the beamforming matrix and the power-splitting factor under outage probability constraints. We propose a data augmentation and model-driven (DA-MD) deep neural network (DNN) algorithm: data augmentation addresses imperfect CSI via massive error sampling, while the model-driven beamforming recovery structure reduces complexity. Our results validate the superiority of the proposed approach for URLLC.

title: Decarbonization Planning Based on Energy Flow Analysis: Supporting Energy Transition
authors: P. B. Woelke, E. Kunkel, P. DiMaggio
abstract: Decarbonization, i.e., the reduction of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions into the atmosphere, represents a dramatic and irreversible shift in the entire value chain of the global economy. This highlights the need to identify the optimal decarbonization pathways for all market sectors. In this article, we present a basic analysis of the energy flow, i.e., energy generation and consumption in the United States, that allows the prioritization of actions supporting the energy transition, with a specific focus on electrification. The analysis results show that while the key steps to decarbonize the energy demand sectors (i.e., buildings, industry, and transportation) are relatively easy to identify, the most effective order of taking these steps is not. Given the variations in the efficiency of electricity generation, measured by the amount of energy wasted during the process, vis-à-vis individual efficiencies of the energy demand sectors and their geographic dependencies, the impact of prioritization is significant. For the energy demand sectors that have lower efficiency than electricity generation, electrification should progress regardless of the pace of decarbonization of energy generation. However, for the remaining energy demand sectors, the optimized decarbonization plan is more nuanced and requires detailed consideration of all available and future technologies. In some cases, immediate electrification may result in increasing GHG emissions, at least until decarbonization of energy generation progresses. Thus, careful energy transition planning is required for all sectors of the economy.

title: Mitigation of Dither-Signal Beat Interference in Optical SSB System with Remodulation-based Distortion Reconstruction
authors: Jun Dong, Tianwai Bo, Zhuo Wang, Haolei Gao, Zhongwei Tan, Yi Dong
abstract: We propose a receiver-side remodulation-based distortion cancellation technique to mitigate the dither-signal beat interference caused by the double-sideband dither signals generated in the transmitter. The proposed scheme improves the system’s receiver sensitivity by ~1.8 dB.

title: SWAN: A Network-Aware Scheduler for Adaptive Optical Network Reconfiguration in Distributed LLM Training
authors: Xingyu Liu, Dianxuan Fu, Xiaomin Liu, Yihao Zhang, Weisheng Hu, Qunbi Zhuge
abstract: We propose SWAN, a network-aware strategy scheduler that supports switching of parallelization strategies in distributed LLM training by orchestrating optical network topology reconfigurations, achieving up to 38.2% higher network throughput in simulations.

title: Enhancing Spectrum Efficiency in Cognitive Radio Networks Using Novel Machine Learning-Based Sensing Method Compared with Rule-Based Spectrum Sensing Method Based on Time
authors: B.T. Geetha, Navaneetha Krishnan K
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Computing Technologies (ICACT)
abstract: The objective of this proposed work is to enhance spectrum efficiency in Cognitive Radio Networks using a novel machine learning-based sensing method, compared with a rule-based spectrum sensing method based on time. A complete set of 16 efficiency samples captured were gathered by altering various time periods. The given samples were separated into two groups, each including eight samples. The efficiency numbers were determined to measure the performance of the innovative machine learning-based sensing technique and the rule-based spectrum sensing approach in Cognitive Radio Networks. The power of G is taken as 0.8. From this study, it is observed that the new machine learning- based spectrum sensing method achieved an efficiency of 95%, whereas the rule-based spectrum sensing method achieved 80%. The two-tailed significant value obtained is 0.079 (p > 0.05), suggesting that the result is not statistically noteworthy. This study demonstrates that the novel machine learning-based spectrum sensing method performed significantly better than the rule-based spectrum sensing method in improving spectrum efficiency in Cognitive Radio Networks.

title: Adaptive Load Shedding for High Wind Penetration Grids Using Real-Time Inertia Identification
authors: Jinming Wang, Jiuqi Chen, Duliang Wang, Feng Hua
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Energy Engineering and Power Systems (EEPS)
abstract: With rapid wind power integration worldwide, power systems face unprecedented frequency stability challenges due to reduced system inertia and increased uncertainty. This paper develops adaptive underfrequency load shedding strategies for high wind penetration grids. An intelligent algorithm incorporating real-time inertia identification and uncertainty quantification is proposed to handle wind power variability and dynamic operating conditions. Probabilistic methods model wind power stochastic characteristics, while multi-time scale frequency response modeling captures system dynamics. By optimizing load shedding parameters through real-time estimation and risk-based decision making, the strategy enhances frequency stability while minimizing unnecessary load curtailment. Case analysis on the Altay power grid with 66.15% wind penetration demonstrates a 17.0% average reduction in total load shedding compared to traditional schemes, while improving minimum frequency by up to 0.55 Hz and reducing recovery time by 26%, providing a robust solution for frequency control in wind-dominated systems.

title: A Quantitative Evaluation of China's Integrated Medical and Elderly Care Policies Using a PMC-LDA Index Model Based on Central and Five Provincial Policy Documents
authors: Jing Zhao, Ting Zhao, Chuanxu Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: To support the reform of integrated medical and elderly care and promote the development of the eldercare industry, this study integrates the Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA) into the Policy Modeling Consistency (PMC) framework, forming a three-dimensional evaluation system covering policy content, tool applicability, and network structure, thereby assessing central–local policy coordination. Based on 132 policy documents (2013–2024) from the central government and five provinces, the study extracts six key policy themes to serve as one of the variables within the PMC model and introduces Euclidean and cosine distances to measure implementation intensity and directional deviation. Results show that Shanghai demonstrates the highest level of coordination, with strong alignment and standardized execution. Guangxi and Inner Mongolia exhibit insufficient policy input and directional deviation, reflected in fiscal gaps, weak collaboration networks, and localized policy adjustments. Beijing and Qinghai require improvements in timeliness and policy network density. The study proposes a differentiated governance strategy, including targeted central oversight for high-deviation provinces, a policy diffusion network anchored in Shanghai, and enhanced policy adaptation mechanisms in ethnic regions.

title: A Hierarchical Privacy-Preserving Scheme with Federated Learning for Medical Applications
authors: Fan Jiang, Li Zhang, Lei Liu, Yongzhi Zhai
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Wireless Communications and Signal Processing (WCSP)
abstract: This paper proposes a Hierarchical PrivacyPreserving Federated Learning (HPP-FL) scheme that integrates Differential Privacy (DP) and Homomorphic Encryption (HE) to enhance privacy protection for EEG data in IoT-based healthcare scenarios. To address risks of intermediate feature leakage and decision parameter exposure in conventional federated learning, the proposed scheme introduces a two-phase privacy protection mechanism. First, dynamic Gaussian noise perturbation with dynamic privacy budget control is applied exclusively to the client-side feature extraction layers to defend against model inversion attacks. Second, a gradient magnitude ranking strategy identifies 60 % of high-sensitivity parameters in classification head, which are then encrypted using Paillier homomorphic encryption to mitigate parameter inference attacks. By establishing a hierarchical parameter processing protocol, where the server performs standard federated averaging on plaintext feature parameters while conducting homomorphic aggregation on encrypted classification parameters, the proposed scheme strikes an effective balance between privacy protection and model performance. Simulation results on the BCI Competition IV 2a motor imagery dataset demonstrate that the proposed HPPFL effectively enhances raw data privacy against leakage while maintaining test accuracy comparable to baseline approaches, demonstrating its practicality and effectiveness for secure medical federated learning applications.

title: MDS-Based Cooperative Positioning Method Using UWB Sensors
authors: Yueshen Li, Yvxin Huang, Xiaobo Gu
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Wireless Communications and Signal Processing (WCSP)
abstract: This study overcomes the limitations of conventional UWB-based trilateration in complex indoor environments by proposing a cooperative positioning method that combines multidimensional scaling (MDS) with least squares (LS). We implemented a DW1000-based hardware platform to compare the MDS-LS algorithm with trilateration under both static and dynamic conditions. Experimental results show the MDS-LS algorithm achieves a 3.90% reduction in average positioning error for static scenarios and improves x-axis tracking accuracy by up to 9.78% in dynamic scenarios. While maintaining low computational complexity, the proposed method demonstrates superior performance in multi-tag environments, providing an efficient solution for high-accuracy indoor localization.

title: Organization Clustering of Social Media Accounts Based on Large Language Models
authors: Shudong Li, Xin Zhang, Mingjun Yao, Tianle Zhang, Tiantian Ji
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th International Conference on Data Science in Cyberspace (DSC)
abstract: Text clustering is a critical task in data analysis with high practical value, particularly for social media data. Traditional methods face limitations in handling high-dimensional sparse data, capturing deep semantics, and managing noise. To address this, this work propose LLM-MSC, an innovative two-stage organizational clustering framework based on Large Language Models (LLMs). This framework first uses LLMs for precise entity extraction and standardization from social media texts via a two-stage prompt engineering strategy. Subsequently, LLMs are re-invoked for dynamic organizational clustering, followed by multi-dimensional quality assessment. Experimental results demonstrate that LLM-MSC outperforms classic baselines like TF-IDF+K-means and BERT+K-means in accuracy, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{F} 1$</tex>-score, and purity. This work also introduce an LLM zero-shot classification baseline utilizing a hybrid strategy (rule matching, LLM semantic understanding, heuristic fallback) to enhance classification stability. LLM-MSC's strong performance validates its capability in complex organizational clustering, offering practical solutions for intelligent media monitoring and public opinion analysis.

title: FedCMB: A Cross-Modal Federated Learning Framework for Multi-Modal Cyberbullying Detection with Shared Feature Space
authors: Weiqi Zhang, Chengzu Dong, Peng Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th International Conference on Data Science in Cyberspace (DSC)
abstract: The increasing multimodality of cyberbullying poses significant challenges to detection tasks, making traditional single-modal approaches inadequate. Federated learning has emerged as an effective distributed learning paradigm for collaborative training while preserving user privacy, but existing methods generally overlook the heterogeneity of client models and modality discrepancies. To address these issues, we propose FedCMB, a cross-modal federated learning framework tailored specifically for multi-modal cyberbullying detection. FedCMB constructs a modality-invariant shared feature space to effectively fuse features from heterogeneous client models. Additionally, we introduce a knowledge distillation-based aggregation method to facilitate efficient knowledge transfer and integration from heterogeneous client models to a unified server-side model. Our experiments show that FedCMB enhances accuracy by 11.4% over baselines while preserving privacy.

title: AIRFLOW: An End-to-End Spatial-Channel Cross Attention Framework for Real-Time Passenger Detection and Tracking
authors: Can Zhou, Lei Wu, Zhangxin Kan, Hai Wang
abstract: Real-time passenger detection and tracking in transportation environments presents significant challenges due to complex backgrounds, varying lighting conditions, dense crowds, and severe occlusions. This paper proposes AIRFLOW, an end-to-end framework built upon RT-DETR that incorporates two novel components: the Spatial-Channel Cross Attention (SPCA) mechanism and the Cross-scale Guided Feature Module (CGFM). SPCA enhances feature representation by modeling bidirectional spatial and channel dependencies simultaneously through explicit cross-attention computation with 8 attention heads, enabling robust detection of occluded passengers. CGFM effectively fuses multi-scale features through semantic guidance to preserve critical spatial and contextual information. Experiments on three public benchmarks and one self-constructed AirportPassenger Dataset demonstrate that AIRFLOWachieves 89.7%, 86.9%, 88.2%, and 82.3% mAP@0.5 respectively, while maintaining 52 FPS inference speed. The framework provides an effective solution for intelligent transportation systems.

title: SensiYOLO: YOLO-based Detection Method for Solid Waste Stockpiles in Remote Sensing Images
authors: Meishu Li, Kun Liu, Benli Zou, Qinghao Peng
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: The intelligent detection of solid waste stockpiles plays a critical role in environmental management, particularly against the backdrop of rapid urbanization and industrialization, which have led to a continuous increase in solid waste generation. Efficient and accurate monitoring of these stockpiles has become an urgent necessity. Although remote sensing technology has been widely adopted for such tasks due to its wide coverage and cost-effectiveness, existing detection methods still face significant limitations in terms of feature representation and adaptability to complex environments. To address these challenges, this study proposes a novel object detection algorithm, SensiYOLO, built upon the YOLOv11 framework and enhanced by two key modules: the Dynamic Spatial-Channel Attention (DSCA) module and the Adaptive Context Perception (ACP) module. The DSCA module leverages multi-head attention to dynamically enhance feature responses across spatial and channel dimensions, thereby improving feature discrimination. Meanwhile, the ACP module combines depthwise separable convolution with strip pooling to achieve lightweight, multi-scale context fusion, effectively capturing semantic information with minimal parameter overhead. Without significantly increasing model complexity, the proposed method demonstrates improved capability in recognizing target information under complex conditions. Experimental results on the Solid Waste Stockpiles (SWS) dataset show that SensiYOLO outperforms the baseline YOLOv11 model, achieving increases of 3.2% in precision, 3.7% in recall, and 3.1% in mAP. The synergistic design of the DSCA and ACP modules enhances feature representation while maintaining computational efficiency, significantly improving the model’s applicability in large-scale and high-precision detection scenarios. This work offers a practical deep learning-based solution to the technical challenges of solid waste stockpile monitoring in complex environments, with strong potential for scalability and real-world deployment in environmental governance.

title: Think Twice Before Determining: Towards Scene-aware Visual Reasoning for Mirror Detection
authors: Mingfeng Zha, Guoqing Wang, Yunqiang Pei, Tianyu Li, Xiongxin Tang, Jiayi Ma, Yang Yang, Heng Tao Shen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Mirror detection (MD) aims to overcome interference caused by reflections and locate mirror regions. Existing methods focus on designing components to explicitly establish the associations between physical entities and corresponding imagings, or utilizing rotation to construct symmetric consistency. We observe that: a) incomplete and incorrect correspondence between entities and imagings; b) other physical materials (e.g., glass) exhibit characteristics partially similar to mirrors, causing confusion when they co-occur; c) complex interfering factors (e.g., occlusion) and reflection mechanisms may expand vector space several times over. To address these issues in a unified manner, we formulate the scene-aware visual reasoning network (SVRNet) based on visual prompts. Specifically, we construct the prototype-guided prompt chain reasoning (PPCR) that generates a mixed chain of thought reasoning based on maximal difference heterogeneous prototypes to construct comprehensive spatial location and semantic perception. Noise may accumulate gradually through the chain, and crucial clues may also disappear. Therefore, we design the prompt evolution (PE) to filter out noise and enhance the coupling between prompts. We further develop the mixture of prompt injection expert (MPIE) to dynamically select the optimal injection strategy in the low-rank space based on specific scene. Due to reflection interference and random parameter space introducing potential ambiguity, we formulate the three-way evidence-aware (TEA) loss to quantify the uncertainty, thereby providing reliable predictions. To leverage historical knowledge and further disentangle representations, we propose the frequency prototype contrastive (FPC) loss for learning more generalizable features across images. Finally, we relabel 25,828 images and formulate the first point-supervised MD framework. Extensive experiments conducted on four mirror benchmarks under three settings demonstrate that our method surpasses state-of-the-art approaches. Promising results are also achieved on six related benchmarks, showing its generality.

title: Enhancing Query Understanding in Educational Question Answering Systems through Neural Models
authors: B. P Swathi, M Geetha, M. V Suhas
abstract: Accurate query type prediction is a critical component in knowledge graph-based Question Answering (QA) systems, enabling efficient query processing and facilitating the generation of query-specific responses. This study focuses on developing a query classification framework tailored for educational QA systems, categorizing queries into Boolean, Factoid, List, and Multi-line types. A curated dataset of labelled queries is constructed and utilized to evaluate the performance of various deep learning architectures, including LSTM, Bi-LSTM, GRU, and Bi-GRU. Early approaches to query-type classification relied primarily on rule-based heuristics, while traditional machine learning classifiers depended on features such as n-grams and syntactic patterns, and more recent neural approaches typically focused on restricted query categories. In contrast, our work introduces a domain-specific, fine-grained query type prediction framework using deep learning approaches. Among the evaluated models, Bi-GRU demonstrated superior generalization and accuracy, achieving a test accuracy of 72%. Comparative analysis with existing works highlights the effectiveness of the proposed approach in capturing diverse query intents within an academic context. Despite its effectiveness, challenges remain in handling ambiguous or incomplete queries, which are addressed through recommendations for multi-label classification and active learning strategies as future enhancements. This research contributes to the development of more robust and adaptable QA systems, particularly in the domain of education.

title: Learned Light Field Compression for Resource-Constrained Acquisition Systems
authors: Lili Zhao, Wanxin Shi, Jie Li, Meng Guo, Lei Yang, Wei Yu
abstract: Light field (LF) imaging enables high-quality 3D scene representation but produces massive data volumes, posing significant challenges for storage, transmission, and on-device processing, especially for resource-constrained acquisition systems. To address this issue, we present a novel LF compression method. It is commonly-known that raw lenslet data captured by LF cameras could be converted into four-dimensional LF representations (a set of LF multiview images). Leveraging the strong view synthesis capability of implicit neural representation (INR), we compress large-scale LF data into a compact 12.8 MB neural network, which renders high-quality LF multiview images from only temporal frame indexes. The proposed algorithm is deployed on our custom LF acquisition system, achieving efficient storage and reconstruction under limited computational and memory resources. Extensive experiments show that our method outperforms the latest international video compression standard VVC/H.266 test model (VTM) in both objective quality metrics and subjective visual fidelity.

title: Validation of a Grip Force Scheduled LPV Model of Time-Varying Neuromuscular Admittance
authors: Rik Palings, Daan M. Pool, Marinus M. van Paassen, Max Mulder
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Haptic Shared Control (HSC) systems offer a means to support human drivers in the transition to fully-automated driving. Matching HSC systems settings with drivers’ time-varying neuromuscular system (NMS) dynamics requires real-time HSC adaptations. This paper presents an experimental validation of a previously proposed method for predicting drivers’ time-varying neuromuscular admittance using an ‘average’ grip force scheduled linear parameter varying (LPV) model. The quality of LPV model predictions is compared to that of Recursive Least Squares (RLS) fits of an admittance model on the same data. Ten participants performed steering wheel manipulation tasks with steering wheel perturbations that needed to be kept within a certain displacement boundary by adapting their grip force. Time-invariant (TI) and time-varying (TV) boundary levels were used to, respectively, construct and validate the LPV model. Results show that the average relation between admittance and grip force that underlies the current LPV method varies too much between TV and TI tasks, hampering accurate admittance predictions. Compared to the quality-of-fit of 80-90% obtained with RLS on the TV data, the LPV model’s predictions are insufficiently accurate and do not exceed 55% on average. An approach that enables individual instead of average LPV models to be constructed directly from TV experiment data needs to be pursued for HSC implementations.

title: Organizing Committees
authors: N/A
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Computational Intelligence and Applications (ICCIA)

title: A Systematic Literature Review on Food Quality Assurance in E-Commerce
authors: Sarah Isniah, Moses Laksono Singgih, Putu Dana Karningsih
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Information Technology, Information Systems and Electrical Engineering (ICITISEE)
abstract: The rapid growth of e-commerce has transformed food supply chains, introducing new challenges in maintaining consistent food quality, safety, and consumer trust. This study proposes an integrated food quality management framework that synergistically combines sensor and Internet of Things (IoT) technologies, blockchain, and artificial intelligence (AI) with managerial and regulatory frameworks to ensure authenticity and freshness in digital trade. Using a Systematic Literature Review (SLR) of 27 peer-reviewed studies (2020-2025), five dominant research themes were identified: sensor-and IoT-based monitoring, blockchain-enabled traceability, AI/ML applications for predictive quality analysis, microbiological and risk-based approaches, and regulatory management frameworks. Findings reveal that while these technologies enhance transparency, predictive accuracy, and quality efficiency, existing implementations remain fragmented and lack interoperability. To address these gaps, this paper proposes a bidirectional multi-layer architecture integrating IoT sensing, AI analytics, blockchain traceability, and governance through data flow and feedback loop mechanisms. This architecture enables end-to-end connectivity, continuous improvement, and consumer-centered trust reinforcement across digital food ecosystems. Future research directions emphasize edge-AI analytics, multi-chain blockchain interoperability, and harmonized global compliance standards (ISO 22000, HACCP). The study contributes to developing a holistic, scalable, and sustainable framework aligned with Industry <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4. 0}$</tex> principles for digital food quality assurance.

title: Recognition of meal-taking activity based on a correlation matrix to identify social isolation in the elderly
authors: Ghazi Bouaziz, Damien Brulin, Eric Campo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Recognition of Activities of Daily Living (ADLs) has been the subject of research for several years now, with the aim of providing effective solutions, particularly in terms of personal assistance and home care. This paper aims to present an original approach to detect signs of social isolation by monitoring key digital indicators such as mobility and nutritional activity. In order to collect data in a real-life environment, we have deployed a sensor-based monitoring system for three months in the homes of five elderly people (aged 60 to 87) living alone. We have compared the results of four algorithms, to identify six activities of daily living (preparing meals, eating, washing up, hygiene, sleep/relaxation and other activities). The logical approach, based on a 20-minute time window, achieved the best results with a detection rate of 88.14% for the activity "eating a meal" in five elderly participants, and with a micro-average F1-score of 0.863 using the public ARUBA-1 database. These results represent an intermediate step in the assessment of social isolation in the elderly through the analysis of their ADLs.

title: Cultural Canvas: Afrofuturist AI Game Design as a Pathway to CS/AI Engagement
authors: Bryan Wallace
abstract: This experience report details the design and implementation of a novel AI game development workshop explicitly framed through an Afrofuturist lens, aimed at engaging middle school students and broadening participation among Black youth in computing and artificial intelligence (CS/AI). Addressing the persistent underrepresentation of Black students in CS/AI fields, the Afrofuturist framework served as the central integrating force, linking technical skill development with the exploration of Black cultural identity, historical reclamation, and self-determination, while fostering creative expression and agency. This report highlights key design considerations, observed potential for student engagement and the deep integration of cultural narratives, and reflections on the workshop’s implementation, offering insights for educators and researchers seeking to cultivate inclusive and empowering pathways into CS/AI for underrepresented students.

title: Origins of Thermal Anomalies Prior to Earthquakes: Lithosphere, Atmosphere, or Ionosphere?
authors: Ying Zhang, Chengxiang Zhan, Xiaohui Du, Chen Zhou, Weiyu Ma, Xian Lu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Thermal infrared (TIR) anomalies preceding earthquakes have been widely studied as potential precursors, yet their detection remains challenged by atmospheric noise and methodological limitations. This study advances the analysis of thermal anomalies by integrating a three-dimensional (3D) “heating core” filter with National Centers for Environmental Prediction (NCEP) multilayer temperature data across 26 isobaric levels (1000-10 hPa). We systematically assess the spatiotemporal relationship between 3D thermal anomalies and earthquakes (ML ≥3.0,4.0,5.0) in mainland China (2008-2019). Results reveal distinct vertical stratification: thermal anomalies in the troposphere ( ≥ 200 hPa) exhibit a pyramidal structure originating near the epicenter, correlating strongly with seismic events, while anomalies in the mesosphere (≤ 50 hPa) suggest a secondary source potentially linked to lithosphere-atmosphere-ionosphere coupling via VLF-induced heating. The 3D approach significantly outperforms 2D methods, reducing non-seismic noise and achieving optimal parameterization ( NL = 4,μ = 0.8–1.0 ) for magnitude-dependent anomaly penetration. These findings highlight the critical role of vertical profiling in enhancing precursor reliability and provide statistical evidence for multi-layer thermal dynamics preceding earthquakes.

title: High-Power GMA Fiber Laser Based on Resistance Gain Narrowing for Damage-Free Tissue Ablation
authors: Ang Liu, Tong Xia, He Zhao, Shuyuan Zhu, Chaowu Yan, Pu Wang
abstract: High-peak-power femtosecond fiber lasers are ideal for biomedical precision processing, but their performance is often limited by gain narrowing. Here, we report a passive, all-fiber gain-flattening scheme based on an unpumped Yb-doped fiber. By utilizing the reabsorption effect of the unpumped Yb-doped fiber as a spectral shaper within the power amplifier, gain narrowing was effectively suppressed. Based on this scheme, the laser system delivered 23.4 W of average power at a 43.8 MHz repetition rate. The broad spectrum supported compression to 84 fs, yielding 0.53 μJ pulse energy and a high peak power of 6.4 MW. To verify its practical utility, this source was applied to ex vivo myocardial tissue ablation. Histological analysis confirmed the athermal ablation mechanism, characterized by exceptionally clean incisions devoid of carbonization, protein denaturation, or other collateral thermal damage. This work provides an effective and practical architecture for high-peak-power femtosecond fiber lasers and demonstrates its significant potential for "cold" processing applications, such as athermal surgery.

title: A Dual-Polarized Stacked Dielectric Resonator Antenna Array with Extremely Low Mutual Coupling for 6G Base Stations
authors: Wenqi Fan, Qi Wu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: This paper introduces a stacked dielectric resonator antenna (sDRA) array with dual-polarization for the “golden band of 6G” (7.125–8.4 GHz) applications. The sDRA element consists of three DRs stacked in ascending permittivity, generating multiple low-Q modes and achieving a factional bandwidth of 62%. Metal posts are integrated to the sDRA element for improving the isolation between two polarizations, and a decoupling and matching network provides broadband decoupling between sDRA elements. A prototype with 2×2 sDRA elements was fabricated and measured. The isolation between any feeding ports is better than 17 dB within the frequency range of 7.1–8.4 GHz, and the envelope correlation coefficient is below 0.02. The proposed method can also be combined with other decoupling structures to construct scalable 2×2 sub-arrays, achieving an extensive scaling of array size. This paper demonstrates 4×4 and 8×8 arrays through full-wave simulation. The sDRA array has compact size, high efficiency, and low coupling, which is potentially useful for 6G massive MIMO base station applications.

title: Decoding of LDPC Codes Using Singularity of SNR Mismatch Over AWGN Channel
authors: Hong-Jae Jeong, Jae-Won Kim
publish: IEEE Transactions on Green Communications and Networking
abstract: In this paper, we propose a new decoding algorithm that guarantees superior decoding performances for low-density parity-check (LDPC) codes without knowledge of channel parameters. Although obtaining correct channel parameters is very difficult in low-latency and energy-efficient communication systems, most studies on LDPC codes assume perfect knowledge of channel parameters. While receivers can obtain correct channel parameters by utilizing numerous pilot signals, increased overhead makes them infeasible in practical systems. In addition, using incorrect channel parameters for decoding usually degrades decoding performances. These challenges highlight the need for a new decoder that performs reliably without correct channel parameters. Meanwhile, the previous studies on repeat-accumulate (RA) codes and LDPC codes have observed that the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) mismatch sometimes enhances decoding performances when the maximum number of decoding iterations is small. Inspired by these observations, we investigate singularity of the SNR mismatch in LDPC codes from numerous frame error rate (FER) simulations. By utilizing this singularity, we propose a new decoding algorithm for the energy-efficient communication system, where correct channel parameters are not available at receivers. The proposed decoder shows a performance gain of 0.25 dB at FER = 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−6</sup> compared to the conventional belief propagation (BP) algorithm.

title: Adaptive Distributed DNN Inference Offloading in Multi-Access Edge Computing Networks Interconnected by Metro Optical Networks
authors: Jingjie Xin, Xin Li, Shanguo Huang
abstract: This paper proposes an adaptive distributed DNN inference offloading scheme to determine partitioning and offloading decisions for DNN inference tasks in the MEC network interconnected by a metro optical network. Simulation results show that the scheme achieves a high acceptance ratio while keeping the computation-load balance.

title: High-speed Broadband Wavelength-Parallel Modulation Enabled by Lithium Niobate Asymmetric Modulator
authors: Chaoqian Li, Yunlong Nie, Hang Song, Chenming Zhao, Yuquan Peng, Chaoyang Zhang, Hao Tang, Xianmin Jin
abstract: We present an integrated asymmetric modulator based on thin-film lithium niobate, achieving broadband wavelength-parallel modulation across the entire C-band with high consistency over 7.3 bit and large modulation range exceeding 0.59, with an electro-optic bandwidth surpassing 64.25 GHz.

title: Closed-Loop Data-Driven Koopman Modeling and Predictive Control for Vehicle Lateral Stability Enhancement
authors: Qiong Huang, Zihan Li, Jieshu Wang, Ping Wang
publish: 2025 9th CAA International Conference on Vehicular Control and Intelligence (CVCI)
abstract: Ensuring vehicle lateral stability on low-friction surfaces remains challenging due to the pronounced nonlinearity of tire-road interactions and limited tire force capacity. Traditional nonlinear Model Predictive Control (NMPC) methods provide accurate dynamic representation but are often computationally prohibitive. To address this, we propose a closed-loop data-driven Koopman Model Predictive Control (CLK-MPC) framework that constructs globally linear predictors from operational data. By leveraging closed-loop measurements, the Koopman operator is approximated via extended dynamic mode decomposition (EDMD), enabling efficient and robust prediction of nonlinear vehicle dynamics. CarSim-MATLAB co-simulation results demonstrate that CLK-MPC achieves tracking performance comparable to NMPC while reducing average computation time from over 30 ms to about 2 ms, confirming its potential for computationally efficient and effective stability control.

title: A 3-D MIMO GBSM for In-Vehicle Communication Scenarios
authors: Houqiu Ye, Zhen Lv, Lijian Xin, Cheng-Xiang Wang
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Wireless Communications and Signal Processing (WCSP)
abstract: In-vehicle communication systems, as critical infrastructure of intelligent transportation systems (ITS), require accurate channel modeling to characterize the propagation properties and support their design and performance evaluation. This paper proposes a three-dimensional (3-D) multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) geometry-based stochastic model (GBSM) for invehicle scenarios. Derived from the 6 G pervasive channel model (6GPCM), this proposed model systematically incorporates the dynamic impacts of human body blockage, road conditions, and vehicle driving speed on channel propagation characteristics. The proposed model is applicable to three typical in-vehicle communication scenarios, i.e., in the engine compartment, beneath the chassis, and in the car compartment, across the frequency bands from sub- 6 GHz to millimeter waves. Through theoretical derivations and simulations, channel capacity and key channel statistical properties such as delay power spectral density (PSD), frequency correlation function (FCF), and root mean square (RMS) delay spread are analyzed. Comparative analysis between simulation results and channel measurement data verifies the accuracy and generality of the proposed model.

title: An Energy-Efficient Blockchain Security Framework for Sustainable IoT and Edge Environments
authors: Yasir Abdelgadir Mohamed, Mohamed Bashir, Akbar Khanan
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Infocomm Technology (ICAIT)
abstract: The exponential growth of Internet of Things (IoT) devices and edge computing nodes has amplified security and sustainability challenges in decentralized environments. Traditional blockchain models, while providing integrity and immutability, are computationally intensive and energy-hungry, making them unsuitable for constrained IoT-edge ecosystems. This paper proposes an energy-efficient blockchain security framework designed to ensure trust, data confidentiality, and low-carbon operation in sustainable IoT deployments. The framework introduces a lightweight consensus algorithm named Proof of Trust and Energy Balance (PoTEB), which integrates device reputation scoring with energy-aware block validation. To further enhance resilience, a hybrid on-chain/off-chain encryption model ensures secure data transmission and adaptive key rotation. Experimental results obtained from Raspberry Pi-based edge nodes demonstrate a 42% reduction in energy consumption compared to Proof-of-Work (PoW) and a 25% latency improvement over Proof-of-Stake (PoS), while maintaining comparable throughput and attack resistance. The proposed framework aligns with Sustainable Development Goals (SDG 9 & 13), fostering responsible innovation and carbon-efficient digital infrastructures.

title: Benchmarking Lightweight DRL and Vision-Language Models for UAV Navigation in Simulation Environments
authors: Yeasin Arafat, Masud Jabir, Ali Iqtidar, Lahlali Chaimae
publish: 2025 22nd International Computer Conference on Wavelet Active Media Technology and Information Processing (ICCWAMTIP)
abstract: Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) playa growing role in intelligent communication and surveillance, but robust, interpretable, and efficient navigation proves difficult. This paper presents a common benchmarking framework for comparing lightweight deep reinforcement learning and vision language models in photorealistic simulation. A hybrid deep reinforcement learning and vision language controller combines policy optimization and semantic reasoning through adaptive attention gating. AirSim and Isaac Sim experiments demonstrate that the hybrid controller achieves an overall score of 0.89, outperforming individual models while maintaining less than five milliseconds of latency. Outcomes verify considerable improvements in navigation success and resilience, providing standard metrics for explainable and effective unmanned aerial vehicle autonomy.

title: BT-D2: A Hierarchical Combat Task Decomposition Framework with Dynamic Constraint Injection in Behavior Tree
authors: Qinglin Li, Xueqin Huang, Xianqiang Zhu, Sheng Zhang, Dianqiu Ma, Qiting Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: This paper addresses challenges such as semantic gaps, logical inconsistencies, and neglect of domain knowledge in task decomposition for complex systems, especially in military command scenarios. We propose the BT-D2 framework — a behavior tree-guided method that integrates large language models (LLMs) with structured domain knowledge to enable dynamic and executable task decomposition. By embedding military doctrines and equipment parameters into hierarchical behavior tree nodes, the framework creates a constraint-based template for transforming high-level instructions into tactical action sequences. Key components include an extended behavior tree architecture for dynamic parameter binding, a multi-agent collaborative workflow for strategic-to-tactical planning, and an adaptive mechanism for semantic alignment and conflict resolution. Experimental results demonstrate that BT-D2 outperforms baseline methods (CoT, ReAct, GTN) in semantic integrity, decomposition diversity, and structural rationality across 200 combat scenarios. Ablation studies validate the critical role of behavior trees in enhancing task executability and hierarchical architecture in improving planning efficiency. This work contributes a novel framework for bridging generative AI with domain-specific constraints, offering promising applications in military planning, logistics, and intelligent systems.

title: A Novel Auxiliary-Assisted Reduced Component Switched-Capacitor Seven-Level Inverter for Standalone Applications
authors: Md. Ahsanul Alam, Md. Tariqul Islam, Md. Fayzur Rahman
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Information and Communication Technology (EICT)
abstract: This paper introduces a novel compact seven-level inverter that uses an Auxiliary-Assisted Switched-Capacitor topology. By integrating a switched-capacitor and an auxiliary circuit, it generates seven output voltage levels using fewer components (saving one voltage source and four switches) compared to the traditional cascaded H-bridge seven-level inverter. The inverter can achieve a voltage gain of 1.5. Both simulations and experiments were used to measure the performance of the proposed inverter. Various load tests were conducted together with an LC filter to achieve a sinusoidal output with a low total harmonic distortion (THD) of 4.11%, meeting IEEE standards. Dynamic changes of loads were also considered to confirm the potential of the proposed topology to work with varying operating conditions. Moreover, a small-scale version of the laboratory was created to verify the feasibility of the inverter design in practice and its overall functionality.

title: Performance Evaluation of 1-Bit RIS Unit Cell with different Ground Plane structure for V2V Communication
authors: Snehit Kamatgekar, Vijay Rayar, Vinayak Dalavi, Prabhakar Manage
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Mobile Networks and Wireless Communications (ICMNWC)
abstract: Reconfigurable Intelligent Surfaces (RIS) have been recognized as a viable approach to improve wireless connectivity in Vehicle-to-Vehicle (V2V) applications. This study presents a performance analysis of two 1-bit reconfigurable unit cell designed at 5.8875 GHz frequency with different ground plane structures. The two designs make use of identical rectangular patch dimensions with different substrate and ground plane sizes integrated with PIN diodes, providing binary phase control. The simulation results gives better result in terms of phase shift for ground plane with $0.374 \boldsymbol{\lambda}$ dimensions compared to ground plane with $0.5 \lambda$ dimensions for ON and OFF states. To analyze system-level performance, each unit cell design was implemented in a $5 \times 5$ RIS array and tested for five distinct 1-bit phase configurations. The smaller ground plane demonstrated enhanced beam steering capability and narrower main lobes, whereas the larger ground plane produced stronger, more uniform beams with slightly increased angular spread.

title: A Chipless RFID Tag with Anti-Metal Capability and High Capacity
authors: Wei Gao, Xuan Zhang, Danyang Li, Li Zhao, Fang Chang, Yuying Chen
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Infocomm Technology (ICAIT)
abstract: Aiming at the problems of signal attenuation and limited capacity of traditional radio-frequency identification (RFID) tags in metallic environments, an anti-metal chipless RFID tag is proposed. The tag adopts a metal-dielectric-metal structure, with four split ring resonator (SRR) units of different sizes integrated on the top layer to generate four independent resonant frequency. By introducing frequency shift coding, a 13.28 bits coding capacity is achieved through the combination of resonant frequency. Meanwhile, leveraging the depolarization characteristics of SRR, the tag can convert horizontally polarized waves into vertically polarized waves, effectively suppressing the interference of reflective clutter from metal surfaces on the tag’s echo signals and improving the signal purity in metallic environments. Results of CST simulations show that the designed tag achieves good anti-metal performance and high capacity in the UWB, demonstrating broad application prospects in complex metallic platform such as industrial automation.

title: Medication Counseling with Large Language Models: Balancing Flexibility and Rigidity
authors: Joar Sabel, Mattias Wingren, Andreas Lundell, Sören Andersson, Sara Rosenberg, Susanne Hägglund, Linda Estman, Malin Andtfolk
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Agentic AI (ICA)
abstract: The introduction of large language models (LLMs) has greatly enhanced the capabilities of software agents. Instead of relying on rule-based interactions, agents can now interact in flexible ways akin to humans. However, this flexibility quickly becomes a problem in fields where errors can be disastrous, such as in a pharmacy context, but the opposite also holds true; a system that is too inflexible will also lead to errors, as it can become too rigid to handle situations that are not accounted for. Work using LLMs in a pharmacy context have adopted a wide scope, accounting for many different medications in brief interactions - our strategy is the opposite: focus on a more narrow and long task. This not only enables a greater understanding of the task at hand, but also provides insight into what challenges are present in an interaction of longer nature. The main challenge, however, remains the same for a narrow and wide system: it needs to strike a balance between adherence to conversational requirements and flexibility. In an effort to strike such a balance, we propose a system meant to provide medication counseling while juggling these two extremes. We also cover our design in constructing such a system, with a focus on methods aiming to fulfill conversation requirements, reduce hallucinations and promote high-quality responses. The methods used have the potential to increase the determinism of the system, while simultaneously not removing the dynamic conversational abilities granted by the usage of LLMs. However, a great deal of work remains ahead, and the development of this kind of system needs to involve continuous testing and a human-in-the-loop. It should also be evaluated outside of commonly used benchmarks for LLMs, as these do not adequately capture the complexities of this kind of conversational system.

title: Bit-Level Probabilistic Shaping Four-Dimensional Modulation with Two-Stage Carrier Phase Recovery for 200G DFB-based Cost-Effective TFDM-PON
authors: Yifan Chen, Chen Wang, Jianjun Yu, Fan Li, Jianyu Long, Mingzhu Yin, Wei Wang, Weihao Ni, Yuheng Liu
abstract: A novel four-dimensional (4D) probabilistically-shaped (PS) 16-ary quadrature amplitude modulation (16QAM) scheme is proposed with a two-stage carrier phase noise recovery (CPR) architecture to mitigate the impact of severe linear phase noise induced by MHz-class distributed feedback (DFB) lasers. The PS-4D structure seamlessly integrates forward error correction (FEC)-compatible bit-weighted distribution matching (BWDM) with set partitioning (SP) through bit-level concatenation. At the receiver, frequency-domain pilot-tone-assisted CPR (FPT-CPR) works together with a second stage based on maximum a posteriori (MAP) decision. In a 200G cost-effective DFB-based time-frequency-division multiplexing passive optical network (TFDM-PON) simulation, a 32-Gbaud PS-4D-16QAM signal transmitted over 20-km standard single-mode fiber (SSMF) achieves 37.4-dB power budget at 7% hard-decision forward error correction (HD-FEC) threshold of 3.8×10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-3</sup>, and ~0.6-dB improvement in receiver optical power sensitivity (RPS) compared to 25-Gbaud polarization-division-multiplexed 16QAM (PDM-16QAM) at similar net bit rates.

title: Evaluating Touch and Crown Interactions on a Linear QWERTY Soft Keyboard on Smartwatches
authors: Gennaro Costagliola, Mattia De Rosa, Camilla Fiumarella, Vittorio Fuccella, Alfonso Piscitelli
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Typing on a smartwatch presents significant challenges due to several factors, including the small size of these devices, the lack of tactile feedback, and the fat finger problem. This study presents an empirical analysis of two distinct text-entry methods for a one-line QWERTY keyboard: a traditional touch-based interaction and an input technique that leverages the rotary-crown, a feature commonly found on a substantial number of smartwatch devices. Interaction via the rotating crown enables text entry even when touch input is impractical—such as when wearing gloves, in wet conditions, or in cases of reduced precision like the ’fat finger’ problem. By rotating the rotary-crown, the user can navigate to and select the desired character, which is then input by pressing the corresponding key to confirm the selection. The method was evaluated in comparison to the touch-interaction: the results demonstrated that participants achieved higher accuracy with the rotary-crown input, with a Total Error Rate of 9%; conversely, participants exhibited faster performance with the touch-interaction, achieving a typing speed of 9.3 words per minute.

title: MCFA: Multi-Choice Full-body Anonymization
authors: Xuan Wang, Zhichao Lian
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: In the age of data explosion, data collection is everywhere, but data may contain a lot of private information. Therefore, anonymization techniques are used to protect privacy information while preserving important data information. For human images, personal privacy information is present not only in the face; parts of the body also contain a lot of personal identification information. Thus, human anonymization should be extended from the face to the full-body. However, current human anonymization mainly focuses on face anonymization. In this paper, we propose a multi-choice full-body anonymization framework that provides different anonymization choices at the semantic level while ensuring the image diversity and face diversity of full-body anonymized data. For full-body anonymized data, we propose a comprehensive evaluation system. We conduct a detailed evaluation of the anonymized data from three aspects: data quality and diversity, anonymization performance, and data utility. We have demonstrated through extensive experiments that our method provides more anonymous choices and better diversity performance compared to state-of-theart methods while ensuring data quality and anonymization performance.

title: Non-Uniform Programmable Silicon Photonic Mesh
authors: Cristina Catalá-Lahoz, José Capmany
abstract: By embedding defect cells inside a uniform hexagonal lattice, programmable photonic meshes attain Vernier-driven path length diversity, extending the free spectral range up to 133 GHz and reducing sampling time to 7.5 picoseconds.

title: Optical Fiber Micro-Displacement Sensor Based on Peak Position Recognition Vernier Method
authors: Qingshun Pang, Cong Shi, Guangxu Bei, Liqiang Zhang, Yicun Yao, Minghong Wang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Infocomm Technology (ICAIT)
abstract: This paper presents a fiber-optic microdisplacement sensor based on an air-gap Fabry-Perot interferometer (FPI). Combined with a virtual peak recognition vernier method, the proposed system achieves significantly enhanced sensitivity. Unlike traditional optical vernier techniques, our method tracks a series of resonance peak positions from the interferometric sensor, rather than relying on the spectral envelope modulation curve. This strategy effectively prevents spectral resolution degradation during envelope fitting and leads to a substantial improvement in sensitivity. Experimental results demonstrate that the processed sensor exhibits a microdisplacement sensitivity of $1511.25 \mathrm{~nm} / \mu \mathrm{m}$ with an amplification factor of approximately 26.7. The sensor also shows good linearity with a high coefficient of determination. With its high sensitivity, low cost, and simple structure, this sensor offers a practical solution for micro-displacement measurement in applications such as precision manufacturing and aerospace.

title: HIC-OTN for Intelligent Computing Center Interconnections
authors: Dechao Zhang, Yuqian Zhang, Jiang Sun, Dong Wang
abstract: This paper introduces the key technical features of the novel HIC-OTN (hitless intelligent computing OTN) to meet the critical requirements for the interconnection of distributed intelligent computing centers, and illustrates related field trials.

title: Demonstration of Hierarchical Digital Twin-enabled End-to-End Key Provisioning in SDN-based Satellite Quantum Key Distribution Networks
authors: Jingjing Liu, Xiaosong Yu, Yongli Zhao, Jie Zhang
abstract: Hierarchical digital twin-enabled end-to-end key provisioning in satellite quantum key distribution networks is demonstrated on our testbed. The software-defined-networking control loops are enhanced with a predictive digital twin network, resulting in a reduced service blocking rate and seconds-level latency.

title: M $^{3}$ SegNet: A Multi-Modal and Multi-Branch Framework for Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma Segmentation in Radiotherapy Planning
authors: Junqiang Ma, Luyi Han, Henry H. Y. Tong, Dengqiang Jia, Hui Xie, Anne W. M. Lee, Hing Ming Hung, Tao Tan, Sung Inda Soong, Yue Sun
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Accurate and simultaneous labeling of multiple structures, including gross tumor volumes, clinical target volumes, and organs at risk, is a fundamental multi-task requirement for radiotherapy planning in nasopharyngeal carcinoma. However, conventional manual labeling is labor-intensive and suffers from substantial inter-observer variability. This variability poses a significant challenge to the multi-modal interpretation of CT and MRI scans. Against this backdrop, automated approaches, particularly multi-modal and multi-task learning, are promising solutions. However, their clinical adoption is limited by three urgent needs: attention mechanisms that fuse multi-modal information at both local and global views, explicit incorporation of anatomical priors to regularize predictions, and a unified framework that enables concurrent segmentation of all desired structures. To overcome these limitations, we propose M <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$^{3}$</tex-math></inline-formula> SegNet, a novel multi-modal and multi-branch framework that concurrently performs all clinically relevant segmentation tasks, integrating feature fusion and anatomical guidance. Our primary contributions are threefold. First, we introduce the Synergistic Global-Local Attention that extracts informative features from various imaging modalities (CT, T1-weighted, T2-weighted, and T1 contrast). Second, we propose an Anatomy-Aware Hierarchical Learning strategy that uses OAR spatial information to guide tumor segmentation. We also integrate Random Modality Dropout to enhance robustness against missing modalities. We validated M <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$^{3}$</tex-math></inline-formula> SegNet on an internal 257-patient NPC dataset and confirmed its generalizability on three external datasets. In experiments, our framework significantly outperformed state-of-the-art methods. By providing a mechanism to leverage multi-modal information and anatomical priors, our M <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$^{3}$</tex-math></inline-formula> SegNet offers a reliable, automated, and clinically translatable solution for NPC radiotherapy planning.
