authors: N/A

title: On-Chip Surround Power Delivery Using 25-Ratio SC DCDC Converter with 0.35-3.3V Output Range Achieving 92.3% Peak Efficiency
authors: Xuchu Mu, Yang Jiang, Xin Ming, Bo Zhang, Rui P. Martins, Pui-In Mak
abstract: The rapid advancement of AI-powered wearable devices, such as augmented reality glasses, has driven the emergence of customized low-power multimodal-processing SoCs and integrated power delivery system with stringent physical constraints, as shown in the Fig. 1 (left). Conventional centralized power delivery schemes using inductor-based topologies suffer from problems of localized hot spots and voltage drops due to the extended power delivery network (PDN) routing. Therefore, this work proposes a surrounding power delivery (SPD) architecture utilizing a stretchable arithmetic progression (SAP) switched-capacitor (SC) DC-DC and further integrates heat distribution considerations together with electrical performance optimizations. As a high power density (PD) solution, SC-based converters are particularly advantageous as advanced ring power supply scheme [1] or our proposed SPD architectures. However, the reconfigurable SC (RSC) converter often faces high implementation costs due to exponential-increased number of switches required as voltage conversion ratio (VCR) levels become finer-grained. While a series-connected RSC scheme can extend and subdivide the inherent VCR range without adding extra power switches, it introduces suboptimal conduction losses in each phase, resulting in reduced efficiency across the entire VCR range. By stretching the output paths, the reconfigurable SAP SC converter supports a stepdown from 5 V input voltage ($V_{\text {IN }}$) to a programmable output range of $0.35-3.3 \mathrm{~V}$ with 25 effective VCRs from $3: 2$ to $9: 1$ by only 8 flying capacitors ($C_{\text {FLY }}$), offering a highly efficient solution for power delivery in compact, energy-constrained systems. By distributing the power delivery network around the load circuit, it reduces the formation of hot spots and alleviates the IR voltage drop issues. Realizing an ultra-thin and lightweight implementation with a total thickness of approximately 1.5 mm, the proposed SAP SC converter achieves a peak efficiency of 92.3% and a maximum output power of 650 mW, validating the suitability of the proposed SPD scheme for compact, power-efficient applications. Mitigating the power conversion efficiency (PCE) degradation in series-connected RSC converters, it operates with high efficiency ($\geq 75 \% $) across a wide output voltage (Vout) range (0.44 V to 3.15 V).

title: Analysis of ECG Signal for the Detection of Arrhythmia and Atrial Fibrillation
authors: D N Niranjan, R Tilak Naidu, Vijay Aditya, S Bindu, M K Prashanth, Keerti Kulkarni
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Mobile Networks and Wireless Communications (ICMNWC)
abstract: ECG monitoring remains a widely trusted approach for detecting rhythm abnormalities pertaining to various issues related to the heart. In this work, we outline a simple, yet effective method built in MATLAB that focuses on filtering ECG signals, identifying essentials waveform features, and interpreting heartbeat intervals. Here, we make use of a Butterworth bandpass filter with the aim suppress noise and correct the slow baseline shifts. Following this, P-waves, R-peaks, and T-waves are located through a combination of peak finding routines and window-based analysis. By estimating the fluctuations in RR intervals, the system helps identify rhythm disturbances linked to arrhythmia and AF which is the main objective of this study. Our observations show that this method significantly improves signal readability and consistently identifies major ECG features. However, because the approach relies on fixed threshold values, it may struggle with highly variable patient data. As a result, future work could benefit from adaptive filtering strategies or the integration of machine learning models for improved performance.

title: Improved High-Fidelity Reversible Data Hiding Uses Pixel Replacement
authors: Xiaobo Hu, Jiayu Zhang, Bohan Kong, Youpeng Jin, Yu Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Image steganography is a technique to hide secret information in cover images. Due to the low embedding efficiency of reversible data hiding (RDH) for large payloads, this paper proposes an improved steganography method based on RDH. The n-leftmost bit replacement (n-LBR) and n-rightmost bit replacement (n-RBR) techniques are employed, where n-LBR replaces the leftmost n bits of a pixel, and n-RBR replaces the rightmost n bits. In the n-LBR and n-RBR stages, 2n bits of secret data are evenly embedded into adjacent pixel pairs of the first two identical images. where 1≤n≤2. The experimental results evaluate the peak signal-to-noise ratio (PSNR) and structural similarity index (SSIM), demonstrating the superiority of the proposed method over state-of-the-art approaches.

title: Quantitative Evaluation of Interactive Walking Behavior in Multiple-Pedestrian Environment
authors: Haruki Ito, Hiroyuki Okuda, Tatsuya Suzuki
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: In this paper, first of all, the group walking behavior by four pedestrians are observed. In the observation, not only the motion data but also the decision making of each pedestrian are collected by using special device. Then, three behavioral indicators: deceleration, detour amount, and decision entropy, are defined and calculated. It has been found that these three indicators successfully quantify the ’smoothness’of the group walking behavior. Finally, the principal component analysis(PCA) is applied to the three dimensional indicator data. As the result, the meaning of three principal components are clearly explained. The discussion based on the PCA will be a basis for the further analysis and classification of the group walking behavior.

title: Optimization Method for Electrochemical-Thermal Coupling Parameters of Lithium-Ion Battery Model
authors: Jianqiang Kang, Ye Jiang, Jing V. Wang, Qian Wang
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Energy Engineering and Power Systems (EEPS)
abstract: Lithium-ion batteries are core for new energy vehicles and energy storage systems, with accurate electrochemical-thermal coupled models critical for BMS design. Key parameters are hard to obtain theoretically, and existing methods lack focus on electrochemical model's multi-rate initial SOC adaptation and coupled model's thermal parameter calibration. This study targets a prismatic 128 Ah LiFePOO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</inf> battery: Bayesian optimizes the electrochemical model's initial SOC (multi-rate conditions), achieving voltage RMSE <12 mV; gradient descent identifies the coupled model's 5 temperature-related parameters, resulting in temperature MAE <1° C. It improves model accuracy, supporting battery performance prediction and thermal safety.

title: A novel sensorless position sensing for free-piston engine generation using observation coil
authors: Fengyuan Yang, Huihua Feng, Boru Jia, Zhiyuan Zhang, Wu Qin, Song Li
abstract: Accurate piston position information is crucial for the control and efficient operation of Free piston engine generator (FPEG). Conventional position sensors, however, are costly, which has restricted the development of FPEG. This paper proposes a novel sensorless position observation method based on the structural characteristics of FPEG. By leveraging observation coils to establish a relationship between magnetic flux variation and displacement, this proposed approach enables real-time monitoring of piston position. An equivalent magnetic network model is developed to analyze the flux variation within the observation coil, and a series of displacement observation experiments were conducted on a test bench. The results show that the calculated magnetic flux exhibits a strong linear relationship with the actual mover position. The proposed method achieves real-time position estimation across various operating strokes with a signal delay of less than 1 ms and a detection error below 4%. This technique demonstrates excellent potential for improving the performance, robustness, and commercial feasibility of FPEG systems.

title: NeuroLearn: An Emotion-Adaptive E-Learning Platform Using AI-Powered Sentiment Analysis for Personalized Education
authors: J John Shiny, H Ashish Thippu, N Aaron Sam Jordan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Intelligent Signal Processing and Effective Communication Technologies (INSPECT)
abstract: The ability to recognize emotions has become essential to the development of intelligent tutoring systems, as it allows for the customization of content delivery according to the affective states of learners. The end-to-end Convolutional Neural Network (CNN)-driven e-learning platform NeuroLearn is presented in this paper. Its purpose is to improve student engagement by delivering content in real-time that is emotionadaptive. The system makes use of a CNN model that was specially trained using the FER-2013 dataset, which consists of more than $\mathbf{1 0, 0 0 0}$ annotated facial images from ten different emotion classes. To enable low-latency, client-side emotion inference from webcam input without jeopardizing user privacy, the trained model is transformed into TensorFlow.js format and deployed within the browser environment. The platform automatically reroutes users to emotion-specific lesson content, which is mapped across five subjects and ten modules per class level (10 th and 12th grade), when it detects the learner’s emotional state. NeuroLearn’s modular and scalable architecture for emotionally intelligent digital learning environments is an exemplary model of how the multiple dimensions of affective computing, deep learning, and adaptive user interface design can be integrated into educational technology.

title: A 300 W Soft-Switching GaN Buck-Boost Converter with Adaptive Bi-Directional GaN Driver Achieving 97.8% Power Efficiency for Movable Solar Panel Applications
authors: Longcheng Pi, Yuhang Zheng, Bin Chen, Wei He, Jianlong Lin, Taihai Chen, Xiang Gao, Lenian He, Kai Huang, Xugang Ke
abstract: Movable Solar Panels (MSP) have revolutionized the efficient utilization of solar energy, as their portability ensures the solar energy access in remote or off-grid locations. And this trend has driven the urgent need for the high-efficiency power converter solutions for the movable solar panel applications. In recent years, gallium-nitride (GaN) devices have been adopted as an ideal alternative to its silicon counterpart, owing to its lower parasitic capacitance, higher switching frequency fsw and near-zero reverse recovery current [1]. These superior attributes enable the use of smaller passive components, which benefits the cost reduction and miniaturization of converter system solutions.

title: FakeApp: A High-Precision Method for Domain Fronting Detection in Real Networks with Neuro-Symbolic Integration
authors: Yibo Xie, Gaopeng Gou, Gang Xiong, Zhen Li, Wei Xia
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Domain fronting is a covert communication technique, which evades detection by connecting with legitimate domains to imitate normal network traffic. But the imitation is flawed, so current detection methods usually treat domain fronting as abnormal traffic. However, these methods show very low precision due to normal-abnormal traffic imbalance in practice. In the paper, we find that domain fronting’s imitation is limited to popular applications (apps), such as Chrome and Firefox browser. Thus, we mitigate traffic imbalance by defining domain fronting detection as an app discrimination problem, rather than previous anomaly detection task.According to the revised definition, we propose FakeApp, a high-precision method for domain fronting detection in real networks. Using frequent item analysis, FakeApp first extracts the imitated app information from domain fronting tools as symbolic features. Then, through deep neural networks, it discriminates whether traffic belongs to genuine or spoofed apps. Finally, FakeApp integrates symbolic features and neural networks together to identify domain fronting in real networks. Evaluations over 2 million flows show that the precision of FakeApp is over 95%, far surpassing state-of-the-art methods on four domain fronting tools. These results also indicate that we have effectively mitigated the traffic imbalance issue.

title: An Experimental Method for Runtime Estimation of Evolutionary Combinatorial Optimization
authors: Min Huang, Pengxiang Chen, Tiefeng Zhang
publish: 2025 9th International Workshop on Control Engineering and Advanced Algorithms (IWCEAA)
abstract: Existing runtime analyses of evolutionary combinatorial optimization rely on algorithmic or problem simplifications. To address this issue, this paper proposes an experimental method to estimate the runtime of evolutionary combinatorial optimization without any simplification. The proposed method simulates the expected value of multiple-gain, which is introduced by multiple-gain model to characterize the expected progress over multiple iterations within the optimization process. Curve fitting techniques are subsequently utilized to derive runtime based on experimental data. To validate the effectiveness and generality of the proposed method, experiments were conducted to estimate the runtime for population-based evolutionary algorithms for the knapsack and traveling salesman problems. The results demonstrate that all the estimated runtimes are accurate, providing a new approach for estimating the runtime of evolutionary combinatorial optimization.

title: Hierarchical Procedural Framework for Low-latency Robot-Assisted Hand-Object Interaction
authors: Mingqi Yuan, Huijiang Wang, Kai-Fung Chu, Fumiya Iida, Bo Li, Wenjun Zeng
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Advances in robotics have been driving the development of human-robot interaction (HRI) technologies. However, accurately perceiving human actions and achieving adaptive control remains a challenge in facilitating seamless coordination between human and robotic movements. In this paper, we propose a hierarchical procedural framework to enable dynamic robot-assisted hand-object interaction (HOI). An open-loop hierarchy leverages the RGB-based 3D reconstruction of the human hand, based on which motion primitives have been designed to translate hand motions into robotic actions. The low-level coordination hierarchy fine-tunes the robot’s action by using the continuously updated 3D hand models. Experimental validation demonstrates the effectiveness of the hierarchical control architecture. The adaptive coordination between human and robot behavior has achieved a delay of ≤ 0.3 seconds in the tele-interaction scenario. A case study of ring-wearing tasks indicates the potential application of this work in assistive technologies such as healthcare and manufacturing.

title: Spectrum Sharing in V2X Networks Based on Multi-Agent Graph Emergent Communication
authors: Yue Pi, Wang Zhang, Yulong Ding, Jin Zhang, Yongheng Liu, Shuanghua Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: This paper introduces a novel spectrum resource sharing framework in Vehicle-to-Everything (V2X) communication networks based on multi-agent reinforcement learning with graph emergent communication (MARLGEC). We formulate resource sharing as a distributed multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) problem, where each vehicle acts as an agent, interacting with the environment to optimize spectrum allocation strategies. The introduction of the emergent communication mechanism enhances cooperation among agents in the distributed framework. Meanwhile, the graph attention mechanism effectively reduces the communication overhead incurred by emergent communication. This enables reliable vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V) payload transmission and improves system performance under varying network conditions. The experimental results validate the method’s effectiveness, demonstrating its ability to adapt to the dynamic environment and outperform existing MARL approaches that lack communication mechanisms.

title: Carbon Emission Calculation Methods and Lowcarbon Optimization Strategies for Industrial Parks in New Power Systems
authors: Heli Meng, Fang Tang, Maobo Bai, Rui Chen, Xingtong Chen, Yinan Wang, Xue Wang
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Energy Engineering and Power Systems (EEPS)
abstract: Under the background of “dual-carbon” target, industrial parks, as the core carriers of energy consumption and carbon emission, are crucial to the design of emission reduction pathways with accurate carbon accounting. In this paper, we propose a regional/industrial park carbon accounting methodology for the integration of power generation and use, which realizes the full-calibre carbon emissions of the industrial park by constructing a multi-source emission model covering purchased electricity, fossil energy, heat/steam consumption and carbon sink trading. A 48 -square-kilometre comprehensive industrial park is taken as the empirical object, and its total carbon emissions in 2024 are calculated to be <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$483,038.76$</tex> tonnes of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO}_{2}$</tex>. The results show that: indirect emissions from purchased electricity account for <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$52.61 \%(254,484.28$</tex> tonnes), which is the main source of emissions; direct emissions from fossil fuels account for <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$46.14 \%(223,170.23$</tex> tonnes); self-generation and self-use of green electricity and trading achieve zero carbon emissions, and carbon sinks and carbon trading offset 538.80 tonnes and 100.00 tonnes, respectively. Based on the analysis of the emission structure, the emission reduction paths of upgrading renewable energy installed capacity, strengthening the gradient use of waste heat, deploying energy storage system, and constructing carbon management system are proposed to provide methodological support for the low-carbon upgrading of the industrial park.

title: A Research on Over-Exposed Image Restoration Based on the Dichromatic Reflection Model and U-Net
authors: Yingqi Li, Yang Chen, Zhi Ji, Wendong Yang, Xue Ni, Jiayu Liang
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Wireless Communications and Signal Processing (WCSP)
abstract: Over-exposed regions in images suffer from severe detail loss, degrading visual quality and hindering downstream tasks. We propose a hybrid restoration framework that combines the dichromatic reflection model (DRM) with a lightweight UNet variant. First, a reflection-component separation network leverages MobileNetV2 to extract semantic features and predict YCbCr-space parameters, explicitly decomposing the input into body-reflection and interface-reflection maps. Next, guided by a highlight mask, a mask-aware U-Net variant fuses crossscale base-layer features along the encoder-decoder path to adaptively recover texture, edges, and structure in the overexposed areas. Training is driven by an end-to-end composite loss integrating perceptual, brightness-balance, pixel-reconstruction, and smoothness terms.

title: Based on Multi-Task Scheduling of Artificial Flexible Workshops Using Hybrid Genetic Algorithms Research
authors: Ying Wang, Yuan Sun
publish: 2025 9th International Workshop on Control Engineering and Advanced Algorithms (IWCEAA)
abstract: To address practical scheduling bottlenecks in the Flexible Job Shop Scheduling Problem with Multi-Task Workers (FJSP-MW), this study proposes a hybrid optimization method (GALS) integrating genetic algorithms with knowledge-driven local search. This approach tackles challenges such as multi-task coordination and mismatches between critical path and lead time objectives. First, an Axiomatic Graph Model oriented toward Total Weighted Delay (TWT) is constructed. Release nodes and delivery nodes are introduced, and “worker edges” are designed to characterize the parallel processing capabilities of multi-task workers. Second, a three-layer neighborhood structure based on the critical path is designed. Combined with classic operation block manipulation and dynamic machine-worker adjustment strategies, it effectively compresses idle time for high-priority tasks. Finally, a multi-task ratio metric is proposed to quantify the contribution of parallel worker load to scheduling performance. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method significantly outperforms comparison algorithms across multiple benchmark cases. In a real-world workshop case, it reduces TWT by 32.14% and shortens makespan by 39.02%, validating its effectiveness and superiority in dual-resource collaborative optimization.

title: Rethinking Query Choices for Differential Privacy Auditing
authors: Zehang Deng, Hongqiao Chen, Shan Jiang, Wanlun Ma, Sheng Wen, Tianqing Zhu, Yang Xiang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: Auditing differential privacy (DP) guarantees often relies on querying trained models with specially crafted queries, such as canaries, examples differing between two neighboring datasets. However, in this work, we revisit this common approach and identify a fundamental limitation: canary-based queries may not capture the strongest privacy leakage, as the most informative queries can shift during the training process. This mismatch can result in loose lower bounds on the privacy parameter <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\varepsilon$</tex-math></inline-formula>, underestimating potential risks from query-based adversaries. To address this issue, we propose two methods. First, we introduce a consistent and optimizable surrogate privacy loss function that better aligns with the true privacy loss, called Privacy-loss Maximization Method (PMM), enabling systematic discovery of stronger queries through optimization. Second, we analyze how the optimal queries evolve with model training and propose a gradient-aligned query generation algorithm, called Gradient-Guided Querying (GGQ), that rapidly identifies high-risk queries by aligning their gradients with the distribution of model parameters. Empirical evaluations across multiple tasks demonstrate that our methods consistently produce stronger privacy audit results, offering a more accurate assessment of the privacy risks associated with training algorithms.

title: TWT-LLM: A Universal and Robust Tagged Watermark for Large Language Models
authors: Jibin Zheng, Li Ma, Wenyin Yang, Fen Liu, Yongqiang Li, Zhengbin Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) generate realistic and coherent text, boosting efficiency and decision-making in various fields. However, their generative capabilities pose risks of intellectual property abuse. Watermarking technology offers a solution for information hiding in LLMs, with large model watermarking gaining attention for its unique methods. A critical challenge is embedding watermarks with minimal impact on text quality while ensuring rapid detection, making it an urgent issue to address. In this paper, to address these challenge, we propose a universal and robust tagged watermark technology for LLMs (TWT-LLM). Firstly, the method of TWT embeds a certain amount of watermark information in the sampling process while generating subsequent word text based on the prompt. Then, to enhance the quality of the generated text, we have proposed a group-based local watermark embedding method, which significantly reduces the impact on text quality. The method involves tagging tokens within each group, only the tokens that have been tagged will embed the watermark information. Moreover, to detect the watermark information in the generated text, we have designed a detection method specifically for this watermark embedding technique. Finally, we conducted experiments using the C4 and HC3 datasets, demonstrating that TWT-LLM achieves a lower False Negative Rate and is lighter compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Field Trial of Decentralized Training with Separation of Compute and Storage over 240km Based on Optical Transport Network for Artificial Intelligence
authors: Shan Cao, Dechao Zhang, Jiang Sun, Mingqing Zuo, Tao Wei, Dong Wang
abstract: A novel OTN-based decentralized training scheme with separation of compute and storage is proposed and demonstrated in a field trial. The PP training efficiency remains 99.29% when the transmission distance extends to 240 km.

title: Individual & Common Attack: Enhancing Transferability in VLP Models through Modal Feature Exploitation
authors: Yaguan Qian, Yaxin Kong, Qiqi Bao, Zhaoquan Gu, Bin Wang, Shouling Ji, Jianping Zhang, Zhen Lei
abstract: Vision–Language Pretrained (VLP) models exhibit strong multimodal understanding and reasoning capabilities, finding wide application in tasks such as image–text retrieval and visual grounding. However, they remain highly vulnerable to adversarial attacks, posing serious reliability concerns in safety-critical scenarios. We observe that existing adversarial examples optimization methods typically rely on individual features from the other modality as guidance, causing the crafted adversarial examples to overfit that modality’s learning preferences and thus limiting their transferability. In order to further enhance the transferability of adversarial examples, we propose a novel adversarial attack framework, I&CA (Individual & Common feature Attack), which simultaneously considers individual features within each modality and common features cross-modal interactions. Concretely, I&CA first drives divergence among individual features within each modality to disrupt single-modality learning, and then suppresses the expression of common features during cross-modal interactions, thereby undermining the robustness of the fusion mechanism. In addition, to prevent adversarial perturbations from overfitting to the learning bias of the other modality, which may distort the representation of common features, we simultaneously introduce augmentation strategies to both modalities. Across various experimental settings and widely recognized multimodal benchmarks, the I&CA framework achieves an average transferability improvement of 6.15% over the state-of-the-art DRA method, delivering significant performance gains in both cross-model and cross-task attack scenarios.

title: Dynamic Deployment of Real Time Services in Edge Computing Systems
authors: Sara Cuccagna, Mauro Femminella, Gianluca Giusepponi, Barbara Guasticchi, Luca Moriconi, Gianluca Reali
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Communications Society
abstract: System-on-Chip (SoC) platforms combining programmable logic (PL) and general-purpose processors (PS) are increasingly used in low-latency and real-time applications running in edge computing platforms, thanks to their computing capabilities, low cost, and modest energy consumption. However, their latency performance is often not fully understood in practical deployments. To address such an issue, this paper presents an experimental study of latency and throughput performance on a Zynq-7030 SoC system, explicitly targeting communications between PS and PL implemented through AXI DMA. The analysis is based on measurements conducted on a real hardware platform. By evaluating different architectural and software design choices, this manuscript provides actionable guidance for designing low-latency PS–PS or PS–PL communications on SoC devices. The presented results highlight that latency and throughput can be protocol-limited or hardware-limited, depending on the selected communication architecture. Finally, we present and evaluate an industrial case study to demonstrate the potential of the usage of SoC devices in terms of achievable performance. Although the experimental evaluation is performed on a specific hardware platform, the methodology and conclusions apply more broadly to heterogeneous SoCs relying on shared-memory DMA and Linux-based and/or real time execution environments.

title: SEGMAMBA3D: A Lightweight Mamba-Based Architecture for 3D Medical Image Segmentation
authors: Muhammad Adnan Farooq Butt, Huang Haiyu, Zeeshan Haider, Abdus Saboor, Faryal Farooq Butt
publish: 2025 22nd International Computer Conference on Wavelet Active Media Technology and Information Processing (ICCWAMTIP)
abstract: Three-dimensional (3D) medical image segmentation remains challenging due to its high computational cost and memory consumption of existing deep learning (DL) models. Recently, transformer-based approaches have demonstrated strong performance by modeling long-range dependencies and global context; however, their quadratic complexity limits scalability to volumetric data. State Space Models (SSMs), such as Mamba, have recently emerged as an efficient alternative, achieving linear complexity with respect to sequence length. In this work, we propose SegMamba3D, a lightweight 3D segmentation architecture based on cascaded Mamba blocks that effectively capture long-range spatial relationships while reducing computational burden. SegMamba3D incorporates an Overlapped 3D Patch Embedding module to preserve local context and a streamlined decoder with hierarchical feature fusion, enabled by memory-core attention. We validate our approach on the Brain Tumor Segmentation (BraTS) dataset, where SegMamba3D achieves competitive segmentation performance with only 4.03 M parameters and 12.58 GFLOPs, yielding a mean Dice score of 81.38, comparable to state-of-the-art (SOTA) models. These results demonstrate that the proposed lightweight SSM-based architecture is both effective and efficient for 3D medical image segmentation.

title: Rankformer: Rank-Aware Feature Aggregation for Efficient Low-light Image Enhancement with Retinex Theory
authors: Yu Wen, Xingxing Yang, Huiyu Zhai, Shengyu Xie
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Low-light image enhancement remains a challenging task due to the severe information loss and inherent noise disturbance, especially in extremely dark regions. While existing methods often directly map low-light images to the normal-light domain, they inadvertently amplify noise distributions simultaneously, which leads to color distortion and brightness shift. In this paper, we present a new approach for low-light image enhancement based on the Retinex theory, which is to decompose low-light images into reflectance and illumination maps. Our key contributions are twofold: First, we introduce a rank-aware feature aggregation mechanism within the self-attention framework. This Top-K selection process preserves the most salient responses, effectively mitigating noise and highlighting informative features without increasing computational complexity. This approach prevents target signal dilution, a common issue in existing methods. Second, we propose a coarse-to-fine reconstruction framework that generates high-quality results. This multi-stage process allows progressive image refinement, ensuring robust enhancement across varying low-light conditions. Extensive experiments conducted on three diverse low-light image datasets demonstrate the superiority of our method in terms of both enhancement quality and computational efficiency. Our approach consistently outperforms state-of-the-art techniques, particularly in challenging low-light scenarios with complex noise patterns. Code is publicly available at https://github.com/Wenyuzhy/RankFormer-master.

title: Prismatic-Revolute Hybrid Biped Robot Walking in Unstructured Terrain using Reinforcement Learning
authors: Krishnendu Roy, R Prasanth Kumar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Robotics and Mechatronics (ICRM)
abstract: This paper presents a reinforcement learning (RL) framework for controlling a planar bipedal robot with nine degrees of freedom (DOF), incorporating prismatic joints in both the shank and thigh segments. The inclusion of prismatic knee and thigh joints allows the robot to dynamically adjust its leg length during locomotion, significantly enhancing adaptability to uneven terrain and improving walking stability. The control architecture is implemented within a custom Gymnasium environment, leveraging the MuJoCo physics engine for high-fidelity simulation of the robot’s dynamics, contact interactions, and frictional effects. The RL policy is trained using state-of-the-art algorithms, with observation inputs comprising joint positions and velocities, ground reaction forces, and friction estimates. Simulation results demonstrate that the bipedal robot can successfully navigate uneven terrain without falling throughout the evaluated episode length, while ensuring all joint torque commands remain within the specified actuator limits.

title: Research on the Characteristics of Electromechanical Coupling Dynamics of New Energy Vehicles
authors: Zhentao Wang, Baodi Zhang, Xin Yuan, Benqing Zhang, Hao Cheng, Zhe Miao
publish: 2025 9th CAA International Conference on Vehicular Control and Intelligence (CVCI)
abstract: In recent years, the research focus in the field of hybrids has gradually shifted from economy to component reliability and driving comfort, with vibration and noise control being closely related to the latter. Meanwhile, the study of torsional vibration characteristics of hybrid power systems is a prerequisite for active vibration reduction. Based on the above research ideas, this paper investigates the dynamics of a series-parallel hybrid powertrain under some operating conditions.

title: Multimodal Large Language Model-Action Unit Approach for Mixed Emotion Descriptors
authors: Cheolhee Kim, Seungyeon Ji, Kyungreem Han
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Facial Expression Recognition (FER) allows computers to identify emotional expressions depicted on a human face. While recent vision-language models have demonstrated remarkable performance across various single-emotion-FER tasks, often outperforming human-level, they usually fail mixed emotion cases. This study describes a Multimodal Large Language Model (MLLM) approach (i.e., Emo-AU (Action Unit) LLM) for mixed emotion detection using the FERPlus dataset. The Emo-AU LLM uses a cross-modal attention mechanism that relates AU and visual features to circumvent the limitations of current visual encoders, which rely on coarse facial features. Our model achieved an accuracy of 98.30% for the single-emotion detection, and it obtained accuracies of 89.76% (major emotion: more labeled by 10 annotators) and 82.42% (minor emotion: less labeled) for the two-emotion cases. The model also explains the reasoning behind the predictions in the benefit of a large language model. This study lays the foundations for understanding facial expressions in context—considering the surrounding situation and social interaction, rather than solely relying on the human face in real and generated image/video.

title: IMDRec: Intent-Aware Multi-Interest Modeling with Diffusion-Enhanced Embeddings for Sequential Recommendation
authors: Wenjun Wu, Jingyi Jia, Linkun Dou, Jingxuan Meng
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Sequential recommendation (SR) aims to predict users’ future behaviors based on their historical interactions. While user interest modeling often lies at the core of SR, user intent—which reflects the high-level motivations behind user behaviors—remains relatively underexplored. Despite the recent efforts in modeling user interest and intent, existing methods still suffer from several critical limitations: (1) They regard the entire user sequence as reflecting a single interest, failing to capture diverse user interests; (2) They approach intent modeling as a task separate from interest extraction, which leads to optimization inconsistency and suboptimal recommendation performance; (3) They lack mechanisms to learn robust item representations under sparse interactions, which further degrades both interest extraction and intent modeling in downstream tasks.To address these challenges, we propose IMDRec, an IntentAware Multi-Interest Modeling with Diffusion-Enhanced Embeddings for Sequential Recommendation. IMDRec first integrates a diffusion-based contrastive learning to enhance the robustness of item embeddings under data sparsity, providing a solid embedding foundation for downstream modeling. On top of this, a multi-expert architecture is adopted to capture diverse user interests. In the final stage, a novel end-to-end intent modeling mechanism is designed to learn discrete intent representations, which serve as high-level guidance to adjust user interest representations for recommendations. Extensive experiments on four real-world datasets demonstrate the superiority and effectiveness of our IMDRec.

title: Detecting Periodontal Bone Loss through Image Processing and Artificial Intelligence
authors: Prachi Karale, Swetta Kukreja
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Intelligent Signal Processing and Effective Communication Technologies (INSPECT)
abstract: Periodontal bone loss, a hallmark of periodontitis, poses a significant challenge for accurate diagnosis. Current clinical methods often lack the precision needed for early intervention. This study studied the usefulness of SVM, CNN in identifying periodontal bone loss using panoramic images from an lasting dataset. The results demonstrated that the CNN algorithms accomplished an accuracy of 85.47% in detecting bone loss. These findings suggest that AI-supported analysis of radiographs can notably expand the accuracy and efficiency of periodontal bone loss detection, facilitating timely treatment and improved patient outcomes.

title: Hypergraph Neural Network-based Multi-Granular Root Cause Localization for Microservice Systems
authors: Yaxiao Li, Lu Wang, Chenxi Zhang, Qingshan Li, Siming Rong, Baiyang Wen, Xuyang Li, Kun Ma, Quanwei Du, KeYang Li, Lingfeng Pan, Xinyue Li, Mingxuan Hui
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: Modern enterprises are increasingly adopting microservice architectures to enhance system flexibility and scalability. However, in the face of ever-changing business requirements, the relationships between system components have become increasingly complex, resulting in significant challenges in maintaining system robustness. In recent years, multimodal data-driven approaches based on graph neural networks have emerged as a predominant solution for root cause localization in microservice systems. Our detailed analysis of architectural characteristics and existing research reveals two critical limitations. First, simple graph is insufficient to represent the one-to-many relationships inherent in microservice component interactions, such as deployment, subordinate, and dependency. Second, the current multimodal data-based method has difficulty in performing localization on faults occurring on hosts, services, and instances at the same time.To address these challenges, we propose HyperRCA, a novel multi-granular root cause analysis approach based on hypergraph neural networks. Our approach models system states during faults via a hypergraph with instances as graph nodes, explicitly capturing heterogeneous relationships through three innovative hyperedge designs: deployment hyperedges for infrastructure relationships, subordinate hyperedges for service hierarchies, and dependency hyperedges for inter-component interactions. We used hypergraph neural networks and multi-layer perceptrons to train a root cause localization model based on hyperedge features to achieve multi-granularity root cause localization. Experimental evaluations demonstrate significant performance improvements over state-of-the-art approaches. HyperRCA achieves a maximum HR@5 improvement of 112.62% on single-granularity datasets and 466.43% in multi-granularity scenarios.

title: Adaptive Switched Time-Varying Neural Networks for Solving Cooperative Control of Multi-Redundant Manipulators under Markovian Switching Topology
authors: Xiangliang Sun, Zhijun Zhang, Xiaohui Ren, Yiqi Liu, Yamei Luo
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: For cooperative motion planning of multi-redundant manipulators systems (MRMs) under randomly switching topologies, an adaptive switched time-varying neural network solver (ASTVNN) is developed by integrating Markov processes. To address the challenge of fixed Laplace matrices being incompatible with randomly switching systems, the network topology is constructed by employing two types of Markov random processes (with fully known transition matrices and partially unknown transition matrices). Furthermore, by integrating the coupling relationships among joint positions, velocities, and physical constraints in MRMs, the cooperative motion planning control is formulated as a time-varying quadratic programming problem. The proposed ASTVNN is designed and implemented to solve this problem, where the ASTVNN with error signals exhibits excellent convergence performance. Furthermore, the convergence of the ASTVNN is demonstrated through Lyapunov stability analysis and linear matrix inequality techniques. Finally, simulation results and physical experiment show that the MRMs can realize trajectory cooperative control under two stochastic switching topologies, comparative experiments show that the proposed ASTVNN has better control effects.

title: The Effects of Electrode Shape Different on the Characteristics of Breakdown Development on Polymer Insulator Sheet using High-Speed Camera
authors: I Made Yulistya Negara, I Gusti Ngurah Satriyadi Hernanda, Dimas Anton Asfani, Daniar Fahmi, Arief Budi Ksatria, Achmad Djohan Prayogi, Namira Roudlotul Jannah
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on High Voltage Engineering and Power Systems (ICHVEPS)
abstract: The breakdown mechanism of polymer insulators is still not completely understood. Visual observation is performed to explain the phenomenon in detail. In this study, visual observation was conducted using a high-speed camera to determine the characteristics of the breakdown development (CBD) of the polymer insulator sheets soaked in mineral oil. The variation used is the electrode shape of the testing tool. There are three types of electrode configurations, including unequal diameter electrodes, equal diameter electrodes, and sphere-plate electrodes based on IEC 600243. The CBD is obtained by image data processing with a millisecond interval. The data is also compared to the results of the electric field distribution on the finite-element method (FEM) simulation. The breakdown voltage (BDV) test between all configurations shows that the highest and lowest BDV values are 47.67 kV (sphere-plate electrodes) and 31.35 kV (unequal diameter electrodes). Furthermore, based on the results of the FEM simulation, the opposite results are shown. The maximum electric field strength based on the FEM simulation results is $15.32 \mathrm{kV} / \mathrm{mm}$ (unequal diameter electrodes) and $13.75 \mathrm{kV} / \mathrm{mm}$ (sphere-plate electrodes). The unequal diameter electrode has the smallest wide range of distribution, ranging from 0 to 75 mm 2. Although the sphere-plate electrode has the largest wide distribution range, it is ranging from 0 to 250 mm 2.

title: Enhanced Helmet Detection using a CNN and Genetic Algorithm for Personal Protective Equipment Compliance
authors: Jorge Rodas-Silva, Jorge Parraga-Alava
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Automated helmet detection is essential for verifying compliance with personal protective equipment (PPE) regulations. Real-time detection of helmet use can significantly reduce the risk of injuries caused by falling objects, machinery accidents or other hazards in high-risk environments. In this paper, we explore the impact of Genetic Algorithm (GA) optimization on the computational efficiency and performance of Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) for automated helmet detection, ensuring compliance with PPE regulations. Our approach includes a robust data collection and annotation stage, a CNN architecture, and GA-based optimization to fine-tune hyperparameters for improved accuracy and computational efficiency. Experimental results demonstrate that the GA-optimized CNN outperforms the baseline model in accuracy and robustness, particularly under challenging conditions such as normal lighting and angle variation. With 94% accuracy and a 98% AUC, an inference time of 23.5 ms, and a memory footprint of 245 MB, the GA-CNN excels helmet detection.

title: Deep Unfolding Beamforming and Antenna Selection for uRLLC Communication Systems
authors: Wu Lan, Wei Huang, Shiwen He, Caihong Kai
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Wireless Communications and Signal Processing (WCSP)
abstract: In ultra-reliable low-latency communication systems with finite blocklength transmission, the joint optimization of beamforming and antenna selection (AS) is challenging due to the coupling between discrete and continuous variables, as well as strict latency and reliability constraints. This paper proposes a deep learning framework that integrates graph convolutional networks (GCNs) and a nonhomogeneous quadratic transformation (NQT)-based deep unfolding network to jointly address beamforming design and antenna selection. Specifically, the GCN models the AS as a graph to predict the optimal AS decisions, while the NQT-based unfolding module efficiently approximates the beamforming vectors by reducing matrix inversion complexity in the weighted minimum mean square error algorithm. Simulation results show that the proposed method achieves superior spectral efficiency and computational efficiency compared to traditional schemes.

title: Detecting Suspicious Wireless Transmission by an Aerial Base Station
authors: Xu Jiang, Xiuzhao Ji, Hongjuan Yang, Bo Li, Jie Tang
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Wireless Communications and Signal Processing (WCSP)
abstract: Owing to the flexible deployment and the high possibility of line-of-sight (LoS) air-ground channel, an autonomous aerial vehicle (AAV) has been extensively employed to support air-ground communications and monitor suspicious terrestrial activities. In this paper, we investigate the detection of suspicious terrestrial transmission by an AAV-enabled aerial base station. Specifically, the AAV serves the ground users as an aerial base station and detects the transmitting behavior of a potential terrestrial transmitter simultaneously. Our objective is to minimize the average detection error probability by optimizing the transmit power, trajectory and detection threshold of the AAV. Since the length of each time slot is limited, we consider the scenario that the AAV can only have limited number of detection samples per time slot. We analyze the detection performance of the AAV and obtain its monotonicity. Then, we propose an iterative algorithm to achieve the optimized AAV time slot, transmit power and trajectory by exploiting the monotonicity of the detection error probability. The numerical results show that our proposed scheme can efficiently enhance the detection performance.

title: Optical Omnidirectional Transmitter for Underwater Wireless Optical Communication
authors: Jiaming Lin, Lu Wang, Shuanghe Liu, Tongzheng Sun, Jian Song, Yuhan Dong
abstract: Underwater wireless optical communication (UWOC) offers high-speed and low-latency data transmission but is often hindered by stringent alignment requirements and limited beam divergence. To overcome these limitations, we propose an optical omnidirectional transmitter based on LED arrays for UWOC applications and experimentally evaluate the spatial illumination distribution and communication performance. The proposed system achieves a quasi-circular radiation pattern in the horizontal plane, enabling alignment-free and mobile operation. Experimental results demonstrate that the system supports data rates of up to 151 Mbps at distance of 5 meters and 50 Mbps at 10 meters, with minimal performance degradation across varying yaw angles. These results confirm the system’s capability to mitigate alignment constraints while ensuring stable and high-speed data transmission, making it a promising solution for dynamic and mobile underwater communication scenarios.

title: Optimization of Insulation Performance for Multi-Layer Insulating Cardboard Structure in UHV Reactor Outlet Device
authors: Xiaoyu Zhao, Geqi Li, Ke Wang, Yikun Zhao
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Energy Engineering and Power Systems (EEPS)
abstract: The direct outlet device of UHV reactor is a key component connecting the reactor and external lines, and its insulation performance directly determines the operational reliability of the UHV power grid. Aiming at the impact of the number of outer insulating cardboard layers of the device's lead tube on insulation performance, this paper adopts a method combining electric field simulation and experimental verification to compare and analyze the electric field distribution and insulation margin of the 2-layer and 4-layer insulating cardboard structures. For the simulation, 2D and 3D electric field models are established, and parameter settings are based on UHV rated operating conditions. the minimum insulation margin of the 4-layer insulating cardboard structure is increased by 12%, resulting in better insulation reliability. The experiment verifies the insulation performance through power frequency withstand voltage and partial discharge tests. The results show that: the minimum insulation margin of both structures is significantly greater than the design threshold of 1.05, which can meet the insulation requirements; This study can provide a reference for the insulation structure optimization and cost control of UHV reactor outlet devices.

title: Stock Prices Forecasting Using a Cerebellar Model Neural Network and Extreme Learning Machine
authors: Jin-Liang Zhang, Chih-Min Lin
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: This paper presents an approach for the forecast of daily stock price. Stock prices are not constant over time and are becoming increasingly uncertain in modern financial markets, so that their forecasting is more important and challenging. A new structure, called a cerebellar model extreme learning machine (CMELM), is proposed, which includes a cerebellar model neural network used as a main predictor and an extreme learning machine used for parameter learning. In order to attain better accuracy, a wavelet is used to decompose the original stock price time series. This framework is tested using the data from the Taiwanese stock market, and the experimental results show that it outperforms the benchmarks that are established in this study. Because it is extremely fast and sufficiently accurate, the proposed method has great potential for practical applications.

title: KANDU-Net: Enhancing Global Context Capture in Medical Image Segmentation with Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks
authors: Chenglin Fang, Kaigui Wu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: The U-Net model has consistently demonstrated exceptional performance in the field of medical image segmentation, with various improvements and enhancements made since its introduction. However, convolution operations have limitations in capturing long-range dependencies and global contextual information, a constraint inherited by U-Net as it relies on convolutions. To address this issue, this paper proposes an innovative architecture. By leveraging the powerful nonlinear representation capabilities of Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks, a new global feature extraction module is introduced. A KAN-convolution dual-channel structure is employed, and a feature fusion module is designed to effectively combine local and global features. Building upon the strengths of U-Net, the KANDU-Net architecture is constructed and validated on the Kvasir, GLAS, and BUSI datasets, achieving the best segmentation performance.

title: Forward Brillouin scattering in few-mode fibers: Opportunities for accurate temperature sensing
authors: Marcelo A. Soto, Yichun Li, Liang Zhang
abstract: This paper provides an overview of the mechanisms, key features, and experimental and simulation results of forward Brillouin scattering in few-mode fibers, highlighting its potential for high-precision temperature sensing.

title: LLM-Guided Genetic Improvement: Envisioning Semantic Aware Automated Software Evolution
authors: Karine Even-Mendoza, Alexander Brownlee, Alina Geiger, Carol Hanna, Justyna Petke, Federica Sarro, Dominik Sobania
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: Genetic Improvement (GI) of software automatically creates alternative software versions that are improved according to certain properties of interests (e.g., running-time). Search-based GI excels at navigating large program spaces, but operates primarily at the syntactic level. In contrast, Large Language Models (LLMs) offer semantic-aware edits, yet lack goal-directed feedback and control (which is instead a strength of GI).As such, we propose the investigation of a new research line on AI-powered GI aimed at incorporating semantic aware search. We take a first step at it by augmenting GI with the use of automated clustering of LLM edits.We provide initial empirical evidence that our proposal, dubbed PatchCat, allows us to automatically and effectively categorize LLM-suggested patches. PatchCat identified 18 different types of software patches and categorized newly suggested patches with high accuracy. It also enabled detecting NoOp edits in advance and, prospectively, to skip test suite execution to save resources in many cases. These results, coupled with the fact that PatchCat works with small, local LLMs, are a promising step toward interpretable, efficient, and green GI.We outline a rich agenda of future work and call for the community to join our vision of building a principled understanding of LLM-driven mutations, guiding the GI search process with semantic signals.

title: Direction of arrival estimation using full eigenstructure projection
authors: Mohammad S. Khan, Praveen B. Choppala, Mohammed Ashik
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Intelligent Signal Processing and Effective Communication Technologies (INSPECT)
abstract: Direction of arrival (DOA) plays a critical role in array signal processing that enables localisation and beamforming in radar, sonar and wireless communications applications. The multiple signal classification is a notable DOA estimation algorithm that operates by projecting a hypothesis steering vector onto the noise subspace such that a correct hypothesis yields an orthogonal projection and consequently a spectral peak. The method, however, requires knowledge of the number of sources (or model order) in the region of surveillance. This assumption can be bypassed by estimating the number using the Akaike information criterion (AIC) or the minimum description length (MDL) methods. However, these methods are susceptible to errors in challenging scenarios when the noise is high or the number of snapshots is small. In this paper, we propose a method that is model order agnostic. The method uses the full eigenstructure of the sample covariance matrix with a clever weighting scheme that suppresses signal subspace and enhances the noise. Simulation results exhibit reliable performance in challenging scenarios, making the method a practical tool for DOA estimation when model order is unknown.

title: Design and Performance Analysis of Compact Planar Multiband Antenna for Wireless Applications
authors: S. Nandhaguru, Bala Vishnu J
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Intelligent Signal Processing and Effective Communication Technologies (INSPECT)
abstract: The multiband patch antenna has emerged as a critical component in satellite, military, and modern wireless communication systems due to its ability to operate across multiple frequency bands. This work presents a compact multiband patch antenna designed to support communication across diverse frequency bands without prior knowledge of the operating frequency, ensuring adaptability and flexibility in dynamic communication environments. The proposed antenna, with dimensions of $40 \times 40 \mathrm{~mm}$, is optimized for 5 G applications, offering enhanced bandwidth and higher data rates, making it suitable for next-generation wireless systems. It operates across four distinct frequency bands, covering WLAN, WiMAX, Cband, and radar applications, specifically at $3.25 \mathrm{GHz}, 5.53 \mathrm{GHz}, 6.87 \mathrm{GHz}$, and 8.56 GHz. The antenna employs a rectangular patch configuration fabricated on a flameretardant 4 (FR4) substrate with a thickness of 1.6 mm. The design achieves a return loss below -10 dB, indicating excellent performance. The development process involved three stages, starting with a basic rectangular patch and evolving into a multiband configuration. The antenna was simulated using CST software and subsequently fabricated, utilizing copper for the coaxial feed line. Comprehensive performance evaluation, including S-parameters, gain, VSWR, and surface current analysis, demonstrates the antenna’s effectiveness for multiband communication applications, highlighting its potential for integration into advanced wireless systems

title: Predictive Disturbance Sequence-Enhanced MPC for Longitudinal–Lateral Cooperative Trajectory Tracking of Autonomous Vehicles
authors: Wenhao Xiao, Guochen Liu, Qingfang Lv, Kang Song, Hui Xie
publish: 2025 9th CAA International Conference on Vehicular Control and Intelligence (CVCI)
abstract: To enhance the robustness and accuracy of trajectory tracking under time-varying and coupled disturbances, this paper proposes a predictive disturbance sequence-enhanced model predictive controller (PDS-MPC) for longitudinal–lateral cooperative control of autonomous vehicles. First, a longitudinal–lateral error model is constructed based on vehicle kinematics. Then, a multi-input multi-output extended state observer (MIMO-ESO) is designed to estimate real-time multi-channel disturbances. Based on these estimations, a coupled disturbance model is developed to generate predictive disturbance sequences. Finally, a novel MPC framework is constructed by embedding the predictive disturbance sequences into the prediction model, thereby enhancing the system's disturbance rejection capability without increasing computational complexity. Simulation results show that compared with conventional MPC and constant disturbance sequence MPC (CDS-MPC), PDS-MPC reduces root mean square error (RMSE) by 24.87% and 14.94% respectively, demonstrating superior tracking performance.

title: Movable Antenna-Enabled Secure Transmission for Active RIS-Aided ISAC Systems
authors: Hongyi Bian, Feilong Zhao, Minghao Chen, Lingling Liu, Yu Yao, Hao Jiang, Feng Shu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering
abstract: The integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) technology empowered by movable antennas (MAs) has increased the possibility of wireless communication development. In this paper, we investigate a discrete MA-enabled active reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS)-aided ISAC system. In this system, the position of discrete MAs can be dynamically adjusted to enhance channel conditions, thereby improving the communication security of legitimate users against potential eavesdropping risks from target. In particular, we formulate an optimization problem for the max-min secrecy rate (SR) by jointly optimizing beamforming matrix, phase shift matrix and MA discrete positions. An efficient alternating optimization (AO) based on penalty- successive convex approximation (SCA) and penalty-dual-decomposition (PDD) approach is proposed to obtain a high-quality initial solution for beamforming matrix and phase shift in the non-convex problem. Next, we propose a dueling double deep Q-Network (D3QN)-twin delayed and deep deterministic policy gradient (TD3) method to cope with the hybrid action space issue of the non-convex problem with highly coupled variables. Numerical results demonstrate that the introduction of MAs can effectively improve SR performance compared to fixed-position antenna (FPA) structure in RIS-aided ISAC systems. In addition, the proposed AO-based D3QN-TD3 method validate the suitability and superiority compared to the D3QN-TD3 method without AO algorithm.

title: A Transition Probability Matrix Approach to Brain Dynamics - A Quantitative Analysis of EEG Sequences
authors: J. J. Joshua Davis, Robert Kozma
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: EEG-based identification of brain states has advanced significantly, enabling cognitive monitoring during daily tasks. Brain dynamics can be studied as a Markovian, Semi-Markovian, or Non-Markovian stochastic process, prescribed by Transition Probability Matrices derived from EEG measurements. This study models brain dynamics as discrete Markov chains using second-by-second dominant frequencies derived from the power spectrum of high-density array EEG signals. By analyzing transition and limiting probabilities across modalities, we reveal distinct neural signatures that differentiate engaged from meditative states. Though preliminary, these findings highlight the method’s potential to enhance BCI systems and deepen our understanding of brain dynamics, brain health and the benefits of meditation in future studies.

title: Benchmarking Lightweight Transformers and Small Language Models for Climate Change Sentiment Analysis
authors: Basirudin Rachman
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Information Technology, Information Systems and Electrical Engineering (ICITISEE)
abstract: Understanding public sentiment toward climate change is essential for guiding communication, policy, and public awareness. This study benchmarks Transformer-based and Small Language Model (SLM) paradigms for climate change sentiment classification using the publicly available Twitter Climate Change Sentiment Dataset. Evaluated models include fine-tuned Transformers (BERT-tiny, DistilBERT, RoBERTa-base, RoBERTa-large, and a custom Transformer), a drift-aware streaming variant, and zero-shot and few-shot SLMs (Phi-3, Mistral 7B, and Qwen2 7.6B). Experiments measured macro-F1, accuracy, and inference efficiency across uniform tweet samples. Results show that RoBERTa-large fine-tuned for 20 epochs on GPU achieved the highest performance (macro-F1 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=0.8217$</tex>), followed by RoBERTabase (0.7874) and DistilBERT (0.7444), outperforming BERT-tiny (0.6767). SLMs performed poorly (macro-F1 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=0.1667-0.5070$</tex>) and exhibited high latency (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>2.5 \mathrm{s} /$</tex> sample), while the driftaware Transformer achieved moderate performance (macro <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{F1}=0.5526$</tex>, accuracy <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=0.5527$</tex>) with resilience to concept drift in streaming conditions. These findings demonstrate that lightweight fine-tuned Transformers remain the most effective and efficient models for domain-specific sentiment analysis, whereas current SLMs are not yet practical for real-time or fine-grained classification without adaptation. Future work will explore prompt optimization, instruction tuning, and adaptive streaming integration to improve the robustness of environmental Natural Language Processing (NLP) systems.

title: HASH-Z: A Height-Correction Adjusted Spherical Harmonic Model for Real-Time Tropospheric Delay Correction over China
authors: Hao Chen, Ningbo Wang, Kefei Zhang, Tomasz Hadas, Zishen Li, Hongxing Zhang, Suqin Wu, Longjiang Li, Hang Zhong, Liang Wang
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Precise point positioning (PPP) has become a key technique in global navigation satellite systems (GNSS) applications, but its use in real time is limited by long convergence times. Tropospheric delay is one of the major contributors to this limitation. Accurate modeling over China is particularly challenging due to pronounced topographic variations, where empirical or conventional polynomial models fail to capture spatiotemporal characteristics. We propose a height-correction adjusted spherical harmonic model (HASH-Z) that incorporates an exponential height-decay term into a regional spherical cap expansion to account for the vertical dependence of zenith wet delay (ZWD). The model is developed from ZWD estimates obtained with PPP ambiguity resolution (PPP-AR) at a GNSS network in China (∼200 km spacing). Validation against IGS reference products confirms that centimeter-level accuracy of PPP-AR-derived ZWD estimates. Across the modeling stations, root mean square errors (RMSE) remain below 2.0 cm for all sites in winter and for more than 83% of sites in summer. A latitude-dependent variability is evident in winter, but largely obscured in summer due to pronounced atmospheric water vapor fluctuations. Independent tests at stations spanning large height differences further confirm the robustness of the model, with RMSE values of 0.5–1.9 cm in winter and 1.2–2.9 cm in summer. When applied in PPP-AR augmentation, the HASH-Z can significantly accelerate convergence by ∼20% in the vertical component and improve positioning accuracy by 4–12%. These results demonstrate that the HASH-Z model can provide an accurate and efficient representation of tropospheric delay over China.

title: Noise-like rectangular pulses with asymmetric spectral stripes in a 1.7-μm ultrafast fiber laser
authors: Zhenhong Wang, Jinhai Zhu, Geguo Du, Jun Liu, Yufeng Song
abstract: In this study, we have observed and characterized distinct noise-like rectangular pulses (NLRPs) in a passively mode-locked fiber laser at 1.7 μm. The corresponding optical spectrum features unique asymmetric stripes, similar to asymmetric spectral modulation. Additionally, this pulse regime possesses the temporal characteristics with free of pulse breakup even under the increased pump power. Furthermore, the time-stretch dispersive Fourier transformation measurements reveal substantial shot-to-shot spectral fluctuations alongside smooth averaged spectrum without spectral stripes, thereby confirming that these NLRPs originate from an ensemble of stochastic sub-pulses with random intensities. Numerical simulations reproduced similar experimental observations and revealed that spectral filtering is an important factor influencing the spectral stripe features. These findings not only offer a new perspective for the design and optimization of ultrafast fiber lasers but may also provide insightful implications for high-resolution distance metrology in practical applications.

title: Multi-scale Dynamic Dilated Transformer for UAV Real-time Ship Inspection
authors: Huijie Miao, Jie Zhang, Jiang Yan, Jian Zhou
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Aiming at the problems encountered in object detection of UAV vessels in China’s offshore waters, this paper, based on the YOLOv11 algorithmic model, creatively proposes a new object detection algorithmic architecture, DCM-Net, based on the problems of multi-scale and complex background of the targets in the images captured by UAVs by making various improvements to the model, so as to significantly improve the performance of the UAV monitoring model. To begin with, we aim to uncover the multidimensional semantic information encapsulated within the image, we introduce the Multi-scale Dilated Attention Transformer (MSDA) module, which captures details of targets across a spectrum of scales and refining the model’s sensitivity to image subtleties. The MSDA module improves the model’s comprehension and expression of the multiscale features while maintaining the computational efficiency. Secondly, we dynamically adjust the model architecture so that DCM-Net is more sensitive to changes in the scale of ship targets, which improves the monitoring performance of the model to a greater extent. Finally, in order to optimize the model for reduced complexity and satisfy the detection task when the resources of the edge devices are insufficient, we introduce the dynamic convolution module to reduce the model computation consumption and improve the model expression ability. Through extensive experimental validation on the public datasets HRSC2016, Seaships, and Shipsdataset, our model improves 3.3%, 16%, and 50% in mAP50 and computational consumption and FPS metrics, respectively. The experimental outcomes demonstrate that our algorithm significantly enhances the model’s detection capabilities.

title: DTU-Net: A Multi-Scale Dilated Transformer Network for Nonlinear Hyperspectral Unmixing
authors: Chentong Wang, Jincheng Gao, Fei Zhu, Abderrahim Halimi, Cédric Richard
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Transformers have shown significant success in hyperspectral unmixing (HU). However, challenges remain. Transformer-based unmixing networks, built on Vision Transformer (ViT) or Swin Transformer, struggle to effectively capture essential multi-scale and long-range spatial correlations. Additionally, these networks predominantly rely on the linear mixing model, lacking the flexibility to accommodate scenarios with significant nonlinear effects. To address these limitations, we propose a multi-scale Dilated Transformer-based unmixing network for nonlinear HU (DTU-Net). Its encoder integrates two branches: a spatial branch mainly employing Multi-Scale Dilated Attention (MSDA) to uniquely capture intricate multi-scale and long-range spatial correlations via adaptive receptive fields, and a spectral branch utilizing 3D-CNNs with channel attention. This design enables comprehensive extraction as well as integration of multi-level spatial and spectral features. The decoder is specifically designed to accommodate both linear and nonlinear mixing. It explicitly models the polynomial post-nonlinear mixing model (PPNMM) by learning nonlinear coefficients as pixel-wise features, which enhances interpretability by directly reflecting the pixel-level nonlinear mixing strength. Experiments on synthetic, ray tracing, and real datasets validate the effectiveness of the proposed DTU-Net, demonstrating its superior performance compared to both PPNMM-derived and advanced unmixing networks. The code is available at: https: //github.com/ChentongWang/DTU-Net.

title: Prompt-Guided Domain Generalization for EEG Emotion Recognition
authors: Xuan Zhang, Wang Zheng, Hongxin Cai, Zhigang Li, Yi Yang, Weijia Liu, Junru Zhu, Jingyu Liu, Bin Hu, Qunxi Dong
abstract: Cross-subject electroencephalogram (EEG) emotion recognition is an important task in affective computing, which aims to learn discriminative and generalizable EEG features to reveal emotions across individuals. To achieve robust generalization, existing methods primarily focus on developing domain alignment constraints to learn features that remain consistent across all source domains, while ignoring the potential benefits of domain-specific information in enhancing model discriminability. As a result, these approaches struggle to utilize relevant source domain information to improve predictions for unseen domains. To address this limitation, we propose a novel prompt-guided domain generalization (PGDG) framework that extends the invariance perspective by incorporating domain-specific information through prompt learning. Specifically, the variational autoencoder is first used to extract domain-invariant features, and then the prompt of each source domain is learned by guiding the classifier in the optimal direction. Finally, a multi-head cross-attention mechanism adaptively integrates these domain prompts from multiple source domains to improve the model's generalization ability in target domains. Experimental results on the SEED and SEED-IV datasets show that PGDG outperforms state-of-the-art methods, demonstrating the potential of prompt-guided generalization in improving cross-subject EEG emotion recognition performance.

title: Typical-Day Selection and Dynamic Programming Dispatch for Photovoltaic-Plus-Battery Energy Storage Systems: Lifecycle Economics and Break-Even Analysis in the Electricity Spot Market
authors: Zhongguang Wu, JingWei Liu, Sheng Feng, Suhua Yao, Wenqin Liu, Shenhe Lin
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Energy Engineering and Power Systems (EEPS)
abstract: With the large-scale integration of renewable generation, optimizing the dispatch and evaluating the investment of photovoltaic (PV) and battery energy storage systems(BESS) in electricity markets has become a research focus. This paper proposes a full life cycle economic assessment and break-even analysis framework for BESS, with a typical day selection and dynamic programming(DP) dispatch model. The framework jointly accounts for the volatility of electricity prices, penalties for forecast inaccuracy, and capital cost constraints of storage. Firstly, hierarchical clustering is employed to extract representative typical days from year-round price and output series, thereby reducing computational complexity while preserving temporal features and empirical distributions. Secondly, based on these typical days, we formulate an electricity spot market charge/discharge optimization model that incorporates market and physical constraints to obtain optimal multi-period storage strategies. Finally, a financial module is introduced to assess investment feasibility and identify break-even conditions. Case studies show that the model effectively characterizes the relationship between capacity sizing and investment payback, providing quantitative guidance for planning and investment decisions of PV+BESS projects. By combining typical day driven analysis, dispatch optimization, and investment boundary identification, the proposed method is well suited for economic evaluation and investment boundary delineation of storage projects in modern power systems.

title: Three-Dimensional Situational Awareness for Everyday Safety: Integration of Epidemiological Data and Three-Dimensional Spatial and Behavioral Data
authors: Naoki Nozaki, Yuya Kawabe, Mikiko Oono, Koji Kitamura, Tatsuhiro Yamanaka, Yoshifumi Nishida
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: An inclusive society has a growing demand for support systems that can accommodate the diversity of human physical and mental functions and the diversity of living environments. This study focuses on preventing home accidents involving young children as a concrete example of methodologies for observing, modeling, and controlling "living situations," which are complex systems composed of people and their environments, where interactions between people and environments change over time. Although previous research has proposed technologies for recognizing children’s behaviors and detecting environmental risks, few have integrated behavior and environment to predict accident pathways and time to occurrence. In this study, the authors propose a system that integrates home data scanned in three dimensions acquired through smartphones, child position data obtained using posture recognition technology, and epidemiological accident databases (N=358,715 cases) collected by the Tokyo Fire Department in Japan. The system estimates accident risks based on the relative positions of furniture and children, and visualizes the predicted paths and expected arrival time to high-risk objects in real-time. The evaluation based on national accident statistics confirmed that the system’s object recognition covers approximately 70% of furniture types involved in serious accidents. By conducting experiments for a six-year-old child and 55 three-dimensional scanned data obtained in actual living environments, the authors also demonstrate the feasibility of risk visualization considering the individuality and dynamic nature of living environments.

title: Bearing fault detection under low-speed and variable-speed conditions: An adaptive multi-period cumulative cross-reference correlation coefficient signal reconstruction
authors: Xin Chen, Chao Li, Yanlei Yin, Yu Guo, Tao Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: The optical encoder-based instantaneous angular speed (IAS) signal offers advantages such as direct correlation with torque, and a non-time-varying transmission path, making it widely studied in fault diagnosis applications. Nonetheless, under low-speed and variable-speed conditions, the IAS fluctuations caused by the faulty rolling element bearings (REBs) remain weak since REBs do not transmit torque. This study discusses the elapsed time-based IAS estimation method and analyses factors influencing the magnitude of IAS fluctuations, including operational speed, fault severity, radial load and random slip. Furthermore, phenomenological models are established for both inner and outer race faults in REBs, incorporating the encoder installation position, random slip and other relevant factors. Finally, to enhance the weak characteristics of the faulty REBs, a multi-period cumulative cross-reference correlation coefficient (MPCRCC) signal reconstruction scheme is proposed, leveraging the IAS fluctuation characteristics, multi-period accumulation, and cross-reference correlation. Simulation and experimental results demonstrate that the MPCRCC algorithm effectively enhances fault-related features of REBs under low-speed and variable-speed conditions.

title: Initial Coin Offerings Versus Equity Financing Strategies Under Cournot Competition
authors: Zhiyuan Chen, Qiaoyun Gong, Jianhong Zhou
abstract: Enabled by blockchain progress, ICOs emerged as an alternative to traditional equity financing, with global investor reach, decentralized governance, and reduced transaction costs.
