To solve these problems, we propose a retrieval filtering and thought enhancement framework for function-level code generation based on large language model. In our model, we design an abstract syntax tree mapping preprocessing module to preprocess the dataset and help large language models learn the detailed syntax information of the dataset. Furthermore, we design a retrieval filtering and thought enhancement module to retrieve the most relevant snippets of code for the task and to enhance the chain-of-thought of our model. In addition, we design a self-repair mechanism to prevent large language models from overfocusing on generated erroneous code, helping them explore more solutions to repair the erroneous code. We experimented and evaluated our model on HumanEval, MBPP, and MultiPLE benchmarks to compare with other baseline models.

title: Design and Implementation of a Voice-Assisted Mobile Robot for Elderly
authors: Sumanth Gowda P, Sanju Sajith, Ottigunta Sathvika, Banani Talukdar, Vighnesh T, Mandar Jatkar, Roopa K R
publish: 2025 International Conference on Robotics and Mechatronics (ICRM)
abstract: As the global elderly population rises, there is a growing demand for intelligent systems that can promote independent living and guarantee safety for senior citizens. The design and development of personal assistant robot for the elderly is presented in this paper with the goal of resolving the daily difficulties faced by them. The proposed system is designed to execute essential daily functions such as medication dispensing, real-time video monitoring, voice-controlled communication, and human-following mobility, all within a domestic environment. Its key features include timely and automated medicine dispensing, autonomous navigation powered by sensor fusion techniques for robust obstacle avoidance and path planning, automatic Google assistant-based voice activated task execution. To make the interaction simple, especially for non-technical users, a user-centric design approach is used. The robot responds to spoken commands, initiates phone calls, set reminders and play audio content. The robot is equipped with an onboard camera that enables continuous surveillance of the elderly user by their family. It can follow the elderly user indoors using sensor fusion-based human-following algorithm. When the battery runs low, it can return to its docking station on its own. Literature review insights reveal that existing assistive robots often lack integration, adaptability, or affordability. Our system builds upon prior work by incorporating cost-effective platforms such as, Google assistant-based voice recognition, and sensor fusion techniques for robust navigation in dynamic environments. The medicine dispenser module offers a secure and intuitive interface for medication adherence, activated by an alarm and reset manually by the user. This project demonstrates a feasible, scalable prototype that enhances quality of life, promotes autonomy, and reduces caregiver dependence thereby presenting a feasible method for elderly care within smart home ecosystems.

title: Small Scale Raspberry Pi Based Autonomous Car: A Practical Guide to Understand Complexity
authors: Nallabati Venkata Durga Sai Sarat Chandra, Nunna Mokshith, Asha C A, Sreekumar P. C
publish: 2025 International Conference on Robotics and Mechatronics (ICRM)
abstract: This paper offers a guideline to develop a smallscale autonomous car using the Raspberry Pi. The aim of this work is to demonstrate that the complexity of autonomous driving can be simplified through an approach that is replicable, cost-effective, and provides access to many features similar to Level 3–4 autonomous vehicles. The system described integrates key functionalities such as ultrasonic sensors for obstacle avoidance, a Pi camera for computer vision tasks including lane tracking and traffic signal recognition, and inter-vehicle communication for cooperative behavior. The implementation incorporates fundamental principles of sensor fusion, control, and machine learning to enable perception of the environment and intelligent driving decisions. This paper is designed to act as an accessible educational reference, highlighting the challenges and solutions encountered in autonomous vehicle technology and offering insights into the underlying engineering aspects.

title: Comprehend, Imitate, and then Update: Unleashing the Power of LLMs in Test Suite Evolution
authors: Tangzhi Xu, Jianhan Liu, Yuan Yao, Cong Li, Feng Xu, Xiaoxing Ma
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: Software testing plays a crucial role in software engineering, ensuring the reliability and correctness of evolving systems. Well-maintained test suites are essential for ensuring software quality. However, in modern development cycles that emphasize rapid feature iteration, the co-evolution of test suites often lags behind, leading to more appearance of obsolete tests. To this end, automated approaches for updating obsolete test code have been proposed, and recent approaches have achieved the state-of-the-art performance with the support of large language models (LLMs). This paper presents COMMITUP, a new approach that leverages LLMs to effectively automate method-level obsolete test code updates. COMMITUP mimics how humans solve the problem, first comprehending the code modifications, searching for similar examples to imitate, and finally performing the update. We evaluate COMMITUP on a curated dataset from real-world Java projects. The results demonstrate the superior performance of COMMITUP, achieving 96.4%, 94.4%, 93.1% success rates for generating compilable, runtime failure-free, and full coverage updates, respectively. We believe our study can provide new insight into LLM-based test code update. The dataset and code are available at https://github.com/SoftWiser-group/CommitUp.

title: Adaptive Pooling and Dynamic Triplet Loss for Image-Text Retrieval
authors: Jinshuai Hu, Xiao Wei, Hongfei Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Image-text retrieval (ITR) is a fundamental task in multimodal learning. It aims to bridge image and text by constructing a shared embedding space that achieves accurate semantic alignment across two modalities. Most existing work has been devoted to designing tailored cross-attention modules to pursue retrieval accuracy but ignores the learning potential of the model network architecture. This work introduces a dual encoder that uses global information to enhance the feature interaction between visual regions. Designing an Adaptive Pooling (AP) module enables the model to automatically learn the optimal aggregation strategy from multiple perspectives based on the local features. We further propose a Dynamic Triplet Loss (DTL) to adjust the learning objective of the model network dynamically for efficient training. Experimental results on two benchmark datasets, Flickr30K and MS-COCO, demonstrate our APDTL model achieves state-of-the-art performance. Our code is released at github.com/jinshuaihu/APDTL.

title: A Differential Protection Method for Intelligent Substations Based on Multi-Scale Feature Extraction and Temporal Modeling
authors: Yong Lai, Bo Zhang, Gang Chen, Shizhen Li, Lili Liu
abstract: With the continuous advancement of smart grid and digital substation technologies, traditional differential protection methods have gradually exposed limitations such as delayed response and high misjudgment rates when dealing with complex operating conditions and nonlinear transient disturbances. To enhance the robustness and intelligence of transformer differential protection, this paper proposes an intelligent differential protection identification method that integrates Neural Network-based Principal Component Analysis (NNPCA), Convolutional Neural Network (CNN), and Lightweight Gated Recurrent Unit (LGRU). Firstly, NNPCA is used to perform nonlinear dimensionality reduction and decorrelation processing on sampled differential current signals, thereby enhancing feature expression capabilities. Then, a multi-scale CNN module is constructed to extract local spatial features of disturbances, and an LGRU network is introduced to model the temporal evolution of differential current, enabling dynamic and accurate identification of internal faults and non-fault disturbances. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms traditional protection strategies in terms of accuracy, response speed, and anti-disturbance performance, showing strong practical value and engineering applicability.

title: A Deep Multiscale Wavelet Scattering-Attention Model for Real-Time Underwater DoA Estimation
authors: Murtiza Ali, Karan Nathwani
abstract: Direction-of-arrival (DoA) estimation is vital for underwater target localisation but is challenged by multipath propagation and noise in dynamic ocean environments. To tackle such issues, we introduce the multiscale attentive wavelet scattering fusion (MAWSF) for DoA estimation in the challenging underwater environment. This MAWSF is a deep learning-based network, trained on simulated underwater data, capable of generalising to real oceanic scenarios. MAWSF performs multi-scale feature extraction using directional convolutions and wavelet scattering transforms to capture spatial patterns and enhance robustness to noise. It also employs attention mechanisms to model global dependencies and enhance context awareness. To emulate real oceanic conditions, we simulate multipath propagation along with varying source-receiver depths, ranges, and ambient noise levels. These simulations are used to generate multi-channel spatial covariance matrices labelled with a one-hot encoded true DoAs vector for training. MAWSF is evaluated on the real SWellEx-96 dataset, where it demonstrated high angular resolution in offgrid DoA estimation. It achieves an RMSE of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$14.76^{\circ }$</tex-math></inline-formula>, surpassing the performance of state-of-the-art networks. Unlike traditional methods, it requires no prior knowledge of noise or multipath counts, making it well-suited for real-time applications.

title: Homomorphic Encryption for Privacy-Preserving Federated Learning in Medical Applications
authors: S Shabana, H S Ranjan Kumar, K Raju, Kiran Puttegowda
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Mobile Networks and Wireless Communications (ICMNWC)
abstract: The growing reliance on machine learning (ML) in healthcare raises critical concerns regarding data privacy and security. While federated learning (FL) enables collaborative model training without centralized data sharing, it remains vulnerable to inference attacks through model gradients and unauthorized access by third parties. To address these challenges, this work proposes a privacy-preserving federated learning framework that integrates homomorphic encryption (HE) with logistic regression for secure medical data analysis. In the proposed approach, local model parameters are encrypted using homomorphic schemes before aggregation on a centralized server, ensuring that neither raw data nor model updates are exposed. Experimental evaluation with BFV, BGV, and CKKS encryption schemes demonstrates that the framework achieves competitive accuracy ($\gt 85 \%$) while safeguarding patient information. Among the tested schemes, BGV provided the highest accuracy ($\sim 89.81 \%$), whereas BFV achieved optimal training efficiency. The results highlight that combining federated learning with homomorphic encryption can effectively balance model performance and data confidentiality, making it a promising solution for privacy-preserving healthcare applications.

title: GMM-LSTM-OrthogonalVAE Based Soft Sensor Modeling for Industrial Impurity Prediction
authors: Yifan Wu, Futao Jiang, Xiuli Zhu, Yamei Ju
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotics, Control and Automation Engineering (RCAE)
abstract: In industrial production processes, process data typically exhibit characteristics such as strong nonlinearity, high dimensionality, and cross-correlation, which pose significant challenges for data-driven soft sensor modeling. Traditional Orthogonal Variational Autoencoders (OVAEs) improve upon standard VAEs by introducing an orthogonal constraint, enabling the extraction of features like strong nonlinearity and autocorrelation under orthogonal conditions. However, their fully connected network structure fails to capture the temporal dynamics of process variables, potentially leading to prediction results affected by delay and lag effects. To address this limitation, we propose a new model: GMM-LSTM-OVAE. This approach integrates the temporal modeling capability of Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks, the feature disentanglement capability of Orthogonal Variational Autoencoders, and the robust modeling advantages of Gaussian Mixture Models (GMM). Using the Dow Data Challenge problem as a case study, the present work validates the performance of the GMM-LSTM-OVAE model in predicting impurity level at primary outlet of a distillation refining system. Experimental results demonstrate that, compared to conventional methods, the proposed model based soft sensor exhibits significant advantages in terms of prediction accuracy.

title: Dual-Encryption Method for Images Based on Autoencoder and LowDimensional Chaotic System
authors: Haiyan Li, Longxuan Dai, Feng Ling, Ye Zhou, Lei Hu
publish: 2025 2nd International Symposium on AI and Cybersecurity (ISAICS)
abstract: In this paper, we propose a dual-image encryption scheme that combines an autoencoder based on multiscale residual modules with a low-dimensional chaotic system. The autoencoder enhanced with multiscale residual modules is employed to accomplish the first layer of encryption. In the second encryption stage, a dual-sequence chaotic pixel scrambling method based on the Henon chaotic map is introduced to perform the initial scrambling. Subsequently, diffusion is achieved through the application of finite field correlation theory. Finally, the Fisher-Yates algorithm is utilized to carry out the second scrambling operation. The proposed method effectively reduces the key space while maintaining strong encryption performance.

title: Broadband Second-Harmonic Generation in a Double-Layer Thin-Film Lithium Niobate Tapered Waveguide
authors: Yuan Li, Lutong Cai, Lin Zhang
abstract: We demonstrate broadband second-harmonic generation in a tapered waveguide on the platform of double-layer thin-film lithium niobate. A bandwidth of around 60 nm and a conversion efficiency of around 45% W<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-1</sup> are achieved.

title: Attention-Enhanced YOLOv8n for High-Precision Fish Species Recognition in Underwater Monitoring
authors: Yan Wu, Haiquan Qiu, Shuailong Ma
publish: 2025 2nd International Symposium on AI and Cybersecurity (ISAICS)
abstract: Fish species recognition, as an important research direction in the field of image processing, has broad application prospects in aquaculture, fishery resource monitoring, and underwater ecological protection. However, due to the complexity of the underwater environment, large variations in fish morphology, strong background interference, and uneven lighting conditions, existing methods still face challenges of insufficient accuracy and limited robustness in practical applications. To address these issues, this paper proposes improvements to the YOLOv8n model. First, an attention-based scale feature fusion module is introduced into the neck network to enhance the model’s global perception and multi-scale feature extraction capabilities. Second, an additional detection layer P2 is incorporated into the head network to improve the detection accuracy of small fish targets and strengthen overall robustness. Experiments conducted under diverse background conditions and varying fish postures demonstrate that the improved model achieves outstanding performance in deep-sea fish recognition tasks, with an accuracy of $91.3 \%$, representing a 3.6 percentage point improvement over the baseline, and an average precision of $93.0 \%$, showing a 0.7 percentage point increase. These results validate the effectiveness and applicability of the proposed method in complex underwater environments and provide an important reference for automatic fish recognition and intelligent monitoring.

title: Intelligent Shooting Training System using Sensor-based Motion Capture and Feedback
authors: Guozhong Qu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Mobile Networks and Wireless Communications (ICMNWC)
abstract: Background: In recent years, an accurate assessment of gun shooting performance is increasingly critical for Internet-of-Things (IoT)-based athlete training and shill monitoring. Where shooting actions involve complex wrist-gunarm coordination, rapid impulse-driven motions and shooterspecific execution patterns. Challenges: Existing Virtual Reality Shooting Performance Assessment System (VR-SPAS) fail to capture phase-specific coordination such a pre-short aiming stability, trigger pull smoothness and post-shot recoil recovery, even though VR-SPAS perform adequately in overall shooting outcomes. Proposed Model: To address these limitations, this research proposes an Action-Phase Gun Shooting Training System (AP-GSTS) for personalized training. Initially, multiaxis Inertial Measurement Units (IMU) signals are collected from wrist-mounted and gun-mounted sensors, which are synchronized with trigger events and segmented into pre-shot, firing as well as post-shot phases. Then, collected signals are preprocessed with Temporal Motion Normalization and Smoothing (TMNS) to preserve micro-instabilities. A Temporal Sequence Encoder (TSE) models phase-aware motion dynamics, which are compared to expert reference sequences to compute interpretable scores for stability, trigger execution and recoil control. Finally, an actionable feedback generator translates these scores into phase-specific recommendations for targeted skill improvement and adaptive training. Results: The experimental results demonstrates that the proposed AP-GSTS framework in terms of mean of 21.52%, Standard Deviation (SD) of 2.22 from 0-25 range, when compared to existing VRSPAS approach.

title: Low-Cost Prosthetic Arm and Wearable Assistive System for Individuals with Paralysis and Incapacitated
authors: G Rajesh, Mamta B. Savadatti, R. Lakshman, R Thanu Shree, Rolly Krishnan, Asmitha Narayana
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Mobile Networks and Wireless Communications (ICMNWC)
abstract: The ability to restore mobility and independence for individuals with motor impairments has driven continuous innovation in the fields of prosthetics and assistive technologies. Most of the existing prosthetic systems depend on either electromyographic or manual control, thus limiting their adaptability and intuitive responsiveness. This work proposes a low-cost, non-invasive brain-computer interface for the control of upper-limb prosthetics. Acquired EEG signals are denoised and processed using a hybrid deep learning framework that combines CNNs and Transformer models to make sure that the intent is recognized correctly. Decoded neural commands, in real time, actuate a 3D-printed prosthetic arm through servo mechanisms. An experimental evaluation using benchmark datasets of EEG resulted in a classification accuracy of 96.8% with an average reaction latency of 420 ms. Moreover, it reduced repetitive cognitive input by 45% with the help of the “memory recap” function. The results hereby establish the validity of developing dependable and reasonably priced neuroprosthetic devices for everyday assistance and rehabilitation.

title: Technical Analysis of Vehicle to Grid (V2G) Implementation in Indonesia for Peak Shaving and Valley Filling (PSVF) Strategy in the Java Madura Bali Load Curve
authors: Kharisma Utomo Mulyodinoto, Budi Sudiarto, Agus Setiawan, Ahmad Raditya Cahya Baswara, Fauzan Hanif Jufri, Muhammad Gillfran Samual
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on High Voltage Engineering and Power Systems (ICHVEPS)
abstract: The increasing integration of electric vehicles (EVs) into modern power systems introduces both challenges and opportunities for grid management, with Vehicle-to-Grid (V2G) technology emerging as a promising solution to enhance flexibility, stability, and renewable energy integration. V2G enables bidirectional energy exchange between EVs and the grid, positioning vehicles not only as consumers but also as distributed energy resources capable of supporting dynamic and resilient system operations. This research investigates the application of V2G as a Peak Shaving and Valley Filling (PSVF) strategy using the Java Madura Bali (JAMALI) load curves for 2023 and 2024 as representative case studies. Through simulation modelling, the study evaluates V2G’s ability to mitigate peak load stresses during high-demand periods and improve load utilization during low-demand intervals, thereby enhancing operational efficiency in a power system increasingly shaped by variable demand and renewable generation. The result shows that the implementation of Vehicle to Grid (V2G) technology within the Java Madura Bali system significantly enhances the load curve profile by effectively reducing peak loads and elevating valley loads, which in turn contributes to improved grid stability through the creation of a more uniform load profile. Consequently, V2G adoption represents a highly promising strategy for demand-side management and the reinforcement of grid reliability, especially in anticipation of rising EV penetration in future energy systems, highlighting its critical role in enabling a sustainable and stable transition to low-carbon power networks.

title: Domain-Adapted Diffusion for Synthetic Data Augmentation in UAV Small Object Detection
authors: Wu Qilong
publish: 2025 22nd International Computer Conference on Wavelet Active Media Technology and Information Processing (ICCWAMTIP)
abstract: Recently, diffusion-based generative models offer new avenues for synthetic data augmentation, yet VA V imagery still suffers from significant domain shift compared to general image datasets used to pre-train these models: small objects, high altitudes, oblique views and cluttered backgrounds all diverge from web-scale image distributions. To address this, we introduce a novel augmentation pipeline combining three key innovations. 1) Fine-tuning a pretrained text-to-image diffusion model by weighting latent loss in small-object regions, thereby adapting the model toward the UAV domain. 2) Deriving diverse scene prompts automatically by applying UMAP dimensionality reduction and HDBSCAN clustering on the original UAV training set, then using a large language model to generate scene-level prompts that when combined with class labels guide synthesis. 3) Filtering generated image-label pairs by cropping detected boxes and computing Contrastive Language-Image Pre-training (CLIP, a model for measuring cross-modal similarity between images and texts) similarity between each crop and its class description, discarding mismatched pairs. Experiments on a UAV small-object detection dataset demonstrate that our augmented data significantly improves detection performance.

title: Feasibility analysis of off-grid Solar-Wind Hybrid Renewable Energy Systems in a Coastal Area of Bangladesh
authors: Muhammad Jobayed Ibna Bashar, Salman Rashid, Md. Anawar Ibrahim, Shihab-Al-Rashid, Md. Zahid Hasan, A.B.M. Noushad Bhuiyan
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Information and Communication Technology (EICT)
abstract: This paper presents a feasibility analysis of an off-grid solar-wind hybrid Renewable Energy System, which is presented in a comprehensive manner for the coastal area of Bangladesh, specifically in Ukhia Upazila of Cox’s Bazar District. Bangladesh has a significant energy demand, but it also faces a substantial energy shortfall, despite achieving $\mathbf{1 0 0 \%}$ electrification coverage. The viability of a $40-\mathrm{MW}$ hybrid renewable energy system, comprising $431,899 \mathrm{~kW}$ of solar panels, 23 MW of wind turbines, $31,661 \mathrm{~kW}$ of converter capacity, and storage, is evaluated. The system design, simulation, and optimization used in the HOMER Pro software showed very good system performance with 100% RES penetration as follows: annual electricity generated $\mathbf{7 3 3, 1 3 0, 9 0 3}$ kWh, higher than the load consumption of $158,974,518 \mathrm{kWh}$. The outcomes for zero CO2 emissions and 29% system efficiency are an NPV of 1.13 billion USD and an LCOE of ${\$}$0.3498USD/kWh. The additional $560,914,178 \mathrm{kWh}$ of electricity per year creates grid and financial opportunities. This research suggests that hybrid renewable systems can be technically and economically feasible within the context of Bangladesh’s coastal regions, ensuring energy security in an environmentally friendly manner and helping to attain renewable energy targets.

title: High-Efficiency Phase-Change Beam Steering for Wavelength-Selective Optical Switching
authors: Xiaoqi He, Yan Li, Yuru Li, Yanfeng Zhang, Zhaohui Li
abstract: We propose a reconfigurable phase-gradient meta-surface based on low-loss phase-change material Sb<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>Se<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> for dynamic beam steering. By leveraging the large refractive index contrast in Sb<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>Se<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> phase-change, the metasurface generates a tunable phase gradient that enables wavelength-selective beam deflection with high efficiency. This approach provides a compact solution for wavelength-selective optical switches (WSSs), with promising applications in wavelength-division multiplexing (WDM) systems requiring dynamic spatial light control for reconfigurable photonic networks.

title: Research on the Trustworthy and Reliable Evaluation Method for Sea-Space-Air-Ground Integrated Communication Nodes in Offshore Wind Farms
authors: Chanjuan Tang, Jing Yu
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Infocomm Technology (ICAIT)
abstract: To address the challenge of evaluating the trustworthiness and reliability of heterogeneous network communication nodes in offshore wind farms, this paper proposes an integrated evaluation method based on the Entropy Weight-TOPSIS model. Firstly, multi-dimensional performance metrics and topological location data of heterogeneous network nodes are systematically collected. Secondly, the entropy weight method is employed to calculate node metric weights and the node contraction method determines topological weights, which are then fused by the linear weighting method to derive the combined weights. Finally, the nodes’ importance is quantified and ranked using the TOPSIS method. Experimental results show that the proposed method can effectively evaluate the reliability of heterogeneous communication network nodes, which is of the significant advantages in improving the reliable performance of the network data transmission compared with the traditional method. The proposed method provides a reliable decision-making basis for optimizing the Sea-Space-Air-Ground integrated communication network in Offshore Wind Farms.

title: Recognized Core Model Based on YOLOv5 Combined with CSL
authors: Lingyu Wang, Yifan Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th International Conference on Power, Intelligent Computing and Systems (ICPICS)
abstract: Cores play a crucial role in geological research and applications, necessitating an efficient method for core extraction from images, as manual segmentation and classification can significantly impede fieldwork. In this study, we propose a rotating frame labeling and detection approach for core identification, integrating YOLOv5s with Circular Smooth Labeling (CSL) for target recognition. To optimize the training process, we employ a combination of warm-up and cosine annealing strategies for adaptive learning rate adjustment. Furthermore, we ensure the reliability of model training by analyzing different loss curves and conducting comparative ablation experiments to evaluate detection performance under varying CSL radius. The experimental results demonstrate that at a CSL radius of 4, the model achieves the highest performance, with a precision of 0.8874, recall of 0.9503, OBBmAP@0.5 of 0.9640, and OBBmAP@0.75 of 0.6979. These findings confirm that the optimal prediction performance is attained at a CSL radius of 4, thereby validating the effectiveness of the YOLOv5s-CSL model for automated core identification in field applications.

title: Design of a Theo Jansen-Type Locomotion System and Its Integration with an Autonomous Control System for Navigation on Uneven Terrain
authors: Adrian Bedoya, Jesús Jimenez, Jose Becerra, Ayrton Nieves, Julio Ronceros, Jose Carrizales
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotics, Control and Automation Engineering (RCAE)
abstract: This paper presents the design and analysis of an autonomous mobile robot for solid waste collection in hard-toreach areas of Metropolitan Lima. Conventional methods of locomotion, such as wheels or tracks, have limitations in uneven terrain, such as hills and unstructured urban areas. To overcome these barriers, a locomotion mechanism inspired by Theo Jansen is proposed, which allows better adaptability and energy efficiency on complex surfaces. The prototype integrates two main components: (1) a stability control system based on an Inertial Measurement Unit (IMU), which dynamically adjusts the robot's displacement to maintain its balance; and (2) a navigation module using odometry and inertial sensors, which allows autonomous control of movement and adaptation to terrain irregularities. The methodology includes mechanical modeling in CAD, structural and dynamic simulations on irregular surfaces, and performance analysis of the locomotion system. Improvements in traction, stability and adaptability are expected compared to traditional systems. This work seeks to contribute to the development of efficient robotic platforms for operations in unstructured and difficult-to-access environments.

title: ALIME: Local Interpretable Explanations based on Generalized Additive Models
authors: Yixin Wang, Yucheng Dong, Haiming Liang, Yao Li, Yuzhu Wu, Quanbo Zha
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Local Interpretable Model-agnostic Explanations (LIME) is an interpretable method used to explain the predictions of machine learning models. It generates perturbed samples around an instance and fits a simple surrogate model, such as linear regression, to approximate the local behavior of the black-box model. This paper introduces Additive Local Interpretable Model (ALIME), a LIME variant based on generalized additive models (GAMs), where feature effects are modeled by penalized splines (P-splines), providing flexibility for capturing nonlinear relationships. Experimental results show that ALIME outperforms the original LIME method in terms of local fidelity. In addition, the shape functions generated by ALIME can clearly capture local feature contributions, providing insight into the relationship between features and model outputs, and enhancing overall interpretability.

title: Vlm-Assisted Pedestrian Crossing Intention Recognition From Monocular Human Pose
authors: Dayi Tan, Wei Tian, Mengjie Zhou, Dongxiao Yin, Lu Xiong
publish: 2025 9th CAA International Conference on Vehicular Control and Intelligence (CVCI)
abstract: Rapid and effective pedestrian crossing detection can provide crucial perceptual information for decision-making and planning in autonomous driving systems, significantly enhancing driving safety. Current pedestrian crossing recognition method based on single pose sequences exhibits poor accuracy in complex scenarios. To address this limitation, we propose a hybrid framework that integrates monocular pose sequences with multimodal data, including semantic segmentation, human bounding box, and vehicle speed. Additionally, we incorporate text features generated by a vision-language model (VLM) to improve scene understanding in complex environments. This approach combines visual and non-visual information for pedestrian crossing recognition. Experimental results on the JAAD dataset demonstrate that our method achieves higher accuracy compared to existing approaches, offering a novel solution for pedestrian crossing detection in autonomous driving scenarios.

title: Integrating Stacked Boosting Models and Random Forest for Hybrid Ensemble Liver Disease Classification
authors: L Natrayan, Yenuga Padma, Siva Kumar Pathuri, Seeniappan Kaliappan, Ramya Maranan, M S Radha Manga Mani
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Intelligent Signal Processing and Effective Communication Technologies (INSPECT)
abstract: Liver disease is one of the health issues of paramount concern in the world today, and early identification is essential to enhance patient outcomes. This paper presents a stacked ensemble learning model that can be used to diagnose liver conditions based on structural medical records having both clinical and biochemical variables. The method combines two strong classifiers namely Random Forest (RF) and AdaBoost into a single ensemble to put into account the interaction among the features and provide greater stability to prediction.In order to enhance generalization, lessen over-fitting and ascertaining confidence assessment, the model was prepared and validated using $\mathbf{k}$-fold cross-validation in a known liver illness benchmark dataset. It is shown that the RF -AdaBoost ensemble with the highest classification accuracy (96.8 percent) outperforms the traditional methods like Decision Trees (91 percent) and Support Vector Machines (88 percent). Other measures such as precision, recall, F1-score and the area under the ROC curve were used to verify that the ensemble was performing better.This suggests that the suggested hybrid model is efficient in dealing with the issue of class imbalance and complex feature interdependence, therefore, can be used as a potential tool in the early diagnosis of liver disease and become an important addition to the clinical decision support systems.

title: Solving The variable-coefficient Helmholtz Using An Artificial Neural Network Approach
authors: Soumaya Nouna, Assia Nouna, Ilyas Tammouch, Abdelamine Elouafi, Nabil Benjaa
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Advanced Communication Technologies and Networking (CommNet)
abstract: We investigate a mesh-free artificial neural network (ANN) solver for the variable-coefficient Helmholtz equation, a core model for time-harmonic wave phenomena in heterogeneous media. The proposed formulation represents the solution as a smooth neural function and trains it by minimizing a composite loss that enforces the PDE residual via automatic differentiation together with Dirichlet boundary data. We evaluate the method on a controlled two-dimensional (2-D) benchmark with spatially varying wavenumber, quantify accuracy using global error metrics (L2, MAE, RMSE), and analyze accuracy cost drivers such as collocation budgeting and boundary sampling. Results indicate that the ANN approach attains competitive accuracy relative to classical discretization pipelines while avoiding explicit meshing and offering flexibility for complex geometries. We discuss practical design choices (activation, loss weighting, sampling) that are important for oscillatory solutions and heterogeneous coefficients. The present study focuses on a specific 2-D variable-coefficient case with a known target function selected for reproducibility and ablations; therefore, the findings should not be interpreted as fully general. We outline extensions to higher-frequency regimes, non-smooth coefficients, mixed boundary conditions, and three-dimensional settings, where the same formulation applies with augmented inputs and scaled collocation/memory budgets. Overall, the study provides a reproducible benchmark and guidance for deploying ANN-based solvers on variable-coefficient Helmholtz problems.

title: Facial Expression Recognition with Combined Eye-Mouth ROI Extraction using Facial Landmarks and CNN
authors: Hassan Afifi, Idriss Chana, Aziz Bouazi, Mostafa Merras, Abdallah Marhraoui Hsaini
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Advanced Communication Technologies and Networking (CommNet)
abstract: Facial expression recognition (FER) has become increasingly important in human-computer interaction, affective computing, and social robotics. This paper presents a novel approach to FER that combines Region of Interest (ROI) extraction with a custom Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) architecture. Our method addresses the limitations of traditional approaches by focusing on the most discriminative facial regions: the eye-eyebrow area and the mouth region.The proposed methodology consists of four main stages: (1) preprocessing the image, (2) detection of facial landmarks, (3) extraction and sequencing of ROI regions in an input image, and (4) feature extraction and classification using a custom CNN with three convolutional layers with various filter sizes and an activation function =1.5*X. Extensive experiments on the FER2013 dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach. The proposed ROI-based CNN achieves an accuracy of 72.04%, outperforming conventional methods by focusing on the most expressive regions of the face. Our comparative analysis reveals that ROI extraction significantly improves recognition performance. The activation function (f(x) = 1.5x) provides a better decay flow that amplifies the response of neurons in order to improve the network’s sensitivity to slight variations in facial expressions and avoid dead neurons.

title: Enhancing Alzheimer's Disease Diagnosis with Explainable Deep Learning Through a CNN Based Approach Using Grad CAM and LIME
authors: Parthiv JP, Pon Harshavardhanan, Rajit Nair
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Computing Technologies (ICACT)
abstract: Alzheimer's Disease (AD) is a progressive neurode- generative disorder, affecting over 50 million individuals globally, with projections to reach 150 million by 2050 due to aging populations. Early detection is crucial for initiating interventions such as cholinesterase inhibitors and lifestyle modifications, yet traditional diagnostic methods like neuropsychological testing and MRI analysis often lack the sensitivity required for early- stage identification. This study introduces a Dual-Attention Aware Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) designed to classify AD stages using structural MRI scans from the augmented Alzheimer's Disease Neuroimaging Initiative (ADNI) dataset. The model incorporates spatial and self-attention mechanisms to enhance feature extraction, achieving a validation accuracy of 96.79 % at its best epoch and a testing accuracy of 76.31 %. Explainable AI (XAI) techniques, including Gradient-weighted Class Activation Mapping (Grad-CAM) and Local Interpretable Model-agnostic Explanations (LIME), are integrated to provide interpretable insights into model predictions. The proposed framework outperforms traditional CNN architectures such as DenseNet121, InceptionV3, and ResNet50, offering a robust and transparent diagnostic tool for clinical application.

title: Intelligent Forecast Model for Photovoltaic Reactive Power Output Considering Data Distribution Drift
authors: Sicheng Huang, Yi Wang, Kemeng Li, Yuanjue Zhang, Juanjuan Lu
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Energy Engineering and Power Systems (EEPS)
abstract: The forecast of photovoltaic reactive power output is particularly important for the safe and stable operation of the power grid. However, the variation of photovoltaic reactive power output is complex, and existing studies have not considered the impact of data distribution drift caused by seasonal changes on the forecast accuracy of photovoltaic output. To address this, this paper proposes a short-term forecast method for photovoltaic reactive power output, which develops a forecast model for a specific season. The method then applies transfer learning to adapt this model to other seasons, thereby mitigating the effects of data distribution drift. Finally, the proposed method is validated through simulations using actual data from a photovoltaic power plant in East China. This approach accurately forecasts photovoltaic reactive power output using a Long Short-Term Memory neural network with an Attention mechanism and demonstrates the feasibility of transfer learning in addressing data distribution drift. It contributes to supplementing the required forecasted values of photovoltaic reactive power output for power grid planning data.

title: Repairing Leaks in Resource Wrappers
authors: Sanjay Malakar, Michael D. Ernst, Martin Kellogg, Manu Sridharan
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: A resource leak occurs when a program fails to release a finite resource like a socket, file descriptor or database connection. While sound static analysis tools can detect all leaks, automatically repairing them remains challenging. Prior work took the output of a detection tool and attempted to repair only leaks from a hard-coded list of library resource types. That approach limits the scope of repairable leaks: real-world code uses resource wrappers that store a resource in a field and must themselves be closed.This paper makes four key contributions to improve resource leak repair in the presence of wrappers. (1) It integrates inference of resource management specifications into the repair pipeline, enabling extant fixing approaches to reason about wrappers. (2) It transforms programs into variants that are easier to analyze, making inference, detection, and fixing tools more effective; for instance, it makes detection tools report problems closer to the root cause, often in a client of a resource wrapper rather than within the wrapper class itself. (3) A novel field containment analysis reasons about resource lifetimes, enabling repair of more leaks involving resources stored in fields. (4) It introduces a new repair pattern and more precise reasoning to better handle resources stored in non-final fields.Prior work fixed 41% of resource leak warnings in the NJR benchmark suite; our implementation Arodnap fixes 68%.

title: Analysis of Mode Chirality in Microring Resonators via Imaging of Out-of-Plane Light Scattering
authors: Jinjiang Lin, Jin Li, Ran Cheng, Jiaqi Zhao, Yang Tan, Jiawei Wang
abstract: We present a direct method to assess mode chirality in spiral microring resonators through out-of-plane light scattering imaging. Experimental and theoretical analyses show that the spiral-edge-induced scattering quantitatively maps intracavity field asymmetries upon bidirectional injection directions, providing a sensitive probe to chirality. The approach further resolves chirality changes induced by molecular coating.

title: Succinct Aero Engine-KG: A Knowledge Graph Framework for Pre-Retrieval in Fault Diagnosis
authors: Tingda Ji, Tao Tao, Xuyun Fu, Yalong Feng, Shisheng Zhong
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Sensing, Diagnostics, Prognostics, and Control
abstract: The increasing structural and functional complexity of aero engine systems, harsh operating environments, and high maintenance and repair costs have posed significant challenges to fault diagnosis. The development of LLM (Large Language Model), KG (Knowledge Graph), and RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) technologies offers new prospects for formulating fault diagnosis solutions. In response, this paper proposes a collaborative RAG pre-knowledge enhancement architecture based on LLM and KG. This architecture is designed to improve the accuracy and completeness of fault diagnosis knowledge acquisition. Consequently, it will support the subsequent efficient construction of fault resolution plans. The architecture incorporates innovative methods such as Using LoRA fine-tuning instead of traditional KG ontology modeling, optimized entity-relationship extraction, and KG essential feature representation, enabling end-to-end knowledge extraction from unstructured text to structured triples. This enhancement of the domain adaptability and semantic coverage of the QA system is a significant contribution of this study. The experimental results demonstrate the capacity of the proposed framework to accurately identify user intent and retrieve relevant terms from the knowledge graph for subsequent RAG-based retrieval.

title: Thermal Distribution Characteristics and Testing Methods of the Electromechanical Coupling System in Hybrid Electric Vehicles
authors: Wei Zhang, Cao Huang, Yuan Gao, Yao Sun
publish: 2025 9th CAA International Conference on Vehicular Control and Intelligence (CVCI)
abstract: The electromechanical coupling system examined in this paper is a key powertrain component in hybrid vehicles, and its thermal distribution directly affects system reliability and efficiency. This paper employs a dedicated thermal test bench equipped with embedded high-precision thermocouples at critical locations-such as the stator winding and bearings-to systematically measure and compare temperature distributions under pure-electric, series, parallel, and idle-charging modes. Results indicate that under low-speed, high-torque conditions, temperature rise is primarily driven by electrical losses, whereas under high-speed, low-torque conditions, mechanical losses become more significant. Additionally, insufficient coolant flow or multi-source power operation leads to pronounced temperature fluctuations and a distinctly asymmetric thermal distribution within the stator winding. Based on these findings, this paper proposes an optimized NTC sensor placement scheme and establishes a flow-temperature coupling model to provide theoretical support and engineering guidance for thermal monitoring and management strategy optimization.

title: Intelligent Environment Interaction Design based on Reinforcement Learning
authors: Yi Fu, Yunfei Guo
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Mobile Networks and Wireless Communications (ICMNWC)
abstract: With the widespread application of smart environment systems in home, VR/AR, and multi-user collaborative scenarios, existing intelligent perception and control technologies still face challenges in personalized adaptation, real-time response, and multi-dimensional state perception, including insufficient precision, redundant actions, and significant user experience variability. To address this issue, this paper proposes a smart environment interaction design method based on A3C reinforcement learning. By uniformly modeling information such as lighting, temperature, device status, and user location, action, and preferences, the system enables adaptive decision-making between discrete device control and continuous parameter adjustment. The A3C network algorithm inputs the state vector and extracts highdimensional features. Actors output action selection probabilities (discrete actions) or continuous action parameters (mean and variance) to guide environmental responses. Experimental results show an average collaborative task completion rate of 87.5%, with relatively similar completion rates across user groups, ranging from a high of 90% (G3) to a low of 85% (G2). This demonstrates that the system effectively supports successful task completion in multi-user collaboration.

title: Cross-Regional Distribution Network Digital Twin Collaborative Simulation Framework Based on Federated Learning and Edge Computing
authors: Bo Wang, Cheng Xu, Liang Sui, Luyao Pei, Meng Xu, Zhixuan Lv
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th International Conference on Power, Intelligent Computing and Systems (ICPICS)
abstract: With the rapid development of smart grid technologies, the complexity and cross-regional interconnection of distribution networks have continuously increased, making traditional centralized simulation methods inadequate for collaborative analysis of large-scale cross-regional distribution networks. This paper proposes a cross-regional distribution network digital twin collaborative simulation framework based on federated learning and edge computing, aiming to address key issues such as data privacy protection, communication efficiency, and computational resource allocation in cross-regional distribution networks. The framework primarily consists of three layers: data perception layer, edge computing layer, and federated learning layer. The data perception layer is responsible for collecting real-time operational data from various regional distribution networks; the edge computing layer constructs regional digital twin models locally and performs preprocessing; the federated learning layer enables cross-regional model parameter sharing and collaborative optimization while protecting data privacy. This research provides a new technical approach for collaborative analysis and optimization of crossregional distribution networks, which is of great significance for promoting the safe and efficient operation of smart grids.

title: Predicting Heart Failure Hospitalizations with LLMs from Health Insurance Data
authors: Everton F. Baro, Luiz S. Oliveira, Alceu De Souza Britto
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Heart failure (HF) represents a global clinical and economic challenge, with hospitalizations accounting for 65% of disease-related costs. This study proposes an approach to predict HF hospitalizations using Large Language Models (LLMs) trained on chronological data from Brazilian health insurance beneficiaries. By converting administrative records (consultations, medications, diagnoses) into temporal narratives, models like RoBERTa and Open-Cabrita3B were fine-tuned to identify clinical deterioration patterns. The HealthHistoryRoBERTapt model, trained with historical health insurance data and specifically adjusted for HF, achieved an AUC-ROC of 0.93-0.95 in prediction windows from 5 to 180 days, significantly outperforming other studies (AUC 0.63-0.76) using static clinical data or basic demographics, and those combining clinical-administrative data (AUC 0.82). It is noteworthy that the ability of the model to maintain an F1-score greater than 0.85 and sensitivity of 0.87 in predictions of up to 150 days, revealing that administrative variables (e.g., history of hospitalizations, frequency of consultations) function as effective proxies for socioeconomic and behavioral factors, traditionally neglected. Compared to other works, this study demonstrates that longitudinal health insurance data combined with NLP techniques capture non-linear risk trajectories, enabling precise predictions for strategic health planning.

title: Strengthening Pharmaceutical Supply Chain Surveillance: A Blockchain-Based Counterfeit Drug Alert Framework
authors: Venkateswarlu Boddu, Malaya Dutta Borah, Naresh Babu M
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Computing Technologies (ICACT)
abstract: This paper proposes a blockchain-based framework to monitor drugs and trigger alerts to safeguard stakeholders when drugs are reported to be faulty. The proposed system uses a decentralised approach, enhancing the overall transparency and security. The framework identifies counterfeit drugs and reports the issue across various stakeholders in the pharmaceutical supply chain, including regulatory departments, hospitals, and manufacturers. The alerts regarding contaminated or counterfeit drugs are ensured due to the integration of blockchain and distributed ledger. Furthermore, the recorded data are secure, traceable, and immutable. The results demonstrate that the framework successfully registers the departments and sends the alert across the departments associated with the blockchain. Also, the results confirm the feasibility of using blockchain to create a transparent and robust counterfeit drug alert network, providing a reliable solution for pharmaceutical safety management.

title:
Improved RIC Bounds in Terms of δ
                    <sub>3s</sub>
                    for Two Optimal Thresholding Algorithms
authors: Wen Jin, Lie-Jun Xie
abstract: This letter derives improved (3s)-restricted isometry constant (RIC) conditions for the relaxed optimal thresholding pursuit (ROTP) algorithm and its partial gradient variant PGROTP. For ROTP, we show that the existing RIC condition δ<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3s</sub> < 0.2 can be improved to δ<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3s</sub> < 0.31922. For PGROTP, which involves a parameter q, we establish a unified RIC condition δ<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3s</sub> < 0.23817 that holds for all q ≥ s, where s denotes the sparsity level of the underlying sparse signal. This result provides the first theoretical guarantee for PGROTP in the previously unexplored regime s < q < 2s. In addition, it substantially improves existing RIC conditions for q ≥ 2s, which depend on q and s, and admit at most δ<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3s</sub> < 0.04071 in the best case. Moreover, for the special case q = s of PGROTP, we further relax the known condition from δ<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3s</sub> < 0.27264 to δ<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3s</sub> < 0.31922.

title: Fatigue Driving Detection by Fusing Neural Network and Physiological Indicator
authors: Muze Li
publish: 2025 9th International Workshop on Control Engineering and Advanced Algorithms (IWCEAA)
abstract: As safe driving has emerged as a new focal point in automotive industry competition, driver fatigue detection technology has attracted significant attention. However, existing methods are invariably constrained by certain limitations, such as poor real-time performance and low recall rates. To address this issue, this paper proposes a neural network-physiological indicator fusion model based on YOLOv11 and Dlib libraries. First, we enhance the YOLOv11 architecture by introducing Ghost convolution and FasterNet modules, reducing the parameter count by 52 % and enabling precise localization of the driver's facial regions. Subsequently, we utilize the Dlib library to extract 68 facial key points and apply a dynamically weighted multi-feature fusion algorithm that integrates PERCLOS, Eye Aspect Ratio (EAR), Mouth Aspect Ratio (MAR), and Euler angles for fatigue state analysis. By incorporating Zero-DCE++ low-light enhancement technology and the SEAM occlusion perception module, the model's robustness is further improved. Compared with traditional neural network models, our model not only achieves higher precision and recall rates but also demonstrates superior real-time performance compared to conventional facial recognition methods. Experiments on the NTHU-DDD dataset show that the average mAP @ 0.5 reaches 98.7 %, with a key point localization error of only 3.1 pixels and a processing speed of 72 frames per second. Compared with single-model approaches, the false positive rate decreases by 36.5 %, showcasing its significant potential for intelligent driving safety applications.

title: Comprehensive Analysis of Channel Estimation in Multiple Input Multiple Output-Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiplexing Wireless Networks
authors: D. Kavitha, K.S. Rajesh
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Mobile Networks and Wireless Communications (ICMNWC)
abstract: In recent years, channel estimation is critical enabler of reliable, high-capacity wireless communicationacross $\mathbf{5 G}$, and emerging $\mathbf{6 G}$ systems. Traditional pilot-assisted approaches provide baseline performance but struggled to meet the stringent accuracy and latency requirements of massive MIMO, millimeter-wave (mmWave), low-earth-orbit (LEO) satellite and TeraHertz (THz) networks. Recent advances in Machine Learning (ML) and Deep Learning (DL) have introduced data-driven estimators that exploited channel sparsity, reduce pilot overhead and adapt to rapidly varying propagation environments. This survey provides a review of state-of-the-art Machine Learning (ML) and Deep Learning (DL) approaches like backpropagation neural networks, Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) and unfolded Bayesian learning. It highlights their methodologies, achieved performance improvements and existing limitations. A detailed comparative analysis of these techniques is provided in terms of accuracy, complexity, scalability and robustness to hardware impairments. Finally, open challenges and research directions are identified by focusing on lightweight model design and crossdomain generalization for future intelligent wireless communication systems

title: A Block Chain Integrated Security Model for Confidential and Decentralized Cloud Data Sharing
authors: K Srujan Raju, K Vinay Kumar, T Krishnaveni, M Prabhakar, Hemalatha K, D. Narayani
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Computing Technologies (ICACT)
abstract: Cloud storage as a primary data management solution requires secure decentralized sharing methods to protect both confidentiality and confidentiality of stored information. Currently deployed cloud security systems use centralized access control systems which leaves data open to accessibility breaches and singular failure points and unauthorized access incidents. A Blockchain-Integrated Security Model (BISM) should be implemented using decentralized trust mechanisms together with cryptographic encryption and smart contract-based access control for secure cloud data sharing. The blockchain feature enables reliable secure unaltered recordkeeping and transparent data which ensures accuracy while smart contracts implement automatic access controls to reduce dependence on outside management. Data confidentiality receives strengthened protection from a security system that unites Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) with Attribute-Based Encryption (ABE) functionalities. BISM excels in both fast access checking and high user count capacity with strong cyberattack protection capabilities thus delivering reliable secure cloud data sharing solutions. When blockchain connects with cloud storage systems it provides an unregulated network security solution which strengthens data protection and preserves both privacy and system integrity while making data accessible without challenge.

title: An Analytic Fault-Location Expression for Three-Ended Transmission Networks Capable of Avoiding Synchronization-Angle Estimation Mismatch
authors: Tzu-Chiao Lin, Zhi-Ren Xu, Bawoke Simachew
abstract: This article presents a distinctive and reliable fault location approach tailored for three-ended transmission lines using voltage and current phasors acquired from intelligent electronic devices (IEDs) based digital relays installed individually at each end, without data synchronization functions. By integrating analytic methodologies with state-of-the-art synchronization algorithms and an imaginary-part observation method, an exclusive faulty branch index and a fault location index are designed to pinpoint closed-form faulty line branch and fault position solutions. Crucially, the unsynchronized phasor measurements among three ends can be simultaneously eliminated from the proposed noniterative calculation process. Not only is the proposed method unaffected by synchronization-angle estimation mismatch, but it also avoids problems such as multiple or approximate solutions, fault-path and source impedance assumptions, numerical divergence, and fault-type selections. The proposed method has been deployed in the fault location platform of Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) since early 2024. Importantly, both simulations and field empirical testing conducted on Taipower's actual fault events have validated the feasibility and effectiveness of the suggested ideas in power industry applications, showcasing its potential impact to enhance fault location accuracy and reliability in real-world operational environments.

title: Hybrid Transformer-Based Deep Learning Model for Automated Kidney Disease Classification Using CT Imaging
authors: Md Yousuf Ahmad, Roise Uddin, Sazid Rahman Kazi, Md Nafis Azad Nobel, Mohammad Mahmudur Rahman, Debabrata Biswas, Mainuddin Adel Rafi, Girigula Durga Bhavani, Irfan Sadiq Rahat
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Computing Technologies (ICACT)
abstract: Automated and accurate classification of kidney diseases from medical imaging is crucial for early diagnosis and treatment planning. This study introduces a novel Swin Transformer V2-based hybrid deep learning model designed for classifying kidney diseases (Cyst, Normal, Stone, Tumor) using CT imaging. Our approach incorporates Multi-scale Feature Fusion (MFF) blocks for robust feature extraction, Parallel Convolutional Attention (PCA) modules to enhance spatial hierarchy representation, and Capsule Networks for refined attention-based classification. Evaluated on a comprehensive dataset of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 2, 4 4 6}$</tex> expert-verified CT images, the proposed hybrid model achieved state-of-the-art performance with an accuracy of 100%, an AUC score of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1. 0 0}$</tex> across all classes, and a Dice Similarity Coefficient (DSC) of 0.99. These results substantially surpass traditional CNN-based methods, highlighting the effectiveness and potential clinical applicability of our advanced hybrid architecture.

title: Confidence Optimization for Probabilistic Encoding
authors: Pengjiu Xia, Yidian Huang, Wenchao Wei, Yuwen Tan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Probabilistic encoding introduces Gaussian noise into neural networks, enabling a smooth transition from deterministic to uncertain states and enhancing generalization ability. However, the randomness of Gaussian noise distorts point-based distance measurements in classification tasks. To mitigate this issue, we propose a confidence optimization probabilistic encoding (CPE) method that improves distance reliability and enhances representation learning. Specifically, we refine probabilistic encoding with two key strategies: First, we introduce a confidence-aware mechanism to adjust distance calculations, ensuring consistency and reliability in probabilistic encoding classification tasks. Second, we replace the conventional KL divergence-based variance regularization, which relies on unreliable prior assumptions, with a simpler L2 regularization term to directly constrain variance. The method we proposed is model-agnostic, and extensive experiments on natural language classification tasks demonstrate that our method significantly improves performance and generalization on both the BERT and the RoBERTa model.

title: Research on the sensing coil packaging reliability of fiber-optic hydrophone
authors: Shuwang Li, Jianfei Wang, Wenyuan Liao, Mo Chen, Hao Niu, Guoguang Lu
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on System Reliability and Safety Engineering (SRSE)
abstract: The sensing coil is an extremely important part of the fiber-optic hydrophone, which needs to achieve micropascal level sound pressure sensing in high hydrostatic pressure environments and the magnitude of the pressure may reach to tens megapascal level. In order to achieve this goal, tens of meters of optical fiber are tightly wound on a centimeter diameter sensitizing substrate, and further watertight packaging using sound transmitting rubber for sonar polyurethane materials. Due to its special structural design, the sensing coil packaging may not only provide good sealing and protection effects, but also potentially complicate the stress environment of internal optical fiber. It is necessary to study the packaging reliability of sensing coil, especially considering its long service life of several years. Unfortunately, it is difficult to effectively characterize the relevant changes in the traditional method such as testing the overall optical insertion loss of sensing coil. In this paper, an innovative method was proposed to accurately monitor the fiber strain change inside the sensing coil by adopting the advanced distributed fiber-optic strain testing technique. Under the excitation of temperature stress, it can be seen from experiment results that packaging will significantly alter the stress-strain response of sensitive coils, in some cases packaging may trigger internal stress-strain abnormal concentration, which in extreme cases may induce optical insertion loss exceedance, optical fiber damage or even breakage.

title: Fine-Grained Action Recognition Using Cross-Modal Attention Network for Human-Robot Sign Language Interaction
authors: Jing Hu, Qing Gao, Xianfeng Cheng, Xuerui Li, Zhaojie Ju
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: With the growing demand for barrier-free communication among the deaf and mute, human-robot sign language interaction has gradually gained attention as an auxiliary tool. Action recognition serves as a crucial information source for robots to understand human behavior, enabling robots to recognize signs and achieve natural interaction with deaf people through it. However, existing Human-Robot Interaction (HRI) technologies based on action recognition mainly focus on coarse-grained human movements, failing to capture and respond to nuanced actions in real-world scenarios. Additionally, multi-modal action recognition often employs early or late fusion methods to integrate various modalities, lacking the exploration of relationships between modalities, resulting in the loss of some correlated information. To enable robots to adapt to diverse scenarios for a more nuanced understanding of human behaviors, we propose a fine-grained action recognition framework using Cross-Modal Attention network (CMA) based on RGB and skeleton. Firstly, holistic features including face, hand, and body are extracted by a pose estimator, effectively representing intricate human actions. Subsequently, to fully leverage the extracted fine-grained features, skeleton is represented as heatmap volumes. Finally, a Cross-Attention Interaction (CAI) module is designed to explore the intrinsic connections between RGB and skeleton, facilitating mutual learning of their respective advantageous features in the deep layers of feature extraction, thereby achieving information interaction. Simultaneously, HRI experiments are conducted on the large-scale fine-grained action dataset, WLASL2000. In this HRI system, the robotic arm responds by performing sign language aligned with the human actions identified by CMA, showcasing the practicality and effectiveness of our proposed model in real-world scenarios.

title: Multi-Objective Trajectory Planning with Passenger Comfort for Intelligent Vehicles
authors: Hao Chen, Xinwei Li, Zhifei Zhang, Hantong Zou
publish: 2025 9th CAA International Conference on Vehicular Control and Intelligence (CVCI)
abstract: Autonomous driving techniques have great potential to mitigate traffic congestion and accidents. The trajectory planning algorithm generates collision-free optimal paths from start to destination, which becomes a significant task for safe and stable vehicle operation. However, conventional trajectory planning methods prioritize rapid obstacle avoidance while ignoring passenger comfort feelings. Therefore, this paper employs sensory conflict theory to improve passenger comfort by selecting lateral/longitudinal acceleration and jerk as key factors. Through setting the threshold values as constraints, these factors are reduced in the planned trajectory. In the planning layer, a point-mass model is adopted to predict vehicle motions, based on model predictive control (MPC) framework. The constraints on acceleration and jerk magnitudes are applied, while lateral and longitudinal acceleration are also incorporated into the cost function to optimize passenger comfort. Moreover, we use quintic polynomial interpolation to smooth discrete trajectory points. As for motion control layer, lateral and longitudinal movements are decoupled. A three-degree-of-freedom vehicle dynamics model is established for lateral trajectory tracking using MPC, while PID control calculates motor torque to regulate longitudinal velocity. CarSim/Simulink co-simulations demonstrate 37.32% and 35.96 % reduction in motion sickness dose value (MSDV) under two obstacle avoidance scenarios compared to conventional MPC, which proves the effectiveness of Com-MPC in enhancing passenger ride comfort.

title: Blockchain-Based Trust Management Scheme for Internet of Vehicles
authors: Xiurui Wang, Kaijie Yang, Jinling Duan, Changsheng Gao, Muxi Li, Xu Liu
publish: 2025 9th CAA International Conference on Vehicular Control and Intelligence (CVCI)
abstract: To address low-efficiency trust management in the Internet of Vehicles (IoV), this paper proposes a hybrid consensus algorithm combining Delegated Proof of Stake (DPoS) and Practical Byzantine Fault Tolerance (PBFT). By selecting dual primary nodes through DPoS voting and trust values, it enhances consensus security. The three-stage consensus protocol is optimized to a fivestage one, reducing node communication and improving efficiency. Experiments show the algorithm increases throughput by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.46 \times$</tex> on average and reduces consensus delay by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.54 \times$</tex>.

title: Enhancing Software Vulnerability Analysis via Large Language Models: A Systematic Review
authors: Lin Wang, Jin Li, Zhaojie Li, Shuaibing Lu, Guanghua Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th International Conference on Data Science in Cyberspace (DSC)
abstract: In the current era of AI advancement, large language models (LLMs) have achieved remarkable breakthroughs in natural language understanding and code generation, and have been rapidly adopted in the field of software security analysis. This paper presents a systematic review of the research advancements in applying LLMs to vulnerability analysis tasks such as binary code analysis, static and dynamic vulnerability detection, and vulnerability validation. Studies show that the strong contextual understanding capabilities of LLMs enable the identification of common vulnerability types across multiple programming languages. Moreover, LLMs can act as intelligent attack agents to perform end-to-end penetration testing. The integration of LLMs with traditional static analysis techniques—such as symbolic execution and taint analysis—also demonstrates significant potential for improving the accuracy of security analysis. However, the application of LLMs in software security still faces several challenges, including high false positive rates, severe hallucination issues, limited context modeling capacity, and substantial resource consumption. This survey aims to provide researchers with a comprehensive technical overview, summarizing the latest achievements in leveraging LLMs for software security analysis, discussing their strengths and limitations, and outlining future research directions.

title: Hyperparameter Optimization Strategies for Enhancing Modified YOLO11 in Fire Detection
authors: Satriadi Putra Santika, Arya Krisna Putra, Abba Suganda Girsang, Ezra Peranginangin
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Data and Software Engineering (ICoDSE)
abstract: Early fire detection is essential to prevent large-scale damage and ensure public safety. However, conventional sensor-based systems often fall short in terms of responsiveness and reliability. In response, deep learning-based object detection has become a promising approach. Among them, the modified YOLO11 model, combined with GhostNet and CBAM, offers a lightweight yet accurate and efficient approach for real-time fire detection. Despite its advantages, the model's performance is highly dependent on the selection of optimal hyperparameters. Therefore, this study aims to evaluate and compare four hyperparameter optimization (HPO) techniques, which are Random Search (RS), Bayesian Optimization (BO), Genetic Algorithm (GA), and JAYA Algorithm to enhance the modified YOLO11 model. The experiment used a dataset of 5,000 annotated indoor fire and smoke images and focused on tuning learning rate, batch size, momentum, and weight decay. The best configuration from each method was used to retrain the model for 100 epochs and evaluated using precision, recall, and mAP. Results show that all HPO methods successfully improved the baseline model's performance. BO achieved the highest precision of 86.861 % and mAP50 of 84.329%, while JAYA recorded the shortest optimization time with 14h 29m. In conclusion, HPO are effective in enhancing fire detection performance, with BO being the most optimal in this study.

title: Blockchain-Powered Vehicle-to-Everything Communication for Next-Generation Intelligent Transportation Networks
authors: Bhulakshmi Makkena, Noori Memon, Sai Charan Madugula, Zein Bassam Bani Younes, Preeti Sharma Nair
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Computing Technologies (ICACT)
abstract: This study indicates that the blockchain-powered vehicle-to-everything (V2X) communication system outperforms standard and mixed V2X systems. In this era of smart transportation networks, automobiles, roadside units (RSUs), and other infrastructure must communicate securely and efficiently. Blockchain technology is beneficial for data accuracy, security, and growth. This article offers a decentralized, multi-layered solution to secure communication using cryptography tools, including public-private key pairs, digital signatures, and reputation-based trust management. The system's consensus technique adds only proven, immutable data to the blockchain. This fosters trust and transparency. Blockchain-powered V2X always outperforms conventional techniques in scale, latency, traffic, security, stability, fault tolerance, and interoperability. With more connected autos, it performs well. Communication is quicker for time-sensitive work and more secure and private. The autonomous system reduces energy utilization and faults. Blockchain-powered V2X can verify data, expand it, and integrate with other technologies. This makes it ideal for smart transportation networks.

title: LLM-based Dynamic Differential Testing for Database Connectors with Reinforcement Learning-Guided Prompt Selection
authors: Ce Lyu, Yanhao Wang, Jie Liang, Minghao Zhao
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: Database connectors are critical components that enable applications to interact with database management systems (DBMS) but their security vulnerabilities are often neglected. Unlike traditional software defects, connector vulnerabilities exhibit subtle behavioral patterns and are inherently challenging to detect. Moreover, non-standardized implementation of connectors leaves potential risks (i.e., unsafe implementations) but is more elusive. As a result, existing fuzzing methods are ineffective in finding such vulnerabilities. Even large language model (LLM)-based methods are still incapable of generating test cases that can invoke all the interface and internal logic of database connectors due to a lack of domain knowledge.In this paper, we propose a new LLM-based test case generation method guided by reinforcement learning (RL) for database connector testing. Specifically, to equip the LLM with sufficient and appropriate domain knowledge, a parameterized template is composed for prompt construction. The LLM then generates test cases instructed by the constructed prompts, which are dynamically evaluated through differential testing across multiple connectors. The testing process is carried out iteratively, where RL is adopted to select the optimal prompt in each round based on behavioral feedback from the previous rounds, to maximize the efficiency of discovering inconsistencies. Finally, we implement and evaluate the aforementioned methodology on two widely used JDBC connectors, namely MySQL Connector/J and OceanBase Connector/J. In the preliminary results, we have reported 16 bugs, among which 10 are officially confirmed, and the rest are acknowledged as unsafe implementations.

title: WhereRU: A Multimodal Indoor Localization System via Deep Learning-Based RFID and Ultrasonic Fusion
authors: Wenrui Liu, Shuai Wang, Jinqing Zhang, Guangxuan Bai, Bofan Pan, Siye Wang, Jing Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Indoor localization systems face critical tradeoffs between accuracy, coverage, robustness, and privacy. Current technologies either achieve high precision at the cost of privacy (camera-based) or preserve privacy while compromising accuracy (signal-based). This limitation is particularly problematic in high-security environments requiring precise tracking within confined spaces (typically 2m × 2m) while prohibiting camera surveillance. We propose WhereRU, a novel multimodal indoor localization system integrating Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) with ultrasonic technologies through a fusion framework. Unlike existing approaches treating modalities as separate components, our system implements deep algorithmic integration where RFID-based coarse-grained localization directly constrains ultrasonic measurements. The system employs WhereNet, a lightweight residual network for RFID processing, achieving 99.74% accuracy at the grid level. This coarse position estimate guides ultrasonic ranging optimization through Limited-memory Broyden-Fletcher-Goldfarb-Shanno Bound (L-BFGS-B) algorithm, effectively mitigating edge-region inaccuracies typical in ultrasonic-only systems. Experimental results demonstrate that WhereRU achieves an average localization error of only 0.107 meters–representing an 81.86% improvement over traditional Time of Arrival methods–while maintaining complete privacy by eliminating biometric data collection. This approach provides a practical solution for secure facilities requiring both centimeter-level localization accuracy and strict privacy preservation.
