title: Kair: A Statistical and Causal Approach to Pinpointing Stragglers in Distributed Model Training
authors: Yitang Yang, Junhong Liu, Jiapeng Chen, Xiaoyang Sun, Tianyu Wo, Chunming Hu, Chengru Song, Jin Ouyang, Renyu Yang
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: The distributed deep learning training process within large-scale clusters serves as the foundation of contemporary artificial intelligence. However, its inherent characteristics make it particularly sensitive to stragglers, specifically the presence of slow workers, which can significantly decelerate the entire procedure. Observability tools are essential for identifying stragglers within systems. However, the prevailing system profiling tools are either designed for single-node analysis, lacking visibility across multiple workers, or they recognize stragglers but only deliver high-level symptoms, providing engineers with insufficient insight into the underlying causes.We design Kair, a robust production-standard observability tool. Kair uses an innovative hierarchical approach, transitioning from statistical anomaly detection to causal inference. It employs Kolmogorov-Smirnov statistics for the identification of statistically anomalous workers and implements a causal path tracing algorithm to accurately determine the specific operations, such as computation or communication, that are responsible for the delay. Kair has been evaluated in a production cluster of 2,048 NVIDIA A800 GPUs and demonstrated high effectiveness in detecting latent stragglers at the framework level that are often overlooked by conventional tools. It offers precise suggestions that markedly reduce processing inefficiencies and engineering workload.

title: Research on the Reliability Improvement Method of Ultrasonic Live Detection for Switchgear
authors: Peng Zhang, Chang Liu, Xuedong Wang, Jian Zhang, Zhen Zhang, Yue Wang, Mingchen Gong, Xiangyu Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Sensing, Diagnostics, Prognostics, and Control
abstract: In response to the adaptability problems such as display failures and component performance drifts of live detection instruments in on-site tests of power equipment caused by low environmental temperatures under extreme low-temperature conditions in the cold regions of northern China, this paper proposes an integrated solution that combines EPP foamed polypropylene high-efficiency thermal insulation materials, precise constant-temperature control technology, and low-temperature sodium vanadium phosphate ion battery technology. A constant-temperature test chamber dedicated to live detection instruments for outdoor switchgear in winter is developed. Through the collaborative innovation of material optimization design, dynamic temperature control strategies, and an adaptable power supply system, precise temperature control of the working environment of the detection instrument is achieved. The results show that the constant-temperature test chamber can stably maintain the temperature around the detection instrument within the working range of 20±2°C, effectively solving problems such as abnormal LCD display and circuit parameter drift caused by low temperatures. The accuracy and reliability of the detection data are significantly improved. The research results provide lightweight, low-energy-consumption, and highly reliable instrument protection equipment for live detection of power equipment in alpine regions, and have important engineering application value for ensuring the safe and stable operation of the power grid in winter.

title: A Robust Trust Management System for V2X Networks Integrating ISAC with Blockchain Smart Contracts
authors: Muhammad Umar Farooq Qaisar, Weijie Yuan, Lin Zhang, Shehzad Ashraf Chaudhry, Guangjie Han, Yunyang Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network and Service Management
abstract: Vehicle-to-everything (V2X) networks face critical security challenges due to their dynamic nature, stringent latency requirements, and susceptibility to malicious attacks. Traditional trust management approaches often rely on centralized authorities or historical data, creating vulnerabilities and scalability limitations. This paper presents a new trust management system that leverages integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) technology and blockchain-based smart contracts to provide secure and decentralized trust evaluation in V2X networks. The proposed framework leverages real-time ISAC signal processing to compute five comprehensive trust metrics: behavior score, reputation score, safety score, uptime score, and response time score. These metrics are derived through advanced Kalman filtering and statistical anomaly detection applied to physical-layer measurements, enabling immediate detection of malicious activities that traditional approaches might miss. Trust records are securely stored and validated through smart contracts deployed on 5G base station blockchains, ensuring tamper-proof storage and automated policy enforcement. Numerical results demonstrate that the proposed protocol achieves faster trust convergence, higher communication reliability, significant reduction in false positive rates, improved detection accuracy, acceptable end-to-end latency, and lower computational overhead compared to state-of-the-art approaches.

title: Research on Intelligent Diagnosis Method of Rotating Machinery Based on Depth-Interpretable Convolutional Kernel Analysis
authors: Qindan Luo, Xueping Sun, Yifei Wang, Ci Zhang, Qiao Li, Hongyu Zhou, Yi Ai
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Sensing, Diagnostics, Prognostics, and Control
abstract: To address the "black-box" problem encountered when applying Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) to rolling bearing fault diagnosis, this paper proposes the construction of a Kernel Feature Analyzer (KFA). Specifically, by quantifying feature correlation and fault feature separability metrics, combined with time-domain, frequency-domain, and spatial-domain analysis, the KFA visualizes the operations of convolutional kernels—which represent semantically opaque concepts to human understanding. It adaptively extracts outputs from each convolutional layer while integrating the fault mechanism of rolling bearings to reveal the specific behaviors of the neural network, thereby assisting in the determination of fault type and severity. Experiments demonstrate that this extractor enhances the interpretability of one-dimensional CNNs (1D CNNs) in the field of rolling bearing fault diagnosis, exhibiting engineering superiority and strong generalization capability.

title: Robust Resilience Enhancement Strategy Against Uncertain Cyber-Physical Coordinated Attacks Considering Power-Communication Network Interdependence
authors: Min Du, Xin Zhang, Jinning Zhang, Rui Zhang, Junbo Zhao
abstract: Due to the interdependence between power and communication networks, cyber-physical power systems (CPPSs) are more vulnerable to cyber-physical coordinated attacks involving uncertainties in attack resources. Such attacks can simultaneously disrupt power and communication networks, causing severe consequences for CPPSs. To address this issue, a distributionally robust resilience enhancement (DRRE) model is proposed to enhance the resilience of CPPSs against uncertain cyber-physical coordinated attacks. An uncertainty set is constructed to describe variations in attack resources, and an ambiguity set based on the Wasserstein metric is developed to characterise the unknown probability distributions of attack resources. Moreover, the DRRE model integrates the functional and topological interdependencies of power and communication networks with the optimal allocation of control centres to enhance system resilience. Then, a combined solution (CS) algorithm integrating the column-and-constraint generation (C&CG) and Benders decomposition (BD) methods is developed to efficiently solve the DRRE model. Finally, simulation results on a modified IEEE RTS-79 system and a practical 62-bus system demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

title: PMB-DETR: A Multi-Scale and Multi-Branch Enhanced Network for Rail Surface Defect Detection
authors: Lei Wang, Liheng Deng, Xiangjia Fan, Youyu Tang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Sensing, Diagnostics, Prognostics, and Control
abstract: As a critical component of railway infrastructure, railway tracks play an essential role in research on surface defect detection. However, track defects are often characterized by small sizes and dense distributions, creating considerable difficulties for achieving precise detection. To overcome these challenges, this paper proposes an improved RT-DETR-based method for railway defect detection. First, a CSP-PKIBlock module is introduced, which integrates multi-scale convolution with a context-aware anchor attention mechanism, thereby producing a marked improvement in multi-scale defect detection, particularly small-scale ones. Second, a multi-branch auxiliary feature network (MAFPN) is combined with a bidirectionally connected feature pyramid module (BiFPN) to enhance the backbone architecture of RT-DETR and strengthen its multi-scale feature representation capability. Finally, the traditional GIoU loss is replaced with ShapeIoU, a metric emphasizing the shape and size consistency of bounding boxes, thus improving the precision of box regression. Experimental evaluations show that the proposed model achieves mAP values of 97.4% and 66.3% on a custom dataset and the public Rail400-Nc8 dataset, respectively, resulting in performance gains of 3.3% and 4.2% compared to the baseline model. Compared with existing state-of-the-art detection methods, the proposed approach delivers superior detection accuracy and computational efficiency for railway surface defect recognition.

title: A Multi-Structural Graph Fusion Approach for Code Representation in Code Search
authors: Longhao Ao, Rongzhi Qi, Haoxuan Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Code search aims to retrieve semantically relevant code snippets on the basis of natural language queries. With the rapid expansion of public code repositories such as GitHub and Gitee, the efficient understanding and matching of relevant code have become critical challenges. Most existing deep learning-based code search approaches rely on feature extraction from code but often fail to account for its structural integrity. They neglect the complex hierarchical structure of the code, resulting in insufficient representational capacity for semantic matching. To address these challenges, we propose an innovative code search method, AcbertGraphC, which constructs a multi-relational graph representation by combining abstract syntax tree (AST), data dependency graph (DDG), and control flow graph (CFG) through a functional program graph and early fusion strategy. Additionally, we utilize meta-path aggregated graph neural networks (MAGNN) to extract complex relation-ships from the multi-relational graph, and leverage a graph attention mechanism to dynamically adjust meta-path selection, thereby enhancing the model’s search capability. The experi-mental results demonstrate that AcbertGraphC can accurately retrieve target code snippets and outperforms existing baseline methods in terms of matching precision.

title: Application of Improved Isolation Forest Algorithm in Residential Electricity Consumption Anomaly Detection
authors: Xiaofeng Lu, Min He, Sheng Zhao, Haohan Qian
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Mobile Networks and Wireless Communications (ICMNWC)
abstract: With the rapid growth of residential electricity consumption data, traditional anomaly detection methods suffer from low detection rates and high false alarm rates when detecting low-amplitude spikes, periodic anomalies, and load changes. To address this issue, this paper proposes an improved isolated forest algorithm for identifying abnormal residential electricity consumption behavior, aiming to improve the accuracy and strength of anomaly detection. Weighted sampling is used to enhance the influence of anomaly samples, a multiscale segmentation technique is proposed to adapt to different daily/weekly electricity consumption trends, and a dynamic threshold method is established to calculate anomaly scores. Experimental validation is based on three months of electricity consumption data from 500 households. The improved isolated forest algorithm achieves an overall accuracy of 95.2% in anomaly detection, with an F1 score improved to 0.94.

title: CWTLNet: Ultra-Short-Term Cryptocurrency Forecasting with Wavelet-Enhanced Deep Architecture
authors: Xingbang Du, Yang Cao, Enzhi Zhang, Rui Zhong, Masaharu Munetomo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: In this study, we propose a novel deep neural model, CWTLNet, specifically designed to address the unique characteristics of cryptocurrency trading, including significant short-term volatility, which operates around the clock, and is prone to sudden price jumps and drops. The architecture consists of two branches. The CWT branch employs a continuous wavelet transform (CWT) to extract time-frequency feature maps from the input time series. These feature maps are then processed by a stack of CWT Blocks, which are composed of residual structures with two Conv1D layers, allowing the model to capture local, ultra-short-term patterns in the data. The linear branch first decomposes the time series into its trend and residual components. Each component is modeled separately using linear models and subsequently recombined. The linear branch is particularly effective at capturing the periodic patterns embedded in the time series. Finally, the outputs of the two branches are fused through a gated mechanism with a temperature coefficient, enabling adaptive weighting of the branch outputs. Experimental results demonstrate that CWTLNet outperforms commonly used models — including LSTM, Transformer, and DLinear — on minute-level trading data for seven different cryptocurrencies. For example, The performance of CWTLNet on the Bitcoin dataset, in terms of Mean Squared Error (MSE) and Mean Absolute Error (MAE), shows improvements of at least 2.7% and 1.7%, respectively, compared to the aforementioned three models.

title: A Dual-Task Self-Supervised Framework for Fault Diagnosis of Rotating Machinery under Limited Annotations
authors: Wenhao Lu, Zhiqiang Cai, Wei Wang
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on System Reliability and Safety Engineering (SRSE)
abstract: Reliable fault diagnosis of rotating machinery is critical for maintaining safety and efficiency in complex industrial environments. However, conventional deep learning methods are limited by their dependence on large-scale labeled datasets, which are expensive and impractical to acquire in real-world applications. To address this limitation, we propose a dual-task self-supervised framework, CGLR-Net, which jointly models global and local features to learn robust and discriminative representations under limited annotations. The framework integrates three components: a Global Alignment Module to enforce cross-condition consistency, a Local Discrimination Module to enhance fine-grained separability, and a Channel Attention Module to emphasize critical diagnostic channels while suppressing redundancy. Experiments on the Paderborn University bearing dataset show that CGLR-Net consistently outperforms state-of-the-art baselines, achieving more than $91 \%$ accuracy with only ten labeled samples per class. Ablation and visualization analyses further confirm the complementarity of global and local tasks, as well as the effectiveness of channel attention in enhancing feature separability and robustness. This study provides a practical solution for small-sample intelligent fault diagnosis and establishes a methodological foundation for applying self-supervised learning in real-world industrial systems.

title: A Lightweight Federated Learning Architecture Approach for Short-Term Load Prediction
authors: Jingdong Wang, Yang Yang, Fanqi Meng
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: In order to address the challenges of distributed power load forecasting with limited resources and the need to protect user privacy, this paper proposes a lightweight federated learning architecture, Deep Separable Temporal Convolutional Network (DS-TCN). The model consists of three core modules: parallel multi-branch inflated causal convolution is used to capture short-term mutations and long-term trends simultaneously; adaptive scale fusion module is used to dynamically weight the features of each branch; and the dynamically aware prediction head automatically adjusts the response strength according to the signal fluctuations through a gating mechanism. In the experiments on the public HUE dataset, all clients of DS-TCN perform 5 rounds of local iterations and 50 rounds of federated training, which dramatically reduces the communication and computation overheads compared to the 500 rounds of federated training of the LSTM model. Moreover, the DS-TCN federated global model achieves RMSE=0.1382, MAE=0.1267, and MSE=0.0194, which is equal to or even exceeds LSTM; the average RMSE at the local end is reduced from 0.0796 in LSTM to 0.0699, with the highest single-household reduction of nearly 49%, which fully proves the superiority of the proposed method.

title: Spatial Interpolation Based on Causal Spatiotemporal Modeling
authors: Han Xie, Shiyong Lan, Yao Ren, Weihong Yuan, Xinyuan Zhou, Zhiang Hou
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: The problem of spatial interpolation is a common challenge in fields such as traffic flow analysis. However, most existing methods directly utilize information from neighboring nodes to infer status of the unobserved location, without considering whether this information contains confounding factors or whether there is a true causal relationship, despite the fact that some unknown confounding factors are inevitably included in the data collection process. To address this, this paper proposes a Causal Attention Spatial Temporal Interpolation (CASI), which leverages causal relationships between nodes for spatial interpolation. The proposed CASI employs dilated convolutions and gating mechanisms to capture temporal dependencies, and introduces the Causal Spatiotemporal Attention (CSTA) mechanism, to uncover spatial causal dependencies between nodes. Subsequently, a novel Graph-Guided Feature Enhance Module (GFEM) is designed, which leverages causal probabilities from CSTA’s Gumbel-Softmax to weight the adjacency matrix in traditional GCN, composing GS-GCN, then adopts self-attention on temporal and spatial dimension respectively to further enhance the features from the improved GCN. We evaluate CASI on three real-world datasets, where it outperforms the optimal baselines across MAE, RMSE and MAPE by up to 3.7%, 1.7%, and 5.4% on PEMS04, 8.5%, 6.0%, and 5.9% on PEMS08, respectively. Ablation studies further demonstrated the effectiveness of the proposed modules in causal spatiotemporal modeling.

title: All-in-One Transformer for Image Restoration Under Adverse Weather Degradations
authors: Jiawei Mao, Yu Yang, Xuesong Yin, Ling Shao, Hao Tang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: Severe weather restoration models often face the simultaneous interaction of multiple degradations in real-world scenarios. Existing approaches typically handle single or composite degradations based on scene descriptors derived from text or image embeddings. However, due to the varying proportions of different degradations within an image, these scene descriptors may not accurately differentiate between degradations, leading to suboptimal restoration in practical applications. To address this issue, we propose a novel Transformer-based restoration framework, AllRestorer, for dealing with four physical severe weather impairments: low-light, haze, rain, and snow. In AllRestorer, we enable the model to adaptively consider all weather impairments, thereby avoiding errors from scene descriptor misdirection. Specifically, we introduce the All-in-One Transformer Block (AiOTB), the core innovation of which is the ability to adaptively handle multiple degradations in a single image, beyond the limitation of existing Transformers that can only handle one type of degradation at a time. To accurately address different variations potentially present within the same type of degradation and minimize ambiguity, AiOTB utilizes a Composite Scene Embedding consisting of both image and text embeddings to define the degradation. Moreover, AiOTB includes an adaptive weight for each degradation, allowing for precise control of the restoration intensity. By leveraging AiOTB, AllRestorer avoids misdirection caused by inaccurate scene descriptors, achieving a 5.00 dB increase in PSNR compared to the baseline on the CDD-11 dataset.

title: Metamorphic Testing for Audio Content Moderation Software
authors: Wenxuan Wang, Yongjiang Wu, Junyuan Zhang, Shuqing Li, Yun Peng, Wenting Chen, Shuai Wang, Michael R. Lyu
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: The rapid growth of audio-centric platforms and applications such as Whatsapp and Twitter has transformed the way people communicate and share audio content in modern society. However, these platforms are increasingly misused to disseminate harmful audio content, such as hate speech, deceptive advertisements, and explicit material, which can have significant negative consequences (e.g., detrimental effects on mental health). In response, researchers and practitioners have been actively developing and deploying audio content moderation tools to tackle this issue. Despite these efforts, malicious actors can bypass moderation systems by making subtle alterations to audio content, such as modifying pitch or inserting noise. Moreover, the effectiveness of modern audio moderation tools against such adversarial inputs remains insufficiently studied. To address these challenges, we propose MTAM, a Metamorphic Testing framework for Audio content Moderation software. Specifically, we conduct a pilot study on 2000 audio clips and define 14 metamorphic relations across two perturbation categories: Audio Features-Based and Heuristic perturbations. MTAM applies these metamorphic relations to toxic audio content to generate test cases that remain harmful while being more likely to evade detection. In our evaluation, we employ MTAM to test five commercial textual content moderation software and an academic model against three kinds of toxic content. The results show that MTAM achieves up to 38.6%, 18.3%, 35.1%, 16.7%, and 51.1% error finding rates (EFR) when testing commercial moderation software provided by Gladia, Assembly AI, Baidu, Nextdata, and Tencent respectively, and it obtains up to 45.7% EFR when testing the state-of-the-art algorithms from the academy. In addition, we leverage the test cases generated by MTAM to retrain the model we explored, which largely improves model robustness (nearly 0% EFR) while maintaining the accuracy on the original test set. We release the code and experiment data to facilitate future research<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>.

title: Jamming Detection and Classification on Physical Layer with a Minimized CNN Model
authors: Lucas Fink, Torsten Reissland, Timo Maiwald, Norman Franchi
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Advanced Communication Technologies and Networking (CommNet)
abstract: Wireless communication networks are vulnerable to attacks via the air interface. So-called jamming attacks can negatively affect a wireless network and their participating wireless nodes, or even lead to a denial of service. In this work a strategy for jamming detection and classification is proposed. It combines targeting an embedded implementation of a convolutional neural network (CNN) that is used for the classification task and aiming high classification accuracy. Unlike other approaches that are mainly about detecting a jammer, this work investigates three scenarios i) classifying the strength of the jammer as well as its signal type; ii) classification of the signal type of the jammer regardless of its signal power; iii) detection of a jammer. Using 2D histograms of demodulated IQ samples in combination with a CNN in a non-line-of-sight (NLOS) scenario, an accuracy of 91.0 % is achieved with a parameter reduction factor of 50 compared to the base line CNN architecture. Transferring the reduced model to a line-of-sight (LOS) dominant scenario leads to an accuracy of 99.1 %. For jamming detection, an accuracy of 99.5 % is achieved for the NLOS scenario and only correct predictions for the LOS scenario. The results demonstrate that a complex jamming detection as well as jamming classification can be executed with a minimized CNN architecture using IQ data directly on the physical layer of a communication system.

title: DeepWIO: A Lightweight Deep Wheel-Inertial Odometry for Mass-Produced Autonomous Driving Systems
authors: Shilin Liu, Weiliang Meng, Xiaopeng Zhang
publish: 2025 9th CAA International Conference on Vehicular Control and Intelligence (CVCI)
abstract: Localization is a crucial module in autonomous driving systems, providing essential position and orientation information for vehicle navigation and decision-making. We focus on Wheel-Inertial Odometry (WIO) due to its high precision and computational efficiency, which make it well-suited for mass production in autonomous vehicles by bypassing the need for computationally expensive feature extraction from images or point clouds. Recent industry trends are shifting towards reducing reliance on HD maps and high-precision RTK sensors, driving demand for scalable, adaptable localization solutions. Traditional WIO methods, typically relying on Kalman-filterbased algorithms, often employ manually designed sensor weighting strategies based on fixed domain knowledge or heuristic rules, limiting their adaptability to changing environments. To address this issue, we propose DeepWIO, a lightweight and flexible deep learning-based framework that dynamically adjusts sensor weighting in real-time. By learning from diverse driving data, our DeepWIO captures complex kinematic patterns and adapts to sensor inaccuracies under varying conditions, significantly enhancing the robustness and fault tolerance of the localization system. Experimental results in different driving scenarios, including highway and urban driving as well as complex parking maneuvers, demonstrate the superior performance and adaptability of our DeepWIO in challenging environments.

title: VUSC: An Extensible Research Platform for Java-Based Static Analysis
authors: Marc Miltenberger, Steven Arzt
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: Detecting security vulnerabilities in backend Web applications as well as mobile apps is extremely important. Static analysis for vulnerability analysis has subsequently developed as an important field of research. Researchers need extensible frameworks to avoid starting from scratch with every new research project. Compared to commercially available scanners, open-source frameworks often only provide basic functionality. This limits the ability of researchers to evaluate novel algorithms. Lacking access to full code scanners, new building blocks are often tested in isolation. In this paper, we present VUSC, a fast, precise and extensible vulnerability scanner for Android and Java bytecode. It features a plugin architecture for commonly used static analyses such as call graph, taint and value analyses, allowing researchers to build upon our work and using VUSC as a reference platform. We show that VUSC achieves a precision of around 90% on benchmarks. Video: https://youtu.be/QpXs9hv5zGc, Dataset: https://github.com/Fraunhofer-SIT/ASE2025-StaticAnalysisInfrastructure/

title: Multi-Feature Power Load Forecasting Based on CNN-GRU Method in Spark Architecture
authors: Qianying Shi, Yunjin Ma, Yuqing Gao
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th International Conference on Power, Intelligent Computing and Systems (ICPICS)
abstract: A multi-feature load forecasting model based on the Spark architecture is proposed to meet the high-precision forecasting demands of modern power systems. The model integrates a convolutional neural network (CNN) and a gated recurrent unit (GRU), utilizing meteorological factors such as air temperature, water vapor pressure, total cloud cover, and historical electric load data to construct feature sets for input. The model is trained to optimize its parameters and generate load forecasts. The results indicate that the proposed method significantly outperforms linear regression, decision tree, random forest, long short-term memory (LSTM), GRU, and CNN-LSTM models in terms of prediction performance. Additionally, the distributed load prediction using linear regression, decision tree, and random forest on the Spark platform demonstrates significantly higher efficiency compared to standalone processing, highlighting the superior performance of Spark in handling big data.

title: Technical Evaluation and BESS Sizing for High Variable Renewable Energy Penetration: Study Case of Lombok Power Grid
authors: Rizkya Amandha Putri, Gema Wachid Aryasatya, Kevin Marojahan Banjar-Nahor, Nanang Hariyanto
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on High Voltage Engineering and Power Systems (ICHVEPS)
abstract: To support Indonesia’s target of achieving Net Zero Emissions (NZE) by 2060, the government is accelerating the deployment of Variable Renewable Energy (VRE) sources, particularly solar and wind. While this transition enhances sustainability and reduces operational costs, the intermittent and unpredictable nature of VRE presents significant challenges for small and isolated power systems like Lombok, particularly in maintaining frequency stability and system reliability. This study presents a comprehensive assessment that integrates production simulation using an optimized generation dispatch model with technical evaluations, including load flow and frequency deviation analysis. The PLEXOS software is used for long-term dispatch planning, while quasi-dynamic simulations in DIgSILENT PowerFactory evaluate system performance under high-VRE scenarios. Additionally, the impact of Battery Energy Storage System (BESS) integration is analyzed to mitigate frequency deviations and enhance grid resilience. The findings offer actionable insights into planning strategies that balance economic optimization with technical feasibility in isolated grids with high renewable penetration.

title: A Study on GOOSE-MOMEDA-Based Methods for Extracting Fault Features from Harmonic Reducers
authors: Youwei Xu, Jiangping Qiu, Yanlin Li, Hongyu Zeng, Zhiwei An, Zhongliang Lv
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Sensing, Diagnostics, Prognostics, and Control
abstract: To address this, an experimental platform is developed, and an adaptive MOMEDA-based method is proposed for parameter optimization in harmonic reducer fault diagnosis. A novel multi-objective optimization criterion is formulated, using minimum envelope entropy as the evaluation metric to adaptively identify the optimal filter length and fault period in the MOMEDA framework. By exploiting the strong global exploration capability of the goose-inspired optimization algorithm, the enhanced MOMEDA approach effectively amplifies weak fault impulses. The processed signal is further analyzed through ensemble empirical mode decomposition (EEMD) to generate a fuzzy entropy-based feature set, which is then used for fault classification and recognition via a support vector machine (SVM).

title: High-Performance Chaotic Signal Generation via Optical Heterodyning of Mutually Injected Semiconductor Lasers
authors: Houlin Wang, Pei Zhou, Yu Huang, Nianqiang Li
abstract: To address the inherent limitations of chaotic signals generated by semiconductor lasers, such as restricted bandwidth, uneven power spectrum, and prominent time-delay signature (TDS), this paper proposes a performance-enhanced chaotic generation scheme based on optical heterodyning of mutually injected semiconductor lasers. In this scheme, two semiconductor lasers are mutually optically injected to individually generate chaotic outputs. Under appropriate injection strength and frequency detuning, a performance-enhanced chaotic microwave signal is generated through heterodyne beating of the two laser outputs in subsequent photodetection. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed approach achieves a significantly broadened chaotic bandwidth of 35.91 GHz and improved spectral flatness of 9.69 dB. Furthermore, the mutual injection structure introduces complex nonlinear feedback that effectively suppresses TDSs, reducing the TDS value to 0.057. The resulting high-quality broadband chaotic signal holds promising potential for applications in random number generation, radar detection, and secure communications.

title: Digital Twin-Assisted Health Assessment for S+C+L-Band Transmission
authors: Yu Tang, Yan Shi, Yujia Yang, Chuangye Wang, Hong Liu, Dongchen Zhang, Shikui Shen, He Zhang, Zelin Wang, Guangquan Wang, Xiaomei Ma, Zhengsi Shi, Xiaocun Liu, Mei Song, Danshi Wang, Baoluo Yan, Xiongyan Tang
abstract: Health assessment is essential for ensuring reliable operation and proactive maintenance in optical networks. In this work, we demonstrate digital twin-assisted health assessment for a 4-span S+C+L-band transmission system, where optical power and OSNR assessment are carried out.

title: Design Study of CenterNet-Based Running Posture Identification System
authors: Yuexing Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th International Conference on Power, Intelligent Computing and Systems (ICPICS)
abstract: Running posture identification is of great value in the field of sports science and health monitoring, but there is still room for improving the accuracy and efficiency of existing methods in complex scenarios. In this paper, we propose a CenterNet-based running pose identification system, which enhances the feature extraction capability by improving the human joint point detection model. The pyramid cut attention module is introduced to optimize the multi-scale feature fusion, the crosshair deformation convolution module is combined to improve the accuracy of joint point localization, and the action classifier is designed to achieve the pose discrimination. Experiments show that the improved model exhibits higher robustness and practicality in running posture analysis, providing technical support for sports injury prevention and training optimization.

title: Comparative Performance Analysis of PD Sensors in Air Insulation: Microstrip Antenna, RC Detector, and HFCT Approaches
authors: Juanto Sirait, Philip Nathanael Erlangga Sitorus, Dyah Ratna Kusuma Mayangsari, Umar Khayam
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on High Voltage Engineering and Power Systems (ICHVEPS)
abstract: Partial Discharge (PD), an important early sign in recognizing the degradation of the insulation system, especially in high voltage equipment with air insulation. Accurate PD detection is essential to avoid sudden equipment failure and improve the reliability of the electric power system. This study compares the effectiveness of three common sensors to detect PD: microstrip antenna, RC detector, and highfrequency current transformer (HFCT). The test was conducted in a laboratory with regular conditions, using a calibrator as a measurement reference to ensure the accuracy of the results. Measurements were made by comparing the oscilloscope readings (volts) and the charge injection value on the calibrator (coulombs). The parameters observed include Background Noise ON/OFF, Partial Discharge Inception Voltage (PDIV), Partial Discharge Extinction Voltage (PDEV), PD waveform, PD pattern, and PD sequence. The test was conducted at three voltage levels ($7 \mathrm{kV}, 8 \mathrm{kV}, 9 \mathrm{kV}$) with needle-plate electrode settings and antenna distance variations ($20 \mathrm{~cm}, 30 \mathrm{~cm}, 45 \mathrm{~cm}$). The results show that each sensor has its advantages: the microstrip antenna excels in detecting electromagnetic emissions at high frequencies, the RC detector is efficient for signals in the time domain, and the HFCT is best for PD current pulses. This finding offers a guideline in selecting the right sensor for monitoring electric power systems using air insulation.

title: Detecting MitM Attacks in SDN Edge Architectures Using Light Models
authors: Anass Sebbar, Othmane Cherqi, Brahim Anegdouil, Mohammed Boulmalf
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Software-defined Networks (SDNs) offer flexibility and programmability but introduce new attack surfaces, especially at the edge. Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) attacks on the control channel between the controller and edge devices pose a significant threat. This paper proposes a lightweight approach for detecting MitM attacks in SDN-based edge architectures. We evaluate several machine learning classifiers based on their effectiveness and efficiency for resource-constrained edge environments. Our approach analyzes real-time network traffic based on features sensitive to MitM activities. Through a simulated case study, we compare the performance of a rule-based baseline against various classifiers, including Gaussian Naive Bayes, Logistic Regression, Decision Tree, Random Forest, LightGBM, and XGBoost. The results demonstrate that the Decision Tree classifier achieves excellent performance, with 99% accuracy, precision, and recall, and critically, exhibits one of the lowest detection latencies (0.7 ms). This balance of high detection capability and low computational overhead positions Decision Trees as a highly suitable lightweight solution for real-time MitM attack detection in SDN edge architectures, outperforming simpler methods like Gaussian Naive Bayes and the rule-based baseline, and offering a more efficient alternative compared to complex ensemble models when latency is a primary concern. We also analyze the relative CPU and memory consumption, further supporting the practicality of Decision Trees for edge deployment.

title: Diagnostic Investigation of Sudden Power Transformer Failures Due Through Fault Currents Using SFRA and Internal Inspection
authors: Fajli Mustafa, I Ketut Ariek Astana Adi, Dian Priyatno, Anzila Rachim, Nasrul Rochmadi, Hikmah Prasetia
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on High Voltage Engineering and Power Systems (ICHVEPS)
abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive diagnostic investigation of sudden power transformer failures caused by through-fault currents (TFC). The study combines Sweep Frequency Response Analysis (SFRA) and internal inspection to identify hidden mechanical damage in transformer windings. A case study of a $150 / 20 \mathrm{kV}$ power transformer reveals that cumulative TFC exposure led to progressive mechanical degradation, ultimately resulting in catastrophic failure. The transformer experienced consistent fault events, peaking at 11 incidents in 2023, with fault currents reaching 15.4 kA on the low-voltage side. SFRA testing detected significant anomalies in Phase T, indicating mechanical deformation, which was subsequently confirmed through internal inspection revealing displaced blocking supports. The research demonstrates that SFRA serves as an effective diagnostic tool for detecting incipient mechanical damage, while internal inspection provides crucial validation. Based on the findings, the paper recommends immediate SFRA testing following significant TFC events and proposes the integration of vibration sensors for proactive mechanical condition monitoring.

title: Design of an Autonomous Intelligent Vehicle Based on Nonlinear PID Control
authors: Chong Yu, Yahui Li, Tingkun Yan, Jiyu Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th International Conference on Power, Intelligent Computing and Systems (ICPICS)
abstract: This paper proposes a hybrid control architecture for lightweight unmanned vehicle control systems, based on nonlinear control. The system employs a multithreaded programming model to achieve parallel processing of perception, recognition, and control tasks on resource-constrained platforms. The system uses a dual-camera coordination mechanism to divide image acquisition perspectives, enhancing image frame processing efficiency and recognition redundancy. To enhance the trajectory tracking stability of the system in complex paths, the software layer integrates image coordinate transformation and nonlinear control algorithms. At the same time, it integrates the HSV tuning tool and the image grayscale histogram enhancement module to improve the robustness and adaptability of target recognition. At the remote end, the system combines FRP intranet penetration with a 5G communication module to build a low-latency remote control platform, achieving stable remote control operations. On this basis, this paper constructs a complete hardware and software system and completes field verification based on a 400 -meter outdoor standard test site to validate the feasibility of the solution. The image processing and nonlinear PID control algorithm in this framework is expected to further advance the technology of autonomous intelligent vehicles.

title: Control Scheme for Networked Systems Based on Dynamic Event-Triggered Mechanism
authors: Hailin Zhu
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th International Conference on Power, Intelligent Computing and Systems (ICPICS)
abstract: The network system's limited communication capacity makes it difficult to guarantee that the data is correctly received by the data terminal. Research on lowering the strain of communication is required in order to more effectively allocate communication resources and boost communication effectiveness. In order to address the issue of communication resource redundancy in networked control systems, an adaptive event-triggered strategy is suggested in order to better save network communication resources and lessen communication stress. The first step is to create an adaptive event-triggering criterion with configurable parameters by determining the system's state equation. By adaptively adjusting their size, the dynamic event-triggering parameters can finally efficiently conserve communication resources. After that, a necessary condition for the system's asymptotic stability is found by building a Lyapunov function and figuring out its forward difference. Lastly, real simulation is used to confirm the viability and progress of the suggested plan. Dynamic event triggering mechanism (DETM) may efficiently conserve communication resources, as demonstrated by experimental results that indicate a 75% reduction in transmission bandwidth.

title: MCMG: Multi-level Controllable Music Generation Model Based on Fine-grained Control
authors: Jingge Zhao, Xiaobing Li, Xinran Zhang, Xiaoqing Wang, Qingwen Zhou, Yun Tie
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: The task of controlled music generation has been well developed, but the lack of modeling of music control attributes and neglect of music structure affect the quality of music creation. In order to solve the above problems, we first classify music into three levels according to its essentially different nature and extract the corresponding interpretable control attributes. Then by adding the control attributes to the music representation, a multi-level connection between music generation process and human composition is established. Finally, we propose a multi-level controllable music generation model with fine-grained control (MCMG). This model considers the structural relationships between music levels, enabling the music generation process highly controllable. The experiments show that our generative model not only improves on the basic music metric compared to the baseline, but also performs well on the controllability metric.

title: Safety-Constrained Reinforcement Learning Method for Urban Eco-Driving
authors: Hongwen He, Jiaqi Li, Jingda Wu
publish: 2025 9th CAA International Conference on Vehicular Control and Intelligence (CVCI)
abstract: Reinforcement Learning (RL) is used for eco-driving in Intelligent and Connected Vehicles (ICVs), but traditional methods face a critical trade-off. Ensuring safety often requires high penalty terms, leading to overly conservative policies that severely compromise energy and traffic efficiency. To resolve this conflict, this paper introduces the Twin Delayed Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient with Safelayer (TD3+Safelayer), a novel framework that decouples safety from performance objectives. The Safelayer module maps the TD3 policy's actions into a verifiably safe action space. SUMO simulations demonstrate that TD3+Safelayer eliminates all collision events present in the baseline models. While achieving this high level of safety, it also reduces energy consumption by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 7. 4 \%}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3 0. 7 \%}$</tex> compared to traditional TD3 and rule-based strategies, respectively.

title: YOLO-RSD: Enhanced Rotated Ship Detection in SAR Images
authors: Ye Wu, Yuhu Shi, Hongyu Chen, Xingyu Hu, Xue Yang, Yang Cai, Yuxin Liu, Weiming Zeng
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: Rotated ship detection in synthetic aperture radar (SAR) imagery remains challenging due to arbitrary orientations, large scale variations, and strong sea clutter. This paper presents YOLO-RSD, a lightweight yet effective oriented object detector tailored for maritime surveillance. We first introduce a Feature-Aligned Spatial Attention (FASA) backbone that integrates deformable convolution with spatial attention to enhance orientation- and scale-adaptive feature extraction. Then, a FuseDiff neck module is designed to achieve consistent cross-scale semantic fusion via multi-branch convolution and context diffusion. Finally, a Task-Aligned Dynamic Detection Head (TDDH) is constructed using task-specific attention to reconcile classification–localization conflicts. Experiments on SSDD+ and RSDD-SAR datasets demonstrate that YOLO-RSD achieves state-of-the-art performance with only 2.61M parameters, outperforming recent YOLO variants and other comparative models in both accuracy and efficiency. The proposed framework offers a general and hardware-friendly paradigm for robust rotated target detection in SAR imagery.

title: Chalcogenide-based Optical Micro-ring Sensor Array Patch for Precise Blood Pressure Monitoring
authors: Xiaokai Cai, Zhangyi Sun, Bonan Chen, Jingshun Pan, Zhaohui Li
abstract: We demonstrate an optical pulse-sensing patch employing 10 chalcogenide microring resonators that precisely monitors pulse waveforms, heart rate, and blood pressure, achieving <4 mmHg deviation from commercial monitors through accurate arterial waveform analysis.

title: Center-guided Classifier for Semantic Segmentation of Remote Sensing Images
authors: Wei Zhang, Qin Huang, Mengting Ma, Yizhen Jiang, Yun Chen, Zhenhua Huang, Wangyu Wu, Kangning Cui, Rongrong Lian, Zhenkai Wu, Xiaowen Ma
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Compared with natural images, remote sensing images (RSIs) have a unique characteristic. i.e., larger intraclass variance, which makes semantic segmentation for remote sensing images more challenging. Moreover, existing semantic segmentation models for remote sensing images usually employ a vanilla softmax classifier, which has three drawbacks: (1) non-direct supervision for the pixel representations during training; (2) inadequate modeling ability of parametric softmax classifiers under large intraclass variance; and (3) opaque process of classification decision. In this paper, we propose a novel classifier (called CenterSeg) customized for RSI semantic segmentation, which solves the above-mentioned problems with multiple prototypes, direct supervision under Grassmann manifold, and interpretability strategy. Specifically, for each class, our CenterSeg obtains local class centers by aggregating corresponding pixel features based on ground-truth masks, and generates multiple prototypes through hard attention assignment and momentum updating. In addition, we introduce the Grassmann manifold and constrain the joint embedding space of pixel features and prototypes based on two additional regularization terms. Especially, during the inference, CenterSeg can further provide interpretability to the model by restricting the prototype as a sample of the training set. Experimental results on three remote sensing segmentation datasets validate the effectiveness of the model. Besides the superior performance, CenterSeg has the advantages of simplicity, lightweight, compatibility, and interpretability. Code is available at https://github.com/xwmaxwma/rssegmentation.

title: Learning What They Pretend to Think: Adversarial ToM for Safety-Critical Driving Policies
authors: Houhuang Bi, Jun Huang, Yichen Han, Zeng Zhang
abstract: In complex driving environments, autonomous agents must interact with diverse road users who exhibit heterogeneous and often unpredictable behaviors. Traditional reinforcement learning (RL) methods struggle to maintain robust performance in the presence of adversarial or deceptive intent. We propose Adversarial Theory of Mind Reinforcement Learning (Adversarial ToM-RL), a novel framework that integrates cognitive modeling with adversarial training to improve agent resilience. Unlike prior adversarial RL that perturbs observations or dynamics, our method operates on belief-level perturbations within a partially observable Markov decision process (POMDP) to simulate deceptive intent in Theory-of-Mind reasoning. Empirical results in hybrid autonomous vehicle crossover scenarios demonstrate that Adversarial ToM-RL reduces collision rates by 38% compared to standard ToM-RL and improves success rates by 8.3%. Our method shows strong robustness against malicious behaviors such as deceptive yielding and late-blocking, maintaining low collision rates and stable performance in adversarial traffic. These findings highlight the critical role of adversarial cognitive modeling in ensuring robust decision-making for security-sensitive multi-agent systems. The framework is general, model-agnostic, and compatible with existing ToM-RL pipelines.

title: Effectiveness of lidar-based assessment in anticipating tree-related disturbances on highvoltage transmission lines
authors: Muhammad Abdel Haq, Michael Van Detinsen Damanik, Luhur Prabhawa, Kanda Kurnia, Syafii, Imra Nur Izrillah
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on High Voltage Engineering and Power Systems (ICHVEPS)
abstract: PT PLN (Persero), Indonesia’s electricity provider, is committed to ensuring reliable and secure power transmission by maintaining the Right of Way (ROW) along its overhead transmission lines (SUTT/SUTET). Tree interference is a major challenge, and visual inspections by Ground Patrol Officers are commonly used to assess vegetation growth. However, these inspections often face accuracy issues, especially in difficult-toaccess areas, resulting in unreliable data and increasing the risk of outages. To overcome this, PLN has adopted Light Detection and Ranging (LiDAR) technology, which uses drones equipped with laser sensors to collect high-resolution, three-dimensional data. In the Sibolga-Martabe-Sidempuan segment, LiDAR revealed many trees dangerously close to the lines, causing threats that were not detected through manual inspections. The data produced provides not only accurate spatial information but also identifies critical vegetation points that are difficult to detect from the ground. Moreover, LiDAR significantly increases the assessment efficiency, covering up to 12 spans per day compared to only 3 spans by manual patrol. Periodic use of LiDAR also enables predictive analysis of vegetation growth. This innovation enhances transmission reliability while allowing Ground Patrol Officers to be reassigned to other critical tasks, supporting PLN’s efforts toward smarter and more efficient power infrastructure management.

title: Multi-UAV Transportation Assignment Network System Research Considering Route Planning
authors: Yushan Teng, Xiaohong Wang, Lizhi Wang, Ruyue Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: The study focuses on the multi-UAV assignment network system problem considering route planning. It firstly establishes geographic environment model and designs the cost function and the flight constraints of the UAV in the transport task process. Combined with the particle swarm optimization algorithm, it uses simulation software to solve the assignment network system problem and constructs the transportation assignment network with complete route information on the basis of the optimal flight route generated by the algorithm. According to the relevant actual scenes, the transportation network simulation experiment and the multi-point distribution simulation experiment are carried out respectively, so as to obtain the optimal assignment planning scheme that accomplishes the cost objective of the multi-UAV under the flow restriction and transportation point requirements.

title: A human-machine-environment interaction system based on VLA model and brain-computer interface
authors: Shaoyang Hua, Yuyang Zhang, Wenyao Zhang, Qile He, Xin Jin
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: The vision language action (VLA) model has shown extraordinary ability in the motion planning of the robots, which has great value in human-machine-environment interaction (HMEI), especially for rehabilitation engineering and robotic arm teleoperation fields. This paper proposes an HMEI system that integrates the brain-computer interface (BCI) with VLA model, enabling robots to interact with surrounding environment according to human intentions. Firstly, neural decoding technique is employed to interpret neural signals into intentions via a time and frequency fusion model. Then, the user’s intentions are converted into a textual instruction, which subsequently guides the VLA model in generating corresponding motion trajectories for robotic arm teleoperation. Experimental results demonstrate smooth and compliant control of the robotic arm, which can be a viable solution for HMEI applications.

title: Automatic Speech Recognition System for Dysarthria Leveraging Mel Spectrograms and Transfer Learning
authors: M Dhanalakshmi, S Bharathipriya, E Vasantha Surya, R Krishna Raj
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Intelligent Signal Processing and Effective Communication Technologies (INSPECT)
abstract: The challenge addressed in this study is the development of an effective automatic speech recognition (ASR) system for dysarthric speech, which is attributed to articulation, rate, and other differences caused by neurological conditions. This paper proposes an automatic speech recognition (ASR) system for dysarthric speech using the TORGO dataset and a sequential network architecture, achieving 98% accuracy. Unlike prior studies that employed coarse severity classifications and conventional deep learning models, our approach implements a fine-grained, five-level classification: normal, mild, moderate, moderate-to-severe, and severe. Using transfer learning and Mel spectrogram analysis, the system mitigates challenges related to variability of speech patterns and the small size of the dataset. One of the significant new things about this work is the inclusion of an automatic severity assessment module, allowing for machine-based evaluation for clinical and rehabilitation purposes. This dual-purpose model improves both recognition performance and the monitoring of speech impairment progression, thus making a valuable tool for healthcare practitioners and researchers.

title: Efficiency-Enhanced Optical Comb Generation Based on Achromatic Time Lens Assisted Cross-Phase Modualtion
authors: Huabei Liu, Qijie Xie, Chunyang Ma, Quanxin Na, Liyang Shao, Lei Wang
abstract: we have demonstrated generation of tunable-space optical combs via cross-phase modulation using rate-multiplied pulse trains. The pulse is pre-processed by an achromatic time lens for enhancing conversion efficiency of the optical comb up to 83%.

title: Novelty of Cloud Computing in the Internet of Things: Improving Real-Time Processing, Analytics, and Data Storage for Connected Devices
authors: Veena K, V.Samuthira Pandi, Riham Alkabbji, Sourabh Kumar, G. Karthikeyan, Devi Priya.L
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Computing Technologies (ICACT)
abstract: Cloud convergence with IoT has fundamentally changed the manner in which inter-connected devices process and analyze data in real time and store in the cloud. Traditional methods of processing and storing this data within the device have become increasingly unfeasible as the volume of data gained from IoT networks is continuously growing at a scale that outpaces device capabilities. Cloud computing allows for efficient scalability and flexibility, providing real-time data analytics and decision-making while enabling access to information remotely. Cloud services help IoT devices in offloading computation, thus reducing latency and energy consumption while ensuring interoperability and connectivity to different environments. Where cloud computing integrates with AIpowered analytics, this information is utilized for predictive maintenance, anomaly detection, and intelligent automation, enhancing the overall efficiency of the IoT ecosystem. Network latency, security vulnerabilities, and data privacy issues are areas that need to be solved before the cloud and IoT can be integrated well. Other emerging technologies like edge and fog computing, 5G connectivity, a blockchainbased security framework, and quantum computing, are likely to fine-tune these cloud-based IoT solutions. Cloud Computing and its Impact on IoT: This study elaborates on the innovative benefits that cloud computing adds to the IoT landscape and emphasizes its effects on real-time data processing, analytics, storage scalability, and extant challenges alongside future directions for improving cloudenabled IoT efficiency, security, and sustainability.

title: Conflict-Free Flight Scheduling Using Strategic Demand Capacity Balancing for Urban Air Mobility Operations
authors: Vahid Hemmati, Yonas Ayalew, Ahmad Mohammadi, Reza Ahmari, Parham Kebria, Abdollah Homaifar, Mehrdad Saif
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: In this paper, we propose a conflict-free multi-agent flight scheduling that ensures robust separation in constrained airspace for Urban Air Mobility (UAM) operations application. First, we introduce Pairwise Conflict Avoidance (PCA) based on delayed departures, leveraging kinematic principles to maintain safe distances. Next, we expand PCA to multi-agent scenarios, formulating an optimization approach that systematically determines departure times under increasing traffic densities. Performance metrics, such as average delay, assess the effectiveness of our solution. Through numerical simulations across diverse multi-agent environments and real-world UAM use cases, our method demonstrates a significant reduction in total delay while ensuring collision-free operations. This approach provides a scalable framework for emerging urban air mobility systems.

title: Reverse-Engineering and Automating BDD for Modern Software Development with LLMs
authors: Sagar B. Patel, Sajal Nigam, Shrikanth Mahale
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Data and Software Engineering (ICoDSE)
abstract: Behavior-Driven Development (BDD) frameworks like Cucumber and Behave align business requirements with executable tests but remain costly to author and maintain, especially for legacy or evolving systems [1], [2]. We present a novel LLM-driven approach, leveraging LLaMA to reverse-engineer requirements from schemas, API payloads, and partial tests to automatically generate Gherkin feature files with corresponding step definitions. Generated artifacts are drafted into automated pull requests and merged into the repositories via human review [3]. Our proposed method when tested across two enterprise systems, over six sprints, reduced authoring time by about 75%, expanded negative test coverage by 30%, and achieved cost savings ranging from $7,725 in conservative adoption to over $40,000 in high-volume adoption, maintaining infrastructure overhead costs below 3%. Beyond efficiency gains, the approach lowers barriers for teams new to BDD and demonstrates a practical, cost-effective path for industry adoption while opening avenues for research in adaptive prompting, coverage-aware generation, and retrieval-augmented workflows. [3].

title: Single-Channel Multi-Service Parallel Processing Method and Implementation Based on SPI Protocol
authors: Gang Li, Binbin Xue, Yanfang Yuan, Lei Zhang, Yanjie Zhang, Kun Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th International Conference on Power, Intelligent Computing and Systems (ICPICS)
abstract: For security chips with only one SPI physical channel, when multiple services received from autonomous devices are processed, the traditional processing method is to serially receive each service data into the device in sequence for processing. Once the processing time of a certain service data is too long, the subsequent services will be blocked for a long time, resulting in low efficiency of the entire communication process. This paper designs a single-channel multi-service parallel processing method based on the SPI protocol, designs a new instruction sequence. The kernel layer uses a multi-task operating system and designs a multi-level caching mechanism. The driver layer adopts the DMA transmission mode to move data, realizes the parallel processing of multiple services, avoids instruction blocking, and improves the efficiency of the entire communication process.

title: CTF: Hybrid Multi-scale Contrastive Transformer for Website Fingerprinting Attack
authors: Juxin Xiao, Yang Song, Yanhui Chen, Yunpeng Li, Jie Yin, Yuling Liu, Qixu Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Website Fingerprinting (WF) attacks, a methodology that allows observers to infer visited websites through encrypted traffic analysis, are usually employed for evaluating the security of anonymous networks like Tor. Although deep learning-based methods have demonstrated significant success in recent studies, existing approaches exhibit limitations. They are insufficient in modeling the intricate characteristics of traffic patterns, which leads to compromised accuracy in identifying challenging samples. To address these limitations, we propose CTF, a novel WF attack comprising three key components: (1) extraction of Hybrid Multi-scale Traffic Features (HMTF) integrating spatio-temporal information, (2) a novel deep learning framework that synergizes CNN for spatial pattern recognition and Transformer for temporal dependency modeling within HMTF, and (3) a supervised contrastive learning mechanism to enhance discriminative capability across website fingerprints. Experimental evaluations across multiple benchmark datasets reveal that CTF achieves 99.09% accuracy in Closed-World scenarios, showing enhanced robustness against four SOTA WF defense mechanisms.

title: AI-Powered Software for Automated Validation of House Construction Plans
authors: Joud Alsayid, Mohammed Alyami, Noura Alnaimi, Yaseen Shaikh, Mariya Almarhoon, Mohammad Alshayeb, Sumayh S. Aljameel
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Agentic AI (ICA)
abstract: Validating house construction plans for compliance with building regulations and guidelines is usually a manual and slow process. This may lead to long delays and inconsistent evaluations. This paper proposes ARCH (Automated Regulation Checker for Housing), an AI-powered platform to automate the validation of $2 D$ construction plans. The platform aims to reduce the review time and enhance stakeholder satisfaction. ARCH uses AI and rule-based validation to evaluate floor plans. It combines YOLOv8 for symbol detection, Raster-to-Graph model for floor plan vectorization, and EasyOCR for text extraction. ARCH was evaluated through a user study involving 31 participants. Over $90 \%$ of users agreed that the platform is easy to use through its integrated submission, review, and tracking features.

title: Spacecraft Pose Estimation Based on High-Resolution Feature Network
authors: Zhiyong Fu, Bo Ru, Zhelong Wang, Luyao Wang, Dongyang Yue, Jiangheng Zhou, Xvqing Li, Lingxiang Tang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Spacecraft pose estimation from monocular images presents significant challenges due to complex environmental conditions such as occlusions, illumination variations, and background interference, as well as estimation inaccuracies caused by multi-scale variations in object distance and viewpoint. To address these issues, this paper proposes a novel monocular pose estimation algorithm. In concrete terms, a high-resolution feature extraction framework is constructed using Higher-HRNet, a variant of the High-Resolution Network (HRNet), to generate multi-scale feature maps and enhance spatial feature representation. To balance estimation accuracy with real-time performance under limited computational resources, lightweight Ghost-BasicBlock and Ghost-Bottleneck modules are designed to reduce model complexity. Moreover, to mitigate the loss of feature representation capacity induced by model compression, a Biformer-Receptive Attention (BRA) mechanism is incorporated in the decoding stage to strengthen spatial-context modeling and improve keypoint localization accuracy. As the culminating process, the six-degree-of-freedom pose of the spacecraft is estimated by integrating the Efficient Perspective-n-Point (EPnP) algorithm with Random Sample Consensus (RANSAC). Experimental results on the SPEED dataset demonstrate that the proposed method achieves a mean translation error (meanET) of 0.0077m and a mean rotation error (meanER) of 0.0232°, with respective medians (medianET and medianER) corresponding to 0.0038m and 0.0112°, respectively—outperforming current state-of-the-art methods.

title: Online Sparse Streaming Feature Selection with Feature Correlation
authors: Hao Tian, Di Wu, Jia Chen, Min Zhou, Xin Luo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Online streaming feature selection(OSFS) employs an online approach to achieve feature selection, has distinct advantages in big data. Existing methods focus on feature selection with complete data, while the issue of missing data in real-world applications affects the performance of models. To address this issue, we focus on the online selection of sparse streaming features and interactions between them, proposing an Online Sparse Streaming Feature Selection with Feature Correlation(OS<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>FS<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">FC</inf>). It mainly consists of two parts: 1) Predictive completion of missing data using a latent feature analysis aligned with the feature selection objective, and 2) Feature selection applied to the completed streaming features, considering feature interaction. The results of the experiments demonstrate that OS<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>FS<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">FC</inf> outperforms several state-of-the-art OSFS algorithms.

title: Building neural networks’ latent space to extract instance-based explanations for sleep staging
authors: Guido Gagliardi, Antonio Luca Alfeo, Mario G.C.A. Cimino, Gaetano Valenza, Maarten De Vos
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Sleep disorders and their diagnosis are a significant public health concern. Automated sleep stage classification using deep learning models has shown promising results, but these models often lack transparency and interpretability. In this study, we propose an eXplainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI) approach to enhance the interpretability of cutting-edge deep learning sleep stage classification models. The proposed approach consists of a three-steps framework: (i) employing contrastive learning to order a neural network latent space based on input similarity; (ii) mining meaningful instances from that space; and (iii) explaining those instances by a customized XAI methodology. By doing this we are capable of extracting human-comprehensible insights about the model decision-making process, enhancing the applicability of the proposed approach in real-world clinical scenarios. The explanations provided point out high and low-representative sleep epochs of each sleep phase. These sleep epochs are analyzed considering both the single sleep epoch and the sequence of adjacent sleep epochs for the sleep phase classification.Our approach proved to maintain the original model performances, improve the model interpretability, and confirm that the network decision-making process is valid even from the perspective of a physician.

title: Augmentation for Imbalanced Fault Samples of AC-Filter Based on Generative Adversarial Capsule Network
authors: Peipei Fan, Xiaowei Ma, Xueyou Zhang, Teng Li, De Zhu, Yixiang Lu
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotics, Control and Automation Engineering (RCAE)
abstract: Aiming at the issues of being prone to imbalanced fault samples in AC-filter at converter stations, this study proposes a generative adversarial capsule network (GACN)-based sample augmentation method for imbalanced fault samples of AC-filter. The proposed methodology focuses on resolving the decline in fault detection accuracy caused by sample imbalance in AC-filter fault detection models. First, an autoencoder is employed to capture the latent feature space of the original sample dataset. Subsequently, a generator is constructed to synthesize feature vectors that approximate the distribution of the latent feature space, thereby reducing the complexity of sample synthesis. A discriminator incorporating capsule network architecture was designed to preserve inter-class differences among generated fault samples. Furthermore, a supervised loss function is introduced to quantify the divergence between synthetic and real sample features, facilitating joint training of the autoencoder and GACN while reducing model training complexity. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method significantly enhances the coverage, authenticity, and validity of synthetic data, effectively balancing the distribution of AC-filter fault samples.

title: BLaVe-CoT: Consistency-Aware Visual Question Answering for Blind and Low Vision Users
authors: Wanyin Cheng, Zanxi Ruan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Visual Question Answering (VQA) holds great potential for assisting Blind and Low Vision (BLV) users, yet real-world usage remains challenging. Due to visual impairments, BLV users often take blurry or poorly framed photos and face difficulty in articulating specific questions about what they cannot fully see. As a result, their visual questions are frequently ambiguous, and different users may interpret them in diverse ways. This leads to multiple valid answers, each grounded in different image regionsposing a mismatch with conventional VQA systems that assume a single answer and region. To bridge this gap, we present BLaVe-CoT, a VQA framework designed to reason about answer consistency in the face of ambiguity. Our method proposes diverse candidate answers using a LoRA-tuned BLIP-2 model, then grounds each answer spatially using PolyFormer, and finally applies a chain-of-thought reasoning module to assess whether the answers refer to the same or different regions. Evaluated on the VQA-AnswerTherapy benchmark, BLaVe-CoT outperforms previous methods and proves more robust to the ambiguity and visual noise common in assistive settings. This work highlights the need for VQA systems that can adapt to real human uncertainty and provide inclusive support for BLV users. To foster further research and accessibility applications, we have made the code publicly available at https://github.com/Accecwan/BLaVe-CoT.

title: A Novel Feature Selection Method Base on Enhanced-CDRIME and Multi-Classifiers for Pain Assessment
authors: Guodao Zhang, Leqi Li, Yupeng Li, Xiaotian Pan, Sufang Yang, JianWei Zhou, Chuanguang Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Multi-source physiological signals are valuable for quantitative pain assessment, but their high dimensionality, nonlinearity, and strong inter-variable correlations present challenges for clinical decision-making. To improve diagnostic accuracy and efficiency, we propose a novel feature selection framework based on an enhanced Rime optimization algorithm (b-CDRIME), which incorporates a co-adaptive hunting strategy and a dispersed foraging strategy. The framework discretizes the original continuous CDRIME algorithm by introducing a V-shaped binary coding strategy, and constructs a multi-objective weighted fitness function that integrates classification accuracy, feature dimension and AUC, which is combined with the dynamic feedback mechanism of the classifier to achieve efficient feature screening and classification performance optimization. On a multi-source physiological signal public pain dataset, this paper utilizes 10 classical classifiers to test our methods on feature selection and performance improvement. The comparative experiments results show that the pain assessment model constructed based on CDRIME with XGBoost has an average classification accuracy of 81.6% while significantly reducing feature dimensionality. These findings validate the good performance and application potential of this study in the task of processing high-dimensional multi-source pain physiological signals.

title: DC Microgrid Control for Fast-Charging Electric Vehicle Stations
authors: D Sarathkumar, T P Saravanan, G.P. Bharathi, T. Rengaraj, G Brindha, J. B. Sajin, Sivakumar Annamalai, C Anandhakumar, J. Karthikeyan, S Monic Prabhanth
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Intelligent Signal Processing and Effective Communication Technologies (INSPECT)
abstract: The growing penetration of electric vehicles (EVs) necessitates the development of fast-charging infrastructure capable of delivering high power with minimal impact on the utility grid. DC microgrids (DCMGs) have emerged as a promising solution to integrate renewable energy sources, energy storage systems, and fast-charging stations in a flexible, efficient, and stable manner. This paper presents a comprehensive study on control strategies for DC microgrids dedicated to fast-charging EV stations. The hierarchical control structure, including primary, secondary, and tertiary layers, is examined to ensure voltage stability, power-sharing, and optimal energy management. Various control methodologies such as droop control, model predictive control, and energy management algorithms are analyzed to address issues like load fluctuations, renewable intermittency, and fast load dynamics induced by EV charging demands. Simulation results validate the effectiveness of the proposed control schemes in enhancing system stability, reducing charging time, and improving energy efficiency. The proposed framework offers valuable insights for the deployment of nextgeneration fast-charging infrastructures supported by DC microgrids.

title: Virtual Firewall Implementation with eBPF for Distributed Denial of Service Attacks in Cloud-Native Environments
authors: Irsyad Nurwidianto Basuki, Yudistira Asnar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Data and Software Engineering (ICoDSE)
abstract: The evolution of cloud-native architecture has significantly enhanced the flexibility and scalability of software development, but it also introduces new attack surfaces and performance bottlenecks with Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks emerging as one of the most critical threats to service availability. Existing DDoS mitigation methods are often inefficient in cloud-native environments These methods suffer from high resource overhead due to frequent user-kernel context switching, limited adaptability to dynamic container workloads, and slow packet processing in large-scale rule sets. The use of eBPF for DDoS mitigation has gained traction due to its ability to process packets within the kernel. This paper presents the design and implementation of a node-level virtual firewall based on the Extended Berkeley Packet Filter (eBPF), deployed on each Kubernetes node via a DaemonSet for cluster-wide protection. The proposed solution integrates a lightweight Decision Tree (DT) machine learning model directly into the kernel using eBPF maps, enabling in-kernel packet classification without user-space transitions. This in-kernel inference design minimizes context-switching overhead common in traditional user-space security tools like iptables and pfSense. The system was rigorously evaluated under five DDoS attack scenarios (LDAP, NetBIOS, SYN, MSSQL, and UDP) and benchmarked against iptables and pfSense. The proposed approach achieved up to 35% lower CPU usage and near-baseline latency in three of the five attacks, demonstrating high efficiency in resource utilization and throughput. These findings validate the potential of eBPF -based intelligent firewalls as a scalable and efficient DDoS mitigation mechanism for cloud-native environments.

title: The Emergence of Deep Reinforcement Learning for Path Planning
authors: Thanh Thi Nguyen, Saeid Nahavandi, Imran Razzak, Dung Nguyen, Nhat Truong Pham, Quoc Viet Hung Nguyen
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: The increasing demand for autonomous systems in complex and dynamic environments has driven significant research into intelligent path planning methodologies. For decades, graph-based search algorithms, linear programming techniques, and evolutionary computation methods have served as foundational approaches in this domain. Recently, deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has emerged as a powerful method for enabling autonomous agents to learn optimal navigation strategies through interaction with their environments.
