This survey provides a comprehensive overview of traditional approaches as well as the recent advancements in DRL applied to path planning tasks, focusing on autonomous vehicles, drones, and robotic platforms. Key algorithms across both conventional and learning-based paradigms are categorized, with their innovations and practical implementations highlighted. This is followed by a thorough discussion of their respective strengths and limitations in terms of computational efficiency, scalability, adaptability, and robustness. The survey concludes by identifying key open challenges and outlining promising avenues for future research. Special attention is given to hybrid approaches that integrate DRL with classical planning techniques to leverage the benefits of both learning-based adaptability and deterministic reliability, offering promising directions for robust and resilient autonomous navigation.

title: Quantized Model Predictive Control for Nonlinear Systems With Delays and Parametric Uncertainties
authors: Xuyang Guo, Zhenping Sun
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: This study develops a quantized control framework for nonlinear systems with state delays, external disturbances, and bounded parametric uncertainties. First, a static logarithmic quantizer is integrated into the controller architecture, where its participation form within the actual computations is determined through theoretical analysis based on the sector bound approach. The nonlinear dynamics are subsequently decomposed into a group of linear subsystems via the Takagi-Sugeno (T-S) fuzzy modeling method. By formulating a Lyapunov-Krasovskii functional (LKF), the input-to-state stability (ISS) is demonstrated, leading to the development of a robust fuzzy model predictive control (RFMPC) algorithm supported by comprehensive proofs. Numerical simulations corroborate the assertions, illustrating the efficacy of the proposed strategy.

title: A Novel Deep Learning Model for Enhancing Chest X-Ray Assessment Using CXRIA-Net
authors: Adde Divya Bharathi, B Sindhuja, Vivekanand Aelgani, P Chander, Komalavalli D, S. Muthukumaran
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Computing Technologies (ICACT)
abstract: A key diagnostic technique for recognizing several lung diseases gives pneumonia, TB, and COVID-19 chest X-ray (CXR) imaging is Manual interpreting CXR pictures, on the other hand, might be laborious and prone to inter-observer variation. This paper presents CXRIA-Net, a deep convolutional neural network (CNN) meant to improve chest X-ray picture assessment precision as well as effectiveness. Employing advanced deep learning technology, the approach simplifies feature extraction, enhances disease classifying, and reduces diagnostic mistakes. The above technique trains CXRIA-Net on a sizable dataset of identified chest X-ray images using transfer learning together with data augmenting to maximize performance. The model shows better precision, sensitiveness, and specificity in finding anomalies when compared to functioning state-of-the-art CNN architectures. Experimental investigations indicate that CXRIA-Net demonstrates excellent diagnostic precision capabilities which establish it as a promising instrument to assist radiologists and healthcare employees during medical imaging assessment. This paper demonstrates how deep learning integration with medical imaging technology reveals AI applications which benefit patient results and radiological task operations. The proposed CXRIA-Net model demonstrates excellent potential to help detect diseases early which enables better clinical decisions and operates with enhanced healthcare system efficiency.

title: Consensus-Guided Dynamic Label Correction for Robust Two-View Deep TSK Fuzzy Classification
authors: Lingyi Shi, Meng Yang, Weiqin Liu, Xibei Yang, Ta Zhou
publish: 2025 2nd International Symposium on AI and Cybersecurity (ISAICS)
abstract: Deep Takagi-Sugeno-Kang fuzzy classifiers (D-TSK-FCs) are susceptible to performance degradation when trained with noisy labelsand lack mechanisms for fine-grained collaboration across multiple views. Existing two-view models often employ static fusion strategies that cannot adaptively exploit complementary information, while-directly fitting corrupted labels biases the learned decision boundaries. This study proposes a Consensus-Guided Dynamic Label-Corrected Two-view Deep TSK Classifier (CG-DLCT), which integrates bidirectional interaction between predictions and supervision. Insteadof assuming fixed labels, CG-DLCT selectively refines them only when both views reach high-confidence agreement, enabling implicit denoising without explicit noise modeling. A core component, Inter-layer Consensus Guided Dual-View Ridge Regression (ICG-DVRR), aligns view-specific parameters toward a consensus-regularized target while propagating confidence, correction flags, and view preferences as a guidance signal for subsequent layers. Experiments on nine-datasets under clean and noisy settings show that CG-DLCT maintains comparable accuracy to state-of-the-art models on clean data andexhibits slower degradation under increasing noise levels. These results indicate that incorporating consensus-based label refinement and feature guidance into deep fuzzy architectures offers a practical approach to improving robustness without sacrificing interpretability.

title: An AI-Driven Model for Automated Detection of Damaged Fruits
authors: Mohebbanaaz, M Jyothirmai, C. Ahalya
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Intelligent Signal Processing and Effective Communication Technologies (INSPECT)
abstract: The quality inspection of fruits is a critical step in the agricultural supply chain, directly impacting food safety, market value, and consumer satisfaction. Manually checking damaged fruits are time-consuming, subjective, and susceptible to human error. To address these limitations, this study presents an AI-driven model for the automated detection of damaged fruits using deep learning (DL) techniques. We developed two convolutional neural network (CNN) architectures-EfficientNet, and InceptionV3-for classifying fruits as damaged or healthy. The models are trained and validated on a curated dataset comprising high-resolution images of various fruits with and without visible defects. Transfer learning is employed to leverage pre-trained weights, improving model convergence and accuracy. Among the evaluated models, efficientNet achieved the highest accuracy of 99.30%, balancing depth and efficiency, while InceptionV3 showed robustness in handling image variations with an accuracy of 98.74%. The results indicate that DL, particularly with optimized CNN architectures, provides a reliable solution for real-time fruit quality assessment. This research contributes to the development of intelligent agricultural systems, enhancing post-harvest handling and reducing food waste.

title: Extreme ultraviolet interference lithography based on table-top HHG light source
authors: Mingjie Yao, Xia Yu, Hao Li, Youyang Zhou, Xiaoshi Zhang
abstract: We present a table-top Extreme ultraviolet interference lithography (EUV-IL) system at 29.6 nm central wavelength of high harmonic generation radiation. The EUV-IL generates periodic aerial images of 22 nm half-pitch (HP) at the two-mirror interference system. In this letter, we investigated the influence of femtosecond EUV laser on high resolution interference pattern. The simulation results of the interference pattern are discussed.

title: Enhancing Small Object Detection in Aerial Images via Transformer Scaling and Dynamic Fusion
authors: Kai Zheng, Jintao Li, Weixuan Liu, Shui Yu, Yun Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: At present, accurate detection of small objects in an aerial imagery remains a challenge in remote sensing due to limited pixel resolution, background clutter, and scale variations. To address these issues for high-precision detection in a complex remote sensing scene, we propose a novel detection framework based on RepViT Dynamic Fusion and YOLOv11, termed RDF-YOLO. The RDF-YOLO brings in two core innovations:(1) a Dynamic Scale RepViT module that integrates lightweight Transformer operations into the backbone to enhance global context modeling and semantic discrimination under noisy conditions, and (2) a dynamic fusion module that incorporates spatially aware dilated convolutions and channel-adaptive fusion strategies to enable flexible, scale-aware feature interaction. Extensive experiments on the challenging AI-TOD dataset show that the RDF-YOLO outperforms state-of-the-art methods by substantial margins. In particular, the RDF-YOLO improves AP50:95 by 6.9% and AP<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">50</inf> by 8.6% over the YOLOv11 baseline and on small-object metrics, including AP<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">vt</inf>, AP<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">t</inf>, and AP<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">s</inf>. These results verify the effectiveness of the RDF-YOLO architecture for robust and efficient detection of small objects in remote sensing imagery. The source code is available at https://github.com/AssiiKk/RDF-YOLO.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning Model in Robot Collaborative Control
authors: Deli Chen, Zhenyu Chen, Xinyue Guo
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th International Conference on Power, Intelligent Computing and Systems (ICPICS)
abstract: In the field of robot collaborative control, multi-agent reinforcement learning is a key technology to achieve efficient collaboration. This paper proposes a hierarchical multi-agent reinforcement learning algorithm (DAML-HRL) based on a dynamic attention mechanism. The dynamic attention mechanism dynamically focuses on key information, and the hierarchical architecture realizes task decomposition and collaborative optimization. Multi-robot collaborative handling and complex terrain exploration task scenarios are built on the Gazebo and PyBullet simulation platforms, and the DAML-HRL algorithm is compared with the QMIX and MAPPO algorithms. The results show that in the collaborative handling task, the DAML-HRL algorithm has a task completion success rate of 92%, which is 23% higher than QMIX and 18% higher than MAPPO, and the handling time is shortened by 28%; in the complex terrain exploration task, the information collection efficiency is improved by 31%, the exploration coverage rate is improved by 25%, and the exploration time is reduced by 30%. At the same time, the DAML-HRL algorithm converges faster, and the average number of convergence steps is reduced by 40% compared with QMIX and 35% compared with MAPPO. The algorithm still maintains good performance when introducing interference such as sensor noise and communication failure and expanding the task scale. Research shows that the DAML-HRL algorithm provides a more efficient and reliable solution for robot collaborative control.

title: Minuku: Detecting Diverse Display Issues in Mobile Apps with Small-scale Dataset
authors: Yongxiang Hu, Ke Liu, Hailiang Jin, Shiyu Guo, Juxing Yuan, Xin Wang, Yangfan Zhou
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: User interface (UI) display issues, such as widgets occlusion, missing elements, and screen overflow, are emerging as a non-negligible source of user complaints in commercial mobile apps. However, existing automated testing tools typically rely on a vast amount of high-quality training data, making them cost-ineffective for industrial practice. Given that display issues are intuitively recognizable by humans, their diverse appearances can be abstracted by the violation of human commonsense expectations of UI appearance. Therefore, this paper proposes to reduce data requirements in display issue detection through commonsense simulation. Although leveraging large vision-language models (VLMs) to replicate human visual ability looks straightforward, off-the-shelf VLMs lack task-specific knowledge of UI designs and display correctness. To address this, we fine-tune a VLM to learn what constitutes an expected display and to reason potential display issues. This approach is termed as Minuku, an industrial data-efficient UI display issue detector. We evaluate the design effectiveness of Minuku via a set of ablation experiments. Moreover, real-world deployments in one of the largest E-commerce app providers further demonstrate that Minuku can effectively detect 40 previously unknown UI display issues and significantly reduce manual effort in industrial settings.

title: A Real-Time Adaptive Music Performance Assistance and Training System using Attentionbased CNN-BiLSTM with Genetic Optimization
authors: Jiali Yu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Mobile Networks and Wireless Communications (ICMNWC)
abstract: In modern times, music learning progressively transformed towards intelligent digital platforms which guide learners in enhancing their music performance using automated analysis and feedback. However, existing Attention-Induced Multi-Head Convolutional Neural Network Optimized with Hunter-Prey Optimization (AIMCNN-HPO) lacks in real-time feedback ability, unable to capture temporal dependencies, depends on computationally heavy HPO and gives no personalized learning adaptation. To address these limitations, Adaptive Learning Attention-Based Convolutional Neural Network-Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory system Optimized with Genetic Algorithm (ACNN-BiLSTM-GA) is proposed. Primarily, audio data collected from Piano Triads Wavset dataset and preprocessed using Adaptive Distorted Gaussian Matched Filter (ADGMF) and normalization to ensure standardize input for model training. Next, feature extraction is employed utilizing Mel-spectrograms, MelFrequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCCs). Further, these features fed to CNN-Attention-BiLSTM network which allows both spatial learning and temporal modeling. Furthermore, GA used for effectively tuning hyperparameters and decrease computational load. Additionally, real-time analysis allows instant feedback and personalized learning component adaptively adjusts difficultly and practice suggestions based on history. Together, these components convert framework into adaptive, interactive music training assistant. Therefore, proposed ACNN-BiLSTM-GA achieved greater results in accuracy ($\mathbf{4 5 \%}$), Learning Skill Ratio (99%), Learning Activity Ratio (99%), Student Performance Rate (99.2%), Teaching Evaluation Rate (95%) And Learning Behavior Rate (99.5%).

title: A comprehensive approach for ransomware real-world case scenarios
authors: Paulo Falcão, Roberto Souto Maior de Barros
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Ransomware is a type of Malware that can cause great damage to their victims. These programs can encrypt and/or lock files in the infected system and, thus, restrict the access of the owner and users to important files. The early detection of ransomware is important, as it can avoid troublesome situations that would otherwise require ransom payment or data back up strategies to regain access to potential important data. Moreover, payment does not guarantee the release of the data and, if the file is truly lost, the damage can go even further, once this opens up the possibility of reputation damage involving customers and partners. One of the main difficulties to deal with ransomware is their rapid and constant evolution, creating methods to deceive outdated detectors, letting the new ransomware be unnoticed. Bearing that in mind, this work proposes a data drift detection approach aiming to improve the detection of new ransomware released in the network, pointing out, at least at mid-term, new patterns that would evidence the need for an update. In particular, semi-supervised learning is adopted as a more fitting way to deal with ransomware, because it requires less time and cost to be updated and deployed again. In addition, this work used publicly available open datasets containing data from malicious ransomware behavior mixed with legitimate system usage of some benign software. Finally, our proposal delivered results that are similar to those of the original papers, and even better in some cases, despite using less than half labeled data.

title: Research on the Evaluation Method of Fault Diagnosis Ability of Complex Electromechanical Systems
authors: JiaoLong Zhang, JingWei Zhao, KaiYe Gao
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on System Reliability and Safety Engineering (SRSE)
abstract: With the development of science and technology, the role of complex electromechanical systems in industry and national defense is becoming increasingly prominent. Its complex structure, frequent faults, and diverse types urgently require effective fault diagnosis and evaluation methods. This paper studies the evaluation of fault diagnosis capability of complex electromechanical systems, constructs an evaluation system covering multi-dimensional indicators such as performance, time and cost, proposes a comprehensive evaluation method based on AHP, entropy weight method and gray correlation analysis (GRA), and implements software modules on the RAMIDS. TesLab platform. The feasibility and effectiveness of the method are verified by the practical application of a certain type of electromechanical system.

title: Benchmarking Vision Transformers and Convolutional Neural Networks for Ulos Batak Pattern Recognition
authors: Grace Lamudur Arta Sihombing, Poltak Sihombing, Romi Fadillah Rahmat, Amalia
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Information Technology, Information Systems and Electrical Engineering (ICITISEE)
abstract: Traditional woven fabrics pose challenges for computer vision due to small datasets and high intra-class similarity. Ulos Batak, a cultural textile from North Sumatra, reflects this difficulty through its fine-grained and visually similar motifs. This study benchmarks Vision Transformers (ViTs) and Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) for Ulos Batak image retrieval, establishing the first comparative baseline for this dataset. Two ViT variants (ViT-Base/16, ViT-Large/16) and two CNN models (ResNet-50, EfficientNet) were evaluated on 895 images. ViTs were selected for their ability to capture global dependencies, while CNNs provide strong baselines due to their inductive bias in capturing local and repetitive textures. Retrieval performance was assessed using ranking-based metrics (mAP@10, MRR@10, nDCG@10), which better reflect retrieval behavior than standard classification metrics. Results show that CNNs outperform ViTs under small-data conditions, with ResNet-50 achieving the best performance (mAP@10=0.0754, MRR@10=1.0, nDCG@10= 0.9604). ViT performance improves with scaling (ViT-L/16 > ViT-B/16), highlighting their potential for modeling global structures. These findings provide a foundational benchmark and motivate future work on adaptive ViT patching (e.g., SIFT) and semantic re-ranking (e.g., BM25) for advancing finegrained cultural heritage retrieval.

title: A Flat, Low-Noise, Multi-Wavelength Laser Source Based on a Brillouin Cavity
authors: Zihan Li, Yue Wang, Yin Xu, Hualong Bao
abstract: A flat, low-noise, multi-wavelength laser source is achieved via FSOIL by injecting external light into the Brillouin cavity. It features 0.08 Hz<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>/Hz white noise and <1 dB spectral flatness with high coherence.

title: A 168 dB FoM ISFET-Integrated CT Delta Sigma Frontend With Gm-Boosted Linearity and Hybrid Noise Shaping Achieving 6.8 m-pH Resolution
authors: Chen Wang, Wenshuo Li, Yuanqi Hu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Biomedical Circuits and Systems
abstract: This paper presents a low-power, ISFET-integrated frontend architecture that directly merges the sensing element with a G<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">m</sub>-C based continuous-time delta sigma modulator (CT-ΔΣM). In the proposed design, the ISFET simultaneously functions as both the biochemical sensor and the input common-source stage of the integrator, eliminating the need for intermediate driver and thereby improving energy efficiency. A passive low-pass filter DAC (LPF-DAC) is introduced to attenuate the input–feedback residue and provide hybrid noise shaping. The input Gm combines source degeneration and gm-boost to mitigate the nonlinearities introduced by input–feedback residue and common-mode variation. Fabricated in 180 nm CMOS, the proposed CT-ΔΣM achieves a measured peak SNDR of 84.2 dB and a dynamic range of 90.4 dB over a 10 kHz bandwidth under a 900 mV<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">pp</sub> input, with a power consumption of only 41.5 µW. These results present a Schreier FoM of 168 dB, representing a 8 dB improvement over prior ISFET frontends. The frontend demonstrates an averaged sensitivity of 29.04 mV/pH, along with a resolution of 6.8 m-pH, validating its applicability for lowpower, high-accuracy biochemical sensing.

title: A Domain Mapping-Based Weakly Supervised Deep Learning Framework for Spatial Downscaling of Nighttime Light Data
authors: Weixing Xu, Zhaocong Wu, Weihua Lin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Global-scale Nighttime Light (NTL) data, such as NPP/VIIRS DNB, have been widely used in various fields due to their high revisit frequency and extensive coverage. However, their coarse spatial resolution has limited their broader applications. Downscaling is a crucial technique for enhancing the spatial resolution of remote sensing data, the application of deep learning (DL) to downscale NTL data remains relatively unexplored. For NTL data, the limited availability of high-resolution NTL data and variations among different NTL datasets (e.g., radiance dynamic range and overpass time) make it challenging to meet the requirement of strictly corresponding sample pairs for supervised DL models. In light of these challenges, this study proposes a weakly supervised deep learning framework based on domain mapping for NTL downscaling. This framework first selects high-resolution scale factors (i.e., impervious surface, road network, and Highlight features) based on the mechanisms of NTL radiation sources and contributions to constrain the downscaling process. Subsequently, a domain mapping-based weakly supervised NTL downscaling model, termed NTL-DownSGAN, was proposed based on Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs). Instead of imposing strict pixel-level constraints, NTL-DownSGAN establishes mappings between HR and CR NTL at the feature level, thus eliminating the need for strictly corresponding sample pairs. Then, our framework was implemented in 200 Chinese cities, downscaling NPP/VIIRS DNB NTL data from 500 m to 130 m. Extensive downscaled results were generated for three megacities (Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Beijing) and their surrounding areas. Results indicate that downscaling effectively resolved the "blooming" effect in the original NPP/VIIRS NTL DNB data, enhancing the distinguishability of lights within urban areas. The downscaled results also exhibited good textural similarity with the Luojia1-01 reference data. Compared with the original NPP/VIIRS DNB, the R values between the downscaled NPP/VIIRS DNB and the Luojia1-01 reference increased by 51.8% (0.490 vs. 0.744), 57.0% (0.583 vs. 0.815), and 71.2% (0.407 vs. 0.702) in the three major city areas of Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Beijing, respectively. Meanwhile, the Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) decreased by 66.1% (27.234 vs. 9.230 nW·cm-²·sr⁻¹), 75.2% (28.091 vs 6.956 nW·cm-²·sr⁻¹), and 71.8% (26.482 vs. 7.460 nW·cm-²·sr⁻¹). Most importantly, the downscaling process improved the accuracy of NTL statistical metrics, such as illuminated area and total radiance. In the three major city areas of Shanghai, Guangzhou and Beijing, downscaled results improved the statistical accuracy of 25.82%, 16.54%, and 15.34% of the illuminated area, and 9.89%, 16.07%, and 8.64% of the total radiance, respectively. Then, Comparisons with other downscaling methods demonstrated the superiority of our proposed NTL-DownSGAN model. Additionally, ablation studies confirmed the effectiveness of scale factors in downscaling NTL data. The importance of these scale factors was ranked as follows: road network, impervious surface, and Highlight features, in descending order. Our framework has demonstrated the feasibility of downscaling NTL data using DL techniques and provides an effective approach for obtaining large-scale, high-resolution NTL data.

title: TrustPKBG: Trustworthy Protocol Knowledge Blueprints Generation via LLM for Low-Altitude UAV Networks
authors: Fan Wu, Yuxin Zhang, Gaolei Li, Jianhua Li, Jin Ma
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cognitive Communications and Networking
abstract: In low-altitude networks, reliable and lightweight flight interconnection among UAVs mainly depends on protocols like Message Queuing Telemetry Transport (MQTT). However, existing protocol analysis methods often fail to adapt to unknown program functions caused by version updates due to a lack of protocol knowledge blueprints (PKB). Moreover, due to the lack of multiple rounds of verification in terms of grammar semantics and execution logic representation, the correctness, validity and credibility of the generated PKB in practical scenarios remain questionable. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a novel trust-worthy protocol knowledge blueprints generation (TrustPKBG) framework for low-altitude UAV networks by large language model (LLM). In TrustPKBG, a Hierarchical Chain-of-Thought (HCoT) strategy is designated to automatically transform technical specifications into a structured, objective, and consistent PKB draft against the bias of human construction. Moreover, to enhance the abstract semantic similarity between PKB drafts and RFC documents, a memory-aware multi-agent collaboration mechanism is also presented, which enables closed-loop error detection and knowledge updating. To demonstrate the superiority of TrustPKBG, we also implement a Fuzzing-based PKB Verifier over MQTT/CoAP. Experimental results demonstrate that fuzzing with TrustPKBG can achieve an average code coverage rate of 33.71% for MQTT and 33.5% for CoAP, which is 50.83% higher than the baseline average coverage rate of 22.35% for MQTT and 27.6% for CoAP, with a valid test ratio of 74.57% for MQTT and 62.3% for CoAP. Furthermore, we explore PKB’s application in protocol code auditing by evaluating open-source MQTT and CoAP implementations for compliance verification, which demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed methods.

title: Examining the Role of Conversational AI in MNCs’ Marketing Strategies in India
authors: Monika Sharma, Lakshman Kumar Yadavalli, Supriya Lamba Sahdev, Ghousia Khatoon
publish: 2025 International Conference on Robotics and Mechatronics (ICRM)
abstract: This study examines the integration of Conversational AI (CAI) in the marketing strategies of leading Multinational Corporations (MNCs) in India, employing the Interpretive Structural Modeling (ISM) framework. Primary data was gathered through in-depth interviews with five top academicians (published in ABDC A/B category journals) and five CMO-level industry experts from Indian MNCs. The research identifies ten critical drivers of CAI adoption in India’s diverse market, such as multilingual support, cost efficiency, and hyper-personalization. Using ISM, the study prioritizes three key enablers: Hyper-personalization, Multilingual and voice-enabled AI capabilities, and Seamless omnichannel integration. These factors are shown to improve customer engagement as well as optimize operational efficiency with the aim of driving market expansion, which case studies in BFSI, e-commerce, and healthcare sectors have demonstrated. These results show CAI transforms India’s economy digitally and reveal some problems. Data privacy remains a concern, and regional languages must adapt now.

title: RAIL: ReArranging Inter-GPU Links for GPU-Centric Clusters
authors: Haixin Nan, Jun Xu, Peirui Cao, Zhaochen Zhang, Yizhi Wang, Zhehao Lin, Yuhang Li, Chengyuan Huang, Wentao Fan, Xiaohu Xu, Zhongming Ji, Shengju Zhang, Dongxu Wang, Lingkun Meng, Rong Gu, Guihai Chen, Chen Tian
abstract: In modern GPU-centric clusters, large-scale AI training relies on two distinct communication domains: a high-bandwidth intra-node domain using proprietary interconnects (e.g., NVLink), and a scale-out inter-node network domain (e.g., RDMA). We observe that the widely-used ring algorithm, often create a significant load imbalance across these domains. This leads to the counter-intuitive scenario where the expensive, high-bandwidth intra-node domain becomes a performance bottleneck, while the inter-node network remains underutilized. This inefficiency is further exacerbated by the disparity in bandwidth provisioning: inter-node network bandwidth is generally more cost-effective and accessible, whereas intra-node bandwidth is often proprietary and more costly to scale. To address this fundamental imbalance, we propose RAIL, aimed at resolving the intra-node bottleneck by strategically rearranging inter-GPU communication paths. This rebalancing ensures that traffic loads are appropriately matched with the distinct transmission capabilities of each domain, thereby maximizing overall communication performance. RAIL incorporates a Load Distributing Strategy (LDS) that can accurately partition physical nodes into logical nodes based on the a transmission capabilities of both domains, shifting excess traffic from the overloaded intra-node domain to the underutilized network domain. Additionally, the Intra-Rail Strategy (IRS) leverages topological characteristics to ensure optimal communication paths through the network domain between logical nodes. Our evaluation demonstrates that RAIL effectively mitigates congestion and achieves a 30.7% average increase in collective communication bus bandwidth compared to the widely-used NCCL solution.

title: Autonomous Healthcare Assistant Robot Using SLAM Gmapping
authors: Achuth R, Arunav H, Abhishek S, Gokul Jagadish, Amal Prakash, Arjun R Nair
publish: 2025 International Conference on Robotics and Mechatronics (ICRM)
abstract: The workforce is the primary determinant of healthcare services. The introduction of an autonomous food and medication delivery robot for hospitals aims to improve the productivity and security of medical personnel. This robot will act as a go-between for the distribution of food, medicine, and medical supplies among patients, wards, and departments. This can help medical professionals during pandemics like COVID-19. Because of their previous experience with COVID-19, they can safely administer food and medication to a patient who is isolated. A depth camera and a LiDAR sensor that run on a robot operating system (ROS) will be integrated into the robot's intelligent navigation system for Simultaneous Localization and Mapping(SLAM). Robots can now distinguish between things or humans in their environment thanks to this technology. The proposed system can function while ensuring the safety of the people being moved as well as the items being transported. That’s how the robot functions. Before choosing the destination on the screen, the individual loads the drugs and other belongings into their assigned storage space. After selecting the best route from the saved map, the robot will leave the base station and use the SLAM Gmapping algorithm to avoid any obstacles on its way to its destination.

title: Non-Line-of-Sight Target Recognition Based on Multi-Detection Points Collaboration Strategy
authors: Qi Zhang, Yue Zheng, Guangyun Shang, Zhonghao Xi, Yongjian Liu
abstract: Non-line-of-sight (NLOS) target recognition, which refers to the identification of objects beyond the line of sight, like around the corner, has widespread applications in unmanned driving, counter-terrorism operations and many other fields. Current research in this field mainly focuses on passive detecting and identifying speckle patterns generated by hidden objects, of which the feasibility has been proved. However, the performances in practical scenarios, like the accuracy and speed, are far from satisfactory. In this work, we rely on the active NLOS detection system and propose a multidetection points collaboration strategy to achieve the recognition of NLOS targets. By taking advantage of the high spatial detection efficiency of the single-photon avalanche diode (SPAD) array and by getting rid of the redundant information hidden in the SPAD-array measurement, the hidden target can be recognized fast and accurately. The preprocessing steps for the original recorded histogram are designed to eliminate the unwanted elements, form the collaborated histogram and then enter a designed convolutional neural network obtaining the classification result. Specially, a number of key variables, which are mutually constrained in selecting the pixels for recognition, are discussed, including the number of pixels in one group used to form a collaborated histogram, the spacing between any two pixels in one group, and the total number of groups injected into the network in one measurement. The proposed strategy and network are validated by experiments, which are conducted on both single hidden object and multiple hidden objects in one scene, and achieve nearly 92% recognition accuracy. As the accuracy, speed and robustness of the network are guaranteed, it shows great potential for NLOS target recognition in practical scenes.

title: Channel Prediction Based on Spatially Dependent Diffusion Models
authors: Zhangyao Song, Xiang Zhang, Li Zhuang, Tao Guo, Xiaoyu Zhao, Yinfei Xu
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Wireless Communications and Signal Processing (WCSP)
abstract: Channel prediction is crucial for addressing the channel aging of time-varying channel in 5 G wireless communication. It aims to use past channel state information (CSI) to predict future CSI. Existing channel prediction methods usually process signals based on the temporal correlation of the channels, i.e., considering only the temporal variation relationship of the corresponding elements of the CSI matrix. However, elements of the matrix may be strongly related, which is essential to address channel aging. In this paper, we propose a channel prediction scheme utilizing spatial dependence based on diffusion models (SDDM) by additionally involving the spatial correlation of the channel. Moreover, we regard channel prediction as the denoising process in diffusion models, where instead of directly predicting the actual CSI, we achieve this by predicting the noise injected by the diffusion model. Specifically, the spatial and temporal correlations are extracted by transformers, which serve as the core of the denoising function within the diffusion model. The simulation results demonstrate that the proposed SDDM channel prediction method achieves better performance compared to methods that only involve temporal correlation in most scenarios.

title: Efficient Online Uncertainty Evaluation for Microgrid Systems
authors: Siyu Zhou, Yan Wan, Zimin Jiang, Peng Zhang, Zongli Lin, Yacov A. Shamash
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: In this study, we present a method for online estimation of the mean performance output in microgrid systems subject to high-dimensional and dynamic uncertainties. We integrate an efficient Multivariate Probabilistic Collocation Method (MPCM) based sampling strategy with a Copula-based conditional probability distribution. This integrated method enables online evaluation of system outputs with high estimation accuracy and efficiency. The online evaluation algorithm is developed, and its theoretical analysis is provided. Real Time Digital Simulator (RTDS) experiments validate the method, demonstrating its feasibility for practical applications.

title: Hankel-Toeplitz Optimization for Channel Estimation in Hybrid RIS
authors: Mingzhi Li, Xiaohuan Wu
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Wireless Communications and Signal Processing (WCSP)
abstract: In multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) communication systems, millimeter wave communication relies on reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (RIS) to optimize propagation environments. This paper utilizes a hybrid RIS architecture integrated with dynamically controllable active elements, which reduces the cost of RIS deployment. Based on this architecture, we propose a rank-constrained structured matrix recovery-based channel estimation algorithm for hybrid RIS multiusers scenarios. This method transforms the channel angle estimation problem into a maximum likelihood-based line spectral estimation task and formulates the optimization in the signal domain, thereby eliminating the sensitivity of parametric algorithms to initialization parameters. The simulation results show the superiority of the proposed methods in estimation accuracy in a single snapshot scenario.

title: Non-Orthogonal Digital-Analog Hybrid Optical Transmission Using Fiber Dispersion in Multi-Distance Passive Optical Network
authors: Jinwoo Park, Joungmoon Lee, Sang-Kook Han
abstract: Non-orthogonal digital-analogue hybrid optical transmission in multi-distance passive optical network is proposed to increase spectral efficiency and demonstrated with proof-of-concept experiments. Dispersion-induced power fading (DIPF) of optical fiber is deliberately utilized to mitigate interference between heterogeneous signals to achieve sufficient signal power

title: C-band thin film lithium niobate hybrid integrated actively mode-locked laser
authors: Qiang Ying, Rui Ma, Zijun Huang, Xinlun Cai
abstract: We demonstrate the first C-band hybrid integrated mode-locked laser fabricated on the thin film lithium niobate platform. The measured central wavelength, pulse width, average power, peak power, pulse energy are 1542.4 nm, 7.228 ps, 1.778 mW, 22 mW and 0.159 pJ, respectively.

title: Detecting Vulnerabilities from Issue Reports for Internet-of-Things
authors: Sogol Masoumzadeh
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: Timely identification of issue reports reflecting software vulnerabilities is crucial, particularly for Internet-of-Things (IoT) where analysis is slower than non-IoT systems. While Machine Learning (ML) and Large Language Models (LLMs) detect vulnerability-indicating issues in non-IoT systems, their IoT use remains unexplored. We are the first to tackle this problem by proposing two approaches: (1) combining ML and LLMs with Natural Language Processing (NLP) techniques to detect vulnerability-indicating issues of 21 Eclipse IoT projects and (2) fine-tuning a pre-trained BERT Masked Language Model (MLM) on 11,000 GitHub issues for classifying vulnerability-indicating issues. Our best performance belongs to a Support Vector Machine (SVM) trained on BERT NLP features, achieving an Area Under the receiver operator characteristic Curve (AUC) of 0.65. The fine-tuned BERT achieves 0.26 accuracy, emphasizing the importance of exposing all data during training. Our contributions set the stage for accurately detecting IoT vulnerabilities from issue reports, similar to non-IoT systems.

title: Application of Multi-Scale Feature Fusion Method Based on Improved YOLOv5 Model in Vegetation Detection
authors: Fanzhao Meng, Haifeng Hu, Jie Tan
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th International Conference on Power, Intelligent Computing and Systems (ICPICS)
abstract: In the application research of multi-scale feature fusion method in vegetation detection, we propose an improved YOLOv5 model-Pooling Separable YOLO (PS-YOLO). This method combines YOLOv5, Depthwise Separable Convolution (DSC), and Spatial Pyramid Pooling (SPP). First of all, YOLOv5 model provides a basic detection framework, and its fast detection ability and high precision make it suitable for vegetation detection tasks. Secondly, the deep separable convolution optimization model structure is introduced to reduce the computational complexity and improve the operation efficiency of the model. Finally, the multi-scale features were fused with the spatial pyramid pool to enhance the detection ability of vegetation targets at different scales. The experimental results show that PS-YOLO performs well in vegetation detection tasks. Compared with the traditional YOLOv5 model, PS-YOLO significantly improves the detection speed and accuracy, and reduces the computational complexity of the model. This verifies the validity and feasibility of PS-YOLO in vegetation detection.

title: Prediction and Analysis of Mechanical Failures in Tobacco Equipment with Neural Network Algorithms Through Voiceprint Detection Technology
authors: Rao Taichun, Lu Qingfeng, Guo Feng, Yan Bin, Chen Liang, Zhang Dong
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th International Conference on Power, Intelligent Computing and Systems (ICPICS)
abstract: To solve mechanical failures in tobacco equipment, based on the development and application of voiceprint detection technology, the voiceprint information of fans is extracted and deeply analyzed, and Filtering Techniques, Mean Autocorrelation Analysis(MAA), Mel Frequency Cepstral Coefficient (MFCC), Wavelet Transform (WT) and Empirical Mode Analysis(EMA) are used for research, and use neural network algorithms to predict and analyze the voiceprint energy of tobacco equipment. These feature engineering of MAA, MMFC, and EMA are used as inputs for the model. The results indicate that the model can analyze equipment failures in advance, issue alarms in advance, and promptly push messages to maintenance personnel. It provides great convenience for predictive maintenance of tobacco equipment failures.

title: Accurate courtship-related social behavior automated recognition in zebrafish
authors: Zhan Shu, Tingting Luo, Xiya Zhang, Haoyuan Sun, Yang Fu, Zhixian Qiao, Binbin Tao, Jingjing Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: In many animal species, courtship-related social behavior is essential for mating success. Given the diversity and complexity of animal courtship-related social behavior, it is challenging to automatically recognize courtship-related social behavior. Zebrafish has emerged as an important animal model for studying courtship behavior. However, to the best of our knowledge, no research has been conducted on the automated recognition of zebrafish courtship-related social behavior. Therefore, this work builds a benchmark dataset of zebrafish courtship-related social behavior and proposes a zebrafish courtship-related social behavior automated recognition (ZCSBAR) framework. The ZCSBAR framework consists of three functional modules, including pose estimation, long-time identity tracking and social behavior recognition. The experimental results show that the ZCSBAR achieves high performance in zebrafish social behavior recognition, specifically the identity recognition index IDF1 reaches 0.902 and the average behavior recognition accuracy reaches 0.859. These findings highlight the potential of ZCSBAR for quantifying the courtship-related social behavior in the fields of animal behavior and reproduction.

title: MGPSyn: Molecular Graph Pretraining Enhanced Synergistic Drug Combination Prediction
authors: Xiaoyi Liang, Hongming Zhu, Xiaoli Zhu, Dongsheng Mao, Qin Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Identifying synergistic anticancer drug combinations is a key challenge due to the vast number of potential drug pairs and the high cost of experimental screening. Recent advances leverage deep learning and graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn molecular representations directly from drug structures, but the limited number of unique drugs in available datasets restricts the effectiveness of such models. In this paper, we propose a framework that addresses this issue through a DDI-enhanced Deep Graph InfoMax pretraining strategy. Our approach captures structural and relational drug features by jointly maximizing local–global mutual information and incorporating drug–drug interaction prediction. A multi-level interaction model with semantic attention further enhances feature fusion, leading to improved synergy prediction performance. We compared our method with five advanced methods on two public datasets. The results demonstrate that the proposed method exhibits superior generalization ability.

title: A Behavior-Aware Heterogeneous Graph Convolutional Neural Network for Multi-Behavior Recommendation
authors: Chen Yipeng
publish: 2025 22nd International Computer Conference on Wavelet Active Media Technology and Information Processing (ICCWAMTIP)
abstract: In modern recommendation systems, researchers are increasingly using various user interaction behaviors (such as clicking, adding to cart, and purchasing) to enhance the accuracy of predictions. Traditional methods typically establish separate bipartite graphs for each behavior and apply graph convolutional networks (GCNs) to learn the specific behavior embeddings of users and items. However, these methods isolate the behavioral context, ignore the correlations between users and item embeddings of different behavioral types during the information dissemination process, and are unable to capture the transformation patterns between user behaviors. To overcome these limitations, we propose a behavior-aware heterogeneous graph convolutional network (BHG) framework. BHG integrates multiple interaction types into a unified information dissemination module, explicitly modeling the complex correlations and high-order connectivity among different behaviors. This framework combines effective cross-behavior information dissemination and aggregation mechanisms to adaptively distinguish the contribution of each behavior to the final prediction. A large number of experiments on real datasets have shown that BHG significantly outperforms multiple baseline models in key metrics such as recall rate and NDCG. Ablation studies have confirmed the effectiveness of each core component.

title: Adaptive Pilot Configuration and Super-Resolution Channel Estimation for Optical OFDM Systems
authors: Panpan Fan, Minghua Cao, Chunfang Chen, Tiantian Zhang, Xinhui Shi, Yue Zhang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Infocomm Technology (ICAIT)
abstract: Optical orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OOFDM) is a widely adopted modulation technique in optical wireless communication (OWC) systems, owing to its high transmission capacity, spectral efficiency, and flexible subcarrier allocation. However, these advantages introduce challenges in channel estimation, such as fixed pilot patterns, excessive overhead, limited estimation accuracy, and elevated computational complexity. To address these challenges, we propose a novel channel estimation method that integrates a swarm intelligence optimization algorithm with deep learning. The proposed approach employs the Black-winged kite algorithm (BKA) for adaptive pilot configuration and introduces an online estimation model, SRODNet, which combines a super-resolution reconstruction network and a denoising network to enhance estimation accuracy. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method can dynamically adjust pilot placement according to varying channel conditions, effectively mitigate turbulence-induced fading, and significantly outperform existing benchmark algorithms in terms of estimation accuracy, interference resilience, and system robustness.

title: Stochastic Random Walk Approach for Efficient Individualistic Autonomous Exploration: An Investigative Study Using Turtlebot3 in Gazebo
authors: Blesson Mathews Luke, S Abraham Sampson
publish: 2025 International Conference on Robotics and Mechatronics (ICRM)
abstract: The field of autonomous robotic exploration, a very modern field of research, is constantly evolving, improving exploration efficiency while enhancing mapping capabilities. This work presents an exploration algorithm based on a stochastic random walk approach for autonomous mapping and localization of mobile robotic systems in unknown static environments. The new algorithm was tested using the Turtlebot3 platform in an existing Gazebo world simulation environment over multiple successive trial runs, each with increasing exploration times ranging from 2 minutes to 15 minutes. The algorithm primarily utilized LiDAR feedback for real-time mapping and obstacle identification during random navigation. The system was able to achieve an average histogram similarity of 99.82% and a mean absolute error of 0.16% while maintaining an average localization error of 2.49m over all the runs combined. The investigative study has therefore shown great promise for indoor autonomous exploration in static environments, while maintaining accuracy, efficiency and quality of mapping.

title: Exploring Factors Affecting Student Satisfaction in Asynchronous Learning: A Preliminary Investigation
authors: Priscilla Stephanie, Erwin Halim, Rafael Marcellino Yodhian, Benedict Hugo Christopher
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Information Technology, Information Systems and Electrical Engineering (ICITISEE)
abstract: Asynchronous learning is a popular method of online learning, and its flexibility has served learners well, challenges of which may influence satisfaction. While it was acknowledged that factors such as course design, student grouping and self-efficacy impact learning outcomes, empirical knowledge in this area is limited. The current study seeks to explore the factors determining student satisfaction in an aL environment, specifically on perceived usefulness, and course design, student-student interaction, self-efficacy, and engagement. The data were obtained in April 2025 by selecting respondents in Indonesia by purposive sampling, involving 50 respondents in the country of Indonesia through a Google Form survey under an asynchronous learning system. The samples are predominantly for students <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(96.2 \%)$</tex> whom largely also urban residence (e.g., Jakarta and Bekasi, Indonesia) as per the view of the actives learners in higher education perception. Data were processed through SmartPLS 4 using the partial least squares structural equation modelling (PLS-SEM) technique to evaluate measurement and structural models. Results suggest students are more satisfied with their experience when they perceive their asynchronous course as useful and are efficacious in their ability to complete the course, and have less satisfaction when they see the course design as structured or the delivery as closed. These perceptions provide a preliminary empirical foundation for educators and instructional designers to design and improve asynchronous learning strategies to meet student preference.

title: Indoor Localization in a Collaborative BLE-Based System Through Dynamic Path Loss Estimation via Location Aware Autonomous Mobile Robot
authors: Azin Moradbeikie, Rolando Azevedo, Cristiano Jesus, David Beserra, Sérgio Ivan Lopes
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Providing Artificial Intelligence as a Service (AIaaS) for the next generation of Industry, known as Industry 5.0, is committed to providing an accurate indoor localization system. Providing Indoor localization, particularly in dynamic industrial environments where operational efficiency relies on precise location information, is a challenging task. This paper presents a Collaborative Indoor Positioning System (CIPS) facilitated by a location-aware autonomous mobile robot equipped with Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) beacons to enhance indoor localization accuracy through dynamic path loss parameter estimation. The robot traverses the facility while periodically broadcasting its ID and real-time location to a central server. By correlating the robot’s ground-truth positions with Received Signal Strength Indicator (RSSI) measurements from fixed BLE receivers, the server continuously updates path loss parameters using a log-normal shadowing model and linear regression. Evaluation of the proposed system is conducted using a real testbed with a deployed application system in an office environment. Experimental results demonstrate a significant improvement in distance estimation accuracy, ranging between 19% and 32%, and a 20% reduction in location estimation error compared to conventional methods, highlighting the potential of the proposed CIPS approach for enhancing indoor localization in industrial settings.

title: Variable Step-Size Model Predictive Control for Heavy-Duty Trucks Path Tracking
authors: Binyi Liu, Xuemei Sun, Jinyong Shangguan, Zhilong Zhou, Dengbo Zhang, Jianhui Shi
publish: 2025 9th CAA International Conference on Vehicular Control and Intelligence (CVCI)
abstract: The long body and high mass pose a serious challenge to the motion control of heavy-duty trucks in high-speed condition. To address this concern, a variable step-size model predictive control (VSMPC) strategy is proposed for heavy-duty trucks path tracking in this paper. Firstly, a heavy-duty truck model is constructed by considering the effect of articulation angle, where the dynamics and kinematics of heavy-duty trucks are devised to guarantee the modeling accuracy. Secondly, a VSMPC method is proposed for heavy-duty trucks path tracking control in high-speed condition, where the zero-order hold and first-order hold discretization methods are employed to the first and second parts of the prediction horizon, respectively. Finally, to evaluate the control effectiveness of the proposed control method, a co-simulation platform based on Trucksim and Matlab/Simulink is developed. The simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method can effectively guarantee the path tracking effect and real-time performance of heavy-duty truck in high-speed condition. Compared to MPC, the maximum lateral offset and heading error of proposed method can be reduced by 18.18% and 4.8%, respectively.

title: Bayesian Transformer for Time Series Forecasting: Integrating Uncertainty Quantification with Attention Mechanisms for Enhanced Prediction Accuracy
authors: Cao Phi Phung, Thai Thi Thanh Nhan, Vo Thanh Van, Tran Quoc Hung, Nguyen Ngoc Phien, Duong Thi Thuy Van
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Computational Intelligence and Applications (ICCIA)
abstract: This paper introduces a novel Bayesian Transformer architecture for time series forecasting that integrates uncertainty quantification with attention mechanisms to enhance prediction accuracy and reliability. Traditional Transformer models, while effective at capturing long-range dependencies in sequential data, lack the ability to quantify prediction uncertainty, which is crucial for real-world applications involving risk assessment and decision-making. Our proposed Bayesian Transformer addresses this limitation by incorporating Monte Carlo Dropout and probabilistic output layers into the standard Transformer architecture, enabling the model to provide both point predictions and uncertainty estimates. We evaluate our approach on three diverse datasets: Electric Power Consumption, Weather Station Data, and IBM Stock Prices, representing different temporal patterns and forecasting challenges. Experimental results demonstrate that our Bayesian Transformer significantly outperforms conventional LSTM, CNN-LSTM, and standard Transformer models across all evaluation metrics. The model achieves RMSE improvements of 17.8–18.5%, MAPE reductions of 15–22%, and MAE enhancements of 20–25% while providing meaningful uncertainty bounds that enhance decision-making capabilities. Additionally, the uncertainty estimates show strong correlation with prediction errors, validating the model’s ability to quantify its own confidence levels effectively.

title: Vibration Control of Hypersonic Waverider Under Shock Wave Interference
authors: Jiachun Ling, Yuhui Wang, Wei Yu
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotics, Control and Automation Engineering (RCAE)
abstract: To investigate the vibration control of hypersonic waveriders subjected to shock wave interference, the structure of a hypersonic waverider is simplified as an axially moving cantilever beam. The external force load induced by shock wave interference is incorporated to establish the corresponding vibration model of the cantilever beam. Furthermore, considering the uncertainties in airflow density and damping coefficient, appropriate adaptive update laws are designed. Subsequently, based on a double-layer sliding surface structure, a specific generalized force control law is developed to regulate both the amplitude and vibration velocity of the cantilever beam. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed vibration model and control strategy is validated through simulation analysis.

title: Simulation and Optimization of the Table Water Production Process Using Industrial Automation Tools at “Gotitas De Vida”
authors: Aracelly Ingrid Santiago Salomon, Franklin Ricra Ricaldi, Paola Lisbeth Acevedo Delgado, Carlos Samuel Medina Jimenez
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotics, Control and Automation Engineering (RCAE)
abstract: In the table water production sector in Peru, many companies still rely on largely manual processes, which limits their productivity and hinders the incorporation of modern quality and efficiency standards. In this context, the company Gotitas de Vida faced significant challenges related to long processing times, manual intervention at critical stages, and a lack of traceability and control in production. In response to this problem, this research evaluated and optimised the table water production process by implementing an automated system at Gotitas de Vida, comprehensively addressing all stages from water collection and filtration to automatic washing and filling of bottles. To this end, state-of-the-art technological components such as sensors, PLCs, HMIs and automatic equipment were used. The methodology combined the diagnosis of bottlenecks, the selection and analysis of appropriate technologies, the modelling of the production process and financial evaluation using key economic indicators. The results were impressive: automation reduced the total production cycle time from 720 to 380 minutes, achieving a 52.78 % improvement in time efficiency and increasing monthly production from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{7, 0 0 0}$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 3, 2 6 3}$</tex> bottles. The automated system facilitated real-time monitoring and control, improving traceability, quality, and compliance with health regulations. Financially, the project achieved a NPV of S/ 3,637,889.06, an IRR of 1609.05 %, and a payback period of only 23 days, confirming its high profitability and low risk. Overall, the proposed comprehensive automation represents a significant contribution to the modernisation of the table water industry under the Industry 4.0 approach, demonstrating that technological integration is essential for optimising processes, increasing competitiveness and ensuring business sustainability in the sector.

title: Simulation Research on Dynamic UAV Real-Time Obstacle Avoidance Based on Interfered Fluid Dynamical System Algorithm
authors: Xiaoning Ma, Haoran Gong, Zhinan Liu, Yumeng Liang, Fanjun Meng, Yikai Zhang
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotics, Control and Automation Engineering (RCAE)
abstract: With the wide application of unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) in the military field, its obstacle avoidance ability in complex and dynamic environments has become a key research topic. Aiming at the continuous, dynamic and sudden characteristics of obstacles faced by UAV in the real environment, this paper studies and applies a dynamic obstacle avoidance method based on Interfered Fluid Dynamical System(IFDS). In this method, the UAV is regarded as a particle in the fluid field, and the obstacle interaction is abstracted as fluid field interference by constructing a fluid disturbance model, so as to realize efficient and real-time obstacle avoidance path planning. The Interfered Fluid Dynamical System Dynamic Obstacle Avoidance (IFDSDOA) method constructs a force field matrix by calculating three main forces, including attractive force, repulsive force and tangential force, to adjust the motion direction of the UAV, and introduces a recovery vector to make the UAV return to the original track after obstacle avoidance. The local scene simulation test verifies the effectiveness and reliability of the proposed method in dealing with the problem of dynamic obstacle avoidance. The UAV successfully avoids the obstacle and reaches the target position, and the average angle curvature (AAC) and maximum flight direction change (MFDC) in the process of obstacle avoidance meet the flight constraints. The IFDSDOA method has the advantages of high computational efficiency and smooth path generation, which provides a new way for real-time obstacle avoidance of UAV in dynamic environments, and is of great significance for improving the task execution efficiency of UAV in complex combat environments.

title: Blinding the Infrared Tracker: An Adversarial Attack Based on Heating-Expanding Perturbations
authors: Xingdi Fan, Wanli Dong, Jiahao Pu, Hanyang Chen, Dong Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Adversarial attacks manipulate deep learning models into generating erroneous predictions by introducing subtle yet carefully crafted perturbations to input data. Such attacks serve dual roles: revealing model vulnerabilities while enhancing robustness. Although adversarial attacks are well- explored in visual tracking, their efficacy in infrared single-object tracking remains limited. To bridge this gap, we propose a novel heating-expanding attack to deceive SiameseRPN-based infrared trackers. By exploiting the inherent thermal-texture discrepancy between visible and infrared imaging modalities, we introduce a novel heating-expanding loss function. This loss function drives the training of an adversarial perturbation generator that synthesizes imperceptible thermal perturbations. When strategically applied at the target-background boundaries, these perturbations trigger progressive bounding box expansion during tracking. The accumulated interference induces complete tracker failure via boundary drift. Benchmark evaluations on LSOTB-TIR and PTB-TIR demonstrate our method’s consistent precision reduction of 45.0% and 45.4% (surpassing SOTA by 7.8/10.2 pp). The approach sustains attack performance against other trackers, reducing norm precision by 12.6% for DaSiamRPN and 4.5% for TaMOs respectively without architecture-specific tuning, proving plug- and-play readiness for deployment.

title: Fourier-Based Continuous Sliding Mode Control: A Robust and Chattering-Free Framework
authors: Efraín Ibarra Jiménez
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotics, Control and Automation Engineering (RCAE)
abstract: This paper proposes Fourier-Based Continuous Sliding-Mode Control (FB-C-SMC), a new approach that replaces the discontinuous sign function in conventional slidingmode control (SMC) with a Fourier series reconstruction. The method eliminates chattering while retaining robustness, finite-time convergence, and disturbance rejection. Two variants are developed: (1) C-SMC-Fourier, a basic continuous controller where disturbance compensation begins after finite-time convergence to a boundary layer, and (2) C-ISMC-Fourier, an advanced version with integral action that achieves instantaneous disturbance estimation from the initial time. Both controllers are rigorously analyzed via Lyapunov theory, proving global stability and exact disturbance rejection. Simulations demonstrate chattering free operation, precise tracking, and superior transient performance of C-ISMC-Fourier in disturbance compensation. The framework is applicable to systems requiring smooth and robust control, such as precision robotics and aerospace systems.

title: Construction of an Immersive Evaluation System for Design Solutions based on VR/AR and Eye Tracking Technology
authors: Yi Fu, Yunfei Guo
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Mobile Networks and Wireless Communications (ICMNWC)
abstract: With the widespread adoption of immersive design solutions in virtual reality (VR) and augmented reality (AR), traditional immersive experience evaluation methods rely heavily on subjective questionnaires and lack real-time, quantitative user behavior data, making it difficult to accurately capture user attention distribution and interaction efficiency. To address this issue, this paper proposes an immersive design evaluation system based on VR/AR and high-precision eye tracking technology. Through three-dimensional scene modeling, gaze-prioritized interaction layout, and optimized viewpoint and movement logic, this system captures user behavior and correlates events in real time. The system integrates features such as eye movement data, gaze duration, heatmaps, pupil diameter changes, and gaze paths to generate a multidimensional immersion index to quantify the user's immersive experience. Experimental results show that, from an overall mean, the average gaze duration in AOI1 is 11.9 seconds, significantly higher than AOI2 (8.70 seconds) and AOI3 (5.64 seconds). This distribution indicates that participants exhibit a significant central visual concentration effect during task performance, with the primary focus of attention being placed on the key areas of the task.

title: MCTS-Refined CoT: High-Quality Fine-Tuning Data for LLM-Based Repository Issue Resolution
authors: Yibo Wang, Zhihao Peng, Ying Wang, Zhao Wei, Hai Yu, Zhiliang Zhu
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: LLMs demonstrate strong performance in automated software engineering, particularly for code generation and issue resolution. While proprietary models like GPT-4o achieve high benchmarks scores on SWE-bench, their API dependence, cost, and privacy concerns limit adoption. Open-source alternatives offer transparency but underperform in complex tasks, especially sub-100B parameter models. Although quality Chain-of-Thought (CoT) data can enhance reasoning, current methods face two critical flaws: (1) weak rejection sampling reduces data quality, and (2) inadequate step validation causes error accumulation. These limitations lead to flawed reasoning chains that impair LLMs’ ability to learn reliable issue resolution.The paper proposes MCTS-REFINE, an enhanced Monte Carlo Tree Search (MCTS)-based algorithm that dynamically validates and optimizes intermediate reasoning steps through a rigorous rejection sampling strategy, generating high-quality CoT data to improve LLM performance in issue resolution tasks. Key innovations include: (1) augmenting MCTS with a reflection mechanism that corrects errors via rejection sampling and refinement, (2) decomposing issue resolution into three subtasks—File Localization, Fault Localization, and Patch Generation—each with clear ground-truth criteria, and (3) enforcing a strict sampling protocol where intermediate outputs must exactly match verified developer patches, ensuring correctness across reasoning paths.Experiments on SWE-bench Lite and SWE-bench Verified demonstrate that LLMs fine-tuned with our CoT dataset achieve substantial improvements over baselines. Notably, Qwen2.5-72B-Instruct achieves 28.3%(Lite) and 35.0%(Verified) resolution rates, surpassing SOTA baseline SWE-Fixer-Qwen-72B with the same parameter scale, which only reached 24.7%(Lite) and 32.8%(Verified). Given precise issue locations as input, our fine-tuned Qwen2.5-72B-Instruct model achieves an impressive issue resolution rate of 43.8%(Verified), comparable to the performance of Deepseek-v3. We open-source our MCTS-REFINE framework, CoT dataset, and fine-tuned models to advance research in AI-driven software engineering.

title: Orlock: A Modular Agent for Natural Interaction in Indoor Navigation
authors: Gonçalo Carnaz, Esmeralda Faria, Paulo Menezes
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Providing effective indoor spatial guidance through natural language remains a key challenge in human-computer interaction. This paper presents Orlock, a virtual agent designed to support wayfinding and spatial orientation within a university building. To ensure a consistent baseline, building maps were shown to participants unfamiliar with the space. Following their interaction with Orlock, participants completed an 18-item questionnaire covering five key dimensions: clarity, usefulness, ease of interaction, overall satisfaction, and design preferences. Results from the 7-point Likert-Scale responses indicated generally high satisfaction, with a clear preference for multimodal feedback combining visual and verbal instructions. These findings highlight the importance of multimodal interaction in orientation systems and offer practical design insights for future development of intelligent spatial guidance agents.

title: Multi-Stage Testing for Open Source IoT Frameworks
authors: Ulrich Norbisrath, Bruno Rossi, Ruben Jubeh, Araz Heydarov
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: The Internet of Things (IoT) has rapidly evolved, integrating networked intelligence into a web of things, servers, and cloudlets. Although there are various tools and approaches for software testing, the broader field of IoT testing presents unique challenges due to the heterogeneity of devices, large-scale deployments, dynamic environments, and real-time needs. This paper presents our approach to developing a multi-stage testing framework for the IoTempower framework, addressing the challenges of testing a versatile and evolving open-source Internet-of-Things framework used extensively in educational settings and beyond. The framework incorporates compilation testing, integration testing, and system testing with a focus on regression testing. This multi-stage testing approach allows us to validate the framework’s functionality at various granularities, from the correct compilation of individual drivers to the seamless interaction of deployed hardware. This approach aims to proactively identify and prevent regressions, facilitating the integration of new features and enhancements without losing our scope of providing a real hands-on IoT experience in the classroom.

title: Parallel Lithium-Ion Battery Fault Diagnosis Based on HO-Optimized VMD and TCN
authors: Yunfei Yu, Zhongkai Zhou
publish: 2025 9th CAA International Conference on Vehicular Control and Intelligence (CVCI)
abstract: Rapid fault diagnosis in parallel battery systems is challenging due to non-measurable cell currents and minor voltage fluctuations. This paper proposes a method combining Variational Mode Decomposition (VMD) algorithm optimized by the Hippopotamus Optimization (HO) algorithm and a Temporal Convolutional Network (TCN). HO-VMD decomposes voltage signals to enhance weak fault features by reconstructing Intrinsic Mode Functions (IMFs) with significant entropy changes. A parallel equivalent circuit model simulates three connection faults, and the TCN model achieves 98.21% diagnosis accuracy, verifying its feasibility in practical scenarios.

title: Adaptive Weight-Based Predictive Energy Management Strategy for Plug-in Hybrid Electric Vehicles Considering Battery Life
authors: Xiao Zhang, Xiaohong Jiao, Yahui Zhang, Zhe Li
publish: 2025 9th CAA International Conference on Vehicular Control and Intelligence (CVCI)
abstract: An adaptive weight-based predictive energy management strategy (EMS) is proposed to reduce fuel costs and extend the battery life of plug-in hybrid electric vehicles (PHEVs). Firstly, based on the dynamic programming (DP) results under historical traffic data, a cascaded neural network is designed to predict the optimal state of charge (SOC) of the battery and vehicle speed. Then, for the multiobjective energy management problem that considers both battery life and fuel economy, the improved differential evolution (DE) algorithm is adopted to generate the Pareto front. Finally, the adaptive weight adjustment mechanism and the initial Pareto front values are introduced into the model predictive control (MPC) framework for online energy management, thus dynamically balancing the energy consumption and battery life of the PHEVs. The effectiveness and advantages of the proposed scheme are verified with other compared strategies through the joint simulation platform of MATLAB and GT-SUITE.

title: Dynamic Barycenter Bridging Network and Twin Support Vector Machine Framework for Communication Fault Diagnosis Systems
authors: Yichen Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Mobile Networks and Wireless Communications (ICMNWC)
abstract: In recent years, the increasing complexity of communication networks and the rising frequency of network faults have emphasized the need for intelligent and generalizable fault diagnosis systems. Traditional diagnostic approaches often struggle with domain shifts, heterogeneous data distributions, and limited labeled samples, resulting in reduced accuracy and unstable performance. Therefore, this research proposes Dynamic Barycenter Bridging Network integrated with Twin Support Vector Machine (DBBN-Twin SVM) for Communication network fault diagnosis. Initially, communication-network data is collected from the UNSWNB15 dataset which contains diverse traffic patterns and multiclass fault labels. Then, data preprocessing and noise reduction techniques are applied for ensuring consistency across heterogeneous sources. After that, DBBN is employed to extract discriminative, domain-aligned features by aligning marginal and conditional distributions through barycenter learning. Finally, Twin SVM performs efficient fault classification by constructing nonparallel hyperplanes with improved separability and reduced computational cost. The proposed DBBN-Twin SVM model achieved better results in terms of accuracy (99.78%), precision (99.61%), recall (99.69%) and F1score (99.69%) when compared with existing model.

title: Smart control of water-fertilizer integrated regulation system based on deep reinforcement learning
authors: Jiamei Liu, Fangle Chang, Longhua Ma, Lei Xie, Hongye Su
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Water-fertilizer integrated regulation system aims to to improve crop yield, nutrient use efficiency (NUE), and water use efficiency (WUE). This study develops an intelligent control system with a cloud server network to centralize data management and process. The system contains of the monitoring module, the intelligent cloud platform module, and the control terminal. In the monitoring module, the sensor network and phenotypic monitoring method were utilized to collect real-time crop and environment data. In the intelligent cloud platform module, a perception-computing-control integrated computing optimization framework was constructed to achieve the localization of control tasks by analyzing perceived data, training predictive control models, and optimizing deep reinforcement learning algorithms. The control terminal contains of task scheduling, equipment control, and data collection drive, as well as a reasonable deployment pipeline in the cloud. Our developed control model has increased crop productivity nearly 9% and achieved water resource savings nearly 15.6%. Multi-modal large models will be applied to adjust model parameters in different environments.

title: Interpreting the Digital Mirror: Relational and Emotional Meaning-Making in Interactive Art
authors: Franciszek Sobiech, Natalia Walczak, Filip Ignatowicz, Laurent Babout, Magdalena Wróbel-Lachowska
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: This paper investigates the interpretive processes within interactive art, focusing on post-participation interviews from an immersive installation featuring a mirror that displayed a previous participant instead of the viewer. The study, conducted through semi-structured interviews, explores how participants interpret and construct personal meaning from their engagement with the artwork. Thematic analysis revealed key areas of interest present thorough the participants’ responses. Additionally, participants found metaphorical discussions more insightful than titles in framing meaning. The findings are analyzed through a framework for the psychology of aesthetics, offering new insights into participant experience in interactive art.

title: Research on Ground Armored Target Detection Technology Based on FPGA + YOLO
authors: Song Chen, Xubin Zhang, Fangyuan Ma, Bin Dong, Yunli Kou, Jiamin Wang
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotics, Control and Automation Engineering (RCAE)
abstract: With its flexible maneuverability and wide field of vision, unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) have become an ideal platform for detecting ground armored targets.However, UAVs usually have low computing power and limited power consumption, which makes it difficult for traditional target detection platforms to meet the actual needs. This paper designs a ground armored target detection algorithm based on FPGA. Through the structure of parallel input and output, it is compatible with the computing of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3 \times 3$</tex> convolution and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1 \times 1$</tex> convolution. The sharing of computing resources was achieved by using the method of weight reuse, and the computing efficiency was improved. Tests were conducted based on the ZYNQ-7035 platform. By comparing the performance of the same detection task with that on the GPU and CPU platforms, the detection speed is only 38.8 % of that on the CPU. The ground armored target detection system designed in this paper has significant advantages in performance and can meet the requirement of low power consumption.

title: Single-Vehicle Trajectory Prediction: A Review and Experimental Embedded Assessment
authors: Oumaima Skalli, Sergio Rodriguez Florez, Abdelhafid El Ouardi, Stefano Masi
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Vehicular Technology
