title: Analysis of Calligraphic Works by Large Models in The AI ERA
authors: Zhao Yahe
publish: 2025 22nd International Computer Conference on Wavelet Active Media Technology and Information Processing (ICCWAMTIP)
abstract: Currently, considerable practical experience has been gained in leveraging technology for traditional art research. To maximize the application potential of large models, this study adopts a novel practical research lens and, for the first time, employs the Doubao-Seed-1.6 multimodal large model to comprehensively analyze 200 works from young and middle-aged calligraphy exhibitions. By comparing the model's analysis results with typical works of five calligraphic styles and integrating professional perspectives such as brushwork and character structure, we identify differences in AI’ s recognition capabilities across styles and their underlying causes. This research supplements critical empirical data for AI-era calligraphy analysis, demonstrates the practical value of large models as auxiliary research tools, and provides new impetus for the digital inheritance and interdisciplinary study of calligraphic culture, supporting the integration of traditional calligraphy with modern technology.

title: Optimization of optical parametric oscillator performance through active temporal pulse shaping
authors: Chen Li, Tao Li, Tianxiang Cheng, Jun Meng, Gaoyou Liu, Zhaojun Liu
abstract: Achieving simultaneously high conversion efficiency and excellent beam quality remains a central challenge in high energy optical parametric oscillators (OPOs). Here, we demon strate that active temporal pulse shaping of the pump provides an effective and independent control parameter for optimizing OPO performance. A high-power master-oscillator power-amplifier laser system at 1064 nm is constructed to generate programmable Gaussian and top-hat nanosecond pulses through active pre compensation based on the inverse Frantz–Nodvik model. Both pulses preserve a near-diffraction-limited spatial quality (M<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> < 1.2) at an average pump power of 15 W (300 Hz). Comparative experiments using a plane-parallel KTiOPO4-OPO reveal that Gaussian pumping achieves slightly higher peak efficiency (∼ 37%) but leads to a severe beam degradation (M<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> ≈ 9), whereas top-hat pumping attains a comparable efficiency (∼ 35%) with a markedly improved beam quality (M<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> ≈ 2.3). These results confirm that the temporal pulse shaping acts as an additional and independent degree of freedom—complementary to cavity design—for optimizing OPO performance. The demonstrated approach offers a straightforward and scalable method for other wavelength regimes and nonlinear systems.

title: Heterogeneous Cooperative Transmission for Free-Space Optical Networks
authors: Feiming Jin, Li Zhang, Zhili Yu
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Wireless Communications and Signal Processing (WCSP)
abstract: Cooperative transmission is a promising solution for Free-Space Optical (FSO) communication to combat the undesirable atmospheric effects by allowing FSO terminal nodes to relay for each other. Traditional cooperative transmission requires all of the links for signal combination to carry the same data, i.e., homogeneous cooperative transmission, which has been regarded as an essential principle in related works. However, the data homogeneity among different FSO links indicates the transmission redundancy which significantly restricts the link utilization. Aiming to break through such a limitation of transmission redundancy, we propose a heterogeneous cooperative transmission for FSO communication, in which the FSO links with different data can obtain performance gain from signal combination, while keeping the signals decomposable from each other. To the best of our knowledge, it is the first work focused on the cooperative transmission among the FSO links carrying different data. The results demonstrate that the proposed system structure can improve bit error rate performance by one order of magnitude over the homogeneous cooperative transmission, and it is more scalable to a wide range of turbulence strength.

title: Compression Algorithms for Computer Network Transmission in Virtual Reality Scenarios-Neural Network-Based Dynamic Rate Control
authors: Zhitao Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Mobile Networks and Wireless Communications (ICMNWC)
abstract: Facing the conflict between high bandwidth and dynamic environment in VR transmission, this paper aims to design a neural network based dynamic rate control (NN-DRC) method. Firstly, a dual-branch network is constructed to model spatial texture and temporal motion feature of VR content. Then, a multi-dimensional perception module is designed to observe network environment in dynamic environment in real time. Finally, an appropriate rate level is output by training rate decision network with content feature as input and network status as output. At last, a lookup table is designed to map the decision to encoder parameters to adjust compression strategy. Experimental results show that, for bursty congestion scenario, the method could utilize 85.2% bandwidth, meanwhile, the lag is greatly alleviated and PSNR could reach 35.8 dB when watching high-speed motion scene. This method could balance transmission efficiency and visual quality, and solve the problem of intelligent bitrate control in dynamic VR scene.

title: A Self-Improving Multi-Agent Framework for Dynamic Portfolio Management
authors: Wanjie Zhan, Chao Yu, Chengdong Xu, Xiawei Wu, Yuhe Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Agentic AI (ICA)
abstract: Portfolio management (PM) is a dynamic asset allocation process aimed at maximizing returns while controlling risks. Recently, LLM-based agents have shown significant application potentials in PM. However, existing approaches often lack a complete modeling of the whole PM process and rely on fixed rule-based methods, limiting their adaptability and effectiveness. To address these limitations, we propose SIMA-DPM, a self-improving multi-agent framework for dynamic PM. SIMA-DPM simulates the end-to-end PM workflow, including stock screening, portfolio construction and risk control, with specialized agents for each stage. Additionally, SIMA-DPM employs a self-improving dynamic stock selection mechanism to iteratively refine selection strategies, so as to adapt to changing market. Experiments on a stock pool of about 680 stocks show that, under controlled risk, SIMA-DPM significantly outperforms baselines.

title: Efficient Shuffled Sliding Window Decoding of SC-LDPC Codes
authors: Qin Du, Lisha Luo, Xuan He
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Wireless Communications and Signal Processing (WCSP)
abstract: Spatially coupled low-density parity-check (SCLDPC) codes provide excellent performance and low latency under sliding window decoding (SWD). To achieve a low-power and low-complexity SC-LDPC decoder, we propose a variant of SWD called size-<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\lambda$</tex> monotonic double-ended queue SWD (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\lambda$</tex> MDQSWD), where <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\lambda$</tex> refers to the storage complexity of the update at a check node (CN). Our <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\lambda$</tex> MDQ-SWD employs the shuffled schedule in SWD and uses the MDQ structure to implement the CN update. Moreover, it considers using only the minimum magnitude from target symbols for the CN update to avoid redundant computations. Simulation results show that, although under <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\lambda=2$</tex>, the proposed algorithm achieves comparable error correction performance to the state-of-the-art algorithms. Moreover, a detailed hardware implementation for the CN update is designed. Analysis using the 90 nm CMOS technology library shows that, compared to the state-of-the-art algorithms, the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\lambda$</tex> MDQ-SWD with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\lambda=2$</tex> reduces the area and increases the clock frequency of CN update by 63.7 % and 107.6 %, respectively.

title: Experimental Coexistence of Quantum Key Distribution and L-band Classical Communication over Hollow-core Fiber
authors: Weiwen Kong, Tianqi Dou, Yuheng Xie, Lei Zhang, Peng Li, Song Gao, Lipeng Feng, Nan Lu, Yongmei Sun, Jianjun Tang
abstract: We experimentally demonstrate the coexistence of L-band classical communications and QKD over 101.6 km hollow-core fiber, with a classical capacity of 13.6 Tbps and a secure key rate maintained above 8 kbps.

title: Matlab Programming Implementation and Application of PPT Criteria
authors: Fan Zhiyi
publish: 2025 22nd International Computer Conference on Wavelet Active Media Technology and Information Processing (ICCWAMTIP)
abstract: Quantum entanglement is an important form of quantum non-locality, and it is a very important physical resource in quantum computing, quantum cryptography and other applications. It can be said that quantum entanglement is the core of the whole quantum information technology. Therefore, determining whether a quantum state is entangled or not is the core of the whole problem. This thesis introduces some basic quantum entanglement criteria, including the Positive Partial Transpose Criterion (PPT Criterion), Computable Cross Norm Realignment Criterion (CCNR Criterion). This thesis focuses on the PPT criterion given by Peres and Horodecki, which is recognized as the strongest operable criterion at present and has quite strong judgment ability. This thesis elaborates the implementation process of PPT criteria and gives the specific process of PPT criteria MATLAB programming. In addition, the programmed PPT criterion is applied to the entanglement judgment of some quantum states, and the difference of the entanglement judgment ability between the PPT criterion and the CCNR criterion and their respective limitations are reflected in the entanglement judgment problem.

title: Accelerated Collaborative Indoor Localization with Spatial Graph Encoding
authors: Qingyang He, Ning Liu, Weina Jiang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Infocomm Technology (ICAIT)
abstract: Indoor localization remains a critical challenge in IoT-driven applications, particularly due to the limitations of infrastructure-dependent systems and the poor discriminability and noise sensitivity of single-device geomagnetic localization. While geomagnetic signals offer a cost-effective, infrastructure-free solution, they often require long sequences for accurate positioning, resulting in slow startup. To address these issues, we propose a robust and accelerated collaborative indoor localization framework that leverages multi-device geomagnetic sequences and Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) Received Signal Strength Indicator (RSSI) to enhance both accuracy and startup speed. Our method constructs a collaboration graph where geomagnetic features serve as node embeddings and BLE RSSI-based relative distances form edge weights. A spatial graph encoder integrates topological relationships via a multi-scale spatial pyramid pooling module, while a novel length-adaptive sequence encoder enables unified feature extraction for both short and long magnetic sequences-significantly accelerating initial localization. Evaluated across diverse indoor environments, our proposed method achieves average localization errors of 1.75 m across three trial sites when the sequence length is 200. Notably, it achieves 3.45 m in the biggest trial within about 1 second, demonstrating its effectiveness in fast-startup scenarios.

title: Comparative Evaluation of DLEC and DNFE for Community Detection in Dynamic Social Networks
authors: Kevin John Wesley Hutabarat, Muhammad Zuhri Catur Candra, Maya Nabila
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Data and Software Engineering (ICoDSE)
abstract: Community detection in dynamic social networks is a challenging task for understanding structural and temporal patterns of social groups. This study presents a comparative evaluation of two deep learning approaches, Deep Learning Evolutionary Clustering (DLEC) and Dynamic Network Feature Embedding (DNFE), which combine node representation learning with temporal regularization to detect communities in an unsupervised manner. These methods utilize both temporal and structural metrics across synthetic and real-world social networks. By integrating temporal smoothness as a key evaluative dimension, the analysis captures not only the structural coherence of communities, but also their progression over time. To assess this further, evaluation using modularity, temporal smoothness, and silhouette score shows that while both methods achieve high modularity, indicating clear topological community structures, the resulting embeddings do not always yield optimal structural clustering. This limitation is influenced by factors such as network sparsity, temporal fluctuations, parameter sensitivity, and inconsistencies between latent representations and actual community numbers. Despite these challenges, DLEC and DNFE demonstrate effectiveness in capturing dynamic community evolution and can be applied efficiently. Taken together, the results affirm the potential of deep learning-based representation methods for analyzing long-term community dynamics in real-world social networks.

title: A Hybrid Time Series and Deep Learning Analysis for Internet of Things Multi-Sensor
authors: Imam Tahyudin, Berlilana, Anton Satria Prabuwono, Bambang Pilu Hartato, Hasri Akbar Awal Rozaq, Ades Tikaningsih, Oktay Yıldız
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Information Technology, Information Systems and Electrical Engineering (ICITISEE)
abstract: This study introduces the Amikom Purwokerto Hand Sanitizer, an Internet of Things (IoT)-based multifunctional device designed to promote a clean-living culture and healthy habits through regular, monitored, and convenient use of hand sanitizer. The device integrates seven main features: automatic hand sanitizer dispensing, automatic body temperature detection, a touchless oximeter, user counting, residual liquid detection, a hybrid power management system, and a data logger connected to a data analytics server. These features not only provide hygiene support but also enable continuous monitoring and recording of vital health indicators. To further utilize the collected data, this study applies a hybrid forecasting approach that combines the Seasonal Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average (SARIMA) model with the Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) deep learning method, optimized through hyperparameter tuning. This combination is designed to capture both linear and non-linear patterns in time series data, with a specific focus on body temperature and blood oxygen saturation levels. Experimental results demonstrate that the Amikom Purwokerto Hand Sanitizer operates effectively across all integrated features, while the hybrid SARIMA-LSTM approach achieves superior predictive accuracy. The model yields a Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) of 0.38 for body temperature and 1.01 for oxygen saturation, resulting in an average RMSE of 0.70, outperforming conventional forecasting techniques.

title: Deep Learning-Based Adaptive Signal Modulation using CNN-ADN for Wireless Networks
authors: S. Julia Faith, K. Manju, T M Aruna, R Varsha, Muquitha Almas
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Mobile Networks and Wireless Communications (ICMNWC)
abstract: In modern times, Deep Neural Networks (DNNs) become essential technology in advance wireless communication systems for automatic signal recognition and intelligent spectrum management. The existing Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) demonstrated robust capability in automatic modulation classification allowing wireless devices for identifying types of modulation. However, it struggled with fixed classification tasks and lack adaptive modulation ability. Additionally, it depended solely on CNN which restricted systems capability for capturing temporal dependencies. To overcome these challenges, Convolutional Neural Network with Adaptive Decision Network (CNN-ADN) framework is proposed that combines design which integrates CNN-based feature learning with adaptive decision layer able to perform both classification and modulation selection. The adaptive mechanism employs SNR-conditioned probability weighting mechanism, enabling model to adjust its decisions according to current quality of channel. Initially, data is collected from synthetic intermediate-frequency (IF) dataset and preprocessed using sampling, quantization, normalization and label encoding to ensure consistent quality of input data. Further, CNN is used to extract spatial features and adaptive decision layer dynamically adjusts modulation scheme based on characteristics of signal and conditions of channel. This combination allows system not only to classify but also select adaptively most effective modulation in different SNR levels. Finally, proposed CNN-ADN framework ensures superior scalability, flexibility and robustness for intelligent wireless communication systems. Therefore, proposed CNN-ADN obtains greater results in cross entropy (0.086), Sum of Squared Error (SSE) (0.141), Mean Absolute Error (MAE) (0.244) compared to existing CNN approach.

title: Memory and Inference Based Meta Reinforcement Learning for Dynamic Flexible Job Shop Scheduling Problem
authors: Lincong Wu, Xiaoxia Li, Xin Lu, Hangyu Pu, Yanguo Jing
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: The Dynamic Flexible Job Shop Scheduling Problem (DFJSP) poses a significant challenge in the field of intelligent manufacturing, due to inherent complexity and dynamic disruptions including machine breakdowns, new job arrivals, and other unforeseen events. Although many reinforcement learning approaches offer greater flexibility, they often suffer from low sample efficiency and struggle to adapt to unforeseen events. To overcome these limitations, we propose Vari-PPO, a meta-reinforcement learning method built upon implicit task inference. The approach leverages variational inference to model latent task characteristics and integrates Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) for dynamic scheduling. Experimental findings demonstrate that the proposed approach exhibits stronger adaptability and generalization than traditional reinforcement learning approaches and pre-trained models across tasks of varying scales and benchmark datasets. It effectively manages fluctuations in makespan under dynamic events, highlighting its robustness and practical value in diverse scheduling environments.

title:
Tackling Neuroenchantment: A multiperspective approach
                    <sup>*</sup>
authors: Guilherme Wood, Eugen Dolezal, Lisa M. Berger, Petra Zandonella, Thomas Gremsl, Elisabeth Staudegger
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: We propose a unified framework to chart the different reasons for neurotechnology use and aid ethical decision making. Neurotechnologies are methods to record, analyze and manipulate brain activity. They are essential tools of diagnostics and rehabilitation but are more and more finding their way into the field of enhancement, which entails several challenges and risks, especially since the borders between rehabilitation and enhancement are not clear. Neuroenchantment, the persuasive power of neurotechnologies, can propagate wrong beliefs and hamper critical thinking, leading to inappropriate risk judgement. We propose a framework of two axes named "discovery" and "recovery" to depict specific technologies and allow comparisons among technologies at individual, social, and cultural levels. Recovery describes rehabilitative reasons of usage and discovery describes enhancement-related reasons, whereby both concepts are associated with one another. The overlap of both can result in a gray zone of ethical decision making. This danger can be better identified with our framework, offering implications for medical, therapeutic, and regulatory efforts.

title: Driving Pattern Analysis with Hybrid CNN-LSTM and Random Forest Models
authors: K. Dora Babu, T. Aditya Sai Srinivas, M. Ramu, K. Swathi, C. Maddilety, A. David Donald
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Intelligent Signal Processing and Effective Communication Technologies (INSPECT)
abstract: Forecasting the behavior of nearby vehicles is vital for enhancing the safety in self-driving systems. Still, the real-world traffic complexities pose significant complications to accurate maneuver anticipation. This study introduces a model that combines Random Forest (RF), CNN, and LSTM within a wide-based framework. RF extracts rule-based interactions between vehicles, CNN captures spatial features, and LSTM identifies temporal patterns in driving trajectories. Integrating these components improves prediction accuracy and improves interpretability. Simulations validate the effectiveness and practicality of the proposed model for predicting driving behavior.

title: IOT Based Smart Water Meter and Electricity Meter for Domestic Utilities
authors: Lijo Jacob Varghese, V Devanath, V Kishore, R Poornima
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Intelligent Signal Processing and Effective Communication Technologies (INSPECT)
abstract: in the evolving world, automation plays an important role to make the life easier. Enhancing the pre-existing models to reduce the time and efforts of human or an organization. The automation is leading to betterment of the world but there are some fields where automation is not yet opted. The project “IOT Based Smart water and Electricity meter for Domestic Utilities” is to leverage automation in local monitoring of domestic utilities especially for government using Embedded System and Cloud Technology. A masterslave configured project using ESP32 as master controller to gather data in local and building a server to store the data in cloud. The project utilizes a distributed working model to enhance the capability in future. The slave unit includes two ESP32 measures the water and electric supply in home with the help of sensors module. Once the values are taken. The slave communicates to Master ESP32. The Master ESP32 enabled with Wi-Fi interacts with the server to save values in the databases. As the project is enabled with Master-Slave configuration it improves the upgradability. The main moto of the project is to reduce the need of manual operation for measuring the Water and Electricity usage values in homes, more visibility on usage using statistical charts and tables through online, reducing the cost and enabling more upgradability.

title: Absolute Valued Message Passing-Based PAPR Reduction in OTFS Under Fading Channel Conditions
authors: Illuru Rajasekhar, M. Monisha
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Computing Technologies (ICACT)
abstract: Orthogonal Time-Frequency Space (OTFS) modulation presents significant advantages over conventional modulations such as OFDM, particularly for high mobility communication environments, by functioning optimally within doubly dispersive channels. OTFS, however, carries an important drawback common to multicarrier modulations the high Peak-to-Average Power Ratio (PAPR) which contributes to diminished power amplifier efficiency and increased distortions caused by nonlinearity. This work proposes an Absolute Valued Message Passing (AVMP) detector, tailored for OTFS systems under fading channel environments. It is tested using Bit Error Rate (BER) and Complementary Cumulative Distribution Function (CCDF) of PAPR metrics through sophisticated MATLAB simulation under different Signal-to-Noise Ratios (SNR) and different orders of modulations (128-QAM, 256QAM, 512-QAM). Results explicitly show that the AVMP detector consistently has better BER and significantly less PAPR than conventional techniques MP-OTFS, ZF-OTFS, conventional OTFS, and OFDM. These achievements confirm the competence of AVMP to upgrade OTFS modulation, significantly boosting communication reliability and efficiency for stochastic wireless environments.

title: Federated Contrastive Learning from Unlabeled Streaming Data in AI-RAN
authors: Haoran Wen, Zhiheng Guo, Chenyuan Feng, Xiang Chen, Tony Q. S. Quek, Xijun Wang
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Wireless Communications and Signal Processing (WCSP)
abstract: The integration of AI into Radio Access Networks (RANs) is fundamental to the emerging 6 G vision. This paper introduces FAI-RAN, a framework designed for efficient Federated Learning (FL) on unlabeled streaming data under the stringent resource constraints of the network edge. Built upon the Open RAN (O-RAN) architecture, FAI-RAN embeds intelligence by deploying a Bootstrap Your Own Latent (BYOL)-based local model in each RAN, coordinated by a global encoder within the near-real-time RAN Intelligent Controller (near-RT RIC). At the core of our framework is a novel Memory Buffer Update (MBU) mechanism designed to combat catastrophic forgetting when learning from unlabeled data streams. To manage limited local memory, the MBU employs an importance-scoring system to intelligently curate the buffer, selectively preserving critical historical knowledge for model updates. This process enables effective adaptation and robust learning, even under strict memory constraints. Extensive experiments demonstrate that FAI-RAN significantly outperforms state-of-the-art baselines across both independent and identically distributed (IID) and non-IID data distributions. These results validate the effectiveness and practical deployability of our framework for next-generation edge intelligence applications.

title: Joint TDOA-FDOA-based Passive Sensing for LEO Satellites
authors: Mingjie Fu, Hangguan Shan, Yue Zhang, Ning Wang, Zhiguo Shi
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Wireless Communications and Signal Processing (WCSP)
abstract: In low earth orbit (LEO) satellite localization, the high velocity of satellites and complex environmental factors often prevent traditional methods from achieving the required realtime positioning accuracy, particularly under high measurement noise or poor geometric configurations of ground stations. To address these issues, we propose an adaptive ellipsoidal grid search algorithm built upon a projected two-step weighted least squares framework. By embedding the satellite's prior geometric constraints into the positioning model and combining the joint observation equations of time difference of arrival (TDOA) and frequency difference of arrival (FDOA), a phased optimization framework is proposed: In the first stage, weighted least squares are used to estimate the position and velocity preliminarily; in the second stage, the calculated values are constrained to the ellipsoid through projection operations to optimize the radial accuracy; in the third stage, an adaptive ellipsoidal grid search strategy is designed to optimize the tangential accuracy. The simulation results show that the estimation errors of the proposed algorithm approach the constrained Cramér-Rao lower bound under medium noise levels and pathological geometric layouts.

title: Integrating Affective Computing and Music Recommendation for Emotional Regulation in Young Adults
authors: Bgcs Ranasinghe, Adai Gunesekera, Mkp Madushanka
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Information Technology Trends (ITT)
abstract: Emotion based music recommendation systems have attracted considerable interest due to their ability to enhance personalization by aligning music selections with users’ emotional states. Unlike traditional recommendation methods relying primarily on listening history or collaborative filtering, these systems leverage affective computing techniques to offer real time, user centered suggestions. This paper presents a pilot study outlining the systematic review process, the analysis derived from it, and how these insights shaped the development and progression of this research project, focusing on their applicability for young users. Electroencephalography (EEG) is highlighted as a reliable and non intrusive method for detecting emotional states such as happiness, and sadness, which guide the selection of appropriate music. A multilayered system architecture was developed, encompassing presentation, data acquisition, processing and analysis, application, data management, and service layers to ensure smooth integration of emotion detection with recommendation engines and incorporate user feedback for continuous enhancement. Initial results demonstrate an accuracy of 85% in emotional state classification through EEG, illustrating the potential of this approach to improve music personalization. Be in par with recommendations of users’ moods, the system supports emotional well being and engagement, specifically in academic and highly stressful settings common among young undergraduates. This research advances understanding in affective computing by demonstrating the promising role of EEG based systems for young community centered music recommendation. Future work will aim to improve detection accuracy, diversify data sources, and explore cost effective EEG solutions to broaden accessibility and practical application.

title: A Capability Matching Evaluation Algorithm for Civil Aircraft EMA Verification via Multi-Control-Strategy Simulation
authors: Lu Jiang, Li Li, Sipeng Song, Weixin Han
publish: 2025 9th International Workshop on Control Engineering and Advanced Algorithms (IWCEAA)
abstract: To meet the high reliability requirements of component level verification in the full process development of civil aviation aircraft electromechanical actuators (EMA), a verification method based on multi control strategy simulation and capability matching evaluation for permanent magnet synchronous motor (PMSM) is proposed. Firstly, a unified PMSM simulation platform was constructed, which implemented five control strategies including model reference adaptive control (MRAC), direct torque control (DTC), sliding mode control (SMC), field weakening control (FWC), and digital redundancy reconstruction. Through four sets of experiments including dynamic response, load disturbance resistance, high-speed operation, and fault-tolerant control, the system obtained performance data of each strategy in different dimensions. This study proposes a capability matching evaluation algorithm, which solves the strategy optimization problem in multiple scenarios by constructing strategy capability vectors and task requirement vectors, introducing qualification screening and matching degree calculation. The results clearly define the applicable boundaries of each strategy: for instance, MRAC is suited for agile maneuvering, DTC for stable cruising, while FWC and digital redundancy reconstruction are essential for high-speed and fault-tolerant operations, respectively. This study provides data-driven decision-making basis for the selection and validation of EMA controllers.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning Based Global-Local Collaborative Trajectory Planning Algorithm
authors: Peiquan Rao, Ang Li
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Wireless Communications and Signal Processing (WCSP)
abstract: Trajectory planning, as a key technology for autonomous robot navigation, is widely used in industrial automation, warehousing and logistics. However, existing algorithms only conduct global planning in advance. When facing unforeseen obstacles, the static path becomes invalid, leading to inefficient detours in local avoidance. This paper construct an autonomous policy space through deep reinforcement learning, break through the static environment assumption of the traditional <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{A}^{*}$</tex> algorithm, and conduct multi-objective collaborative optimization to form a global re-planning decision-making ability to deal with huge unknown obstacles, significantly improving path smoothness and environmental dynamic adaptability. The constructed neural network simultaneously optimize the parameters of the local obstacle avoidance algorithm. We also employ maximum-speed constraints in obstacle-free zones and automatically switch to obstacle-avoidance priority mode when obstacle density surpasses a threshold. Experimental results show this method enhances path smoothness around large obstacles and shortens path length.

title: The Cooperation Between Large Language Models Provides Teaching Guidance for Students
authors: Han Yan, Lei Niu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Agentic AI (ICA)
abstract: In recent years, large language models (LLMs) have shown potential in education by assessing text quality for teaching assistance. However, limitations like knowledge illusions, insufficient domain expertise, and single feedback patterns hinder LLM-based agents’ ability to provide highquality, personalized tutoring. To mitigate these issues, this paper proposes a framework for student guidance via cooperation between LLM-based agents, which consisting of three modules: the task decomposition module, the task implementation module, and the teacher-aided interaction module. The task decomposition module decomposes student questions into sub-tasks; the task implementation module executes sub-tasks step-by-step; the teacher-aided interaction module intervenes only when LLM solutions are controversial. The contribution of this paper lies in providing a new approach for cooperation among LLMs, which can offer better educational guidance to students and is expected to enhance the reliability of LLMs in the field of education.

title: Bi-level Coordinated Optimization of Multiple Flexibility Resources under High Renewable Penetration
authors: Chenxi Wu, Jian Chen, Shunnan Liu, Kai Li, Yeyan Xu, Zhilan Tao
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Energy Engineering and Power Systems (EEPS)
abstract: This paper proposes a two-level optimization model for the coordinated planning of multiple flexibility resources. The upper level minimizes investment cost by determining resource types and capacities, while the lower level evaluates operational flexibility through typical-day scheduling and flexibility insufficiency probability. An iterative algorithm based on minimum cost increment ratio is used for solution. Case studies demonstrate the model's effectiveness in improving flexibility, reducing cost, and enhancing renewable energy integration.

title: Research on Locomotive Adhesion Control Based on Model-Free Adaptive Sliding Mode
authors: Buyun Ding, Xiaojuan Wei, Ningzhou Li
publish: 2025 9th International Workshop on Control Engineering and Advanced Algorithms (IWCEAA)
abstract: The generation of tractive effort in electric locomotives relies on the effective transmission of the motor's traction torque through the wheel-rail adhesion. In view of the inherent strong nonlinearity, large inertia, and hysteresis characteristics of traction operating conditions, research into optimized adhesion control methods is crucial. To this end, this paper proposes a Model-Free Adaptive Sliding Mode Controller (MFASMC), which incorporates an Improved Partial Form Dynamic Linearization (PFDL) method and integrates a Sliding Mode Controller (SMC). Intended to enhancing the system's dynamic response performance and anti-interference capability. Finally, simulation comparisons were conducted with a standalone SMC controller and an MFA control system. The simulation results demonstrate that the MFASMC exhibits stronger adaptability, faster response speed, and higher robustness when dealing with complex rail surface mutations.

title: Binary Waveform Design for Spectrally-Compatible Cognitive MIMO Radar DOA Estimation
authors: Kai Zhong, Jinfeng Hu, Dongxu An, Huan Wan, Yiran Zhang, Xin Tai, Yongfeng Zuo, Ye Yuan, Cunhua Pan, Kah Chan Teh, Xianxiang Yu, Huiyong Li, Guolong Cui
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cognitive Communications and Networking
abstract: Unimodular waveform design is a key technology in cognitive Multiple Input Multiple Output (MIMO) radar systems. Existing research mainly includes two categories: unimodular continuous/binary waveform design for detection, and unimodular continuous waveform design for Direction of Arrival (DOA) estimation without spectral constraints. Different from existing methods, our focus lies in investigating unimodular binary waveform design for DOA estimation within spectrally crowded environments. This problem is formulated as minimizing the mean square error (MSE) for DOA estimation, subject to the constraints of binary waveform and multiple spectral constraints. Due to the spectral constraint and nonconvex nature of the binary waveform constraint, the problem is NP-hard and challenging to solve directly. Fortunately, we observe that the problem can be decomposed into multiple more tractable subproblems by introducing auxiliary variables. Leveraging this characteristic, we propose an efficient Problem Decomposition-based Sequential Optimization (PDSO) method to tackle this problem. The method introduces two auxiliary variables to decompose the problem into two subproblems: one of which can be solved in closed-form, while the other is efficiently addressed by the Binary Alternating Directions Method of Multipliers (B-ADMM) algorithm. Compared to the existing methods, the proposed approach demonstrates superior performance in terms of computational cost, DOA resolution, and suppression of spectral interference.

title: AI Data-Driven Framework for Optimal Electrical Machine Design in Aerospace Application
authors: Amit Ranjan Roy, R. M. Ram Kumar, Gaurang Vakil, Gaurav Kumar, Muhammad Raza Khowja, Liya Tom, Kuldeep Singh, Chris Gerada, Arvind Choubey
abstract: Nowadays, a permanent magnet synchronous motor (PMSM) has emerged as a potential alternative for aerospace actuator applications. The PMSM is a high-power-to-weight-ratio electrical machine and can provide reliable operation within the required thermal limits. An electrical machine designer applies multiphysics optimization techniques to optimize the parameters of an electrical machine. The optimization process is combined with electromagnetic and thermal finite element analysis (FEA) to generate feasible machine designs. FEA is computationally expensive and time-consuming, which makes it difficult to analyze over varied geometrical parameters and increases the likelihood of selecting a suboptimal electrical machine design. This work introduces the application of AI in machine design & selection of optimal machine dimensions, which reduces the requirement of FEA for an increased number of variations in geometric parameters. Three AI models have been developed for this purpose. The first AI model has been developed to predict the output parameter based on nine types of geometric input parameters. The output parameters are treated as input for the second AI model to predict whether this configuration is feasible or non-feasible. The third AI data-driven model uses clustering of the output parameters of feasible machines to identify the most suitable machine according to user requirements. The application of AI achieved an improvement of 31% in torque density of PMSM. The selected optimal electrical machine has been prototyped and validated through experimental tests. Multiple design is also possible to obtain using the same framework. To showcase additional design through the framework, two additional machine design having different geometries for increase in torque & decrease in total weight and decrease in torque ripple, & magnet weight have been presented.

title: Artificial Bee Colony Optimization Algorithm based Unified Power Quality Conditioner in Grid Connected Renewable Energy Systems to Improve Power Quality
authors: Rajeev Varma Rajakakarlapudi, Divya Mishra, Balasubramani. R, Praful V. Nandankar, G. Satish, L Natrayan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Mobile Networks and Wireless Communications (ICMNWC)
abstract: A Power Quality Conditioner is a long transmission-line platform electrical device that combines two converters to balance power quality at the output of the electrical power distribution system. In previous machine learning approaches, UPQC based long transmission lines have limitations, including high harmonic distortion, sudden power loss, and peak voltage rise, sag, and swell. To solve this problem, a novel Artificial Bee Reptile Mixed Optimization (ABRMO) is proposed for the UPQC application, combining a Integrating a bidirectionally linked solar power source and dynamic behaviors for active optimizations transmission structure. The Reptile continuously regulates the DC link voltage between the series and shunt, which operates the switching mechanism with a proper Pulse Width Modulation (PWM) controller to minimize distortion and compensate for voltage sag/swell conditions using an alternative power source, PV, applied via a Voltage Source Converter (VSC). This output reduces sag and swells under different conditions with switch-state control, and the THD is 4.34%. The optimization algorithm improves stability, rapid convergence, and optimal power-quality performance compared to the previous optimization based UPQC.

title: AI-Empowered Smart Contract Vulnerability Detection for Decentralized Blockchain Systems
authors: Chi Jiang, Caixing Shao, Xiaoyan Huang, Ming Tao, Yin Zhang, Yan Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering
abstract: Blockchain technology is evolving toward next-generation blockchain systems, where AI-empowered optimization plays a key role in enhancing scalability, efficiency, and security. However, in the context of smart contract vulnerability detection, however, most vulnerabilities originate from a few critical code fragments, resulting in a severe signal-to-noise imbalance. This imbalance introduces representation noise and redundant information in complex contract code, obscuring the true vulnerability semantics and hindering the effectiveness of AI-based models such as graph neural networks (GNNs). To address this challenge, we propose CoTA, a feature augmentation framework that leverages two easily obtainable signals: code-cohort feature and task-shared feature. Code-cohort features capture the observation that contracts with similar structural/behavioral patterns often implement similar business functions, and thus share vulnerability priors (e.g., higher reentrancy risk in fund-transfer-heavy cohorts). Task-shared feature, on the other hand, learned via a multi-task setup that jointly trains coarse contract-level multi-label classification and fine-grained function-level labeling to distill shared representations. Extensive experiments on real-world dataset show that CoTA achieves consistent improvements in detection accuracy, offering a practical and effective solution for smart contract security analysis.

title: Vehicle-RNA: Reverse Engineering with Dynamic Time Warping for Automotive Protocol
authors: Sangmin Park, Huy Kang Kim, Sanghoon Jeon
abstract: As modern vehicles evolve and offer advanced functions managed by numerous ECUs, the potential for security threats increases due to the presence of expanded threat surfaces. Although research into Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) and automotive fuzzing has progressed, such systems often rely on publicly available CAN data because proprietary CAN DBCs limit access to essential information. This hampers the ability to counter sophisticated attacks, highlighting the need for precise mapping of CAN IDs and payloads. CAN reverse engineering is crucial but is challenged by time-consuming manual analysis and incomplete PID information. To overcome these limitations, we propose the Vehicle-RNA framework, which employs machine learning and dynamic time warping to automate the identification of CAN ID functions. The Vehicle-RNA framework is particularly effective in scenarios with limited data, achieving an F1-score of 0.9388 and accurately identifying 10 CAN IDs previously unanalyzed by OpenDBC, which represents a significant advancement in automotive cybersecurity.

title: A Convergent Generalized Krylov Subspace Method for Compressed Sensing MRI Reconstruction with Gradient-Driven Denoisers_supp1-3655489.pdf
authors: Tao Hong
abstract: Model-based reconstruction plays a key role in compressed sensing (CS) MRI, as it incorporates effective image regularizers to improve the quality of reconstruction. The Plug-and-Play and Regularization-by-Denoising frameworks leverage advanced denoisers (e.g., convolutional neural network (CNN)-based denoisers) and have demonstrated strong empirical performance. However, their theoretical guarantees remain limited, as practical CNNs often violate key assumptions. In contrast, gradient-driven denoisers achieve competitive performance, and the required assumptions for theoretical analysis are easily satisfied. However, solving the associated optimization problem remains computationally demanding. To address this challenge, we propose a generalized Krylov subspace method (GKSM) to solve the optimization problem efficiently. Moreover, we also establish rigorous convergence guarantees for GKSM in nonconvex settings. Numerical experiments on CS MRI reconstruction with spiral and radial acquisitions validate both the computational efficiency of GKSM and the accuracy of the theoretical predictions. The proposed optimization method is applicable to any linear inverse problem.

title: CLMN: Concept based Language Models via Neural Symbolic Reasoning
authors: Yibo Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Deep learning’s remarkable performance in natural language processing (NLP) faces critical interpretability challenges, particularly in high-stakes domains like healthcare and finance where model transparency is essential. While concept bottleneck models (CBMs) have enhanced interpretability in computer vision by linking predictions to human-understandable concepts, their adaptation to NLP remains understudied with persistent limitations. Existing approaches either enforce rigid binary concept activations that degrade textual representation quality or obscure semantic interpretability through latent concept embeddings, while failing to capture dynamic concept interactions crucial for understanding linguistic nuances like negation or contextual modification. This paper proposes the Concept Language Model Network (CLMN), a novel neural-symbolic framework that reconciles performance and interpretability through continuous concept embeddings enhanced by fuzzy logic-based reasoning. CLMN addresses the information loss in traditional CBMs by projecting concepts into an interpretable embedding space while preserving human-readable semantics, and introduces adaptive concept interaction modeling through learnable neural-symbolic rules that explicitly represent how concepts influence each other and final pre-dictions. By supplementing original text features with concept-aware representations and enabling automatic derivation of interpretable logic rules, our framework achieves superior performance on multiple NLP benchmarks while providing transparent explanations. Extensive experiments across various pre-trained language models and datasets demonstrate that CLMN outperforms existing concept-based methods in both accuracy and explanation quality, establishing a new paradigm for developing high-performance yet interpretable NLP systems through synergistic integration of neural representations and symbolic reasoning in a unified concept space.

title: Multi-Feature Domain Fusion Extraction of Buildings from Airborne L-Band CSAR Images Using Sub-Aperture Image Scattering Characteristics
authors: Xiaodong Yan, Yongping Song, Leping Chen, Daoxiang An
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: As one of the critical targets in urban areas, the detection and extraction of buildings in synthetic aperture radar (SAR) images are of paramount importance. Distinguishing artificial structures, such as buildings, from natural backgrounds through feature extraction serves as the foundation for subsequent interpretation. Unlike conventional linear synthetic aperture radar (LSAR), Circular synthetic aperture radar (CSAR) enables multi-aspect observation and can acquire target scattering information from various aspects, which facilitates the extraction of ground targets from the CSAR image. Low-frequency SAR systems (e.g., L-band, P-band) present greater challenges for building extraction due to their longer wavelengths and lower resolution. Consequently, low-frequency SAR is predominantly employed for concealed target imaging and detection, with limited applications in man-made feature extraction. To address these limitations, this paper proposes a novel multi-feature domain fusion-based method for building extraction in low-frequency CSAR images. Specifically, the method exploits two distinct characteristics of buildings in CSAR sub-aperture sequences: strong scattering and anisotropic scattering. For strong scattering, a spatial-frequency matrix decomposition-based strong scattering points extraction (SFMD-SSPE) method is proposed, which integrates frequency-domain and spatial-domain information to identify high-intensity scattering pixels across sub-apertures. For anisotropic scattering, a low-rank anisotropic scattering points extraction (LASPE) method is designed, leveraging the statistical properties of the aspect-domain to isolate anisotropic scattering points. Experimental validation on airborne L-band measured data demonstrates that the proposed method achieves superior performance compared to existing CSAR feature extraction approaches. The fusion of multi-domain features effectively enhances the accuracy and robustness of building extraction.

title: TripletAudit: Context-Aware Sensitive Content Detection for Reimbursement
authors: Gege Qi, Wenjing Chang, Yue Wang, Jianjun Yu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Sensitive content detection in financial reimbursement documents is fundamental to corporate compliance management. Traditional keyword-based approaches suffer from high false-positive rates due to their inability to capture contextual semantics. In this paper, we propose TripletAudit, a context-aware framework for sensitive content detection that leverages triplet learning, incorporating a hierarchical architecture combining BERT for semantic embedding, Bi-Lstm for sequential modeling, and multi-head attention for context understanding. Our triplet learning mechanism effectively distinguishes between sensitive and non-sensitive contexts through anchor-positive-negative samples. Experiments on real-world reimbursement datasets demonstrate that TripletAudit achieves state-of-the-art performance with 94.03% accuracy and 93.24% F1-score, significantly outperforming baseline methods in financial compliance scenarios.

title: Personalized Tasks Recommendation for Multi-Disciplinary Learning
authors: Longji Zhang, Jinhua Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Agentic AI (ICA)
abstract: This paper studies personalized task recommendation in a novel and practical context, where a learner completes learning tasks from multiple disciplines concurrently over a learning period with varying academic emotions. The aim is to maximize the average learning performance in all disciplines while meeting their requirement for performance increment. To this end, this paper outlines a mixed integer linear program (MILP) to optimize tasks recommended for each discipline in each time slot/interval within a given learning period. In addition, to deal with uncontrollable and causal learning emotions of a learner, this paper also proposes a model predictive control (MPC)-based approach, which determines task recommendations based on learning emotions predicted by a Gaussian mixture model (GMM).

title: A Unified Two-Stage Framework for Human-Aligned Information Extraction Using Large Language Models
authors: Zhiheng Ning, Wenlin Jiang, Han Lu, Xiaojun Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: The information extraction (IE) task, aims to transform unstructured text into structured knowledge. How-ever, due to challenges in human needs alignment, large language models (LLMs) often struggle with in IE tasks. This paper proposes a unified two-stage framework to enhance LLMs in IE tasks. First, we introduce a structured schema representation using JSON-LD (JSON for Linked Data) to eliminate ambiguity and enhance model robustness. Second, we design a two-stage learning method: supervised fine-tuning (SFT) for schema understanding, followed by direct preference optimization (DPO), using an automatic negative sampling strategy to align the output with human preferences. Experiments on 19 datasets for general and domain-specific IE tasks show state-of-the-art (SoTA) performance in both zero-shot and supervised settings. Our method achieves a relative improvement of 6.7% and 19.6% in the IE ability for unseen schemas, and maintains robustness in fine-grained entity recognition, outperforming existing baselines. The results highlight the effectiveness of structured schema representation and preference alignment in bridging the gap between LLMs and complex IE requirements.

title: SynBEV: A Height-Depth Synergy Framework for Infrastructure-Centric Camera 3D Object Detection
authors: Wenjie Ji, Jinkun Xu, Chunlin Li, Jie Hu, Ke Xiao
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Wireless Communications and Signal Processing (WCSP)
abstract: Infrastructure-centric camera-based 3D object detection systems have played a crucial role in advancing autonomous driving technologies. However, two major challenges remain that hinder their practical deployment: (1) limited detection accuracy for small-scale targets (e.g., pedestrians and cyclists) and occluded objects, and (2) degraded fusion performance caused by inherent geometric inconsistencies between depthbased and height-based representations in complex environments. To overcome these limitations, we propose the SynBEV framework, which introduces two key innovations. First, an attentionenhanced, camera-aware hybrid lifting module (attCHL) dynamically calibrates monocular features using camera parameter guidance, significantly improving detection performance for small objects. Second, a hierarchical height-depth fusion mechanism (HD-Fuser) is introduced to adaptively resolve feature conflicts, ensuring robust and coherent feature integration. Experimental results demonstrate that our method achieves state-of-the-art performance on the DAIR-V2X-I benchmark, validating the effectiveness of SynBEV for object detection.

title: Optical Format Conversion from QPSK to OOK/PAM4 Channels Enabled by Polarization-assisted Phase-sensitive Amplifier
authors: Yuxuan Dong, Yanxia Tan, Jiabin Cui, Guo-Wei Lu, Yuefeng Ji, Ninghua Zhu, Huashun Wen
abstract: An optical format conversion scheme between Quadrature Phase-Shift Keying(QPSK) and On-Off Keying(OOK)/Four-level Pulse Amplitude Modulation(PAM-4) signals is proposed in this paper. This scheme is mainly enabled by polarization-assisted non-degenerated phase-sensitive amplifier(PSA) based vector moving, which separates the signal and the generated idler into two distinct polarization states. The constellation diagrams, eye diagrams and Bit Error Rate (BER) curves of the proposed system are displayed to illustrate the system’s performance. When the input Optical Signal-to-Noise Rate(OSNR) is 20 dB, the converted OOK signal achieves a BER of 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-3</sup> at a receiver OSNR of 14.46dB, while the converted PAM4 signal reaches the same BER at 16.32dB.

title: A Multi-Modal Semantic Fusion for UAV Detection Under Intense Illumination Background
authors: Haonan Chen, Yuben Qu, Guangliang Pan, Guangyu Wu, Minxue Fang, Jiahuan Ji, Qihui Wu
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Wireless Communications and Signal Processing (WCSP)
abstract: With the widespread deployment of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), the need for effective safety monitoring has become increasingly critical. Under intense illumination, the traditional UAV detection methods relying on a single visual modality are highly prone to problems such as image overexposure and texture degradation. These issues substantially undermine the detection accuracy and robustness of the system. To address the challenge of UAV detection under intense illumination, we propose a Radar-Visible-Infrared Semantic fusion for UAV detection Net (RVISUNet), which integrates multimodal features at the semantic level. Specifically, the framework first converts radar-derived track information into two-dimensional Gaussian heatmaps and extracts semantic cues from radar data; this process guides the visible and infrared imaging modalities to focus on potential target regions. Furthermore, semantic information from the three modalities is fused to enable more efficient and accurate detection. To validate the proposed method, a physical platform was constructed based on an integrated perception system (incorporating radar, infrared, and visible light sensors), and a UAV dataset was collected under representative intense illumination scenarios. Experimental comparisons with mainstream visual detection methods show that RVISUNet achieves a 4.1% improvement in AP@0.5 compared to the baseline model.

title: A Multi-objective Evolutionary Algorithm for Combined Heat and Power Environmental Economic Dispatch
authors: Gui Xu, Qun Niu, Min Zheng
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Computational Intelligence and Applications (ICCIA)
abstract: As a significant research topic in the field of power system operation, the Environmental Economic Dispatch (EED) problem for power systems with co-generations has attracted substantial interests. Unlike the conventional economic load dispatch problem, the objective function for the EED problem includes not only fuel costs but also emission costs, making it a multi-objective optimization problem. For such a multi-objective optimization problem with complex constraints, conventional optimization algorithms are often slow to solve. The intelligent optimization algorithms emerging in recent years have shown the potential in dealing with such problems. In this article, a multi-objective covariance matrix adaptation evolution strategy (CMAES) algorithm NSA-CMAES is proposed. It is based on the single-objective CMA-ES algorithm, but the NSGA-II framework is introduced to combine external files and cross-strategy. The NSA-CMAES algorithm is tested on the EED problem for a power system with seven units including renewable energy. Compared with the popular multi-objective algorithms and reference’s algorithm, the proposed algorithm is shown to have superior performance.

title:
EEG-Driven Detection of Motion Mismatch in Upper-Limb Movements
                    <sup>*</sup>
authors: Ibrahim Koukash, Satoshi Nishikawa, Kazuo Kiguchi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: In recent years, research and development of human-assist robots equipped with brain-computer interfaces (BCIs) have accelerated due to the increasing number of stroke cases worldwide, which are a major contributor to permanent disabilities and loss of independence. BCIs can be an effective neurorehabilitation tool, as they assist the impaired sensorimotor loop by providing compensatory somatosensory feedback during motor attempts. The human-assist robot must support the user’s movements based on their intended actions. However, determining whether the robot’s assist motion is as intended by the user in real time remains challenging. This paper proposes a multi-stage method that utilizes time-frequency and statistical analyses for electroencephalography (EEG) signals to detect whether the arm movements are as intended. Furthermore, it employs a binary classifier with threshold optimization—guided by the highest classification accuracy— to determine the most effective threshold for distinguishing between intentional and unintentional movements. The effectiveness of the proposed method was evaluated through experiments involving multiple arm movements that combine both simple and complex tasks. A disturbance mechanism device was built and employed during these experiments to generate the sense of motion mismatch by applying disturbance forces. The experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method in detecting motion mismatch and distinguishing between intentional and unintentional movements. The proposed method is applicable to human-assist robots to assess whether the robot’s assist movement matches the user’s intended motion.

title: YOLOv5-Based Pedestrian Fall Detection Technology for Smart Elderly Care and Public Safety
authors: Ouyang Di
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th International Conference on Power, Intelligent Computing and Systems (ICPICS)
abstract: With the accelerating global aging process and growing urban environmental complexity, pedestrian fall incidents have become more frequent, highlighting the need for efficient fall detection technology. This study proposes an YOLOv5-based method to address the limitations of traditional approaches, such as poor real-time performance and low accuracy in complex scenarios. The proposed method optimizes the network architecture, integrates an attention mechanism, and refines multi-scale feature fusion to enhance detection robustness. Experimental results show that the improved model achieves an accuracy of 94.1 %, recall of 99 %, F1-score of 95 %, and mAP of 95.6 % on the test set, outperforming traditional methods (e.g., HOG+SVM) and earlier YOLO versions. Notably, it maintains a lightweight design with 7.5M parameters and 15.8 GFLOPs computation, enabling real-time deployment on edge devices. The key contributions include constructing a diverse dataset through rigorous annotation, enhancing YOLOv5 for complex scenes, and verifying its practical efficiency in elderly care and public safety. This technology paves the way for integration with smart systems to broaden fall-detection applications.

title: Low Voltage Universal Bi-quad Filter using MIMO DDTA for Biomedical Application
authors: Chandra Shankar, Ritesh Kumar Jaiswal, Yatheesh K. C
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Intelligent Signal Processing and Effective Communication Technologies (INSPECT)
abstract: A flexible low-voltage mixed-mode filter using a multiple input/output differential difference transconductance amplifier (MIMODDTA) is introduced. Multiple-input capability for the filter is provided by an MI GD MOST technique, retaining one differential pair to ensure reduced power consumption. In one topology, it accommodates five fundamental filtering functions-lowpass (LP), high-pass (HP), band-pass (BP), bandreject(BR), and all-pass (AP)-through four operating modes: voltage (VM), current (CM), trans-admittance (TAM), and trans impedance (TIM), allowing for a total twenty filtering functionsBecause the CM filter has a high output impedance and the VM filter has a low output/high input impedance, so fulfil the requirement of buffer circuits. Further, the inherent frequency of all filtering responses is also electronically adjustable using a control current. The filter can be used in many low-frequency applications such as biomedical and sensor related that require very low supply voltage and power.

title: YOLOv8-GCSA-WL: An Algorithm for Keypoint Detection and Localization in X-ray Images of Pig Carcass Hind Legs
authors: Mou Jinzhuo, Tian Chenghua, Zhang Hao, Jia Pei, Zhao Yixun, Zhao Hongjian
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Sensing, Diagnostics, Prognostics, and Control
abstract: In the automated pig slaughtering industry, to address the urgent need for precise robotic segmentation of pig carcass hind legs, this paper proposes an improved keypoint detection and localization algorithm, YOLOv8-GCSA-WL. To overcome the insufficient accuracy of traditional vision algorithms in complex industrial environments—impaired by factors such as blood stains and water vapor occlusion—this study innovatively utilizes X-ray images as the data source. To enhance the model's global perception and multi-scale representation of key features against complex backgrounds, a Global Channel-Space Attention (GCSA) module is designed and introduced. By capturing global long-range dependencies and local fine-grained spatial information in parallel, the GCSA module significantly improves the model's performance and balance. Furthermore, considering the high-precision requirements of industrial segmentation tasks, the keypoint localization loss function was replaced with Wing Loss, which effectively improves coordinate prediction accuracy due to its high sensitivity to small-range errors. Extensive experiments conducted on a self-constructed X-ray dataset of pig carcass hind legs validate the superior performance of the YOLOv8-GCSA-WL model. Its keypoint detection metric, P<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">mAP50-95</inf> reached 0.961, significantly outperforming the baseline model, while also maintaining a high performance of 0.923 in the object detection task, thereby achieving a better balance between accuracy and efficiency. This paper confirms the high precision and robustness of the proposed algorithm in real-world industrial scenarios, providing a valuable reference for the development of automated and intelligent meat segmentation production lines.

title: Long-Distance ISAC Design for OFDM Systems with Insufficient CP
authors: Jun Tang, Cunhua Pan, Hong Ren
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Wireless Communications and Signal Processing (WCSP)
abstract: In orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDM)-based integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) systems, when the channel impulse response (CIR) or the echo delays exceed the cyclic prefix (CP) length, the received signal will suffer from the inter-symbol interference (ISI) and the inter-carrier interference (ICI), thereby leading to performance bottleneck. To address this issue, this paper proposes an ISAC scheme based on interference alignment (IA) theory for scenarios with insufficient CP. Specifically, at the transmitter, we employ precoding to ensure that the ISI and the desired signals span the disjoint subspaces. At the receiver, we correspondingly propose a compressed sensing (CS)-based time domain channel estimation method by leveraging the sparse characteristics of the channel, followed by the symbol equalization based on the minimum mean square error (MMSE) criterion. The proposed scheme achieves interference suppression at the cost of less degrees of freedom (DoFs) loss. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves higher sensing detection probability and lower communication bit error rate (BER) than existing approaches.

title: PerturbGen: A Population Based Perturbation Method for Processor Test Generation
authors: Jingkai Wang, Renzhi Chen, Lei Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: The increasing complexity of processor design demands higher requirements for simulation-based verification, particularly in test case generation. Existing random test generators often struggle to thoroughly validate the deep processor states or fail to provide sufficient coverage diversity. In this paper, we propose PerturbGen, an evolutionary algorithm-inspired population-based perturbation test generation method, designed to enhance traditional random test generators. Per-turbGen introduces crossover and mutation operators from evolutionary algorithm, applying perturbations at both the population and member levels to generate high-quality tests. Our approach also includes a coverage-guided feedback loop for iteratively filtering members to guide the exploration of uncovered areas in the processor. We evaluated PerturbGen on an open-source RISC-V processor and compared it with two widely-used random test generators. Our method achieves relative improvements of 3.56%, 5.70%, and 14.01% in three key coverage metrics, respectively, proving the superiority of PerturbGen. Our code is open-sourced at the anonymous link: https://anonymous.4open.science/r/PerturbGen-2B07.

title: QoE-Based Intent Dependency Using Multi-Agent PPO in Autonomous Aerial Vehicles
authors: Rui Yuan, Huajun Cui, Zanhao Wang, Jinghuan Liu, Yinqiu Liu, Yunzhe Jiang
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Wireless Communications and Signal Processing (WCSP)
abstract: Owing to the symbiotic interdependence in Autonomous Aerial Vehicles (AAV), the intent-parsing accuracy and policy efficiency of each participant are reciprocally amplified by the others, rendering ultra-reliable intent prediction and low latency action optimization mission-critical. While many solutions can model intent dependencies, they confront severe challenges in high-dimensional action sequence generation and prohibitive on-board computation overhead. We present an intent-driven framework for autonomous network optimization, comprising prediction and decision components. Specifically, for prediction, we propose hyper-dimensional transformer (HDT), which employs a hyper-dimensional embedding layer to project inputs into hyper-dimensional space, leveraging hyperdimensional vector computation to replace complex matrix and attention operations. For decision-making, we introduce Joint action based Multi-Agent Proximal Policy Optimization (JA-MAPPO). Building upon MAPPO, it uses two parameterindependent networks to sample actions separately and cascades the user-intent network into the trajectory network, preserving action dependencies. We validate on a real IoT action dataset with authentic communication data; experiments demonstrate that HDT and JA-MAPPO deliver exceptional performance.

title: Detection of Eye Diseases using Transfer Learning based AI models using Retina Images
authors: C. Ahalya, Mohebbanaaz, M Jyothirmai
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Intelligent Signal Processing and Effective Communication Technologies (INSPECT)
abstract: The timely diagnosis of ocular diseases is critical in preventing-irreversible vision impairment and blindness. In this research, we proposed a AI-based classification model for the automated detection of four eye conditions-Normal, Cataract, Glaucoma, and Diabetic Retinopathy-using retinal fundus images. The proposed method utilizes transfer learning to adapt pre-trained convolutional neural network (CNN) architectures, including ResNet50, VGG16 and EfficientNet, for effective feature extraction and classification. Retinal images undergo standardized preprocessing steps such as resizing, normalization, and augmentation to enhance model generalization. The system is trained and validated on publicly available datasets, achieving high performance across multiple evaluation metrics. Experimental results demonstrate the efficacy of transfer learning in achieving reliable multi-class classification with limited labeled medical data. This approach presents a scalable and resource-efficient solution for clinical screening and decision support in ophthalmology.

title: Epidemic Informed Co-Evolution of Nodes and Edges with Graph Neural Networks for Source Detection
authors: Ruixiao Wang, Lanlan Yu, Xinfu Yang, Quan-Hui Liu, Tao Zhou, Jiancheng Lv
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Accurate identification of the epidemic source is crucial for controlling the spread of infectious disease. During the spread of an epidemic, transmission occurs through the edges, which represent the contact relationship between individuals. Source detection, as a reverse problem, should be significantly benefited by leveraging the epidemic state of edges, as it entails both the direction of transmission and the likelihood of disease spreading through the edges. Although Graph Neural Network (GNN)-based methods have been developed for source detection, their performance is limited due to overlooking the epidemic state of edges. Here, we propose a novel GNN-based model, Adaptive Node and Edge Co-evolution Source Detection graph neural network (ANEC-SD), which utilizes the epidemic state of edges and optimizes the node representations individually to enhance prediction performance. In specific, the ANEC-SD consists of two innovative components, where the Co-evolution of Node and Edge Representations Layer is designed to refine the message aggregation mechanism for effectively characterizing the heterogeneous impact from a node to its neighbors by leveraging the epidemic state of edges. While the Propagation Controller determines the optimal number of propagation layers for each node according to node centrality within the infected subgraph, thereby mitigating the issue of over-smoothing. Experiments on six real-world networks demonstrate that our model significantly outperforms existing methods, achieving a 30% improvement on four out of six networks. Further analysis highlights the pivotal role of epidemic state of edges in message passing.

title: Composite Signal Fiber-longitudinal Power Profile Estimation Scheme Used in Digital Subcarrier Multiplexing Systems
authors: Runzhe Fan, Xulong Yan, Fan Zhang, Xian Zhou
abstract: A composite signal fiber-longitudinal power profile estimation scheme is proposed for digital subcarrier multiplexing (DSCM) systems. For the 4×30GBaud DSCM system, localization mean absolute error (MAE) improved from 7 km to below 1 km, while anomaly estimation MAE improved from 0.8 dB to below 0.15 dB.

title: The Evolution Analysis of Opinion Dynamics under Asynchronous Update Strategy in Cooperation Competition Networks
authors: Haozhe Zhang, Xiao Zhong, Hong-Xiang Hu
publish: 2025 2nd International Symposium on AI and Cybersecurity (ISAICS)
abstract: This paper examines the evolution of opinions within a structurally unbalanced cooperation-competition network utilizing asynchronous update strategies, involving multiple Friedkin-Johnsen (F-J) individuals. The framework under investigation is characterized by a hierarchical tree-like structure with isolated clusters at the same levels. The asynchronous update strategy implies that only one individual updates its opinion at each time step, while all other individuals maintain their current opinions. Methodologically, this research begins with a specific individual in the network and defines its korder eccentric neighborhood. It subsequently refines the network into hierarchical layers to analyze dynamic interactions of opinions on a layer-by-layer basis. Sufficient conditions for opinion convergence are established. The findings indicate that if the network comprises fully stubborn, partially stubborn, and non-stubborn individuals, then ultimately, all the opinions will converge. Numerical simulations are conducted to validate these theoretical results.

title: Waveguide-Integrated Graphene-Colloidal-Quantum-Dots-Graphene heterostructure Photodetector with High sensitivity
authors: Hengtai Xiang, Jing Liu, Laiwen Yu, Yuanrong Li, Liang Gao, Jingshu Guo, Jiang Tang, Daoxin Dai
abstract: A graphene–colloidal quantum dot–graphene heterojunction waveguide photodetector is demonstrated, achieving a high responsivity of 37.9 A/W, a low dark current of 1.7 nA, and a noise-equivalent power of 0.01 pW/Hz<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1/2</sup>.

title: Multiplexed Bessel-Gaussian Vortex Beam Chaotic Communication in Obstructed Turbulent Links
authors: Jinyun Cao, Ning Jiang, Feng Wen, Mingliang Deng, Anran Li, Kun Qiu
abstract: A free-space optical (FSO) communication system based on chaotic encryption and multiplexed Bessel-Gaussian vortex beams (BGVB) is proposed. This enables high-fidelity transmission at 16 Gbit/s aggregate capacity with enhanced security and robustness.

title: Combinatorial Reinforcement Learning for Competitive Pricing-Based Resource Trading in Integrated Satellite-Terrestrial 6G Networks
authors: Ahmed Tageldin, Mohamed Basher Omer, Peng Chen
publish: 2025 22nd International Computer Conference on Wavelet Active Media Technology and Information Processing (ICCWAMTIP)
abstract: The integration of Integrated Satellite-Terrestrial Networks (ISTNs) with network slicing creates complex, competitive resource trading markets for 6G. Nevertheless, conventional multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) algorithms encounter challenges in this context. Their efficacy is constrained by the market's inherent asymmetry, particularly the difficulty in modeling the diverse roles of buyers and sellers, and the intricate combinatorial action space users encounter when selecting both a provider and a service level. To overcome these limitations, we propose the Combinatorial Client-Master Multi-Agent Dueling Double DQN (CCM-MAD3QN), a novel framework designed for such market dynamics. Our approach models users as Master agents, leveraging a state-of-the-art Dueling Double DQN (D3QN) critic to make efficient combinatorial purchasing decisions, while MVNOs act as Client agents that propose prices. This structure explicitly models the buyer-seller interaction and enables more stable, accurate decision-making by mitigating Q-value overestimation bias. Simulation results demonstrate that our CCMMAD3QN framework significantly outperforms strong MARL baselines, achieving higher overall social welfare and user utility.
