title: A Fault Detection Method for Autonomous Underwater Vehicles via Physical Errors and Prediction Networks
authors: Tao Xie, Yang Li, Ying Li, Jin Ke, Yiyang Chen, Hongtian Chen
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotics, Control and Automation Engineering (RCAE)
abstract: Real-time fault diagnosis of autonomous underwater vehicles (AUVs) is crucial for ensuring overall vehicle safety. The thruster, as a critical component, operates in harsh environments and is prone to failures. This paper proposes a physical error estimation network to address the thruster fault diagnosis problem. Specifically, sensor data from the thruster are first collected and used to establish corresponding fault mechanism models. An estimation network is then utilized to construct a predictive model for physical data, generating online residual data. Finally, a residual fault detector to determine whether the thruster has malfunctioned. Experiments conducted on AUVs demonstrate the proposed PIEN can rapidly generate excellent fault diagnosis model and outperforms manually designed models in diagnostic performance.

title: A Systematic Comparison of Loss Functions and Training Strategies for Fine-Grained Vehicle Classification
authors: Wanqing Yan, Xiaoru Song
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotics, Control and Automation Engineering (RCAE)
abstract: In recent years, fine-grained vehicle classification has emerged as a focal research topic in computer vision. To investigate how loss functions and training strategies influence classification performance, this study systematically compares the behavior of ArcFace Loss, CosFace Loss, Cross-Entropy Loss, and Focal Loss on fine-grained vehicle recognition tasks. Experimental results demonstrate that Cross-Entropy Loss and Focal Loss typically achieve higher classification accuracy-especially when an appropriate learning-rate schedule is employed-whereas the more sophisticated margin-based losses, ArcFace Loss and CosFace Loss, do not exhibit a clear performance advantage. The comparative findings presented in this paper offer valuable empirical guidance for selecting loss functions and tuning training parameters in fine-grained vehicle classification applications.

title: Neural Cointegration With Relaxed Integration Orders and Stationarity Guarantees for Nonstationary Rotating Machinery Monitoring_supp1-3654364.pdf
authors: Yujie Wei
abstract: Rotating machinery often operates under time-varying conditions. This can result in nonstationary behavior that violates the stationarity assumption underlying many fault monitoring methods. Cointegration analysis can address nonstationarity but assumes that all monitored variables are linearly related and integrated of order one. To overcome these limitations, this study reformulates the cointegration model in a functional-coefficient form. The coefficients therein are parameterized using neural networks to capture nonlinear relationships and accommodate variables with arbitrary integration orders. An iterative Bayesian inference algorithm is developed to estimate model parameters, with a stationarity constraint imposed on the cointegration error during estimation. This constraint mitigates overfitting to noise and enforces a consistent cointegration structure across varying noise levels. A heuristic fault isolation strategy is further introduced to eliminate the need for manual regularization. The effectiveness of the proposed method is validated through numerical simulations and two real-world cases involving large-scale rotating machinery.

title: Optimized Cyber-Physical Systems: Combining IGA, PLM, and Dynamic Pricing for Efficient Lifecycle Management
authors: Mohan Reddy Sareddy, M Thanjaivadivel
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Intelligent Signal Processing and Effective Communication Technologies (INSPECT)
abstract: Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) enable automation and smart operations through their role as a key bridge between the physical and digital worlds. Product Lifecycle Management (PLM), Intelligent Genetic Algorithms (IGA), CPS, and dynamic pricing strategies are all integrated in this proposed integrated optimization framework of this study.By utilizing real-time analytics and evolutionary algorithms, the framework improves market flexibility, lifecycle integration, and industrial resource utilization. PLM offers cross-phase information continuity, dynamic pricing adapts to evolving market demands, and CPS-based simulation supports optimal scheduling. Experimental findings indicate that our framework attains 94% accuracy and 95% recall, which surpasses MAS, MBSE, and FEA techniques. This quantitative proof verifies its adaptability and applicability in next-generation industrial optimization.

title: E-Commerce Data Analysis and Visualization Using Python: A Case Study of Amazon and Flipkart
authors: Hemachandrika S, Venkata Naga Chetan Kumar Pulipati, Anusha Koneti, Shaik Mahammad Irfan, Muralidhar Kurni, Ramesh Krishnamaneni
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Computing Technologies (ICACT)
abstract: The exponential growth of e-commerce has resulted in massive transactional and behavioral datasets, demanding robust analytical methods for actionable insights. This paper introduces a Python-based framework for e-commerce data analysis that integrates Pandas and NumPy for data manipulation and Matplotlib for visualization. We analyze customer behavior, sales dynamics, and market segmentation using descriptive statistics and apply machine learning models for sales forecasting and inventory optimization. Our experiments reveal significant patterns that enhance marketing effectiveness, operational efficiency, and customer satisfaction. The results underscore Python's value as a practical and scalable solution for data-driven strategy in online retail. The proposed framework is replicable by practitioners and contributes to advancing analytics capabilities in e-commerce environments.

title: Transformer-Based Authorship Attribution: Fine-Tuning BERT and S-BERT for High-Accuracy Stylometric Analysis
authors: Arvind Kumar Chaudhary, Sai Bhuvana Kurada, Atharva Mangeshkumar Agrawal, Ashmita Chakraborty, Bhavesh Arjan Dhirwani, Priyank Agarwal, Yash Shindey
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Computing Technologies (ICACT)
abstract: Authorship attribution the task of determining the author of a text has witnessed significant advancements with the emergence of transformer-based models in Natural Language Processing (NLP). This study investigates the use of Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers (BERT) and its sentence-level extension, Sentence-BERT (S-BERT), for high-precision author-ship identification. By leveraging contextual embeddings in conjunction with clustering and classification strategies, a robust framework is developed to detect subtle stylistic patterns indicative of authorial identity. The system is trained and evaluated on a diverse corpus drawn from the Gutenberg dataset and enriched with contemporary texts collected from platforms such as Twitter and Stack Overflow. The proposed methodology achieves a peak classification accuracy of 90% and an F1 score of 0.84, substantially outperforming traditional machine learning techniques. Additionally, t-SNE visualization and K-means clustering are utilized to analyze and enhance the interpretability of the embedding space. These findings highlight the efficacy of transformer-based sentence embeddings in capturing complex linguistic cues for authorship attribution tasks.

title: On the Fundamentals of Quantum Electronics: Schrödinger and Dirac Equations
authors: Xiaomin Ren
abstract: The fundamentals of quantum mechanics, surely also of quantum electronics, have been found of some imperfections. Based on the relevant remedy regarding de Broglie relationship of wave-particle duality, both Schrödinger equation and Dirac equation are comprehensively modified.

title: Low-latency FPGA Design of Attribute-based Encryption Accelerator over BLS12-381 Curve
authors: Anawin Opasatian, Momoko Fukuda, Makoto Ikeda
abstract: Attribute-Based Encryption (ABE) [1–3] integrates access control directly into the encryption and decryption processes, making it highly suitable for applications such as file encryption systems, as illustrated in Fig. 1. Despite its advantages, ABE suffers from high computational overhead. To the best of our knowledge, a dedicated ABE accelerator has not yet been realized, primarily due to the complexity of supporting various functions associated with elliptic curve cryptography. When implemented over the BLS12-381 curve, these functions must operate on the prime field (G1), the quadratic extension field (G2), and the twelfth-degree extension field (GT). The core functions necessary for ABE execution include elliptic curve scalar multiplication (G1_MUL, G2_MUL), hashing to the curve (G1_HASH), exponentiation (GT_EXP), and pairing (PAIR).

title: Forecasting of Home and Public Charging Station for Electric Vehicle Based on Dual Stage Monte Carlo Simulation Case Study in Lampung Province, Indonesia
authors: C B Erizon Sihotang, Arwindra Rizqiawan, Fathin Saifur Rahman, Rizky Mochamad
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on High Voltage Engineering and Power Systems (ICHVEPS)
abstract: The acceleration of the transition to clean and sustainable energy has driven increased adoption of electric vehicles as the future of transportation. The development of charging infrastructure is a vital strategic initiative, and the main challenge in this development is how to effectively predict the number of home charging installations in Lampung Province and project the need for public electric vehicle charging stations (PEVCS). This paper presents a framework for estimating charging infrastructure needs using the dual-stage Monte Carlo simulation. First, this methodology estimates the number of electric vehicles by calculating the number of installed home charging units, as this reflects the electric vehicle population owned by residents in Lampung Province. Then, the second Monte Carlo simulation is used to calculate the growth of the adjustment factor for the number of transactions and transaction duration per PEVCS within 1 week, which serves as the basis for determining the projected PEVCS needs. This calculation is influenced by the number of transactions per PEVCS and the average remaining capacity of 20 kV distribution transformers per year. The projected number of installed home charging units and the calculated PEVCS needs are from 2025 to 2031. This research serves as a case study in Lampung Province, a region experiencing a significant increase in the use of electric vehicles. The framework and methodology used are general and can be replicated in other areas, making the findings of this research a strategic reference for electric vehicle infrastructure planning at the national and regional levels.

title: HyT-Pose: Accurate Pose Estimation by Iteratively Fusing Global and Local Context
authors: Yunxiang Liu, Jiakai Pan
abstract: High-resolution feature recovery is pivotal for accurate Human Pose Estimation (HPE), yet prevailing decoders often rely on local, fixed upsampling operators (e.g., deconvolution) that fail to capture the global structural context of human poses. This limitation inevitably leads to the loss of high-frequency details and the generation of artifacts. To bridge this gap, we present HyT-Pose, a novel hybrid architecture that recasts pose decoding as an iterative, structure-aware super-resolution task. Distinct from traditional reconstruction paradigms, HyT-Pose introduces a strictly synchronized ‘‘Enhance-Amplify-Refine’’ framework. Specifically, we propose a Learnable Linear Upsampling (LLU) mechanism that leverages global receptive fields to adaptively ‘‘infer’’ missing spatial details rather than merely interpolating them. This mechanism is synergized with Transformer-based global context enhancement and a Multi-scale Dynamic Refinement unit (FBlock) to progressively purify feature representations. Extensive experiments on COCO, MPII, and CrowdPose benchmarks demonstrate that HyT-Pose significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods. Notably, it achieves 76.3 AP on COCO val, establishing a new paradigm for high-precision and efficient pose estimation.

title: Derivation of the Stress Voltage Waveform Enhancement Factor for Partial Discharge Risk Assessment in Transportation Motor Windings
authors: Yatai Ji, Paolo Giangrande, Weiduo Zhao, Pinjia Zhang
abstract: Due to the increasing DC bus voltage, electrical machines (EMs) for transportation applications are exposed to a great partial discharge (PD) risk nowadays. Thus, PD risk assessment is essential for fulfilling the reliability requirement. Partial discharge inception voltage (PDIV) measurement under sinusoidal voltage is sometimes preferred because it demands an easy experiment setup, both in terms of the voltage source and PD detection system. However, the obtained results may lead to an underestimation of PD risks since, in actual applications, EMs are fed through inverters and pulse-width modulation (PWM) voltage waveforms are applied. In this paper, the difference between PDIV results obtained under sinusoidal and pulse voltage signals is quantified, and different environmental conditions are investigated, considering the potential transportation electrification applications. Finally, based on the experimental results, a stress voltage waveform enhancement factor is proposed and precisely determined. The study reveals that this factor is not constant under varying environmental conditions, with a maximum value of 1.18 observed at 220 °C and 200 mbar. Furthermore, the influence of the statistical processing method on the derived factors is analyzed, showing a maximum variation of approximately 10% when different Weibull percentiles are employed.

title: Study Case of Current Transformer Breakdown due to Insulation Liquid Leakage
authors: Joko Muslim, Didik Fauzi Dakhlan, Amiruddin, Perdana Adhyatmaja, Fajli Mustafa
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on High Voltage Engineering and Power Systems (ICHVEPS)
abstract: This paper presents a case of current transformer (CT) breakdown in 150 kV coupler bay which led to partial blackout (BO). Regular and routine inspections have been carried out to assess the health index of this CT however inadequate to justify the precise condition. Physical inspection has addressed the leakage of insulating oil prior weeks and mitigation has been made to take out this CT from service but failed just in a week time before the planned shut down for replacement. Investigation was carried out with numerous findings led to internal breakdown at upper part of the top core in CT. Simulation to replicate the event indicated that at the severe condition of leakage when the insulation oil level is below the CT core and its paper insulation, the divergent field may be appeared then evolved and intensified to range of $5.8-11.5 \mathrm{kV} / \mathrm{cm}$ at the interface between upper part of core and the air which may eventually worsen and lead to breakdown. The reconstruction of dielectric failure process and simulation of related model in the failed CT was studied in order to disclose the main causa and the mechanism of failure thus can be anticipated by improving the maintenance procedures to prevent such events to occur in the future.

title: CLUG: Contrastive Learning Unified Retrieval with Graph-Ranked Demonstrations for Enhanced In-Context Learning*
authors: Xiantao Xu, Minghao Hu, ShiLong Liu, Wei Luo, Yushan Tan, Zhunchen Luo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Large language models (LLMs) have demonstrated the ability to perform in-context learning (ICL) with only a few demostrations, achieving remarkable performance across various downstream tasks. The selection of demonstrations plays a critical role in shaping the performance of ICL due to its high sensitivity. However, previous researchers have primarily focused on either the tricks for selecting demonstrations or the sequencing of demonstrations, thereby neglecting the critical role of retrieval models in ICL. The rigid structures and parameters employed in these studies often fail to align with the specific requirements of downstream tasks. To address this problem, we propose CLUG: contrastive learning unified retrieval with graph-ranked demonstrations for enhanced in-context learning, integrating demonstrations retrieval selection and demonstrations order to establish semantically coherent sequences of demonstrations, thereby ensuring enhanced semantic alignment and consistency. Experimental results across multiple datasets demonstrate consistent improvements with our method. Additional analyses further validate and explain the effectiveness and generalizability of our approach.

title:

                    Digital Power Delivery with Surrounding Pass-gates Architecture based on Directional-Selective Nested Quadrant Section Control in 28nm CMOS
authors: Wonae Park, Junyeop Kim, Yuli Han, Gunmo Koo, Joo-Young Kim, Kunhee Cho
abstract: With the growing demand for high-performance computing and the increasing number of cores, efficient power management in large scale digital systems has become crucial [1]. Distributed LDO architectures, using arrayed [2–7] or peripheral [8] pass-gate configurations (Fig. 1), provide current at multiple points, but require complex loop control and suffer from high quiescent current. Moreover, Vout regulation is typically limited to designated sensing nodes, causing Vout deviations in unsensed regions. Furthermore, mismatches among multiple LDOs lead to imbalanced current sharing, which limits the maximum load current capability, particularly in fine-grained power distributions. As a result, the overall power efficiency of the power delivery system is significantly limited.

title: Research on Optimized Vibration Signal Processing for Auxiliary Equipment of Power Synchronous Condensers Using ICEEMDAN-SANC Joint Denoising
authors: Nengfeng Qian, Hengda Gong, Shaobo Wang, Zilong Xing
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th International Conference on Power, Intelligent Computing and Systems (ICPICS)
abstract: In modern power systems, the stable operation of synchronous condensers and their auxiliary equipment is critical to grid safety and reliability. Bearings, as critical components, directly impact system efficiency and operational stability. Bearing failures can lead to unscheduled downtime, power supply disruptions, and significant economic losses. Therefore, the development of effective bearing fault diagnosis techniques is of paramount importance. This paper proposes an Improved Complete Ensemble Empirical Mode Decomposition with Adaptive Noise (ICEEMDAN) and Self-Adaptive Noise Cancelling (SANC) to address noisy vibration signals from power equipment bearings. The proposed approach effectively enhances signal quality, reduces noise interference, and provides clearer data for fault detection, thereby facilitating early fault identification and timely maintenance. This method contributes to improving the reliability and safety of power systems by enabling proactive equipment management.

title: Incomplete multi-view clustering via robust representation learning and tensor-based co-regularization
authors: Cheng Liang, Daoyuan Wang, Fei Guo, Shichao Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: As incompleteness is common in real-world data, incomplete multi-view clustering is of great significance in the unsupervised learning field because it allows the partitioning of multi-view data with missing information into distinct groups. In this paper, we propose a novel generalized framework for incomplete multi-view clustering based on robust representation learning and tensor-based co-regularization (RRLTCR). Specifically, a robust principal component analysis is first used to learn a robust representation for each view. To explore high-order relationships among views, the view-specific spectral embeddings are stacked into a third-order tensor with a Schatten p-norm constraint. By spreading the complementary information of the high-quality available data from each view on a global scale, our model is able to alleviate the adverse effects of data noise and uncover the underlying common cluster structure. An effective iterative optimization strategy is developed to efficiently solve our model. According to the experimental results on seven datasets, our proposed framework has the potential to improve the clustering performance for a variety of incomplete multi-view clustering problems. Our research work brings a generalized framework for incomplete multi-view clustering, which can also assist in exploring the large cohort of existing incomplete multimodality datasets for other downstream tasks.

title: Key Technologies of Optical Fiber Intensive Communication for Flexible DC Converter Valve
authors: Haiwang Jin, Jinbo Li, Taihu Ma, Linyang Teng, Yuqi Feng, Chenglong Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th International Conference on Power, Intelligent Computing and Systems (ICPICS)
abstract: As a new generation of DC transmission technology, flexible DC transmission technology has broad application prospects in large-scale new energy grid connection, grid interconnection and other fields. With the continuous improvement of the voltage level and capacity of the flexible DC transmission system, the number of sub modules in the converter valve has increased sharply. The traditional point-to-point optical fiber communication mode leads to a large amount of optical fiber usage, high system complexity and low reliability. Aiming at the problems existing in the flexible DC converter valve communication system, this paper proposes an optical fiber intensive communication technology scheme. By using the ring network topology, every six sub modules are composed of a communication unit, and the number of optical fibers is greatly reduced. A physical dynamic model test platform including 54 sub modules was built, and the proposed optical fiber intensive communication scheme was comprehensively verified by experiments. Experimental results show that after using the optical fiber intensive technology, the use of optical fibers is reduced from 108 to 18, with a reduction rate of 83%. At the same time, the system has the ability of N-1 fault redundancy, with downlink delay of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$6.6 \mu \mathrm{s}$</tex> and uplink delay of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4.4 \mu \mathrm{s}$</tex>, which meet the requirements of engineering applications. This study provides important technical support for the engineering application of flexible DC transmission system.

title: SE-Jury: An LLM-as-Ensemble-Judge Metric for Narrowing the Gap with Human Evaluation in SE
authors: Xin Zhou, Kisub Kim, Ting Zhang, Martin Weyssow, Luís F. Gomes, Guang Yang, Kui Liu, Xin Xia, David Lo
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) and other automated techniques have been increasingly used to support software developers by generating software artifacts such as code snippets, patches, and comments. However, accurately assessing the correctness of these generated artifacts remains a significant challenge. On one hand, human evaluation provides high accuracy but is labor-intensive and lacks scalability. On the other hand, many automatic evaluation metrics are scalable and require minimal human effort, but they often fail to accurately reflect the actual correctness of generated software artifacts.In this paper, we present SE-Jury, the first evaluation metric for LLM-as-Ensemble-Judge specifically designed to accurately assess the correctness of generated software artifacts. SE-Jury first defines five distinct evaluation strategies, each implemented as an independent judge. A dynamic team selection mechanism then identifies the most appropriate subset of judges as a team to produce a final correctness score through ensembling. We evaluate SE-Jury across a diverse set of software engineering (SE) benchmarks that span three popular SE tasks: code generation, automated program repair, and code summarization. Results demonstrate that SE-Jury consistently achieves a higher correlation with human judgments, with improvements ranging from 29.6%–140.8% over existing automatic metrics. SE-Jury reaches agreement levels with human annotators that are close to inter-annotator agreement in code generation and program repair. These findings underscore SE-Jury’s potential as a scalable and reliable alternative to human evaluation in these SE tasks.

title: Optimization of Permanent Magnet Array of Vernier Permanent Magnet Linear Motor Based on PSO
authors: Binrong Zhu, Shengguo Zhang, Hanyu Li, Jiayu Ma, Jiaran Zhu
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th International Conference on Power, Intelligent Computing and Systems (ICPICS)
abstract: To achieve high thrust density in electromagnetic launch systems, this study proposes a collaborative optimization method for the dimensional design of permanent magnet (PM) arrays. A moving-magnet planar motor topology is adopted, and a one-dimensional analytical magnetic field model is established for rapid computation. A two-stage particle swarm optimization (PSO) strategy is implemented to maximize the absolute average z-direction flux density under strict mass constraints. The optimized design achieves a width ratio <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\alpha$</tex> increased from 0.5 to 0.7 and a PM thickness expanded from 25 mm to 35 mm. COMSOL simulations verify a 17.2% improvement in the absolute average z-direction flux density, while the mass growth is effectively restrained. The results provide a practical and manufacturable design framework for high-performance electromagnetic launch systems.

title: Watson: A Cognitive Observability Framework for the Reasoning of LLM-Powered Agents
authors: Benjamin Rombaut, Sogol Masoumzadeh, Kirill Vasilevski, Dayi Lin, Ahmed E. Hassan
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: Large language models (LLMs) are increasingly integrated into autonomous systems, giving rise to a new class of software known as Agentware, where LLM-powered agents perform complex, open-ended tasks in domains such as software engineering, customer service, and data analysis. However, their high autonomy and opaque reasoning processes pose significant challenges for traditional software observability methods. To address this, we introduce the concept of cognitive observability—the ability to recover and inspect the implicit reasoning behind agent decisions. We present Watson, a general-purpose framework for observing the reasoning processes of fast-thinking LLM agents without altering their behavior. Watson retroactively infers reasoning traces using prompt attribution techniques. We evaluate Watson in both manual debugging and automated correction scenarios across the MMLU benchmark and the AutoCodeRover and OpenHands agents on the SWE-bench-lite dataset. In both static and dynamic settings, Watson surfaces actionable reasoning insights and supports targeted interventions, demonstrating its practical utility for improving transparency and reliability in Agentware systems.

title: Highlighting System Using ArUco Markers for Surgical Instruments in Knee Replacement Surgery
authors: Kouki Nagamune
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: In recent years, the shortage of nurses has become a global problem. Furthermore, in large-scale surgeries such as total knee arthroplasty, a large number of surgical instruments with similar shapes are prepared, which places a heavy burden on operating room nurses who manage them. To solve these problems, we have developed an automatic surgical instrument recognition system to support operating room nurses. We have also developed a system that applies projection mapping technology to highlight automatically recognized surgical instruments in the real world in real time, making it easy for nurses in the operating room to understand. In this study, we propose a method to correct the highlighting using ArUco markers. In experiments, we confirmed object detection using surgical instruments and demonstrated the effectiveness of this system.

title: Partial Discharge Monitoring Using the UHF Method as an Early Warning System in Gas Insulated Switchgear: A Case Study in PLN Indonesia
authors: Andika Bagaskara, Harry Gumilang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on High Voltage Engineering and Power Systems (ICHVEPS)
abstract: Gas Insulated Switchgear (GIS) has become a preferred choice in modern substations due to its reliability, compactness, and low maintenance requirements. However, despite these advantages, failures still occur, often due to insulation defects arising from manufacturing, installation, or ageing processes. This study investigates the effectiveness of Ultra High Frequency (UHF)-based Partial Discharge (PD) monitoring as a diagnostic tool for assessing the internal condition of GIS. By analyzing PD signals recorded during substation events across Indonesia, the study identifies common defect patterns such as free-moving particles, surface contamination, and other insulation irregularities. Experimental observations confirm that PD activity often precedes major failures, indicating the potential of continuous UHF-based monitoring as an early warning system. Root cause analysis highlights the critical role of quality control, environmental conditions, and maintenance practices in GIS reliability. The findings underscore the importance of integrating real-time PD monitoring and adopting preventive measures to reduce failure risks and extend the service life of GIS equipment. It was observed that PD should be analyzed in the beginning, check the patterns in the PD, and combine analysis between internal sensor and external sensor. Therefore, the precisely analysis can obtain the accurately data.

title: Stability Assessment of Virtual Synchronous Generator based on Double-Loop Control towards Net Zero Energy System
authors: Nottakorn Sukmanont, Nidchabendha Chandanachulaka Roekrai, Thongchart Kerdphol
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on High Voltage Engineering and Power Systems (ICHVEPS)
abstract: Modern power grids rely on inverter-based resources (IBRs) to transition towards a net-zero energy system, posing a challenge of reduced grid inertia with deteriorated grid stability. The virtual synchronous generator (VSG) addresses this by enhancing grid inertia but overlooks voltage stability. The integration of IBRs may exacerbate stability concerns due to their potential inability to produce reactive power. This exacerbation further compounds the low-inertia challenge, particularly regarding voltage instability. To fill in this gap, this paper introduces a stability assessment of the VSG concept considering double-loop control in regulating both grid inertia and voltage during IBR penetration. The inner loop is used to provide the current reference and voltage regulation, while the outer loop is designed to regulate the grid inertia -based frequency stability. The simulation results show that applying VSG-based double-loop technology could ensure desirable inertia, frequency and voltage stability during high IBR penetration. It is obvious that the studied VSG not only improves grid’s resilience and adaptability to fluctuations inherent in IBR but also plays crucial roles in maintaining simultaneous grid frequency and voltage towards a net zero energy system.

title: ARG: Testing Query Rewriters via Abstract Rule Guided Fuzzing
authors: Dawei Li, Yuxiao Guo, Qifan Liu, Jie Liang, Zhiyong Wu, Jingzhou Fu, Chi Zhang, Yu Jiang
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: Query rewriters transform a query into a more efficient yet semantically equivalent form, which is vital for optimizing query execution. Despite its importance, query rewriting is inherently complex, influenced by factors including rewrite rule design, rule interactions, and semantic preservation. Consequently, its implementation struggles to prevent problems, which may result in system crashes or incorrect query results. Existing DBMS testing approaches are generally designed for broad bug detection. However, due to the diversity of rewrite rules, they cover only a limited subset of rewrite scenarios, potentially overlooking critical bugs.In this paper, we propose Abstract Rule Guided (ARG) fuzzing to detect bugs in query rewrites. The key idea is to use feedback from abstract rules to guide query generation, thereby activating more rewriting logic and enhancing bug detection. Abstract rules provide a unified representation of the patterns (e.g., AST structures and related constraints) that trigger rewrites, as well as the resulting transformations. We track abstract rules to identify which patterns have been covered. This feedback is then used to dynamically adjust query generation, prioritizing unexplored patterns to avoid redundancy and expose more rewriting logic. We implemented ARG to test four popular query rewrites, namely Apache Calcite, WeTune, SQLSolver, and LearnedRewrite. ARG discovered 38 previously unknown bugs, consisting of 4 crashes, 13 invalid SQL outputs, and 21 semantic deviations. Among them, 19 have been confirmed, while the remaining cases are still under investigation. We also compared ARG against popular DBMS testing tools. In 24 hours, ARG triggered 76% and 1017% more written rules, triggered 13 and 15 more bugs than SQLsmith and SQLancer, respectively.

title: Predictive Modelling for Solar Production
authors: Megha K J, Kailasamani Shunmugesh, Rajesh Kannan Megalingam, Sony Kurian
publish: 2025 International Conference on Robotics and Mechatronics (ICRM)
abstract: The growing global demand for renewable energy sources has positioned Solar energy as a vital and key factor in the move towards sustainable energy systems. In particular, Solar Photo Voltaic (PV) panels have been demonstrated as possible sustainable energy systems but are affected by environmental factors like irradiance, humidity and temperature that can create uncertainty in their means of producing energy. To address this, Machine Learning (ML) algorithms are employed to forecast the solar energy produced and to help understand this uncertainty and improve solar energy modelling. In this study five separate multiple regression based ML models, Decision Tree (DT), Random Forest (RF), Gradient Boosting (GB), Light Gradient Boosting Machine (Light GBM) and Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost) are used to develop predictions of solar energy production based on environmental input data. Results confirmed that ensemble models, particularly XGBoost and RF, outperformed others in predictive generalization and accuracy in terms of lowest value of Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE), Mean Absolute Error (MAE) and the highest value of R-squared(R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>), which are accepted as one of the most important performance criteria by the ML models.

title: Democratizing the Cryptocurrency Ecosystem by Just-In-Time Transformation of Mining Programs
authors: Wei Liu, Zhenhua Li, Feng Qian, Feiyu Jin, Hao Lin, Yannan Zheng, Bo Xiao, Xiaokang Qin, Tianyin Xu
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: Democracy is crucial to a cryptocurrency ecosystem, as the diversity of miners (farms, personal computers, web clients, or even cloud functions) underlays the credibility of the cryptocurrency. Among miners, web clients used to be the vast majority, e.g., 50M+ as of March 2018. As time went on, however, cryptomining was gradually monopolized by mining farms with dedicated hardware (e.g., ASICs), and web clients scaled down to ∼0.1M. To suppress mining farms, certain cryptocurrencies (like Monero) adopted new mining algorithms such as RandomX whose execution relies on general-purpose hardware architectures. Unfortunately, this further impairs web-based cryptomining as web clients cannot provide the desired architecture support to these algorithms. This paper explores how to revive software democracy of efficient web-based crypto-mining, using a novel program transformation technique termed Vectra. Vectra employs just-in-time (JIT) transformations of mining programs for web architectures; it effectively identifies and merges isomorphic instructions upon execution. Vectra ensures correct transformations based on symbolic constraints of the instructions. Real-world deployments show that Vectra reduces WASM instructions by about 7× and achieves a 3× –16× speedup for web cryptomining in diverse execution environments like PCs, mobile phones, and serverless platforms, which translates to a high (69%–274%) return-on-investment (ROI) for common users.

title: A Fault Tolerance Control Strategy for Four-Wheel Independent Steering Electric Vehicles via Torque Vector Distribution
authors: Shixiao Chang, Ning Zhang, Zhihao Wu, Guodong Yin
publish: 2025 9th CAA International Conference on Vehicular Control and Intelligence (CVCI)
abstract: This paper proposes a hierarchical dynamic fault-tolerant control strategy that integrates torque vector distribution and differential steering. The fault-tolerant controller aims to realize path tracking and driving stability in the failure of steering actuator. A seven-degree-of-freedom four-wheel independent steering vehicle model with drive-steering redundancy is developed based on the corner module configuration. The upper-level controller is designed to generate the desired mechanical parameters for path tracking and the lower-level controller allocates torque and steering angles. In case of single-wheel steering failure, the weight parameters of the failed actuators are dynamically adjusted through the hierarchical control architecture to realize the coordinated control of the remaining actuators. The simulation results of double lane change maneuver demonstrate that the errors of tracking the yaw rate and yaw angle are reduced by 22.2 % and 7.2 %.

title: Emergency Response Strategy for Heterogeneous EV Clusters in Islanded Microgrids
authors: Jiaqi Yuan, Mingquan Qiu, Qi Kang, Yun Zhang, Runpei Li, Danlei Ding, He Li, Chao Wang, Lei Zhang, Feng Hu, Dehua Qi
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Energy Engineering and Power Systems (EEPS)
abstract: With the widespread application of islanded microgrids in remote areas, emergency rescue and other scenarios, multi type electric vehicle battery clusters as flexible and adjustable distributed energy storage resources are of great significance for improving the emergency power supply capacity of microgrids. This article focuses on the emergency power supply problem of multiple types of EV battery clusters in isolated microgrids, accurately evaluates the V2G available discharge capacity of private EV and bus EV battery clusters, and constructs a two-layer game model for optimization scheduling. Firstly, based on the structural characteristics of islanded microgrids, establish a power function model for distributed power sources, loads, and energy storage units; Then, based on the user's behavioral characteristics, evaluate the V2G available discharge capacity of private EV and bus EV battery clusters separately; Finally, an EV dominated master-slave game optimization model was constructed, with the lower distributed energy layer responsible for supplementing power supply when EV power supply is insufficient. The double-layer nonlinear model was transformed into a singlelayer mixed integer linear programming problem using KKT conditions to solve the model. The simulation results show that the proposed method can accurately evaluate the discharge capacity of multiple types of EV battery clusters participating in emergency power supply of islanded microgrids, enhance the stability of islanded microgrid operation, and significantly reduce power loss.

title: Sub-7GHz-Aided Adaptive MCS Selection for Millimeter-Wave Beamforming
authors: Wei Jiang, Yi Zhong
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Wireless Communications and Signal Processing (WCSP)
abstract: Millimeter-wave (mmWave) beamforming training (BFT) in IEEE 802.11ad/ay systems incurs significant time overhead due to constraints from a static Modulation and Coding Scheme (MCS) and redundant signaling. This study proposes a Sub-7GHz-aided adaptive MCS selection framework for mmWave beamforming training. Using dual-band cooperation and a quantitative SNR-PER-throughput model, the protocol dynamically selects optimal MCS levels, achieving balanced robustness while minimizing time overhead. The proposed framework introduces two MCS mapping schemes. Scheme 1 prioritizes throughput maximization through probabilistic SNR thresholds, while Scheme 2 incorporates error vector magnitude (EVM) constraints from IEEE 802.11ad for enhanced robustness. Link-level simulations demonstrate that adaptive MCS application reduces the duration of the BFT by 39.85 % (to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$572 \mu ~\mathrm{s}$</tex>) under high SNR conditions compared to legacy MCS 0 baselines, with Scheme 1 achieving effective throughput gains of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.16 x$</tex> and Scheme 2 maintaining the probability of success of BFT 100 %. This work establishes a lightweight BFT paradigm compatible with Multi-Link Operation (MLO) in IEEE 802.11be, offering scalable solutions for high-mobility mmWave scenarios through Sub-7GHz control plane offloading.

title: Swin Transformer Based Massive MIMO Channel Feedback and Hybrid Beamforming
authors: Ninghao Jia, Boqian Lin, Minghui Wu, Ziqi Han, De Mi, Zhen Gao
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Wireless Communications and Signal Processing (WCSP)
abstract: With the growing complexity and scale of multipleinput multiple-output (MIMO) systems, efficient channel state information (CSI) acquisition and precoding have become critical challenges. Traditional methods often struggle with high pilot and computational overhead. Inspired by the rapid development of deep learning (DL), we explore the potential of the Swin Transformer, a hierarchical Transformer known for its efficiency in extracting both local and global features, to address these issues. Specifically, we propose a Swin Transformer-based Channel Acquisition Network (SCAN) that jointly optimizes pilot design, CSI compression at the user equipment (UE), and CSI reconstruction at the base station (BS). Additionally, a model-driven Swin Transformer-based WMMSE Adaptive Network (SWAN) is proposed for efficient digital precoding, where the Transformer learns to predict key parameters of the WMMSE algorithm, enabling low-complexity and effective precoder generation. Simulation results show that our framework significantly improves CSI reconstruction accuracy and spectral efficiency, while maintaining low computational complexity and high robustness.

title: Lightweight and Dynamic Content-Augmented Object Detection for UAVs
authors: Mahdi SadeghiBakhi, Henry Leung, Xin Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: This paper presents a novel lightweight and robust object detection framework tailored for UAV-based applications. The core of the proposed method is the Dynamic Content-Augmented Feature Pyramid Network (DCA-FPN), which integrates a Global Content Extraction Module (GCEM), an Adaptive Branching Network (ABN), and a Linear Transformer (LT) to enhance multi-scale feature representation and contextual understanding. These components collectively improve detection performance for small and occluded objects while addressing the misalignment issues inherent in traditional feature pyramids. Built on a MobileNet backbone with depthwise separable convolutions, the framework offers low computational complexity and real-time readiness for edge devices. Experimental results on the Vis-Drone dataset show a state-of-the-art mean Average Precision (mAP) of 42.50%, while additional evaluations on the MS COCO benchmark confirm competitive performance across diverse object scales. Furthermore, testing on the GDIT Aerial Airport dataset demonstrates the model’s applicability in infrastructure monitoring tasks, particularly in detecting airplanes across varied sizes and conditions. These results highlight the robustness, efficiency, and deployment potential of the proposed framework in real-world, resource-constrained UAV scenarios.

title: YOLO-SSL: A Lightweight and High-Precision Model for UAV-Based Power Transmission Line Defect Detection
authors: Lei Wang, Yinghua Zhou
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Accurate detection of power transmission line defects and prompt feedback to inspection personnel are crucial for the normal operation of power transmission lines. Addressing the problems of complex background, small defect size, high false detection, and missed detection rates in existing UAV inspection for power transmission line defect detection, we propose a YOLO-SSL model to improve the accuracy of power transmission line defect detection without significantly increasing the complexity of the model. First, we incorporate the SPD-Conv module to replace stride convolution and pooling layers, enhancing detection performance for low-resolution images and small objects while effectively extracting features and reducing redundant computations. Secondly, we design a dedicated small target detection layer to make the network focus more on minor defects and improve detection effectiveness. Finally, we propose a new scalable lightweight receptive field module (LwRFB) that better captures target features of different sizes without adding noticeable number of parameters. The experimental results show that the mAP@0.5 of the proposed YOLO-SSL reaches 89.7%, which is 4.8% higher than that of YOLO11n. Moreover, the YOLO-SSL is a lightweight model, meeting edge device deployment needs and demonstrating high application value.

title: Enhancing UWOC Link Distance by 69.5% with an APD-Based Relay
authors: Shiji Lin, Chao Shen, Junhui Hu, Fangnian Du, Junwen Zhang, Nan Chi
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Infocomm Technology (ICAIT)
abstract: Underwater optical wireless communication (UWOC) offers high bandwidth and low latency, but its link distance is severely constrained by absorption and scattering in aquatic environments. In this work, an avalanche photodiode (APD)-based relay module is designed and experimentally validated to extend the transmission distance of high-speed UWOC links. The relay integrates an APD, an electrical amplifier(EA), an attenuator(ATT), a bias tee, and a laser diode(LD) to perform optical-to-electrical conversion, signal reshaping, electrical-to-optical and re-transmission. Experiments are conducted at data rates of $1,1.2,1.5$, and $1.7 \mathrm{Gbit} / \mathrm{s}$, with optical filters employed to emulate underwater attenuation. Results show that without relay, communication links fail at an equivalent attenuation of approximately 35 dB, whereas the relayassisted configuration maintains successful transmission up to 50 dB. The proposed relay enables an equivalent transmission distance improvement of $16.81-22.81 \mathrm{~dB}$ in attenuation margin, corresponding to 48.3% to 69.5% extension in communication range. These findings demonstrate that APD-based relay technology is an effective strategy to enhance the practical communication range of UWOC systems.

title: Unified Artificial Intelligence and Formal Reasoning Approach to Software Security
authors: Arif Muhammed, R Shekhar
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Mobile Networks and Wireless Communications (ICMNWC)
abstract: Software vulnerabilities represent serious security concerns; every year, over 25,000 Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVEs) are issued, and cybercrime spending is estimated to be USD 23.82 trillion by 2027. Traditional static analysis tools achieve only 60-70% detection accuracy with 3040% false positives, while recent large language model approaches lack strong validation controls. This paper proposes an integrated framework incorporating machine learning-driven vulnerability analysis, automated patch generation, and formal verification methods. It has semantic extraction based on BERT on CVE descriptions, a SecureFalcon-inspired multi-class severity classifier, a context-aware LLM patch generator with chain-ofthought reasoning, and a verification of bounded model checking. Evaluation on 15,247 real-world vulnerabilities demonstrates 96.2% detection accuracy, 76.4% end-to-end remediation success, and 68.7% false-positive reduction compared to LLM-only approaches, with average processing time of 3.2 minutes per CVE. The framework provides mathematically verified corrections with dynamic software-defined networking protection during remediation phases.

title: Low-Latency Terrestrial Interference Detection for Satellite-to-Device Communications
authors: Runnan Liu, Weifeng Zhu, Shu Sun, Wenjun Zhang
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Wireless Communications and Signal Processing (WCSP)
abstract: Direct satellite-to-device communication is a promising future direction due to its lower latency and enhanced efficiency. However, intermittent and unpredictable terrestrial interference significantly affects system reliability and performance. Continuously employing sophisticated interference mitigation techniques is practically inefficient. Motivated by the periodic idle intervals characteristic of burst-mode satellite transmissions, this paper investigates online interference detection frameworks specifically tailored for satellite-to-device scenarios. We first rigorously formulate interference detection as a binary hypothesis testing problem, leveraging differences between Rayleigh (no interference) and Rician (interference present) distributions. Then, we propose a cumulative sum (CUSUM)-based online detector for scenarios with known interference directions, explicitly characterizing the trade-off between detection latency and false alarm rate, and establish its asymptotic optimality. For practical scenarios involving unknown interference directions, we further propose a generalized likelihood ratio (GLR)-based detection method, jointly estimating the interference direction via the Root-MUSIC algorithm. Numerical results validate our theoretical findings and demonstrate that our proposed methods achieve high detection accuracy with remarkably low latency, highlighting their practical applicability in future satellite-todevice communication systems.

title: Phase Modulation-based Fiber-Optic Radio Frequency Transfer Using Dispersion Shifting
authors: Junwei Ren, Long Wang, Liang Hu, Jianping Chen, Guiling Wu
abstract: We propose and demonstrate a phase modulation-based fiber-optic radio frequency transfer using dispersion shifting. The measured frequency stabilities reach 4.8 × 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−14</sup> at 1 s and 7.7 × 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−17</sup> at 10,000 s, respectively.

title: ALSGCN: An Attention-based Long- and Short-term Graph Convolutional Network for Stock Recommendation
authors: Junpeng Yu, Wenjie Yao, Zhihao Li, Lele Gao, Wenyun Xiao, Hongnian Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Stock recommendation plays a critical role in financial investment decision-making. In real-world markets, stocks exhibit complex interdependencies through correlated price movements. Existing approaches derive stock relationships either from fundamental information (e.g., industry categories) or price temporal patterns. However, these methods face limitations: domain expertise-based approaches fail to capture implicit correlations, while short-term relationship modeling suffers from inadequate temporal feature representation. To address these challenges, we propose ALSGCN, an Attention-based Long- and Short-term Graph Convolutional Network for stock recommendation. ALSGCN captures dynamic stock relationships through two key components: (1) a market-aware mechanism that models long-term dependencies by incorporating the influence of large-cap stocks, and (2) an attention-based temporal feature extraction module that adaptively weights information across time steps. These complementary relationship representations are integrated through a multichannel graph attention module for effective feature learning. Extensive experiments on two real-world datasets demonstrate that ALSGCN consistently outperforms state-of-the-art baselines across most evaluation metrics. Code is available at https://github.com/hongnianwang/ALSGCN.

title: Multi-core Fiber Featuring Air-hole-assisted Trench for Efficient OAM Mode Transmission
authors: Rosni Sayed, Abdul Khaleque, Kumary Sumi Rani Shaha
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Information and Communication Technology (EICT)
abstract: A multi-core fiber incorporating an air-hole-assisted trench structure is designed to enable efficient orbital angular momentum (OAM) mode transmission. The fiber features multiple cores with trench-assisted ring profiles, where strategically placed air holes significantly suppress inter-ring crosstalk and enhance mode stability across a broad wavelength range. A comprehensive finite element method (FEM) analysis confirms the fiber’s performance, supporting up to 574 OAM modes at 1.55 $\mu$ m and 518 OAM modes throughout the full O-E-S-C-L bands. This design attains an unprecedented low inter-ring crosstalk of -108.34 dB at $1.55 \mu \mathrm{~m}$ and -83 dB across a distance of 100 km, with effective refractive index separation exceeding $4.9 \times 10^{-4}$. It also offers a large effective mode area, minimal confinement loss ($10^{-12}$ to $10^{-8} \mathrm{~dB} / \mathrm{m}$), and mode purities exceeding 99%. These results highlight the fiber’s potential for supporting largescale OAM multiplexing in optical networks.
