title:
Object-Centric Transformer Framework for Fine-Grained Image-Text Retrieval with Global Consistency
                    <sup>*</sup>
authors: Sitong Shen, Mayire Ibrayim, Peichao Jiang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Cross-modal image-text retrieval enables efficient heterogeneous modality interaction via vision-language semantic alignment, advancing multimodal intelligence applications. However, traditional cross-modal retrieval methods typically rely on pre-trained feature extractors, whose performance limitations hinder the accuracy of image-text retrieval. In this paper, we propose an end-to-end Transformer-based cross-modal image-text retrieval framework, OCGC, which extracts visual and textual features through Transformer models. The framework employs a Global-Attentive Slot Fusion module to aggregate object-centric visual features to address feature redundancy, combined with a Global Semantic Consistency Alignment module to enhance cross-modal feature alignment between aggregated image features and text embeddings. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed model performs exceptionally well on two benchmark datasets, outperforming the state-of-the-art methods by over 6% Rsum on the Flickr30K dataset.

title: Advancing Streaming Performance with Opportunistic Linked Increase Algorithm in Network Congestion Control
authors: M.L. Suresh, Sabah Abdul Wahab Sheet, Malik Bader Alazzam, Ozoda Talipova, Sajiv G, Lokesh Gupta
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Intelligent Signal Processing and Effective Communication Technologies (INSPECT)
abstract: Congestion control is essential to provide a smooth transmission of data in a current network especially in latency sensitive applications like video streaming. Existing traditional congestion control algorithms fail to cope with dynamic network conditions causing suboptimal use of bandwidth, high latency and packet loss. This paper introduces an improved OLIA to real-time adaptive streaming. The given framework presents a dynamic congestion window adaptation algorithm that is grounded on real-time network feedback and a rational adaptive retransmission to enhance bandwidth use and minimize unnecessary retransmissions. Adaptive window adjustment relies on the feedback-based scaling factor based on the occupancy of the queue and lost packets, and the retransmission mechanism rearranges the priority of the lost packets on the network conditions. NS-3 $\mathbf{5 G}$ traffic datasets were used in experiments with different network topologies. Findings indicate that network performance improved significantly: throughput improved to $\mathbf{1 5. 8} \mathrm{Mbps}$, packet loss dropped to 1.8 percent, latency dropped to 25.3 ms, jitter dropped to 3.6 ms and fairness index was also enhanced to 0.98. The suggested improvements allow playing video faster, less buffering and better user experience, which indicates the efficiency of OLIA in high bandwidth, latency sensitive streaming.

title: New binary quantum codes from Hermitian dual-containing Quasi-cyclic codes
authors: Liangdong Lu, Gaochi Zhang, Ganyu Feng, Wenzheng Ma
publish: 2025 2nd International Symposium on AI and Cybersecurity (ISAICS)
abstract: In this paper, we introduce a class of dualcontaining 2 -generator quasi-cyclic codes over $G F(4)$. By Hermitian construction, we show computation constructions of binary quantum codes with good parameters from quaternary quasi-cyclic codes. Furthermore, 3 new quantum codes [[42, 10, 9]], [[74,,36, 9]] and [[78, 40, 9]] are derived from Hermitian dual-containing quasi-cyclic codes by an exhaustive search, along with 24 newly derived codes that enhance the previously best-known lower bounds on minimum distance.

title: Fault-Tolerant Multi-Protocol IoT Gateway with Resumable Transfer and Watchdog Orchestration
authors: Jianguo Yan, Yu Zhao, Wei Zhu, Yifan Ying
publish: 2025 2nd International Symposium on AI and Cybersecurity (ISAICS)
abstract: Due to limited bandwidth, network instability, and protocol incompatibility, existing IoT gateways often struggle to ensure reliability and handle disruptions in IoT networks. To overcome these problems, this paper proposes a high-reliability, multi-protocol IoT gateway design, which integrates the STM32F405RGT6 microcontroller with 4G LTE, Ethernet, and CAN interfaces for industrial and remote applications. A multi-level watchdog was involved to ensure stability, while a resumable transfer protocol maintains continuous data transmission even during network interruptions. Experimental results show that the system achieves a data transmission success rate over $\mathbf{9 8 \%}$ and the average recovery time is less than 2 seconds under various fault conditions, including power failures and network congestion. The system has been tested in the factory, showing its stability advantages in maintaining data integrity. This IoT gateway solution is ideal for critical applications such as industrial automation, smart cities, and emergency response, significantly improving the reliability and efficiency of IoT networks by ensuring robust fault tolerance and data traceability.

title: A novel phase change material-based non-volatile optical router for optical network-on-chip
authors: Xiangyu He, Pengxing Guo, Wei Sun, Haoxuan Huang, Shengqiang Li, Weigang Hou, Lei Guo
abstract: This paper introduces, for the first time, a novel nonvolatile optical router based on phase change material Sb<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>Se<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>, delivering high extinction ratio, reduced insertion loss, enhanced area efficiency, and low power consumption, making it ideal for high-performance optical network-on-chip.

title: FastCoder: Accelerating Repository-level Code Generation via Efficient Retrieval and Verification
authors: Qianhui Zhao, Li Zhang, Fang Liu, Xiaoli Lian, Qiaoyuanhe Meng, Ziqian Jiao, Zetong Zhou, Jia Li, Lin Shi
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: Code generation is a latency-sensitive task that demands high timeliness. However, with the growing interest and inherent difficulty in repository-level code generation, most existing code generation studies focus on improving the correctness of generated code while overlooking the inference efficiency, which is substantially affected by the overhead during LLM generation. Although there has been work on accelerating LLM inference, these approaches are not tailored to the specific characteristics of code generation; instead, they treat code the same as natural language sequences and ignore its unique syntax and semantic characteristics, which are also crucial for improving efficiency. Consequently, these approaches exhibit limited effectiveness in code generation tasks, particularly for repository-level scenarios with considerable complexity and difficulty. To alleviate this issue, following draft-verification paradigm, we propose FastCoder, a simple yet highly efficient inference acceleration approach specifically designed for code generation, without compromising the quality of the output. FastCoder constructs a multi-source datastore, providing access to both general and project-specific knowledge, facilitating the retrieval of high-quality draft sequences. Moreover, FastCoder reduces the retrieval cost by controlling retrieval timing, and enhances efficiency through parallel retrieval and a context- and LLM preference-aware cache. Experimental results show that FastCoder can reach up to 2.53× and 2.54× speedup compared to autoregressive decoding in repository-level and standalone code generation tasks, respectively, outperforming state-of-the-art inference acceleration approaches by up to 88%. FastCoder can also be integrated with existing correctness-focused code generation approaches to accelerate the LLM generation process, and reach a speedup exceeding 2.6×.

title: Toward Multiphysics-Informed Machine Learning for Sustainable Data Center Operations: Intelligence Evolution With Deployable Solutions for Computing Infrastructure
authors: Ruihang Wang, Qingang Zhang, Jimin Jia, Yonggang Wen, Stuart Kennedy
abstract: The revolution in artificial intelligence (AI) has brought sustainable challenges in data center (DC) management due to the high carbon emissions and short cooling response time associated with high-power density racks. While machine learning (ML) offers promise for intelligent management, its adoption is hindered by safety and reliability concerns. To address this, we propose a multiphysics-informed ML (MPIML) framework that integrates physical priors into data-driven models for enhanced accuracy and safety. We introduce an integrated system architecture comprising three core engines: DCLib for versatile facility modeling, DCTwin for high-fidelity multiphysics simulation, and DCBrain for decision-making optimization. This system enables critical predictive and prescriptive applications, such as carbon-aware information technology (IT) capacity provisioning, safety-aware intelligent cooling control, and battery health forecasting. An illustrative example on an industry-grade DC cooling control demonstrates that our MPIML approach reduces annual carbon emissions up to 200 kilotons compared with conventional methods while ensuring operational constraints are met. We conclude by outlining key challenges and future directions for developing autonomous and sustainable DCs.

title: A 24–31-GHz Compact Low-Power Complex Impedance Sensor for Beamforming Transmitters in 22-nm FD-SOI
authors: Xuepu Wu, Yang Zhang, Giovanni Mangraviti, Rana ElKashlan, Dries Peumans, Piet Wambacq
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: Variations of the load impedance at the output of a transmitter (TX) can cause a significant performance degradation of the power amplifier (PA) characteristics, such as output power, linearity, and efficiency. This performance can be restored by making a PA actively or passively reconfigurable, which requires a sensor to measure its load impedance. To this end, we propose a complex impedance sensor to measure impedance variations at the output of a PA operating around 28 GHz. As the sensor employs lumped sensing elements, this complex voltage sensing method is compatible with most currently existing PA designs. The sensor is combined with the output balun of a differential PA with only a small impact on the PA performance. Compared to earlier designs, this sensor comes with an improved dynamic range and bandwidth. The prototype is fabricated in a 22-nm FD-SOI CMOS technology; it consumes 8 mW of power and occupies 0.0043 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. By sweeping the input from 24 to 31 GHz with an input power from −13 to −6 dBm, this sensor can sense reflection coefficients up to a magnitude of 0.74 with a maximum error of 0.17 and root-mean-square (rms) error lower than 0.042.

title: Fault Estimation for Four-Wheel Independently Actuated Electric Vehicles Based on a Fuzzy Proportional-Integral Observer
authors: Xiangyuan Bian, Juntao Pan, Xueyuan Zhang
publish: 2025 9th CAA International Conference on Vehicular Control and Intelligence (CVCI)
abstract: This work investigates the problem of fault estimation in the context of four-wheel independently actuated (FWIA) electric vehicle systems prone to simultaneous sensor and actuator faults. First, by augmenting the sensor faults as part of the system state, the original system under study is transformed into a new augmented system. Based on this augmented system, a proportional-integral observer (PIO) is designed to achieve simultaneous estimation of the original system states, sensor faults, and abrupt actuator faults. During observer design, a specialized Takagi-Sugeno (TS) fuzzy framework is utilized to decouple immeasurable nonlinear components from measurable nonlinear variables. This strategy circumvents the challenge posed by unmeasurable premise variables, significantly lowering design conservativeness in the observer development. By combining the fuzzy Lyapunov method and linear matrix inequality (LMI) techniques, stability conditions for the error system and closed-loop system are derived, facilitating the computation of the observer gain matrix. The effectiveness and practicality of the proposed method are finally verified through simulation studies.

title: Analysis Model for G-Band Photomixer Modules Based on MUTC-PDs
authors: Yuxin Tian, Bing Xiong, Guizhen Wang, Changzheng Sun, Zhibiao Hao, Jian Wang, Lai Wang, Yanjun Han, Hongtao Li, Yi Luo
abstract: We present a novel model to predict the performance of photomixer modules based on MUTC-PDs. By taking packaging introduced deviances into account, the model provides excellent prediction for the frequency responses of G-band photomixers.

title: Task Offloading and Resource Allocation for AoI and Delay Optimization in UAV-Enabled MEC Networks
authors: Haocheng Wang, Chenxi Liu, Xiaoling Hu, Mugen Peng
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Wireless Communications and Signal Processing (WCSP)
abstract: In this paper, we consider a multi-UAV network where terrestrial base stations (BSs), UAV-mounted BSs, and low earth orbit (LEO) satellites jointly provide communication coverage and computation offloading services for UAV user equipments (UEs). In our system, we use the long-term cost, defined as the weighted sum of task processing delay, age of information (AoI), and queue length, to characterize the performance of our system. Based on this metric, we formulate a joint task offloading, resource allocation, and UAV UE trajectory optimization problem. To solve this non-convex problem, we decompose it into two subproblems, namely, a joint offloading and trajectory optimization subproblem and a resource allocation subproblem. A novel twin delayed deep deterministic policy gradient algorithm (TD3)-based algorithm and convex optimization methods are proposed to solve these two subproblems efficiently. Numerical results show that, compared to various baselines, our proposed algorithms can achieve significantly improved long-term cost.

title: A Review of the Role of 6G and Wearable Technologies in Shaping the Future
authors: Vanlalruata Hnamte, Jamal Hussain, Chhakchhuak Laldinsanga, Ashfaq Ahmad Najar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Computing Technologies (ICACT)
abstract: The integration of 6 G networks and wearable devices is expected to significantly enhance the smart healthcare sector through real-time patient monitoring, personalised treatment, and seamless connectivity. This study aims to demonstrate how 6G-powered wearable devices can assist in solving healthcare problems, including chronic disease control, emergency care, and medication compliance. These wearable devices can offer faster, more precise, and energy-harvesting healthcare solutions by taking advantage of the low latency, massive connectivity, and AI capabilities of 6 G networks. An offloading framework is proposed in this study to share the computational load among the three layers of local, edge, and cloud servers in a dynamic manner to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the network. However, issues such as security, interoperability, and energy management remain important. This paper identifies research gaps, suggests practical recommendations, and highlights future work to improve the implementation of wearable systems enabled by 6 G, which will advance a highly automated healthcare system.

title: Implementing Edge Computing and Cloud Computing: Emerging New Opportunities for Real-Time Analytics and Self-Designing Systems
authors: P. Krishnamoorthy, Monisha M, V. Samuthira Pandi, Ibrahim Mohammad Khrais, Navdeep Singh, G. Karthikeyan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Computing Technologies (ICACT)
abstract: Recent data explosion has been driven by a few factors, such as the rapid acceleration of digital technologies, the addition of data generated flows, and the necessity for better processing, storing, and analysis of more data. To understand this better, edge computing and cloud computing have risen as two mutually supportive paradigms that provide better scoop with important opportunities for real-time analytics, including self-designing systems. Because edge computing places computational power closer to where the data is generated, it allows for processing that happens in real time and reduces latency, bandwidth usage, and reliance on a centralized cloud server. In contrast, cloud computing offers scalable and flexible infrastructure for large-scale data storage, advanced analytics, and machine learning capabilities. These new computing paradigms can be integrated into a single framework that would enable the development of mixed initiative systems that could make decisions in real time and could autonomously optimize and adapt to their environment and learn from it. This study investigates the synergies obtained in the combination between edge and cloud computing, illustrating their contribution to real-time big data analysis and self-designing systems. This is where edge computing comes in, allowing critical data to be processed at or near the source, overcoming the latency and bandwidth constraints of cloud-only solutions. It highlights also how cloud computing supplements this by providing centralized sources to facilitate complex analytics, and the storage of massive amounts of data and training of models. The architecture is hybrid, where real-time data can be extracted from the edge and cloud resources are there to perform deep analytics and generate long-term optimization strategies. Therefore, this architecture is especially useful for time-critical applications, e.g., smart manufacturing, autonomous vehicles, IoT-based health care, or industrial automation, where immediate decision-making is required. The study also goes on to investigate the degree to which edge-cloud systems could contribute to self-designing systems, autonomous systems with self-optimization, self-healing and self-configuration capabilities. Self-designing systems suitable for real-time control of deployment scenarios can use real-time feedback and local data processing at the edge while having access to the vast learning capabilities of cloud-based AI models. Overall, these study results prove that edge and cloud computing combined can not only improve the latency and effectiveness of real-time analytics but also provide new avenues of applications in different fields where independent and intelligent decision making is vital. The paper ends with a brief overview of challenges such as security, data privacy and resource management that need to be overcome for realizing the full capabilities of edge-cloud integration for real-time analytics and self-designing systems.

title: Adaptive Decision Feedback Equalization for High-Speed Serializer/Deserializer Communication System
authors: Guo-Ming Sung, Sachin D. Kohale, Shu-Wen Chang, Li-Fen Tung, Chwan-Lu Tseng, Jen-Hsiang Chou
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: An 8-tap feed-forward equalizer (FFE) and 10-tap decision feedback equalizer (DFE) were designed for the IEEE 802.3u 100Base-TX specification. The weights of these adaptive filters are updated with a sign–sign least-mean-square (SSLMS) algorithm. To ensure the flexibility of the circuits for various environments channel lengths, the equalizers are designed such that the number of taps can be adjusted to between 1 and 8 for the FFE and 1 and 10 for the DFE. Results indicated that the equalizer can compensate for channel delays of more than 20 dB, and it achieved a bit error rate of 2 × 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−3</sup>. Both FFE and DFE not only mitigate signal distortion but also significantly eliminate inter-symbol interference (ISI) in high-speed serializer/deserializer (SerDes) communication systems. The application-specific integrated circuit (ASIC) was designed using Verilog Hardware Description Language (HDL) and implemented with the TSMC 90-nm CMOS 1P9M standard cell process. In simulations, the chip area, delay cycle, and logic gate counts were 845.445 × 845.445 μm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, 12 cycles, and 75 187 gates, respectively. The supplied voltage and frequency of the proposed adaptive DFE were 1.2 V and 250 MHz, respectively.

title: A Broadband HgTe Quantum Dot/Si Heterojunction Photodetector: Theoretical Design and Optical Performance Analysis
authors: Zheng Hao Xing, Hui Juan Niu, Jun Qiang Zhang, Xi Ying Huang, Meng Yu Dong, ChuanTong Cheng
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Infocomm Technology (ICAIT)
abstract: This work presents the theoretical design and optimization of a high-responsivity HgTe CQD/Si photodetector using finite-difference time-domain (FDTD) simulations. By optimizing a four-layer mesa architecture (Ag/Si/HgTe/ITO), a broad low-reflectance window is achieved in the short-wave infrared. Significantly, the reflectance at the critical telecommunication wavelength of 1550 nm is suppressed to a near-zero value, resulting in near-unity absorption. Furthermore, its application potential is demonstrated through an experiment monitoring atmospheric transmittance under varying humidity conditions. This combined theoretical design and experimental demonstration validates the proposed architecture for future low-cost environmental sensing applications.

title: Bandgap-Dispersion Engineered Athermal MZI Filter with Wavelength-Selective Thermal Drift
authors: Zhiyuan Zhou, Yao Sun, Yaxiao Lai, Changyu Hu, Hao Hu, Bo Zhao, Jun Liu, Shuang Zheng, Minming Zhang
abstract: We demonstrate an athermal MZI filter with near 0 pm/K wavelength shift from 30°C to 90°C around 1555 nm using silicon nitride subwavelength waveguides. By exploiting strong dispersion near the photonic bandgap edge, the MZI exhibits 15 pm/K temperature sensitivity at 1510 nm. High-sensitivity temperature sensing and low-sensitivity temperature sensing can be achieved simultaneously. This dual-function operation provides integrated sensing and drift-free transmission.

title: Deep-SchizoNet: A Lightweight Region-Wise Approach to Detect Schizophrenia Using 1D CNN-BiLSTM Hybrid Model
authors: Madan Mohan Saha Momit, Nafis-Ul Momin, Hridoy Kundu
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Information and Communication Technology (EICT)
abstract: Schizophrenia is a chronic psychiatric disorder where timely and objective detection remains a challenge. Electroencephalogram (EEG) offers a non-invasive method to detect neural abnormalities. Existing approaches are based on handcrafted features or 2D transformations, which lack scalability. This work suggests a lightweight custom model, Deep-SchizoNet (DSN), that classifies schizophrenia from raw EEG without extensive pre-processing using 1D-CNNs and BiLSTM layers. When evaluated on the Warsaw EEG dataset, the model obtains $\mathbf{9 8. 7 0 \%}$ accuracy on an $\mathbf{8 0 - 2 0}$ segment-based split, 93.1% in subject-wise validation, and $\mathbf{9 4. 8 \%} \boldsymbol{\pm} \mathbf{5. 5}$ in 10-fold cross-validation. Region-wise analysis shows that the temporal region has the most discriminative signals (97.23%), followed by frontal (94.37%), parietal (89.96%), and the occipital (86.49%) region. At the electrode level, parietal electrodes (P3, Pz, and P4) are pointed out to be the most significant, and low-channel wearable EEG devices for long-term real-time monitoring can be envisaged. These results demonstrate raw-signal deep learning as a computationally efficient, scalable device for EEG-based schizophrenia detection, and offer a possibility of personal mental health monitoring system.

title: EEG-Based Motor Task Classification Using Complex STFT and Hilbert Transform Features
authors: Anand Mohan, Ojaswi Chopra, Ruchi Singh, Pradnya Praveen Simpi, Pratham Kumar Srivastava, R. S. Anand
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Neurological disorders like stroke, epilepsy, and dementia can severely impair motor function, limiting independence and quality of life. Traditional assistive technologies, such as prosthetic limbs or voice-controlled systems, often require invasive procedures, expensive equipment, or physical efforts. These may not be feasible for many individuals, highlighting the need for AI-driven EEG analysis for risk factor prediction, diagnosis and rehabilitation. Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCIs) powered by EEG-based movement classification offer a noninvasive, affordable, and accessible alternative, enabling individuals to control devices using their thoughts alone. This study aims to develop a robust EEG-based system capable of classifying different types of hand movements, both real and imagined, using machine learning. By improving classification accuracy and reducing noise in EEG signals, this research contributes toward making hands-free interaction with technology a reality. This study will help in empowering people with disabilities and bridging the accessibility gap in assistive technologies. Feature extraction is performed using the proposed Complex STFT with Hilbert Transform (CSTFT-H) method. Machine learning models, including CNN, SVM, DT, RF and MLP are utilized to analyze EEG signals and classify them into motor imagery and motor movement. Hyperparameter tuning and k-fold validation are applied to optimize model performance.The proposed model achieved 86% accuracy for classifying all four motor activity tasks across all subjects. This would greatly benefit individuals with physical disabilities by successfully interpreting motor-related EEG data in real-time.

title: A Prescription-Centric Estimation Framework for Bi-Level Power System Operations with Analytical Representation
authors: Yuhao Jing, Fusen Guo, Chunyang Zhang, Li Qiao, Huadong Mo, Daoyi Dong
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: The increasing integration of renewable energy sources and battery energy storage systems has amplified uncertainties in power system operations, necessitating advanced estimation methods that transcend traditional quality-oriented approaches. In this paper, we propose a prescription-centric estimation framework that embeds decision-making insights directly into the anticipation process. By leveraging parametric programming and implicit gradient representations, our approach establishes an analytical mapping between uncertain parameters and optimal operational decisions, thereby addressing the inherent asymmetry between uncertainty estimation and system re-balancing costs. Notably, the proposed method breaks through the limitations imposed by linearization constraints in conventional estimation networks and optimization models, paving the way for more accurate and robust decision-making. An iterative bi-level nonlinear optimization strategy is also introduced to overcome the shortcomings of purely data-driven methods. The effectiveness of the framework is demonstrated through case studies, underscoring its potential to enhance both decision accuracy and efficiency in power system operations.

title: Photon-Counting Polarimetric Imaging LiDAR with a Learning-Based Denoiser
authors: Song Li, Haoruan Sun, Hedong Liu, Pengcheng Shao, Yuanzhe Lan, Haofeng Hu, Xiaolong Hu
abstract: We implement a four-branch denoiser for polarimetric imaging LiADR that uses a fractal superconducting nanowire single-photon detector. This denoiser permits the polarimetric imaging LiDAR to acquire images with decent qualities in photon-starved conditions and relatively short acquisition time.

title: AlignGenRec: Aligning Collaborative and Textual Knowledge for Generative Recommendation with LLMs
authors: Jinshuo Xing, Xiaoge Li, Yanan Ma, Yunsheng Ren
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Recommender systems based on collaborative filtering (CF) effectively model user-item interactions but struggle with data sparsity and cold-start issues. On the other hand, large language models (LLMs) offer strong semantic understanding but fail to capture structured user-item relationships. To bridge this gap, we propose AlignGenRec, a framework that integrates collaborative and textual knowledge for generative recommendation. Specifically, we introduce an embedding alignment mechanism that aligns item embeddings from a pre-trained CF model with text embeddings from item descriptions. These aligned embeddings are then transferred to the LLM without requiring fine-tuning, enabling structured knowledge integration while preserving generative capabilities. Additionally, constrained sequence decoding ensures that generated recommendations correspond to valid items, improving recommendation accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that AlignGenRec outperforms both CF-based and LLM-based baselines, particularly in cold-start scenarios, with performance improvements of 7 - 11% across three benchmark datasets. Beyond recommendation tasks, AlignGenRec also supports preference prediction and user profiling, highlighting its versatility in real-world applications.

title: Enhancing CNNs for AES Side-Channel Key Recovery using Random Search-based Neural Architecture Search
authors: Amina Amrouche, Larbi Boubchir, Saïd Yahiaoui
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Side-channel attacks and deep learning have both attracted significant attention in recent years. As deep learning continues to advance, its application in side-channel analysis has opened new possibilities for cryptographic key recovery. This paper presents a clear approach for recovering AES keys from side-channel traces using deep learning and introduces an efficient Neural Architecture Search (NAS) method based on random search to enhance the performance of standard Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) in side-channel analysis. Specifically, we apply NAS to the VGG16 and ResNet18 architectures, resulting in two optimized models, referred to as NAS-VGG and NAS-ResNet. Our method significantly reduces training time, achieving improved performance after only 10 epochs, compared to the original models, which required 50 or more epochs. Furthermore, the NAS-VGG model not only outperforms the original VGG16 in terms of guessing entropy (GE), but also surpasses a well-established CNN-based approach from the literature, reaching GE = 0 with as few as ∼450 traces. These results demonstrate the effectiveness of random search-based NAS in discovering compact, high-performing architectures with minimal computational cost.

title: Ultra-Thin Silicon Nitride-Assisted Polarization-Insensitive Edge Coupler Based on Thin-Film Lithium Niobate
authors: Zikuan Liu, Zhiguo Yu, Huan Guan, Yanbo Ren, Zhuoting Wang, Paiguang Zhao, Zhiyong Li
abstract: A novel ultra-thin silicon nitride-assisted thin-film lithium niobate polarization-independent end-coupler has been proposed and validated, with optimized matching for TE and TM modes. Simulations show coupling loss as low as 0.22-dB at 1550 nm, with over 98% polarization overlap integration for both modes. Experimental results show single-end face loss of 0.7 dB near 1610 nm, with stable performance over a wide wavelength range and large manufacturing tolerances, supporting high-performance LNOI photonic integration systems.

title: A Named Entity Recognition Method for Data Structure Knowledge Graphs Based on CAC-BERT-Fusion
authors: Hui Yan, Zhouyu Kan, Mingxin Li, Xiaoqing Xu, Yicong Zhang, Linlu Zheng, Duo Long
publish: 2025 2nd International Symposium on AI and Cybersecurity (ISAICS)
abstract: The professional entity recognition of knowledge graphs for data structures is key to AI empowerment in courses, but existing methods struggle to capture the characteristics and semantic associations of domain terminology. To address this, this study proposes the CAC-BERT-Fusion model, which enhances entity recognition performance through multi-component integration. The model centers around CAC, utilizing convolutional networks to mine local semantics and contextual relationships, and combines BERT’s semantic representation capabilities through BiLSTM, Attention, and CRF fusion to improve adaptability to entities such as algorithm names and data structure terms. In experiments conducted on a self-built corpus, the model achieved an improvement of $\mathbf{4. 2 \% - 6. 8 \%}$ in F1 scores compared to the baseline model, especially showing significant advantages in recognizing rare terms and complex structures. This model provides an innovative solution for entity recognition in educational texts, and its fusion mechanism has implications for NLP tasks in specialized fields, which can be extended to scenarios such as knowledge graph construction.

title: HSI-MFF:Trajectory Prediction with Hierarchical Scene Interaction and Multi-Scale Feature Fusion
authors: Yuqin Xu, Ming Xu, Qinhao Wu, Haitao Zhou, Zhixuan Shen, Shiyao Li
publish: 2025 2nd International Symposium on AI and Cybersecurity (ISAICS)
abstract: Complex scene interaction modeling remains critical for autonomous driving trajectory prediction. While Transformer-based methods achieve high accuracy, their quadratic complexity incurs excessive overhead, and inadequate feature representation degrades decoding performance. To tackle these challenges, we propose a hierarchical scene interaction and multi-scale feature fusion-based trajectory prediction model (HSI-MFF). The hierarchical model combining local-global scene interaction and multi-scale feature fusion. Our hybrid architecture integrates attention and Mamba for efficient spatiotemporal modeling, while an adaptive gating mechanism dynamically fuses multi-scale features. Extensive experiments on Agroverse benchmarks demonstrate that our HSI-MFF achieves a balance between accuracy and efficiency, enabling both accurate and fast trajectory prediction.

title: Disassembly and Assembly Line Balancing Problem with Robot Movement Space Constraints Solved Using the Improved Parallel A2C Algorithm
authors: Wenjing Zeng, Xiwang Guo, Jiacun Wang, Shujin Qin, Liang Qi, Bin Hu, Siqi Chen, Jun Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: The disassembly and assembly line balancing problem (DALP) is a critical task in industrial production, involving the efficient organization of disassembly and assembly tasks to improve the productivity and flexibility of production lines. In practical applications, task allocation, robot movement, and workstation layout optimization are key factors affecting production efficiency. This study proposes an improved parallel advantage actor-critic algorithm to address DALP with space constraints due to robot movement. Considering the limitations of workstation space, this approach optimizes the robot's movement paths between workstations, reducing the cost of opening workstations, and optimizing task allocation strategies. To enhance the convergence speed and stability of the conventional Parallel A2C algorithm, action space optimization and a greedy strategy are incorporated into the algorithm. Experimental results demonstrate that the improved parallel advantage actor-critic outperforms the A2C and AC algorithms in terms of efficiency and performance, particularly in handling disassembly tasks with space constraints, significantly improving the operational efficiency and economic benefits of the production line.

title: Strong 1112 nm Dispersive Wave Generation in z-cut TFLN Waveguide for Potential Ytterbium Clock Applications
authors: Tianyou Tang, Xiang Bai, Zhibang Guo, Lin Chen, Lingfang Wang
abstract: A strong 1112 nm dispersive wave was generated in a 1 μm-wide z-cut TFLN waveguide, showing potential for integrated photonic-chip optical clocks through supercontinuum evolution under varying pump power and polarization.

title: Domain-aware Adversarial Domain Augmentation Network for Hyperspectral Image Classification
authors: Yi Huang, Jiangtao Peng, Weiwei Sun, Na Chen, Zhijing Ye, Qian Du
abstract: Classifying hyperspectral remote sensing images across different scenes has recently emerged as a significant challenge. When only historical labeled images (source domain, SD) are available, it is crucial to leverage these images effectively to train a model with strong generalization ability that can be directly applied to classify unseen samples (target domain, TD). To address these challenges, this paper proposes a novel single-domain generalization (SDG) network, termed the domain-aware adversarial domain augmentation network (DADAnet) for cross-scene hyperspectral image classification (HSIC). DADAnet involves two stages: adversarial domain augmentation (ADA) and task-specific training. ADA employs a progressive adversarial generation strategy to construct an augmented domain (AD). To enhance variability in both spatial and spectral dimensions, a domain-aware spatial-spectral mask (DSSM) encoder is constructed to increase the diversity of the generated adversarial samples. Furthermore, a two-level contrastive loss (TCC) is designed and incorporated into the ADA to ensure both the diversity and effectiveness of AD samples. Finally, DADAnet performs supervised learning jointly on the SD and AD during the task-specific training stage. Experimental results on two public hyperspectral image datasets and a new Hangzhouwan (HZW) dataset demonstrate that the proposed DADAnet outperforms existing domain adaptation (DA) and domain generalization (DG) methods, achieving overall accuracies of 80.69%, 63.75%, and 87.61% on three datasets, respectively.

title: TSE-Transformer: A TLS Semantic Enhancement Transformer for Website Fingerprinting Under Encrypted VPN Tunnels
authors: Ran Pengcheng, Mei Lei, Yang Yang
publish: 2025 22nd International Computer Conference on Wavelet Active Media Technology and Information Processing (ICCWAMTIP)
abstract: In recent years, a series of privacy and security incidents has heightened public awareness of online privacy protection, prompting more users to adopt VPN tools to conceal their identities and access the Internet through proxy channels. However, while the anonymity provided by VPNs protects ordinary users' privacy, it also creates opportunities for malicious actors, making VPN s a potential carrier for illicit online activities. Existing studies typically apply traditional application fingerprinting methods directly to VPN traffic, overlooking the obfuscation and repackaging mechanisms introduced during VPN transmission, which results in a significant degradation of identification performance. To address this issue, this paper proposes TSE- Transformer, a TLS Semantic Enhancement Transformer designed for high-precision website fingerprinting in VPN environments. Considering that VPN traffic may undergo operations such as aggregation and padding, we introduce TLS traffic-featuring more stable website characteristics-as semantic anchors to enhance the representation of VPN website fingerprints. Experiments conducted on the ISCX-VPN-App, ISCX- VPN-Service, and a self-constructed dataset demonstrate that the proposed method consistently outperforms existing state-of-the-art approaches in website identification for VPN traffic.

title: Bengali Shallow Parsing with XLM-RoBERTa: A Rule-Guided Multitask Approach
authors: Radha Rani Paul, Julia Rahman
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Information and Communication Technology (EICT)
abstract: In syntactic analysis, chunking, also called shallow parsing, is a crucial Natural Language Processing (NLP) approach that involves locating and extracting phrase fragments from a sentence, including verb phrases (VPs) and noun phrases (NPs), among others. This research paper investigates the potential of a pre-trained multilingual transformer-based model named XLM-RoBERTa for Bengali shallow parsing by generating a rule-based IOB chunk-labeled dataset using annotated data with Universal Part-of-Speech (UPOS) tags. This is the first study to employ rule-based heuristics and a transformer strategy, such as XLM-RoBERTa, for multitask fine-tuning, which has not been previously applied to Bengali shallow parsing. In contrast, UD-based chunking was examined in a few Portuguese and English NP-chunking studies. Our model achieves 85.21% accuracy on UPOS tagging and 84.53% accuracy on chunking and shows strong performance on frequent categories such as noun and verb phrases.

title: Discovery of Biomarkers and Drug Targets in different Kidney Diseases by Explainable AI and Functional Genomics
authors: Nusrat Jahan Bindu, Md. Lutfor Rahaman, Jebin Akter Tithi, Muhammad Shahin Uddin, Md. Abul Basar, Md. Anowar Kabir
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Information and Communication Technology (EICT)
abstract: Diabetic kidney disease (DKD) and chronic kidney disease (CKD) are progressive renal diseases that play a major role in the global burden of kidney dysfunction. Both diseases are closely linked with increased morbidity and mortality worldwide. The objectives of this research were to uncover diagnostic biomarkers related to immune response between DKD and CKD, also investigate their correlation with immune cell infiltration. This study utilised microarray datasets GSE37171 and GSE30566, obtained from the NCBI GEO database. Those included samples from DKD glomeruli, renal tubuli, and end-stage renal failure patients. By using a machine learning algorithm and an Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI) based feature selection method like SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations), the top 500 significant DEGs were found from each dataset. Then, 30 common DEGs are selected for further examination. Functional enrichment analysis of the 30 common genes indicated their involvement in immune regulation, kidney development, and inflammatory pathways. Protein-protein interaction (PPI) networks are analysed and constructed by using NetworkAnalyst and visualised by Cytoscape software. Top 10 hub genes identified by cytoHubba extension. Top hub genes are CBLB, PTPRC, S100A8, LCK, GRB2, FYN, PTPN11, ITGAM, SELL, and PIK3R2. The potential therapeutic compounds are suggested for immune-related common biomarkers between CKD and DKD. This discovery would contribute significantly to the common molecular pathways that cause kidney disease and could be a useful target for the advancement of useful medicines and the creation of new drugs.

title: A U-net and Transformer Paralleled Network for Robust Cuffless Blood Pressure Estimation Based on CWT-transformed PPG Images
authors: Boyuan Gu, Jiahao Tang, Yunhan Tang, Haiyang Sun, Changting Xie
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: This paper proposes a parallel U-Net and Transformer network for blood pressure (BP) estimation using Photoplethysmography (PPG) signals transformed into timefrequency images using CWT. It combines the U-Net’s excellent capability of extracting local features with the Transformer’s advantage in capturing long-range dependencies when processing sequential data. Specifically, the PPG signal is first segmented into 5-second windows. These segments are then transformed into 2-D images using continuous wavelet transform (CWT), incorporating both the real and imaginary components of the signal fragments. These images are used as inputs to the deep-learning network. For continuous BP signals, the peaks of the waveform are extracted, and the 5-second average of systolic blood pressure (SBP) and diastolic blood pressure (DBP) are computed to serve as the labels and references. The effectiveness and robustness of the proposed model are evaluated on a dataset constructed by us consisting of 16 subjects under 3 different conditions (Sit, Ex and Db), and the results are compared with traditional PPG-based BP estimation methods. Experimental results demonstrate an average mean absolute error (MAE) of 6.99 mmHg for SBP and 7.27 mmHg for DBP. Specifically, our approach achieved a BHS Grade A on the sit dataset and a BHS Grade C on both the Ex and Db datasets. Cross dataset validation is further conducted to prove the effectiveness of our model.

title: Dynamically Reconfigurable Phase-Change Metasurface on Single-Mode Fiber for Near-Infrared Spectroscopy
authors: Wanting Ou, Siqing Zeng, Hongfei Chen, Yuru Li, Ying Li, Yan Li, Zhaohui Li
abstract: This paper proposes an ultra-wideband spectrometer based on the integration of single-mode fiber and a chalcogenide phase-change material. The chalcogenide phase-change material Sb2Se3 exhibits a near-zero extinction coefficient and a high refractive index in the near-infrared region. It can dynamically switch between amorphous and crystalline states, exhibiting a significant difference in refractive index between the two states. An Sb2Se3 film was integrated onto a single-mode optical fiber, and its phase state was reversibly modulated through controlled crystallization and amorphization induced by continuous-wave and femtosecond laser irradiation, enabling the realization of a reconfigurable metasurface. As a result, we obtain a spectral resolution of 2 nm and cover a response bandwidth of 275 nm in the wavelength range from 1400 nm to 1675 nm.

title: Cognitive Psychology Effects in Lexical Decision Tasks: Contrasting Human Behavior with Fine-Tuned Transformer-Based Models
authors: Ruichi Dai, Shengjian Ding, Weixuan Li, Ruimin Lyu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: This study investigates the task of genuine-fake word classification in the Chinese language, with the objective of comparing human lexical decision-making with that of fine-tuned transformer-based language models. We propose an integrated framework that combines behavioral experiment data with multiple fine-tuned transformer-based models, enhanced with downstream classification layers. Experimental results show that these models consistently outperform human participants in accuracy, precision, and F1-score across all word frequency levels, with particularly greater stability in recognizing low-frequency words. From a cognitive perspective, the findings support the word frequency effect and information processing theory, indicating that low-frequency items impose higher cognitive load. Human participants may mitigate uncertainty through semantic compensation and risk-sensitive strategies. This study not only confirms the effectiveness of fine-tuned language models in lexical anomaly detection, but also provides empirical insights into the cognitive mechanisms underlying human word recognition.

title: RSSI NearLink Wireless Ranging Algorithm Using Multilayer Perceptron and Hybrid Filtering Approach
authors: Yajin Liu, Xiangming Kong, Changsheng Gao, Haowen Li, Yunfeng Hu, Bin Ma
publish: 2025 9th CAA International Conference on Vehicular Control and Intelligence (CVCI)
abstract: With the rapid development of wireless communication technology, accurate wireless ranging has become crucial across various domains. This paper introduces an Received Signal Strength Indicator(RSSI) wireless ranging algorithm that combines NearLink technology, multilayer perceptron (MLP), and hybrid filtering. NearLink, a novel short-range wireless communication technology, provides low latency, high reliability, and strong anti-interference capabilities. The hybrid filtering technique integrates median filtering, weighted averaging, spline interpolation smoothing, and error-adjusted smoothing to enhance the quality and stability of RSSI data collected from NearLink-equipped anchors. Subsequently, an MLP is employed to establish a nonlinear relationship between the filtered RSSI data and distance. Experimental results demonstrate that this algorithm achieves high prediction accuracy and stability across three NearLink anchor points, maintaining average absolute errors and root mean square errors below 0.2. Additionally, the algorithm exhibits strong robustness with minimal error fluctuation between different anchor points.

title: Strategic Defense Planning for the Batam-Bintan Power Grid Against Intentional Attacks: Integrating Renewable Energy Solutions
authors: Eko Yudo Pramono, Ardylla Rommyonegge, Bambang Anggoro Soedjarno, Kevin M. Banjar-Nahor, Nanang Hariyanto
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on High Voltage Engineering and Power Systems (ICHVEPS)
abstract: The Batam-Bintan power grid, a vital infrastructure with 16 substations, 17 transmission lines, and a 327.3 MW load, faces considerable vulnerabilities to intentional attacks, underscoring the critical need for robust security planning. This research investigates these vulnerabilities and introduces an innovative defense framework integrating game theory, optimal power flow, and probabilistic risk assessment, featuring a novel attacker intelligence algorithm, K-means clustering for defender placement, and iterative risk optimization for defender sizing, validated on IEEE systems and applied to the Batam-Bintan grid using DIgSILENT and Python. Analysis of 207 credible attack scenarios revealed a potential 176.44 MW load shedding and an 88.09 MW network vulnerability risk, which could be reduced to $\mathbf{5 4. 2 7} \mathrm{MW}$ with a 128,770 thousand USD investment in a PV system at Air Raja Substation, highlighting the importance of integrating security considerations into power system planning for enhanced resilience against physical threats; future work will focus on adaptive defense mechanisms against evolving attack strategies.

title: A 7.99-to-11.61 GHz, 2D-Tessellation-Scalable 8-Core Oscillator Featuring -153.7dBc/H z Absolute PN and FoM of 191.8 dBc \ Hz at 10 MHz offset
authors: Juntao Lan, Dejian Li, Wei Deng, Haikun Jia, Baoyong Chi
abstract: With the continuous development of 6 G communication technology, the data rate and operating frequency band of the transceiver continue to increase, which has set stringent requirement for the VCO and the local oscillator (LO). Low phase noise, minimized area, wide frequency tuning range, and low power consumption have become a widely pursued objective, which poses a serious challenge to the prior art. For ultra-low phase noise VCOs, two primary strategies have emerged to achieve ultra-low PN: multi-core parallel-resonance VCOs(PR VCO) and series-resonance VCOs(SR VCO). Thus far, the SR VCO has demonstrated excellent phase noise performance, but at the expense of a relatively narrow tuning range, high power consumption and large chip area [1]. In terms of various performance metrics of VCOs, the multi-core PR VCO achieves a better balance. By coupling N cores together, the theoretical phase noise performance can be improved by $10 \log (\mathrm{~N})$ without sacrificing too much tuning range and area utilization [2]. However, this theoretical goal is, in fact, also a challenge for multi-core design, as there are various mismatches in the coupling process that prevent the multi-core VCO from progressing towards the ideal target. The 16-core topology proposed in [3] couples the cores by slab inductors, which connect each core to form a loop. However, as the number of cores increases, the larger the area of the loop becomes, the greater the mismatch that occurs between the opposite cores in the loop. In the 20 -core topology proposed in [4], the coupling direction between cores is also unidimensional, with PMOS and NMOS cores each unfolded in the form of two lines, which are then coupled together through a weak magnetic field between the lines, with a low area utilization while scaling up. As the number of cores increases, these topological structures can all lead to significant mismatches. The key to addressing such mismatches lies in proposing new topological structures. To address the mismatch issues that may arise from unidimensional coupling, a bi-dimensional(2D) coupled multi-core VCO topology is proposed. The proposed topology expands in the form of a semi-regular tessellation of octagons, where each unit in the tessellation exhibits strong magnetic coupling with its four adjacent units. Based on this topology, an 8 -core VCO is proposed. Each unit that makes up this structure consists of a compact dualcore VCO, ensuring that each unit is fully repeatable without configuration and has minimal mismatch when expanding to massive cores, as shown in the right of Fig. 1.

title: A 890-nW Dual-Mode Reconfigurable Front-End with Dynamic Compensation Feedback Circuits for Multimodal V/R/I/C Sensing
authors: Ting Zhou, Chao Wang, Jiajie Huang, Jian Zhao, Jinghua Zhang, Yong Lian, Yongfu Li
abstract: Sensing technologies continue to evolve and become ubiquitous, which greatly improves the quality of life. The multi-modal sensor systems record different types of electrical signals simultaneously while demanding small dimensions, low cost, long battery life, and lightweight requirements [1–5]. The nature of these signals can be classified into voltage, current, resistive, and capacitive (V/I/R/C). Prior multi-modal integrated circuits [2] customized their analog frontend (AFE) circuits based on the type of signals to achieve the best performance at the expense of design complexity, area, and power consumption. The reconfigurable signal acquisition circuit aims to use the least number of circuit components and configure itself to provide the correct signal conditioning interface, thereby addressing the aforementioned problems [1], [3–5].

title: Research on YOLO Object Detection Based on Frequency Band Decomposition and Cross-Domain Feature Fusion
authors: Mingyu Yuan, Xiaoning Liu, Sixun Zhou
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th International Conference on Power, Intelligent Computing and Systems (ICPICS)
abstract: To address the issue that existing YOLO models can only utilize spatial information and fail to make use of frequency-domain information, resulting in poor performance in low-resolution or noisy images, based on the YOLOv11 architecture, this paper proposes a frequency-domain feature enhancement method based on frequency band division to enhance the original features. This paper proposes the Frequency-Aware Fusion Block (FAFB). The extraction and reconstruction of frequency-domain features are achieved through Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) and Inverse Fast Fourier Transform (IFFT). The Frequency Band Decomposition and Enhancement Module (FDFEM) is used to decompose the input features into high, medium, and low frequencies. Different frequency band signals are processed according to their respective characteristics to achieve in-depth feature extraction. Multiple FAFB modules are integrated into the C3k2 feature extraction module of YOLOv11 to construct the Multi-Branch Frequency-Enhanced Fusion (MBFEF) module, enabling parallel frequency-domain processing and efficient fusion of multi-scale features. The results show a significant improvement in the overall mean Average Precision (mAP). The mAP on the original dataset, low-resolution dataset, and raindrop noise dataset has increased by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.4 \%, 0.6 \%$</tex>, and 1.4% respectively, and the mAP50 has increased by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.6 \%, 0.5 \%$</tex>, and 1.1% respectively. The performance verifies the effectiveness and universality of introducing frequency-domain information in improving object detection performance.

title: Revisiting and Improving the NEAT Algorithm
authors: Dimitar Lyubchev, Angel Marchev
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Neuroevolution of Augmenting Topologies (NEAT) stands out as a pioneering framework for simultaneously evolving weights and architectures of artificial neural networks; however, several implicit design choices remain underexplored, particularly in large-scale or zero-knowledge scenarios. This paper revisits the canonical NEAT algorithm and the widely adopted neat Python library, presenting an extensive experimental campaign that spans synthetic control tasks. serves its dual goals of methodological critique and targeted enhancement. The aim is to introduce lightweight yet impactful extensions, including: balanced crossover, rejuvenation-driven speciation, adaptive hyper-parameters, and GPU-accelerated batch evaluation. Thus, achieving improved convergence speed, solution compactness, and behavioral diversity. Some empirical results demonstrate consistent performance gains across the examined domains, affirming the practical value of our refinements. These contributions advance NEAT toward a more scalable, adaptive, and high-performance solution for automated neural architecture discovery.

title: Techno-Economic Assessment of Hybrid Wind Energy Systems with Diverse Storage Technologies for Remote Island Electrification: A Case Study of Wetar Island, Indonesia
authors: Abdul Goffar Al Mubarok, Bilawal Aulia Annas, Hendrie Bastian
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on High Voltage Engineering and Power Systems (ICHVEPS)
abstract: Electrifying remote islands in Indonesia remains a persistent challenge due to high logistical costs, technical limitations, and regulatory constraints. Addressing a gap in the global literature, this study presents the first comparative techno-economic assessment of hybrid renewable energy systems (HRES) integrating hydrogen and hydro-pumped storage tailored to Indonesia’s unique regulatory and geographic conditions. Focusing on Wetar Island, four configurations are analyzed: stand-alone wind turbines (WT), WT with battery storage (WT-BESS), WT with hydrogen storage (WT-HSS), and WT with hydro-pumped storage (WTHPS). The analysis employs a mixed-integer linear programming (MILP) framework implemented in Python with the Pyomo optimization package to optimize component sizing and dispatch over project lifespans of 20,25, and 30 years. Results show that WT-HSS provides the highest Net Present Value (USD 2.47 million) and Internal Rate of Return ($\mathbf{1 0. 8 5 \%}$), while WT-HPS achieves the lowest Levelized Cost of Energy (10.14 cent USD/kWh) and highest Benefit-Cost Ratio (1.75). Aligned with Indonesia’s renewable energy pricing regulation (Perpres 112/2022), this study demonstrates the value of diversified storage in achieving reliable and financially viable rural electrification.

title: State of Health Estimation for Lithium-Ion Batteries Based on Features from Dynamic Time Warping of Expansion Curves
authors: Xiangrui Meng, Xuliang Zhang, Yang Zhou, Huiying Ling, Ruoyu Wang, Yuhao Wu, Jinlei Sun, Zhao Liu
publish: 2025 9th CAA International Conference on Vehicular Control and Intelligence (CVCI)
abstract: Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have become the core energy storage components in electric vehicle powertrains due to their high energy density and long cycle life. The state of health (SOH) of LIBs serves as a critical indicator for evaluating their remaining lifespan and reliability. Conventional expansion-based SOH estimation methods typically extract only peak and valley points from expansion curves as features, failing to analyze the complete evolution patterns of entire expansion profiles. This limitation inadequately characterizes the expansion dynamics and compromises SOH estimation accuracy. To address these challenges, this study proposes a novel SOH estimation method based on features from dynamic time warping of expansion curves. Building upon analysis of charge/discharge expansion characteristics, correlations between battery aging states and surface expansion variations during cycling were established. The methodology employs dynamic time warping (DTW) algorithms to evaluate similarities between charge/discharge expansion profiles across different aging states, incorporating four key parameters as long short-term memory (LSTM) network inputs: reversible expansion, irreversible expansion, DTW-processed expansion curves, and single-cycle duration, with battery SOH as the network output. Under a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$6: 1: 3$</tex> ratio for training, validation, and test sets, the proposed method achieves remarkable estimation performance, with MAE and RMSE values of 0.329 % and 0.390 % respectively. These results demonstrate the effectiveness of framework in accurate SOH estimation for LIB systems.

title: Game-Theoretic Traffic Coordination at Unsignalized Intersections with Integrated Safety and Equity Constraints
authors: Hanwen Zhang, Jicheng Chen, Henglai Wei, Yan Li
publish: 2025 9th CAA International Conference on Vehicular Control and Intelligence (CVCI)
abstract: This study presents an innovative game-theoretic framework for coordinating autonomous vehicles at unsignalized intersections, where multiple vehicles approach from different directions without centralized signaling. The framework introduces explicit safety constraints to prevent collisions and incorporates platoon integrity conditions to enhance traffic cohesion. To maintain system-wide efficiency, a global constraint on total waiting time is enforced. The core of the approach is a min-max optimization model that minimizes the maximum weighted waiting time among all vehicles, thereby ensuring equitable treatment and preventing any vehicle from facing excessive delays. Vehiclespecific priority weights are embedded to reflect heterogeneous right-of-way preferences. Through simulation experiments, the proposed strategy is benchmarked against two conventional methods. Results demonstrate its superior performance in reducing peak waiting times while preserving both safety and fairness, offering a scalable and collision-free solution for intelligent traffic management in mixed autonomous settings.
